Air traffic controllers' strike hits flights over France
Air traffic controllers' strike hits flights over France
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 20, 2023 Monday 6:11 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 221 words
Dateline: Paris (dpa) - 
Body
An air traffic controllers' strike in France led to cancellations and delays on Monday, and also affected flights 
travelling from other countries through French airspace.
Ahead of the industrial action, the Civil Aviation Authority (DGAC) had asked Paris-Orly and Toulouse airports to 
reduce the number of flights by 25%. In Bordeaux and Marseille, 20% of flights were to be cancelled.
Other airports and airlines flying over France, on their way from Germany to Spain, for example, were also affected.
The airline Ryanair called on the EU to protect overflight rights and the freedom of movement of EU citizens during 
the air traffic controllers' strike.
This year, air traffic has already been disrupted on 65 days during strikes by French air traffic controllers, leading to 
the cancellation of thousands of flights from Germany, Spain, Italy, Ireland and the UK.
France had prioritized flights within France during emergency operations during the strikes, which budget airline 
Ryanair described as unfair.
The current strike by French air traffic controllers was directed against a government decision that obliges air traffic 
controllers to give 48 hours notice of whether or not they will take part in a strike.
This is intended to make restrictions in air traffic more predictable and allow time for measures to mitigate them.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 20, 2023
Air traffic controllers' strike hits flights over France

Profits up for first half of year at budget airline Ryanair
Profits up for first half of year at budget airline Ryanair
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 6, 2023 Monday 11:27 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 178 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair reported a rise in profits in the first half of the year.
Profit attributable to equity holders, based on international reporting standards, came to (EURO)2.18 billion ($2.34 
billion) compared to (EURO)1.26 billion last year.
On a pre-exceptional basis, profit for the half-year increased 59%.
Earnings per share was (EURO)1.90 compared to (EURO)1.11.
On IFRS basis, first-half total operating revenues were (EURO)8.58 billion compared to (EURO)6.62 billion, 
previous year.
On pre-exceptional basis, total operating revenues increased 30%.
Traffic grew 11% to 105.4 million.
Ryanair now expects that fiscal 2024 profit after tax will finish in a range of between (EURO)1.85 - (EURO)2.05 
billion, assuming modest losses over the second half winter period.
The company continues to target approximately 183.5 million in traffic for the fiscal year.
The Board declared a maiden ordinary dividend of approximately (EURO)0.35 per share in aggregate through an 
interim and final dividend, payable in February 2024 and after the AGM in September 2024 respectively.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Profits up for first half of year at budget airline Ryanair
Load-Date: November 6, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair Holdings says September passenger traffic up 9% year on year
Ryanair Holdings says September passenger traffic up 9% year on year
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 3, 2023 Tuesday 9:04 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 90 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair Holdings on Tuesday reported an increase of 9% in passenger traffic for the month of 
September, 2023, compared to a year ago.
Load factor for the month remained unchanged compared to the previous year.
Ryanair operated over 97,350 flights in September, 2023.
For the month of September, guests were 17.4 million compared to 15.9 million, last year.
Load factor was at 94%, flat with last year.
For the rolling period, guests were 178.9 million, an increase of 17% from last year.
Load factor was 94%, up 4 percentage points.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 3, 2023
End of Document
Delivery troubles mean Ryanair cutting autumn and winter schedule
Delivery troubles mean Ryanair cutting autumn and winter schedule
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 28, 2023 Thursday 2:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 285 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair is reducing its autumn and winter schedule due to problems in the delivery of Boeing aircraft.
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary said, "At this early date, we do not expect these delivery delays will materially affect 
our full year traffic target of 183.5m, but if the delays worsen or extend further into the Jan to Mar 2024 period, we 
may have to revisit this figure and possibly adjust it slightly downward."
Ryanair now expects to receive only 14 aircraft between October and December, while earlier it was expecting 
deliveries of 27 aircraft between September and December.
According to the company, the expected reduction in deliveries was due to production delays at the Spirit Fuselage 
facility in Wichita, combined with Boeings repair and delivery delays in Seattle.
Ryanair will make a number of adjustments to its winter 2023 schedule this week. The company is reducing the 
number of Charleroi based aircraft by three, Dublin based aircraft by two, and will reduce five aircraft across four 
Italian bases, including Bergamo, Naples and Pisa.
There will also be aircraft reductions in East Midlands, Porto, and Cologne. These flight cancellations will take effect 
from the end of October.
Passengers will be offered seats on alternative flights or full refunds as they so wish. Ryanair said it is working with 
Boeing to try to get delivery of all 57 contracted B737 aircraft before the end of May 2024.
The company hopes to enter the summer 2024 peak travel season with all 57 new Boeing aircraft deliveries as 
expected.
The company noted that it has no spare aircraft this winter as scheduled maintenance is necessary across full fleet 
of over 550 aircraft to prepare for summer 2024 schedule.
Delivery troubles mean Ryanair cutting autumn and winter schedule
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 28, 2023
End of Document
Meloni pushes EU to give thumbs up to Lufthansa-ITA airline deal
Meloni pushes EU to give thumbs up to Lufthansa-ITA airline deal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 10, 2023 Sunday 11:00 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 328 words
Byline: Christoph Sator in Rome
Dateline: New Delhi/Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Italian Prime Minister Giorgia Meloni is putting pressure on the European Commission to back an agreement where 
German airline Lufthansa would take over a minority stake in the Italian airline ITA.
"It is strange that the European Commission is blocking the solution to the ITA problem," Meloni said on Sunday 
after the G20 summit wrapped up in New Delhi.
Lufthansa is to take over a 41% stake in ITA, which was formed in 2020 after a restructuring of the failed carrier 
Alitalia, for an initial investment of (EURO)325 million ($348 million).
The Italian government took control of the airline in March 2020 when various takeover bids failed.
After months of negotiations, the German MDax-listed Lufthansa Group and Rome announced the deal at the end 
of April.
The European Commission must still approve the agreement.
The decision is the responsibility of the EU Economy Commissioner, Paolo Gentiloni.
Gentiloni, a social democrat and former Italian prime minister, belongs to a rival political party to Meloni's far-right 
party Fratelli d'Italia (Brothers of Italy).
The deal is subject to competition law reviews at both a national and European level.
EU competition authorities are expected to pay particular attention to whether a monopoly situation is created at the 
airports in Rome and Milan.
Meloni pushes EU to give thumbs up to Lufthansa-ITA airline deal
At present, the Lufthansa Group only attracts transfer passengers from wealthier northern Italy to the Munich hub 
with flights operated by Air Dolomiti.
Now, with ITA, Lufthansa is acquiring a market share in an environment dominated by non-domestic low-cost 
carriers such as Ryanair and Easyjet.
Deutsche Lufthansa AG has already taken over the former state-owned airlines of neighbouring Switzerland, 
Austria and Belgium and has continued to operate them as independent brands.
The Belgian Sabena successor Brussels Airlines was taken over by Lufthansa in two stages, initially also starting 
with a minority stake.
Lufthansa is also looking to possibly take over Portugal's TAP.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Marissa Smart, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 11, 2023
End of Document
Fan guide to Paris Olympics: The latest top stories from dpa trends
Fan guide to Paris Olympics: The latest top stories from dpa trends
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 27, 2023 Thursday 1:05 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 439 words
Body
In exactly one year, around 10,500 athletes will flock to Paris to compete in 32 different sports in the 2024 
Olympics, not to mention millions of fans.
If you are planning to go, you shouldn't wait too long to book your accommodation, as prices for some hotels have 
already soared to (EURO)3,000 ($3,300) for a long weekend in August 2024.
This week on dpa trends, we've compiled some tips for those looking to head to the 2024 Paris Olympics - including 
how to get your hands on the remaining tickets - and have figured out how to take truly memorable holiday pics.
Elena Radwan,dpa trends & features

Ryanair reports higher profit for the first quarter, revenues up 40%
Ryanair reports higher profit for the first quarter, revenues up 40%
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 24, 2023 Monday 10:37 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 107 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Irish low-cost airline Ryanair reported a first quarter profit of (EURO)663 million ($734 million), an increase of 290% 
from last year.
Earnings per share, in euro cent, was (EURO)58.22 compared to (EURO)16.53. First quarter revenue rose 40% to 
(EURO)3.65 billion.
Scheduled revenues increased 57% to (EURO)2.47 billion. Traffic grew 11% to 50.4 million customers.
The company expects fiscal 2024 traffic to grow to approximately 183.5 million, up 9%, which is slower than the 185 
million originally expected, due to Boeing delivery delays.
Ryanair remains cautiously optimistic that fiscal 2024 profit after tax will be modestly ahead of last year.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 24, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair to invest $3 billion, restart flights to Ukraine after war
Ryanair to invest $3 billion, restart flights to Ukraine after war
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 20, 2023 Thursday 5:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 410 words
Dateline: Kiev (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's largest low-cost airline Ryanair plans to invest over $3 billion to rebuild Ukraine's aviation industry once 
the war ends and the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) declares flying into and out of Ukraine is safe 
again.
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary also promised a swift restart of flights in Ukraine after the end of the war, following a 
trip to Kiev on Thursday.
Ryanair will resume flights eight weeks after airspace reopens, the company said after meeting Ukrainian 
government representatives.
Up to 30 aircraft will be stationed at Kiev, Lviv and Odessa airports and 600 flights a week will be offered to 20 EU 
capitals, O'Leary said during the visit.
Within five years, the offer is to be doubled from initially five to 10 million seats per year.
Ryanair said it was the second largest airline in Ukraine before the invasion.
The airports in Kharkiv and Kherson are also to be returned to as soon as the infrastructure has been restored, 
O'Leary said in a statement.
Ryanair managers met Ukraine's Deputy Prime Minister for Restoration of Ukraine and Infrastructure Minister 
Oleksandr Kubrakov, a company statement said.
They also discussed Ukraine's main airports, Kiev, Lviv and Odessa in Boryspil International Airport, invited by 
Oleksiy Dubrevskyy, who heads Boryspil International Airport.
The Ryanair senior management examined the condition of airport terminals, baggage claim and passenger check-
in and boarding gate areas, control points, and aprons during the visit.
Ryanair to invest $3 billion, restart flights to Ukraine after war
Ryanair also plans to open daily domestic flights between Kiev, Lviv, and Odessa, as soon as the airports are 
operational.
Ryanair will base up to 30 new Boeing 737 MAX aircraft worth over $3 billion at the three main Ukrainian airports, 
"giving Ukrainian citizens and visitors access to Europe's lowest air fares, as Ukraine rebuilds its economy in a post 
invasion environment," the statement said.
Russia launched its full-scale invasion of Ukraine nearly 17 months ago. "Ryanair was Ukraine's second largest 
airline before the unlawful Russian invasion in February 2022," O'Leary said.
"Once the skies over Ukraine have reopened for commercial aviation, Ryanair will charge back into Ukraine linking 
the main Ukraine airports with over 20 EU capitals, and we are working closely with the Ukrainian government to 
rebuild Ukraine's aviation, industry and its economy."
"The fastest way to rebuild and restore the Ukrainian economy will be with low fare air travel," he said.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 20, 2023
End of Document
Nearly 60 Belgian flights cancelled on second day of Ryanair strike
Nearly 60 Belgian flights cancelled on second day of Ryanair strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 16, 2023 Sunday 11:21 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 187 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Nearly 60 flights to and from Belgium's Charleroi airport were cancelled on Sunday as pilots of low-cost airline 
Ryanair walked out on the second day of their planned two-day strike.
The walkout led to the cancellation of 29 flights arriving at and another 29 flights departing from Charleroi, 
according to information provided on the airport's website.
Together with flights already impacted on Saturday, a total of 120 flights are affected, news agency Belga reported 
on Saturday.
Belgian public broadcaster RTBF estimated that almost 8,000 passengers could not leave Belgium as planned.
On Saturday the pilots of Belgian-based Ryanair said they were ready to go on strike again if management doesn't 
meet their demands, RTBF reported.
The pilots and the budget airline are at odds over pay cuts and issues with rest periods.
The pilots are demanding that their salaries be restored to levels before the Covid-19 pandemic.
Pilots had at the time accepted a temporary pay cut to help the firm ride out the financial impact of travel restrictions 
imposed during the pandemic.
Ryanair does not offer flights from Charleroi to Germany.

Air traffic strikes in Italy leave nearly 1,000 flights grounded
Air traffic strikes in Italy leave nearly 1,000 flights grounded
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 16, 2023 Sunday 4:37 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 190 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Italy's nationwide air traffic strike on Saturday resulted in nearly 1,000 flight cancellations, the news agency ANSA 
reported on Sunday.
According to the unions, which had called for the strike, nearly 100% of employees expected to strike participated in 
the action, the agency said.
The walkout affected airport ground staff, which are responsible, among other things, for handling and check-in 
services.
At Italy's major airports in Rome, Milan, Naples and Venice alone, several hundred flights were cancelled, affecting 
about 250,000 passengers.
The consumer protection association Codacons believes that damages due to cancellations and delays were in the 
millions, ANSA reported further.
In addition to ground staff, pilots of Malta Air, who handle Ryanair flights in Italy, and pilots and flight attendants of 
budget airline Vueling also went on strike.
This was the second major walkout in Italy, following a rail strike on Thursday that caused significant problems for 
public transport.
The strikes are hitting the country, a popular holiday destination, in the middle of the peak travel season and during 
a heat wave with high temperatures.

Belgium : 120 flights cancelled as Ryanair pilots strike over pay cuts
Belgium: 120 flights cancelled as Ryanair pilots strike over pay cuts
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 15, 2023 Saturday 12:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 136 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Pilots of budget airline Ryanair are on strike in Belgium this weekend over pay cuts, leading to the cancellation of 
120 flights to and from Charleroi airport, news agency Belga reported.
The pilots are demanding that their salaries be restored to levels before the Covid-19 pandemic.
Pilots had at the time accepted a temporary pay cut to help the firm ride out the financial impact of the travel 
restrictions imposed during the pandemic.
Pilots also reported issues with their rest periods, according to Belgian media.
Several meetings held between pilots' representatives and Ryanair failed to resolve the dispute, meaning 80% of 
Ryanair pilots based at Charleroi airport went on strike.
In total 120 flights from and to Charleroi airport have been cancelled, of which 62 were scheduled for Saturday and 
58 for Sunday.

Major disruption at Italian airports amid air traffic strike
Major disruption at Italian airports amid air traffic strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 15, 2023 Saturday 12:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 173 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Travellers at Italian airports are preparing for delays as ground staff strike and many flights are cancelled on 
Saturday.
The Italian consumer protection association Codacons estimated that around 1,000 flights and more than 250,000 
passengers could be affected by the strike. Ground staff are striking from 10 am to 6 pm (0800-1600 GMT).
Hundreds of flights, including ones to and from Germany, have already been cancelled. Airports have been urging 
people to check the status of their flights before travelling.
In addition to ground staff striking, pilots working for Air Malta, who handle Ryanair flights in Italy, plan to strike from 
12 pm to 4 pm.
Pilots and flight attendants working for budget airline Vueling are also called on to strike from 10 am to 6 pm.
Ryanair issued an announcement saying flights to and from Italy would be limited or cancelled due to the strikes.
After a nationwide railway strike on Thursday, this is the second disruption for Italy's public transportation amid the 
peak of Italian travel season and a heat wave.

Italy's air traffic control and external ground handling workers are planning to go on strike on Saturday, amid the 
peak travel season, meaning delays are likely.
Many flight connections could be affected, Italian media reported on Friday. Airlines called on passengers to check 
the status of their flights and expect possible cancellations and delays.
Ground staff handling checking in at Italian airports are planning to walk out from 10 am to 6 pm (0800 to 1600 
GMT) on Saturday.
In addition, pilots working for Malta Air, who handle Ryanair flights in Italy, plan to strike from 12 pm to 4 pm.
Pilots and flight attendants working for budget airline Vueling were called on to strike on Saturday from 10 am to 6 
pm.

The airline ITA Airways will face cancellations of some 133 flights on that day.

Railway strikes in Italy cause train cancellations and delays
Railway strikes in Italy cause train cancellations and delays
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 13, 2023 Thursday 12:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 194 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
A nationwide strike of transport workers began in Italy on Thursday, with staff of two major railway companies 
walking out of work in the morning.
Staff of the state-owned railway company Trenitalia, and employees of the private competitor Italo, stopped work at 
3 am (0100 GMT) on Thursday morning.
Operations are set to resume immediately after the strike is over, Trenitalia said on Wednesday evening. However, 
it is expected that the delays, some of them severe, could extend throughout the day.
Originally, the walkout was to last until 2 am on Friday morning. After failed negotiations with unions, Italy's 
Infrastructure and Transport Minister Matteo Salvini issued an order to shorten the strike to 12 hours, prompting 
criticism from several unions.
Further travel disruptions are planned for the weekend.
A strike at airports has been announced for Saturday. Ground staff plan to walk out of work from 10 am to 6 pm.
Malta Air pilots, who operate Ryanair flights in Italy, also plan to strike on Saturday from 12 to 4 pm. In addition, 
pilots and flight attendants from the low-cost airline Vueling are also being called to strike on Saturday from 10 am 
to 6 pm.

Transport strikes to hit rail and air in Italy next week
Transport strikes to hit rail and air in Italy next week
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 9, 2023 Sunday 1:22 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 140 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Strikes at Italian air and rail service providers are set to go ahead at the end of the coming week, a number of trade 
unions indicated over the weekend.
Workers at the Trenitalia national rail company and its private competitor Italo are to stop working at 3 am (0100 
GMT) on Thursday for 23 hours, returning early on Friday morning.
The rail companies said many services would be cut, with long-distance travel hit hard. Passengers were advised to 
check connections shortly before travelling.
Ground staff are set to strike for eight hours from 10 am at airports on Saturday. Check-in desks will be affected.
Pilots at Malta Air, which operates Ryanair flights in Italy, are to strike for four hours from noon on Saturday.
And pilots and cabin staff working for budget carrier Vueling are to strike for eight hours starting at 10 am on 
Saturday.

European consumers file 'greenwashing' complaint against airlines
European consumers file 'greenwashing' complaint against airlines
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 22, 2023 Thursday 5:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 327 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Umbrella European consumer protection organization BEUC and 23 of its members filed a complaint with the 
European Commission on Thursday against 17 European airlines, saying they misled the public about their 
environmental policies.
Lufthansa, Air France and Ryanair are among the airlines targeted by a so-called cease-and-desist complaint. The 
consumer groups claim the airlines breached EU rules on unfair commercial practices.
The 23 member organizations come from 19 EU countries, the BEUC wrote in a press release. The German 
consumer group VZBV is part of the action, which complains about so-called "greenwashing" practices, in which 
companies present policies as environmentally friendly when they are not.
"We are calling for a Europe-wide investigation into the issue and for the concerned airlines - and the entire sector - 
to stop making claims that give consumers the impression that flying is sustainable," the statement said.
"This is simply untrue as flying is not sustainable and is not bound to become so in the near future."
BEUC said its members had found numerous examples of misleading practices. For example, claims that CO2 
emissions can be "offset," "neutralized" or "compensated" are factually incorrect. The benefits of offsetting 
measures are highly uncertain, while the damage caused by CO2 emissions from air travel is certain.
The claim that air travel can be "sustainable", "responsible" or "green" is also misleading.
"None of the strategies employed by the aviation sector are currently capable of preventing greenhouse gas 
emissions."
Lufthansa said it had taken note of BEUC's announcement but had not yet received any complaints.
European consumers file 'greenwashing' complaint against airlines
"Irrespective of this, we naturally deal with every complaint we receive and examine it carefully," the airline said 
when queried for a response.
The group is striving for a neutral CO2 balance by 2050. By 2030, net CO2 emissions are to be halved compared to 
2019 through reduction and compensation measures.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miriam Widman, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 22, 2023
End of Document
Passenger numbers in May up 10% at Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair
Passenger numbers in May up 10% at Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 2, 2023 Friday 12:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 109 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Passenger numbers at Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair saw a significant increase in May 2023 compared to the same 
month of last year.
Ryanair Holdings plc reported that passenger traffic in May was up 10% year-on-year to 17 million.
Load factor for the period was 94%, an increase of teo percentage points from previous year.
For the rolling 12-month period, passenger traffic was up 39% to 171.9 million guests.
Load factor for the period was 94%, up 10 percentage points from last year.
Ryanair operated over 94,400 flights for the month.
The company noted that, over 300 flights afeecting approximately 54,000 passengers, were cancelled due to ATC 
strikes in May.

Germany 's Lufthansa to take over 40% stake in Italy 's ITA Airways
Germany's Lufthansa to take over 40% stake in Italy's ITA Airways
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2023 Thursday 7:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 515 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt and Manuel Schwarz in Rome
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
German airline Lufthansa has agreed to take over a minority stake in the Italian airline ITA Airways, both airlines 
announced at the signing of the contract in Rome on Thursday.
ITA was formed in 2020 after a restructuring of the failed Alitalia, which the government in Rome took over in March 
of the same year when various takeover bids failed.
After months of negotiations this year with the Italian state, Lufthansa acquired an initial 40% of ITA's shares.
Earlier media reports said the German airline plans to pay between (EURO)320 million and (EURO)330 million 
($343.36 million-$354.09 million) for the stake.
Both parties have now confirmed the agreement in principle, but have not yet confirmed specific figures.
Once ITA Airways begins to make profit again, the reports said Lufthansa may then invest a further (EURO)500 
million to acquire 50% to 55% of its shares, which would be a majority stake.
The Italian state would thus remain a shareholder for the time being, in contrast to Lufthansa's initial plans.
The deal is subject to competition law reviews at both a national and European level.
While Italia Trasporto Aereo (ITA) took over the flight operations of its insolvent predecessor Alitalia in October 
2021, it is not its legal successor.
ITA has, however, secured take-off and landing rights as well as the Alitalia brand. The legendary name could 
possibly soon be reactivated under the new corporate umbrella.
Germany 's Lufthansa to take over 40% stake in Italy 's ITA Airways
Lufthansa strategy chief Jörg Eberhart, who already headed the regional subsidiary Air Dolomiti operating in 
northern Italy, is being discussed as the new head of ITA.
Last year ITA made a loss of (EURO)486 million ($521 million) on a turnover of just under (EURO)1.6 billion. At the 
end of March, the company cited the aftermath of the coronavirus pandemic, increased fuel costs due to the 
Ukraine war and the poor euro-dollar exchange rate as the reasons for the figures in the red.
The target for 2027 is now 94 aircraft and a turnover of (EURO)4.1 billion.
Lufthansa chief executive Carsten Spohr spoke of a win-win situation for Italy, ITA and his company. He wants to 
bring the lean Alitalia successor with its young fleet into the profit zone via higher load factors, cheaper purchasing 
and better flight coordination.
Lufthansa has wanted to gain a foothold in its second most important foreign market for many years. An attempt 
launched in 2009 under the name Lufthansa Italia came to an end in 2011.
At present, the Lufthansa Group only attracts transfer passengers from rich northern Italy to the Munich hub with 
flights operated by Air Dolomiti. Now, with ITA, Lufthansa is acquiring market share in an environment dominated by 
non-domestic low-cost carriers such as Ryanair and Easyjet.
Deutsche Lufthansa AG has already taken over the former state-owned airlines of neighbouring Switzerland, 
Austria and Belgium and has continued to operate them as independent brands.
The Belgian Sabena successor Brussels Airlines had been taken over by Lufthansa in two stages, initially also 
starting with a minority stake.
Another possible takeover target is TAP of Portugal.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 25, 2023
End of Document
EU court annuls approval of (EURO)130m in state aid for Italian airlines
EU court annuls approval of (EURO)130m in state aid for Italian airlines
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2023 Wednesday 2:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 193 words
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
A European Union court has annulled the approval for state aid granted to Italian airlines worth (EURO)130 million 
($140 million) during the Covid-19 pandemic in a ruling on Wednesday.
The EU General Court cancelled the European Commission's approval after finding that the basis for compatibility 
with EU law had not been sufficiently justified, according to a statement.
Budget airline Ryanair filed the complaint against the state support from Italy. It follows a similar court decision 
taken against German state aid awarded to German airline company Lufthansa.
The (EURO)130 million in funds was intended to compensate the airlines for damages suffered as a result of Covid-
19-related travel restrictions.
According to the EU General Court, the commission should have either explained why the competition authority had 
no issue with the state aid or started an investigation.
State support is usually closely regulated, however restrictions were loosened during the pandemic. The 
commission is the bloc's top authority on competition matters and approves state subsidies.
The ruling may be appealed at the European Court of Justice (ECJ), the bloc's highest court.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Elena Radwan, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 24, 2023
EU court annuls approval of (EURO)130m in state aid for Italian airlines
End of Document
Belarusian blogger Protasevich pardoned
Belarusian blogger Protasevich pardoned
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 22, 2023 Monday 3:41 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 272 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
A Belarusian blogger handed a jail sentence for opposition activities, Roman Protasevich, has been pardoned two 
years after his spectacular arrest and just a few weeks after his conviction.
"First and foremost, I am incredibly grateful to the country and the president personally for this decision," 
Protasevich said in Minsk on Monday, according to Belarusian media.
Protasevich was shown several times on Belarusian state television after his arrest, where he distanced himself 
from his opposition activism.
Protasevich's spectacular arrest in May 2021 caused a stir far beyond the borders of the ex-Soviet republic. 
Together with his then girlfriend Sofia Sapega, he was on a flight from Athens to Vilnius when the Ryanair plane 
was forced to land in Minsk by the Belarusian authorities because of an alleged bomb threat. Subsequently, both 
were detained.
Sapega, a Russian citizen, was later sentenced to six years in prison - and has since been transferred to Russia.
Protasevich was sentenced to eight years in prison in early May. The prosecution accused the former editor-in-chief 
of the opposition Telegram channel Nexta of an attempted coup d'état.
Nexta called for protests against the authoritarian ruler Alexander Lukashenko, who had himself declared the 
winner of the 2020 presidential election. Lukashenko brutally suppressed the subsequent street protests. The vote 
was not recognized internationally.
Protasevich's relatives assume that he made his pro-government statements in detention under pressure and 
torture.
Hundreds of Lukashenko opponents remain in prison. Many have rejected any kind of deal with the authorities.
Belarusian blogger Protasevich pardoned
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 22, 2023
End of Document
Low-cost airline Ryanair turns profit in FY23; total revenues up 124%
Low-cost airline Ryanair turns profit in FY23; total revenues up 124%
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 22, 2023 Monday 8:41 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 138 words
Dateline: Brussels/Frankfurt/Paris (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's largest low-cost airline Ryanair on Monday reported pre-tax profit of (EURO)1.4 billion ($1.5 billion) for the 
year ended on March 31, 2023, compared to a loss of (EURO)429.8 million in the year prior.
Profit per share was (EURO)1.15 euros compared to a loss of (EURO)0.21, according to the Dublin-based 
company.
Pre except. pretax profit stood at (EURO)1.57 billion, compared to a loss of (EURO)560.3 million last year.
Ryanair said the profit was due to strong traffic recovery, improving fares, industry leading cost base and 
advantageous fuel hedges.
Total operating revenues increased to (EURO)10.78 billion from (EURO)4.80 billion last year.
Traffic rose 74% to 168.6 million, Ryanair said.
Meanwhile, scheduled revenue grew over 160% to (EURO)6.93 billion.
For the forth quarter, Ryanair posted a loss of (EURO)154 million.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Elena Radwan, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 22, 2023

EU court annuls approval of (EURO)6 billion in state aid for Lufthansa
EU court annuls approval of (EURO)6 billion in state aid for Lufthansa
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 10, 2023 Wednesday 11:08 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 221 words
Byline:  Ciarán Sunderland, Doris Pundy and Regina Wank in Brussels
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
A European Union court has annulled the approval for German state aid granted to Lufthansa worth (EURO)6 billion 
($6.6 billion) during the Covid-19 pandemic in a ruling on Wednesday.
The EU General Court cancelled the decision by the European Commission to approve the state aid, citing "several 
errors" in a statement.
The commission wrongly assumed Lufthansa could not borrow from financial markets, misjudged the German 
airline's market power at certain airports and agreed conditions which did not ensure effective competition between 
airlines, the EU court found.
The billion-euro aid package for Lufthansa was awarded in the spring of 2020 and received approval from the 
commission, the bloc's top competition watchdog, later in June.
Ryanair and German leisure airline Condor filed a legal case against the decision.
The EU's usually strict aid rules were loosened at the outbreak of the pandemic to allow governments to support 
struggling companies but still required commission approval.
Germany's largest airline, Lufthansa, received financial support from the government after Covid-19 travel 
restrictions brought business to a standstill.
Tens of thousands of jobs were on the line in the company, which employs around 110,000 people.
The ruling may be appealed at the European Court of Justice (ECJ), the bloc's highest court.
EU court annuls approval of (EURO)6 billion in state aid for Lufthansa
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 10, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair orders 300 additional Boeing 737 Max aircraft
Ryanair orders 300 additional Boeing 737 Max aircraft
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 9, 2023 Tuesday 6:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 201 words
Dateline: New York (dpa) - 
Body
Irish airline Ryanair has placed an order for 300 Boeing 737-MAX-10 aircraft worth a total of $40 billion, the airline 
said on Tuesday.
Following the news, Boeing was seen trading up by 2.18% at $201.57 per share in the pre-market trading on the 
New York Stock Exchange.
The aircraft are expected to be delivered during the period from 2027 to 2033. Boeing's B737-MAX-10 aircraft will 
enable Ryanair to facilitate a traffic growth of 80% from 168 million in March 2023 to 300 million a year by March 
2034.
Ryanair expects 50% of these deliveries will replace older B737NGs. In addition to significant revenue growth, the 
new order offers Ryanair with extra seats to further widen Ryanair's unit-cost advantage over all EU competitor 
airlines.
Ryanair Group chief executive Michael O'Leary said: "These new, fuel-efficient, greener technology aircraft offer 
21% more seats, burn 20% less fuel and are 50% quieter than our B737-NGs. This order, coupled with our 
remaining gamechanger deliveries, will create 10,000 new jobs for highly paid aviation professionals over the next 
decade, and these jobs will be located across all of Europe's main economies where Ryanair is currently the 
number 1 or number 2 airline."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Charlotte Nijhuis, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 9, 2023
Ryanair orders 300 additional Boeing 737 Max aircraft
End of Document
Belarusian opposition blogger Protasevich given 8 years in prison
Belarusian opposition blogger Protasevich given 8 years in prison
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 3, 2023 Wednesday 12:39 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 234 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Roman Protasevich, a prominent blogger and critic of the authoritarian Belarusian government whose 2021 arrest 
caused international outrage, was sentenced to eight years in a prison camp by a court in Minsk on Wednesday.
Prosecutors had accused the 27-year-old blogger of plotting to seize power, among other things, according to 
Belarusian state news agency Belta.
Protasevich, who used to be editor-in-chief of the opposition blog Nexta, is widely viewed internationally as a 
political prisoner.
His spectacular arrest in May 2021 caused outrage around the world. He was on a flight from Greece to Lithuania 
with his then-girlfriend Sofia Sapega when the Belarusian authorities forced the Ryanair plane to land in Minsk 
because of what they claimed was a bomb threat.
Both the blogger and Sapega were promptly arrested and imprisoned. Sapega, who is a Russian citizen, was 
sentenced to six years in prison.
After his arrest, Protasevich appeared several times on Belarusian state television, where he distanced himself from 
his opposition activities. However, relatives believe that his statements were coerced under immense pressure and 
possible torture.
Belarusian strongman Alexander Lukashenko, who is also a close confidant of Russian President Vladimir Putin, 
has led a brutal and severe crackdown on political opponents and critics, especially after widespread anti-regime 
protests in the summer of 2020.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bryn Stole, <international@dpa.com;
Belarusian opposition blogger Protasevich given 8 years in prison
Load-Date: May 3, 2023
End of Document
Germany 's summer air traffic to stay well below pre-Covid level
Germany's summer air traffic to stay well below pre-Covid level
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 14, 2023 Friday 00:21:45+02:00Invalid date found for VDI: (VDI not available) XCEDOCID: 2 LNI: 680V-
0RM1-DXFJ-53PW-00000-00. Date output 'as-is'. GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 159 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Air traffic to and from Germany this coming summer will remain significantly below the pre-pandemic level, the 
latest flight schedules show.
An analysis of the schedules by the German Aviation Association (BDL) found 128 million seats will be offered from 
April through September. This corresponds to 82% of the capacity in the same period in 2019.
Only in the North Africa-Levant region - Israel, Jordan, Lebanon, Egypt, Tunisia, Algeria and Morocco - is there 
more capacity on offer than four years ago, at 103%, the industry association said Thursday.
Domestic air traffic has fallen particularly sharply to 54% of the pre-crisis level.
Compared to the rest of Europe, the number of flights on offer in Germany is comparatively low. Point-to-point 
airlines such as Ryanair and Wizz Air have shifted business and growth from the German market to other countries.
In the rest of Europe except Germany, the number of seats on offer is 97% of the pre-crisis level.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: April 13, 2023
End of Document
EU court rules sanctions for forced landing in Belarus were lawful
EU court rules sanctions for forced landing in Belarus were lawful
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 15, 2023 Wednesday 2:08 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 212 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Sanctions imposed against the state-owned company responsible for Belarusian airspace over the forced landing of 
a plane in May 2021 are lawful, the EU general court in Luxembourg ruled on Wednesday.
The lower court's decision can be appealed to the European Court of Justice (ECJ).
In May 2021, fighter jets from the Belarus airforce compelled Ryanair Flight FR4978, with more than 100 people on 
board, to land in Minsk on its way from Athens to Vilnius.
Among the passengers was the Belarusian blogger Roman Protasevich, who is critical of the government and co-
founder of the opposition Telegram channel Nexta, and his girlfriend at the time, Sofia Sapega. Both were arrested 
after landing.
The European Union then imposed sanctions, including entry bans and asset freezes.
The state-owned company Belaeronavigatsia, which is responsible for Belarusian airspace, filed a lawsuit 
challenging the sanctions, but was unsuccessful.
The judges said that Belaeronavigatsia "could not reasonably have been unaware" that this action would contribute 
"to the repression of civil society and democratic opposition in Belarus." 
The sanctions were also not disproportionate, the court ruled, as they were issued due to the ongoing disregard for 
human rights and the rule of law in Belarus.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miriam Widman <international@dpa.com;
EU court rules sanctions for forced landing in Belarus were lawful
Load-Date: February 15, 2023
End of Document

Ryanair plane lands safely in Athens after pilot calls in bomb threat
Ryanair plane lands safely in Athens after pilot calls in bomb threat
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 22, 2023 Sunday 6:37 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 96 words
Dateline: Athens (dpa) - 
Body
A Ryanair plane travelling from Poland to Athens landed safely in the Greek capital after the pilot reported a bomb 
threat during the flight, an airport spokesperson told dpa on Sunday.
"All people are well and safe," said Elena Dimopoulou, the airport spokesperson.
The plane had departed from the Polish city of Katowice with about 190 people on board, she said. Special police 
units checked the plane and the luggage.
The Greek state radio ERT reported that after the pilot called in the threat, fighter bombers were deployed and 
accompanied the aircraft until it landed safely.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miriam Widman <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 22, 2023

German air travel recovers more slowly from pandemic than EU peers
German air travel recovers more slowly from pandemic than EU peers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 7, 2023 Saturday 10:52 AM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 224 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Air travel in Germany is recovering more slowly than in other European countries, an industry association said 
on Friday.
For the first half of 2023, the number of seats on offer looks set to reach around 78% of the 2019 figure before the 
pandemic broke out, according to the German Aviation Association (BDL).
However, other European countries are already offering 94% of the pre-pandemic level, the group said.
That is partly due to a lower level of domestic air travel, at 56% of pre-pandemic flight capacity, the group said.
But it is also because low-cost airlines are giving most German airports a wide berth as they ramp up their offerings 
elsewhere. Current flight plans show that the number of connections from German airports are down more than a 
third compared to before the pandemic.
However, some low-cost point-to-point airlines such as Ryanair or Wizz have significantly expanded the number of 
flights they are offering since the pandemic in the rest of Europe outside of Germany, with 114% of the 2019 level.
Of all Germany's larger airports, only four - Dortmund, Hahn, Karlsruhe and Memmingen - will have more flights 
available than in the same period in 2019. All are used by lower-cost airlines.
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary had criticized German airports in the past for their high fees and announced plans to 
grow in other markets.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, <international@dpa.com;
German air travel recovers more slowly from pandemic than EU peers
Load-Date: January 7, 2023
End of Document
Ryanair expects higher annual profits after strong third quarter
Ryanair expects higher annual profits after strong third quarter
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 4, 2023 Wednesday 10:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2023 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 122 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's largest low-cost airline Ryanair is expecting a higher annual profit than expected after a surprisingly strong 
third quarter.
After taxes and adjusted for special items, the company announced on Wednesday that it expects to post a profit of 
(EURO)1.325 to 1.425 billion ($1.5 billion) if no negative events follow.
Previously, Ryanair had assumed a figure of (EURO)1 to 1.2 billion.
The company still expects 168 million passengers for the financial year ending on 30 March.
A profit of just under (EURO)200 million is likely to have been achieved in the third quarter, the Irish firm added. A 
strong pent-up demand from customers was noted in the holiday season as the majority of coronavirus restrictions 
in Europe were abolished.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Meadows; <international@dpa.com;

Ryanair boss O'Leary set to stay until July 2028

dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 8, 2022 Thursday 3:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 106 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair said on Thursday that it was extending the contract of group chief executive officer, Michael 
O'Leary, until July 2028.
The Irish airline group also said it had appointed Anne Nolan as a non-executive director with immediate effect.
Nolan is a former chair of the Irish Aviation Authority and previously served as chief executive of the Irish 
Pharmaceutical Healthcare Association. She has also served on various boards including the Food Safety Authority 
of Ireland and the Irish Medicines Board.
Ryanair Holdings plc is the largest airline group in Europe, comprising Ryanair, Ryanair UK, Buzz, Lauda and Malta 
Air.

Ryanair to work with Amadeus booking system
Ryanair to work with Amadeus booking system
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 11, 2022 Friday 9:45 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 237 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair has also entered into a cooperation agreement with Amadeus, the booking system 
provider used in many travel agencies.
All Ryanair connections will be bookable on the Amadeus travel platform from the end of 2022, the Irish airline 
announced on Friday. A corresponding contract was signed on the same day.
"We are pleased to announce this partnership with Amadeus, the world's leading travel technology company, 
further expanding Ryanair's offering and enabling corporate customers in particular greater access to our unrivalled 
network of connections, high frequencies, on-time performance, and unbeatable low fares as they return to 
collaborating with colleagues face-to-face," Ryanair's Dara Brady said.
The partnership expands Ryanair's offering and gives business customers in particular better access to the route 
network, it said. Lufthansa had already announced a cooperation with Amadeus in mid-September.
Amadeus belongs to the so-called global distribution systems that travel agencies in particular use for organizing 
and managing air travel and customer data.
"This partnership illustrates the value of our platform for low-cost carriers, offering the airline access to the widest 
network of travel sellers worldwide and the technology to help them get the most out of the indirect channel," Jose-
Luis Aragon, regional vice-president of the air distribution Europe department at Amadeus said.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;

Ryanair returns to profit, raises traffic guidance
Ryanair returns to profit, raises traffic guidance
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 7, 2022 Monday 9:19 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Dateline: Washington (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair announced a return to profit for the half-year period which ended on September 30, the 
company reported on Monday.
The Irish airline said its profit was (EURO)1.26 billion ($1.25 billion) or (EURO)1.1 per share, compared to a net 
loss of (EURO)47.6 million or (EURO)0.04 per share in the previous year.
Pre-exceptional profit after tax for the period was (EURO)1.37 billion, compared to a pre-Covid half year profit of 
(EURO)1.15 billion, due to record in the second quarter traffic, strong operational reliability and robust summer 
fares which in the second quarter were 14% up on pre-Covid pricing.
Total operating revenues for the quarter grew to (EURO)6.62 billion, up from (EURO)2.15 billion euros in the prior 
year.
While it remained dependent on Boeing meeting their delivery commitments, Ryanair modestly raised its fiscal year 
2023 traffic guidance to 168 million passengers, up from prior outlook of 166.5 million passengers.
Looking ahead for fiscal year 2023, Ryanair expects that it will minimize its winter losses which would deliver a 
profit after tax (pre-exceptionals) in a range of (EURO)1 billion to (EURO)1.20 billion.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rebekah Lyell, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 7, 2022
End of Document
German carrier Lufthansa slashes domestic flights to cut costs
German carrier Lufthansa slashes domestic flights to cut costs
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 22, 2022 Saturday 10:20 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 251 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
German airline Lufthansa has reduced its domestic flight schedule to cut costs, which include high fees at the 
country's airports, chief executive Carsten Spohr has said.
Due to the high fees at German airports, Lufthansa is increasingly using its aircraft "more efficiently and profitably 
on other European routes," Spohr told dpa.
The carrier had also expanded cooperation with German railway operator Deutsche Bahn, the chief executive said.
Lufthansa and Deutsche Bahn have been offering a so-called Rail&Fly deal for years, with airline tickets for 
international flights including a train ride to a domestic airport.
Germany's domestic aviation sector has still not recovered from the impact of the coronavirus pandemic, which 
brought numerous travel restrictions, according to data compiled by the German Airports Association (ADV).
In September, some 1.9 million passengers were recorded on domestic flights, which accounts for only 45.3% of 
the pre-pandemic levels recorded in September of 2019.
In comparison, passenger levels on European flights have already returned to 80.2% compared to pre-pandemic 
levels, according to the ADV.
At the same time, domestic tickets were around 25% more expensive in August than three years earlier, according 
to Germany's Federal Statistical Office.
Lufthansa's domestic flights are mainly operated by the carrier itself as well as its subsidiary Eurowings, with 
competitors from abroad like low-cost airlines Easyjet and Ryanair having mostly withdrawn from the market.
German carrier Lufthansa slashes domestic flights to cut costs
Editorial contactsEditing by: Elena Radwan, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 22, 2022
End of Document
Italian airport strikes lead to hundreds of cancelled flights
Italian airport strikes lead to hundreds of cancelled flights
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 21, 2022 Friday 1:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 240 words
Byline: Johannes Neudecker in Rome
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
A strike over pay and work conditions by employees of the Italian air traffic control company Enav led to hundreds 
of flights to and from Italy being cancelled on Friday.
Italy's state-owned ITA Airways cancelled just over 200 flights, most of them domestic. Other airlines, like low-cost 
carriers easyJet and Eurowings, have also scrubbed flights from their schedules.
Ryanair alone said more than 600 flights were cancelled and about 110,000 passengers affected.
Air traffic control unions CGIL, CISL and UIL had called for the work stoppage, which was expected to affect Rome, 
Milan Malpensa and Venice airports the hardest.
The strike was known by airlines and passengers well in advance, resulting in few long queues or crowded airport 
halls. Compared to the usual volume of passengers on a Friday, Terminal 1 at Rome's Fiumicino was "half empty," 
according to the ANSA news agency.
"We apologize to all passengers who may be inconvenienced because of the strike," UIL wrote in a statement. It 
said Enav's stance toward workers' demands made the labour action unavoidable.
The unions demand changes in working hours and schedules from the partly state-owned Enav. The unions said 
they would press ahead with their demands - if necessary - with further protest actions.
The last strike at Enav was on July 17. At that time, too, numerous flights were cancelled in the middle of the 
summer vacation season, leaving passengers stranded at airports.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Italian airport strikes lead to hundreds of cancelled flights
Load-Date: October 21, 2022
End of Document
'Smoke that thunders': The latest from dpa trends - travel
'Smoke that thunders': The latest from dpa trends - travel
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 17, 2022 Monday 1:05 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 286 words
Body
Mosi-oa-Tuny - "the smoke that thunders" - is what the locals call the spectacular Victoria Falls in the border region 
of Zimbabwe and Zambia, said to be the widest continuous waterfalls in the world.
A visit can easily be combined with a safari excursion as the Zambezi river is also the natural habitat of many wild 
animals and a paradise for bird-watchers.
This week in the travel and events section from the dpa trends and features desk, we're giving you some highlights 
of Zimbabwe, plus an Italian museum deciding to make its biggest attraction share the spotlight.
Elena Radwan,dpa trends & features

Ryanair prepares to raise prices as fuel costs soar
Ryanair prepares to raise prices as fuel costs soar
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 26, 2022 Monday 10:16 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 196 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair is planning to raise prices as fuel becomes more expensive, the head of the Irish firm's 
German business told dpa.
"The average price for a Ryanair ticket is likely to rise from 40 to 50 euros [$38.6 to $48.2] in five years," Andreas 
Gruber said.
The airline is trying to reduce the impact of rising oil prices with futures contracts that fix prices and by buying cheap 
paraffin for its stocks, but it cannot completely cushion rising fuel prices, said Gruber, who is also head of Ryanair 
subsidiary Laudamotion.
The airline sees itself at an advantage over more expensive rivals amid economic hard times.
"In the recession, more people will pay attention to the ticket price," Gruber said.
Ryanair is not alone in raising prices: Lufthansa for example has announced higher fares for the rest of the year.
Ryanair appears to have let behind the slump in passenger numbers during the coronavirus pandemic.
In the current financial year (April 2022 to March 2023), Ryanair is expected to transport 166 million passengers in 
Europe, well above the level before the pandemic hit.
In the next financial year, passenger numbers should rise to 185 million, Gruber said.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair prepares to raise prices as fuel costs soar
Load-Date: September 26, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair cancels several Budapest flights due to 'excess profit tax'
Ryanair cancels several Budapest flights due to 'excess profit tax'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 13, 2022 Tuesday 7:45 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 258 words
Dateline: Budapest (dpa) - 
Body
Irish low-cost airline Ryanair is cancelling several flights to and from Budapest because of a new excess profit tax in 
Hungary.
The move affects eight out of 53 destinations that will be cancelled completely and seven other routes where the 
number of flights will be reduced, Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary said at a press conference in Budapest on 
Tuesday.
"The Hungarian [government's] idiotic 'excess profits' tax on the loss-making air transport sector (and Hungarian 
citizens/visitors) has done nothing but damage Hungarian tourism, connectivity, traffic, and jobs as evidenced by 
these severe cuts to our Budapest winter schedule, which were made in direct response to this ridiculous 'excess 
profits' tax," he said.
Hungary's right-wing nationalist government introduced the tax in July this year to skim off real or perceived excess 
profits from various sectors of the economy.
Among others, energy companies, banks, insurance and telecom firms have fallen under the new taxation. Airlines 
have to pay around (EURO)10 ($10) to the state for each ticket departing from a Hungarian airport.
Ryanair immediately included this amount in their ticket prices. However, the relevant Hungarian tax law explicitly 
prohibits this practice. The Hungarian consumer protection authority therefore fined the Irish airline 300 million 
forints ($752,725) in August.
Ryanair announced that it would take legal action and, if necessary, go to EU courts: The airline argues that the 
Hungarian ban on offsetting tax increases with price increases violates European law.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair cancels several Budapest flights due to 'excess profit tax'
Load-Date: September 13, 2022
End of Document
Flights cancelled in Spain due to Iberia Express cabin crew strike
Flights cancelled in Spain due to Iberia Express cabin crew strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 26, 2022 Friday 10:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 252 words
Dateline: Madrid (dpa) - 
Body
In Spain, 92 domestic flights are being cancelled, affecting some 17,000 passengers, due to a ten-day strike by 
cabin crew working for Iberia Express, the budget airline that is part of the Iberia group.
The flights that are being cancelled include connections from Madrid to Palma de Mallorca, Gran Canaria, Santiago 
de Compostela, Seville, Málaga and Tenerife, Spanish trade union USO said on Friday. They were due to depart 
between August 28 and September 6.
The cabin crew are holding the strike demanding the company start negotiating on a collective agreement and raise 
salaries, frozen since 2015, to the higher cost of living.
So far, only 24 flights between Sunday and Tuesday are definitely cancelled due to the industrial action, Iberia 
Express said, according to El País newspaper.
The Spain-based cabin crew of Irish low-cost airline Ryanair are also demanding better working conditions by 
striking from Monday to Thursday each week, which began on August 8 and is due to continue until January 7, 
2023. Ryanair is not complying with the law and is also refusing to negotiate, workers said.
British budget airline Easyjet cabin crew also went on strike for better working conditions in Spain this summer, but 
called an early end to the protest in July after reaching an agreement with management.
The wave of summer strikes has had little impact on passengers in Spain due to regulations maintaining minimum 
services. Even when staff walk out, often only a relatively small proportion of flights are cancelled.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams <international@dpa.com;
Flights cancelled in Spain due to Iberia Express cabin crew strike
Load-Date: August 26, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair cabin crew strike in Spain causes only minor disruption
Ryanair cabin crew strike in Spain causes only minor disruption
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 8, 2022 Monday 7:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 213 words
Dateline: Madrid (dpa) - 
Body
The start of a long-planned strike by Ryanair cabin crew in Spain caused only limited disruption at the country's 
airports.
Ten flights had been cancelled on Monday and there had been 111 delays by the afternoon, the USO trade union 
said.
The Dublin-based budget airline predicted that operations over the months ahead would be disrupted minimally if at 
all.
Ryanair's Spain-based cabin crew are demanding an improvement in working conditions. Following unsuccessful 
strike action in in June and July, the unions involved, USO and Sitcpla, said crew would strike between Monday and 
Thursday every week from Monday up to January 7 next year.
They accused Ryanair of failing to comply with Spanish law in refusing to negotiate.
Among the demands are observing "basic labour rights," including at least 22 days' holiday per year, 
implementation of occupational health and safety legislation and raising pay to the level that applied before the 
pandemic.
The airports affected include the main hubs at Madrid, Barcelona and Mallorca, and also Málaga, Sevilla, Alicante, 
Valencia, Girona, Ibiza and Santiago de Compostela.
The maintenance of "minimal service" prescribed under Spanish law during strikes means that only some flights 
can be cancelled, usually only a relatively small number.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Nathalia Araújo, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair cabin crew strike in Spain causes only minor disruption
Load-Date: August 8, 2022
End of Document
EasyJet cabin crew in Spain reach pay deal, end strike
EasyJet cabin crew in Spain reach pay deal, end strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 28, 2022 Thursday 9:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 274 words
Dateline: Madrid (dpa) - 
Body
The Spanish-based cabin crew of low-cost carrier EasyJet cancelled their strike planned for the weekend after 
reaching a pay agreement with management.
The work stoppages scheduled for Friday through Sunday have been called off, the Spanish union USO announced 
on Thursday.
It said the British airline had promised a 22% pay increase spread over the next three years. The USO called this a 
"significant" improvement, although not as high as the 40% it had hoped to achieve.
More than 300 of the some 400 flight attendants working for EasyJet in Spain had voted on the agreement and 
approved it by nearly 75%, the union said.
Cabin crews stationed in Barcelona, Palma de Mallorca and Málaga had gone on strike for more money between 
July 1 and 3 and between July 15 and 17. In total, the employees planned to strike for nine days in July.
The basic salary of EasyJet flight attendants in Spain is currently (EURO)950 ($967 dollars) a month, according to 
USO. That is (EURO)850 less than in Germany or France, it said.
"With the basic salary, we can hardly pay the rent or the mortgage," the representative of the airline employees at 
USO, Miguel Galán, had said.
A day earlier Ryanair cabin crew, who have been on strike for better working conditions and pay in Spain since the 
end of June, announced a five-month extension of their walkout.
Between August 8 and January 7, 2023, they will strike every week from Monday to Thursday, the USO and Sitcpla 
unions announced.
EasyJet cabin crew in Spain reach pay deal, end strike
So far, because of the requirement by Spanish law for airlines to maintain "minimum services" during strikes, only a 
relatively small proportion of flights has actually been cancelled.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;

Ryanair cabin crew extend strikes in Spain for five months
Ryanair cabin crew extend strikes in Spain for five months
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 27, 2022 Wednesday 4:45 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 276 words
Dateline: Madrid (dpa) - 
Body
Cabin crew at the low-cost airline Ryanair, who have been on strike for better working conditions in Spain since the 
end of June, are extending their walkouts for another five months.
The Spanish unions USO and Sitcpla announced on Wednesday that they would strike every week from Monday to 
Thursday between August 8 and January 7, 2023.
The four-day-a-week strike was instituted as the Irish airline is not complying with Spanish law and is also refusing 
to negotiate, they said.
They are demanding compliance with "basic labour rights" such as 22 working days of annual leave, 14 statutory 
public holidays, implementation of the Health and Safety at Work Act and a pay rise to pre-pandemic levels.
Ryanair cabin crew have already called a total of 18 strike days since June 24 and up to Thursday, but so far these 
have not led to a resolution of the industrial dispute.
These work stoppages have led to the cancellation of a total of about 300 flights and about 3,000 delays, the state 
television station RTVE reported on Wednesday.
Numerous airports are affected by the Ryanair strikes: Málaga, Seville, Alicante, Valencia, Girona, Ibiza and 
Santiago de Compostela, in addition to Madrid, Barcelona and Mallorca.
However, because of the requirement by Spanish law for airlines to maintain "minimum services" during strikes, 
only a - often relatively small - proportion of flights has actually been cancelled.
In the case of the Ryanair strikes, for example, the Transport Ministry recently decided that at least 73% to 82% of 
all scheduled flights must be completed on the strike days, depending on the airport, meaning the impact on 
travellers has been limited.
Ryanair cabin crew extend strikes in Spain for five months
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 27, 2022
End of Document
Aviation authority: Forced Ryanair landing in Belarus unlawful
Aviation authority: Forced Ryanair landing in Belarus unlawful
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 20, 2022 Wednesday 9:39 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 239 words
Dateline: New York (dpa) - 
Body
The International Civil Aviation Organization ICAO has deemed the forced landing of a Ryanair flight in Belarus in 
May 2021 was "unlawful interference."
The Montreal-based UN specialized agency released a Tuesday statement after evaluating new material including 
audio recordings from the Minsk air traffic controller.
The bomb threat cited as a reason for the emergency landing was "deliberately false," endangered flight safety and 
was based on instructions from senior Belarusian government officials, the ICAO found.
Belarusian authorities forced Ryanair flight FR4978, which was on its way from Athens to Vilnius with more than 
100 people on board, to land in Minsk.
The anti-government Belarusian blogger Roman Protasevich, co-founder of the opposition Telegram 
channel Nexta, and his girlfriend at the time, Sofia Sapega, were among those on board.
Both were detained after the plane landed. The European Union closed its airspace to Belarusian aircraft 
afterwards.
Sapega was sentenced to six years in prison in May for running an opposition channel on Telegram. She asked 
Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko for a pardon in late June.
Protasevich is still facing trial, according to media reports.
The US indicted four Belarusian government officials in absentia in January over the forced landing.
Prosecutors in New York charged them with "conspiracy to commit aircraft piracy." They said four US citizens were 
among the passengers.
Aviation authority: Forced Ryanair landing in Belarus unlawful
Editorial contactsEditing by: Helen Corbett, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 20, 2022
End of Document
Boeing retains lead in new orders at Farnborough Airshow
Boeing retains lead in new orders at Farnborough Airshow
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 19, 2022 Tuesday 2:26 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 156 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
US aircraft manufacturer Boeing kept its nose ahead of European rival Airbus in the race for new orders on the 
second day of the Farnborough International Airshow outside of London.
Private equity firm 777 Partners was buying 30 more Boeing 737 MAX medium-haul planes, the manufacturer said 
on Tuesday.
The aircraft will be a special 737-8-200 version with more seats and additional doors, which Boeing developed for 
low-cost carriers such as Ryanair.
There is also a preliminary contract with 777 Partners for 36 more aircraft.
Airbus meanwhile reported an order from US airline Delta for 12 A220-300 aircraft, the longer version of the 
smallest Airbus model A220.
On Monday, Delta said it was ordering 100 of Boeing's 737-10 jets, with options for an additional 30 planes from the 
company.
The Farnborough trade show, which runs through the week, is staged every two years and has become a venue for 
Boeing and Airbus to face off for new orders.

Boeing retains lead in new orders at Farnborough Airshow

Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
More than 200 flights were cancelled in Italy on Sunday due to a four-hour strike by airport and airline workers.
Flights within Italy were badly affected but also routes to Frankfurt, Paris, London and Zurich suffered cancellations.
Several Italian trade unions called the work stoppage, which affected air traffic control firm ENAV as well as carriers 
Ryanair, EasyJet und Volotea.
The dispute is over employee rights, working conditions and minimum wages.

Strike at Italian airports and low-cost airlines on Sunday
Strike at Italian airports and low-cost airlines on Sunday
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 16, 2022 Saturday 1:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 231 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Due to a threatened work stoppage at Italian airports, travellers have to be prepared for delays and cancellations of 
numerous flights on Sunday.
Several trade unions called on staff of the air traffic control company ENAV as well as the low-cost airlines Ryanair, 
EasyJet and Volotea to take part in the four-hour work stoppage, according to notices from the trade union 
confederations.
The reason is a dispute over workers' rights, working conditions and the payment of minimum wages in the 
industry.
EasyJet has cancelled flights from Milan's Linate airport to Berlin and from Rome-Fiumicino to Amsterdam because 
of the strike. Ryanair said it had been forced to cancel some flights because of the strike at ENAV. Passengers had 
already been informed, the airline said.
According to ENAV, the work stoppage will last from 2 pm to 6 pm (1200-1600 GMT). Flights between 7 am and 10 
am and 6 pm to 9 pm will not be affected.
With work stoppages looming, Tourism Minister Massimo Garavaglia called during the week for everything to be 
done to avoid inconvenience in the recovering sector.
"An unrest among air traffic control staff threatens to block the most dynamic sector of the economy, which is 
currently driving the country's growth to a significant extent. To block transport is to block the country," said the 
politician from the far-right Lega party, which is considered pro-business.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Strike at Italian airports and low-cost airlines on Sunday

Ryanair: $1.5bn saved in fuel costs due to long-term supply contracts
Ryanair: $1.5bn saved in fuel costs due to long-term supply contracts
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 13, 2022 Wednesday 6:50 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 153 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
European budget airline Ryanair will save around $1.5 billion this year due to long-term jet fuel supply contracts, 
chief executive Michael O'Leary said on Wednesday in Vienna.
The airline will receive the majority of the fuel it needs until March 2023 at a price of roughly $73 per barrel while 
prices have recently risen to up to $120 per barrel.
"We have secured all the fuel we need at much lower prices," O'Leary said.
Ryanair will be able to transport over 200 million passengers annually within a few years, O'Leary said, compared 
to around 150 million before the Covid-19 pandemic.
The Irish company is in talks with around 30 to 40 airports about setting up new routes. O'Leary announced 
connections from Vienna to Helsinki, Copenhagen, and Tuzla for the winter flight plan.
Vienna is among the fastest-growing locations of the Ryanair Group. It employs around 16,000 people overall and 
boasts a fleet of 470 planes.
Editorial contactsEditing by: David von Kerssenbrock Krosigk, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 13, 2022
End of Document
More airline strikes to hit Spain , causing trouble for holiday season
More airline strikes to hit Spain, causing trouble for holiday season
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 2, 2022 Saturday 9:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 318 words
Byline: Emilio Rappold in Madrid
Dateline: Madrid (dpa) - 
Body
The cabin crew staff at low-cost airline Ryanair plans to strike for better working conditions on 12 more days in July, 
as a wave of industrial action hits Spain during the busy holiday season.
The walkouts have been scheduled for July 12-15, 18-21, and 25-28, the Spanish unions USO and Sitcpla 
announced on Saturday.
Numerous airports are affected by the Ryanair strikes: Madrid, Barcelona and Mallorca, as well as Málaga, Seville, 
Alicante, Valencia, Girona, Ibiza and Santiago de Compostela.
Ryanair cabin crew had already gone on strike in Spain at the end of June and also between Thursday and 
Saturday. The Irish airline "does not respect court rulings and laws and uses fear, coercion and threats against its 
workers," USO said. Labour Minister Yolanda Díaz must intervene, it said.
The cabin crew of rival airline Easyjet will also stop work in Spain on a total of nine days between through the end 
of July - as early as this weekend, as well as between July 15-17 and between July 29-31.
In the case of the British airline, the cabin crew is demanding significantly higher salaries as well as a limit to flying 
times, as is the case in other countries.
On Saturday, 15 flights were cancelled throughout Spain by the afternoon because of the strikes - 10 Ryanair and 
five Easyjet flights - state television station RTVE reported, citing the authorities. In addition, there were around 200 
delays.
However, there were no cancellations on Mallorca on Saturday for the time being.
More airline strikes to hit Spain , causing trouble for holiday season
Because of the maintenance of "minimum services" prescribed by Spanish legislation in the event of strikes, only 
some flights, often only a relatively small proportion - may be cancelled.
In the case of the Ryanair strikes, for example, the Transport Ministry in Madrid decided that between 73% (Alicante 
and Palma de Mallorca) and 82% (Ibiza) of all programmed flights must be completed on the strike days, depending 
on the airport.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 2, 2022
