Russian jailed after forced Ryanair landing asks Minsk for clemency
Russian jailed after forced Ryanair landing asks Minsk for clemency
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 27, 2022 Monday 12:35 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 282 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
A prominent critic of the Belarusian government, who hit the headlines when she and her then-partner were 
removed from a Ryanair plane forced to land in Minsk, has petitioned for clemency after more than a year in 
custody, according to a media report.
According to the BBC's Russian-language service, Sofia Sapega wrote that her support for the Belarusian 
opposition was attributable to "youth and stupidity." The Russian national also wrote that she now recognized the 
movement's lawlessness and illegitimacy.
It is unclear under what circumstances she wrote the plea.
Belarus was rocked by protests in 2020 after election results that returned Alexander Lukasehnko to the presidency 
were widely derided as fixed. Authorities cracked down hard on the protest movement, with many jailed and others 
fleeing the country.
One who fled was blogger Roman Protasevich. However, he was taken into custody in 2021 after a flight he was 
on, travelling from Athens to Vilnius, was forced to land in Belarus after officials there cited a bomb threat.
Sapega was also on the plane and taken into custody. She was sentenced to six years because she was 
responsible for an opposition news channel on the Telegram messaging service.
The incident prompted an airspace ban from the European Union, which had already laid sanctions on Belarus due 
to allegations of election tampering. Officials were especially angered by the fact that the flight was between two 
EU countries, but was still rerouted.
Protasevich, who operated the opposition Telegram channel Nexta, has also apologized for his prior government 
opposition in jailhouse interviews. Opposition members say Protasevich's new comments were likely coerced.
Russian jailed after forced Ryanair landing asks Minsk for clemency

Ryanair, Brussels Airlines scrap hundreds of flights in Belgium
Ryanair, Brussels Airlines scrap hundreds of flights in Belgium
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 24, 2022 Friday 5:26 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 174 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Nearly 130 flights were scrubbed from the weekend schedule at Charleroi Airport in Brussels due to a strike by 
Ryanair workers, adding to the Belgian capital's air travel chaos.
The employees of the Ireland-based low-cost carrier are demanding that the company apply Belgium's minimum 
wage rules for cabin crew.
The CSC trade union also criticizes, among other things, that there is no food or drink on board for staff to consume 
and that wage cuts are being imposed under the threat of mass lay-offs.
The nearly 130 flights were cancelled on Friday and over the weekend at Charleroi, one of the two main airports the 
Belgian capital, according to the Belga news agency.
Meanwhile, pilots and cabin crew at Brussels Airlines have been on strike in Belgium since Thursday. The 
employees of the Lufthansa subsidiary say they are suffering under an increasingly heavy workload.
The airline announced before the start of the three-day strike that 40,000 passengers were expected to be affected. 
Belga reported that 315 flights would be cancelled by Saturday.

Lufthansa slashes 2,000 more flights in July due to staff shortages
Lufthansa slashes 2,000 more flights in July due to staff shortages
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 23, 2022 Thursday 7:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 316 words
Byline: Jens Albes in Koblenz and Vanessa Reiber in Brussels
Dateline: Frankfurt/Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
German airline Lufthansa is cancelling more than 2,000 additional flights at its Frankfurt and Munich hubs due to 
staff shortages.
The company announced two weeks ago that it would cancel 900 connections in July. Now it will "take out of the 
system a further 2,200 of a total of 80,000 flights," Lufthansa said on Thursday.
"The cancellations will affect domestic German and intra-European flights in particular, but not the classic holiday 
destinations that are well utilized during this season," the company said, adding that flight schedules could also 
change.
"Aviation security strikes, weather events and in particular an increased rate of staff sick with Covid-19 have put 
additional strain on the system," Lufthansa said, explaining the decision.
Lufthansa passengers would be informed immediately of cancellations and, if possible, rebooked on other suitable 
flights. Alternatively, feeder flights within Germany could be replaced by train travel to the hubs, from where the 
planes would then take off for foreign destinations.
Lufthansa said it hoped the reduction to its schedule would "ensure greater overall stability."
In Brussels, meanwhile, strikes this week at Lufthansa Group's Brussels Airline, along with low-cost Irish carrier 
Ryanair, were affecting tens of thousands of passengers at the city's main Brussels Airport and the Brussels South 
Charleroi Airport.
Brussels Airlines alone cancelled more than 300 flights. Some 40,000 passengers are expected to be affected due 
to the walk-outs by cabin crew and pilots from Thursday to Saturday.
Lufthansa slashes 2,000 more flights in July due to staff shortages
They say they are suffering from heavy workloads and worsening work conditions.
Employees of Ryanair are planning an industrial action from Friday to Sunday. According to the Belga news 
agency, 80 Ryanair connections at Charleroi airport are to be cancelled.
Ryanair workers are demanding compliance with Belgian minimum wage rules for cabin crew.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Nathalia Araújo, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 23, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair loses EU court case on state aid given to rival Finnair
Ryanair loses EU court case on state aid given to rival Finnair
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 22, 2022 Wednesday 5:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 216 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Irish low-cost airline Ryanair lost a legal challenge against the EU's approval of millions in pandemic-related state 
aid to rival Finnair, according to a ruling published on Wednesday.
The aid given by the Finnish government was compatible with EU law, judges at the Luxembourg-based General 
Court said.
Finland had notified authorities it was providing financial aid to the tune of hundreds of millions of euros to the ailing 
airline Finnair in 2020. The aid was then approved by the European Commission, the EU's executive arm.
Ryanair challenged the commission's decision, citing a lack of a formal review process and the violation of 
principles regarding equal treatment.
The court dismissed the action on the grounds of faulty reasoning on the part of Ryanair.
In the judges' view, it was sufficient that Finnair had serious difficulties in maintaining flight operations and that a 
default would have had a considerable impact on the Finnish economy.
Ryanair has taken action against the European Commission on several occasions regarding state aid offered to 
competitors to cushion the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic.
Recently, the EU court had rejected a complaint against millions in aid that went to the German airline Condor. In 
other cases, however, Ryanair's lawsuits have met with success.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair loses EU court case on state aid given to rival Finnair
Load-Date: June 22, 2022
End of Document

Ryanair slammed over Afrikaans tests for South African passengers
Ryanair slammed over Afrikaans tests for South African passengers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 6, 2022 Monday 7:59 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 169 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Irish budget airline Ryanair has come under fire for language tests it requires South African passengers to take 
before flying to Britain.
Several people affected expressed outrage on social media because they were asked to take a test with several 
knowledge questions in Afrikaans, the BBC and several other media outlets reported on Monday.
Afrikaans is one of several official languages in South Africa and is only spoken by a predominantly white minority 
of the population.
Those affected complained that the practice was discriminatory and reminiscent of the oppressive system in the 
country's apartheid-era discrimination against people of non-European descent.
Ryanair, when asked by dpa, said it had introduced the test in Afrikaans after becoming aware of an increased 
incidence of forged South African passports.
"If they are unable to complete this questionnaire, they will be refused travel and issued with a full refund," it added.
The test is not a requirement of British border authorities, the BBC reported.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 6, 2022
End of Document
Greenpeace : European airlines not doing enough to protect climate
Greenpeace: European airlines not doing enough to protect climate
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 1, 2022 Wednesday 7:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 265 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Seven of the largest European airlines are failing to take credible action on their climate ambitions, environmental 
organization Greenpeace said in a press release on Wednesday.
"Europe's biggest airlines are putting up a smokescreen of false solutions to distract from their staggering 
emissions, and keep transport in the EU hooked on oil," said Herwig Schuster, a spokesperson for the organization.
A report commissioned by Greenpeace looked at seven airlines including Lufthansa, Air France-KLM, the 
International Airlines Group IAG (which includes British Airways), Easyjet, and Ryanair.
Greenpeace accused the airlines of hiding their emissions behind false promises and "greenwashing," while not 
doing enough to lower carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions.
In order to keep global warming from lifting the world's temperature by 1.5 degrees Celsius, Greenpeace has said 
that European airlines will have to reduce their air traffic by at least 2% annually between now and 2040.
However, "none of the companies analysed has annual reduction goals for its greenhouse gas emissions, 
committed to reduce flights, or pledged to fully decarbonise by 2040," the press release stated.
A spokesperson for Lufthansa said that the airline will look carefully at the Greenpeace study, and that the airline 
has plans to halve net CO2 emissions by 2030 from their 2019 levels.
Easyjet also responded, saying that it is aware of its responsibility and is working on becoming more climate 
friendly.
Ryanair said that the data and conclusions of the report are outdated, and that it has an ambitious climate strategy.
Greenpeace : European airlines not doing enough to protect climate
Editorial contactsEditing by: David von Kerssenbrock Krosigk, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 1, 2022
End of Document
Masks required on flights to and from Germany despite looser EU rules
Masks required on flights to and from Germany despite looser EU rules
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 16, 2022 Monday 3:10 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 284 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Despite loosened EU restrictions from Monday, passengers flying to and from Germany will still be required to wear 
masks in flight, according to the interior ministry in Berlin.
FFP2 or medical masks must be worn during boarding and disembarking and throughout the flight.
They may only be removed for eating and drinking. Children under the age of six are exempt from the requirement.
The ministry explained that the mask requirement corresponds to the new EU recommendations.
The aviation security agency EASA and the EU health authority ECDC no longer recommend that masks be worn in 
airports and on planes as a general rule from Monday.
But if masks are compulsory at the point of departure or the destination, masks need to be worn during the flight.
In Germany the nationwide mask requirement on planes and long-distance trains remains in place until September 
23. Masks are also compulsory on local bus and train transport.
German Transport Minister Volker Wissing and the transport industry have called for the mask requirement on 
planes, trains and buses to be scrapped.
However, the federal government has no plans to abolish the mask requirement for the time being.
Health Minister Karl Lauterbach (SPD) explained that, with the number of coronavirus cases still very high, "there is 
no scope to do without masks on public transport."
In general, relaxed EU rules do not mean that masks are no longer required on all flights. Europe's largest low-cost 
airline Ryanair has published a list of 15 EU countries in which national laws still require the wearing of face masks 
to prevent the spread of the virus.
Masks required on flights to and from Germany despite looser EU rules
Besides Germany, these include popular tourist destinations such as Spain, Greece, Portugal and Italy.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Thomas Cronenberg, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 15, 2022
End of Document

Jail sentence handed to woman in 2021 forced Ryanair landing in Minsk
Jail sentence handed to woman in 2021 forced Ryanair landing in Minsk
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 6, 2022 Friday 12:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 272 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
One of the two people detained in Belarus last year after Minsk forced a Greece-to-Lithuania flight to land so it 
could take them into custody - an event that enraged the European Union - has been sentenced to jail for 
incitement and making threats.
Sofia Sapega was on the Ryanair flight last May when it crossed over Belarusian airspace. Authorities in Minsk 
initially forced the flight to land in Minsk after alleging there had been a bomb on board.
She was travelling with her boyfriend, Belarusian blogger Roman Protasevich, who is believed to have been the 
main target of the action. He was a key leader in 2020 protests against widely disputed elections that returned 
Alexander Lukashenko to another term as president in Belarus before fleeing the country.
Sapega's sentence was announced by human rights group Viasna. The group reported on its website that "there's 
been a harsh verdict against the political prisoner Sofia Sapega: six years of prison and a 167,500-rouble 
fine [about $50,000]."
The EU decried the incident, noticing it endangered aerial safety and interrupted a flight travelling between two 
EU countries. In its wake, the EU blocked Belarusian airlines from its airspace in the aftermath.
Sapega had been accused of incitement, urging people to conduct violence and murders and insulting government, 
police and court officials.
Protasevich's trial is under way, according to media reports. The one-time editor of a Telegram news channel has 
appeared on state TV multiple times since his detention to distance himself from his former opposition allies. Those 
close to him say he is making the statements under duress.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Jail sentence handed to woman in 2021 forced Ryanair landing in Minsk
Load-Date: May 6, 2022

Ryanair reports rise in passengers, but Ukraine conflict weighs
Ryanair reports rise in passengers, but Ukraine conflict weighs
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 4, 2022 Monday 10:39 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 125 words
Dateline: Brussels/Frankfurt/Paris (dpa) - 
Body
Passenger numbers jumped from half a million to 11.2 million in the year to March, reported carrier Ryanair on 
Monday.
However, it noted that March traffic was impacted by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, which caused 2,000 flights to 
and from Ukraine to be cancelled in the month.
Ryanair operated more than 67,800 flights in March. Load factor was 87% compared to 77%, prior year. For the 
rolling annual period, load factor was 82% compared to 71%, last year.
Rolling annual traffic increased to 97.1 million guests from 27.5 million. Ryanair said it expects to report a pre-
exceptional fiscal 2022 net loss of between (EURO)350 million ($386.6 million) and (EURO)400 million. The 
previously guided loss range was (EURO)250 million to (EURO)450 million.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: April 4, 2022
End of Document
EU member states reach agreement for new Belarus sanctions
EU member states reach agreement for new Belarus sanctions
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 2, 2022 Wednesday 11:43 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 201 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
EU member states agreed new sanctions on Belarus, Russia's ally in the invasion of Ukraine, the French 
presidency of the European Council announced on Wednesday on Twitter.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen announced on Sunday new sanctions on Belarus, "the 
other aggressor" in the invasion of Ukraine.
Russia launched offensives against Ukraine from Belarus which borders the country to the north. Minsk's 
strongman leader Alexander Lukashenko is considered an ally and military supporter of Kremlin leader Vladimir 
Putin.
Von der Leyen said the measures are to target Belarus' most important export products such as minerals, fuels, 
tobacco, wood, cement, iron and steel.
Personal sanctions are also to target Belarusian officials that support Russia's invasion, von der Leyen said.
The sanctions package is to enter into force as soon as the measures are published in the EU Official Journal 
according to France, which currently holds the rotating EU presidency.
The EU already enacted far-reaching sanctions targeting Belarus last year because of Lukashenko's repression of 
civil society, the forced rerouting of a Ryanair plane and the orchestration of a migrant crisis on the bloc's border.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 2, 2022
EU member states reach agreement for new Belarus sanctions
End of Document
EU agency issues airspace warning for Ukraine , Moldova and Belarus
EU agency issues airspace warning for Ukraine, Moldova and Belarus
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 24, 2022 Thursday 4:16 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 123 words
Dateline: Cologne (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) has issued extensive warnings to airlines regarding Ukrainian, 
Moldovan and Belarusian airspace.
Landings, take-offs and overflights are prohibited in Ukraine and Moldova. A ban on flights over Belarus remains in 
place, the agency announced in Cologne on Thursday.
In Russian airspace over Moscow and the Rostov region bordering Ukraine, aircraft operators have been called 
upon to exercise increased caution because the possible use of medium-range missiles.
After the start of the Russian invasion, several airlines suspended their Ukraine air traffic. Lufthansa, Ryanair, Wizz 
Air, Air Baltic, Qatar and Turkish Airlines were among those to inform their passengers of flight cancellations.
Load-Date: February 24, 2022
End of Document
Passenger plane skids off runway in Poland
Passenger plane skids off runway in Poland
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 2, 2022 Wednesday 1:07 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 92 words
Dateline: Warsaw (dpa) - 
Body
A plane arriving from Germany with 102 passengers on board veered off the runway while landing at Poland's 
Katowice airport.
An airport spokesman told the PAP news agency that no one was injured in the incident, and there was also no 
damage to the Boeing 737-800.
The Ryanair aircraft took off from Cologne-Bonn Airport on Tuesday evening and arrived in Katowice at 11:55 pm 
(2255 GMT), the spokesperson said.
The cause of the accident is still being investigated.
The airport was closed for five hours and other aircraft were diverted to Krakow and Warsaw.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;

MONDAY, JANUARY 31
NEW YORK: UN Security Council set to meet on Ukraine crisis
HEIDELBERG, GERMANY: Memorial ceremony to remember the person killed and others injured by a student 
gunman in the city of Heidelberg on January 24
BERLIN: Germany's conservative Christian Democrats release the results of a postal ballot for a new leader; it is 
the final stage in a process that is expected to see Friedrich Merz officially named as the leader of the opposition

Lufthansa loses ECJ lawsuit in dispute over airport state aid
Lufthansa loses ECJ lawsuit in dispute over airport state aid
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 20, 2022 Thursday 1:46 PM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 266 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Lufthansa has lost a years-long dispute over millions of euros in state aid for a regional airport in the German state 
of Rhineland-Palatinate.
The European Court of Justice (ECJ) on Thursday rejected a complaint by the German airline regarding the state's 
support for Frankfurt-Hahn Airport.
Among other things, the case concerned a credit line - comparable to an overdraft facility on a current account - 
amounting to 45 million euros (51 million dollars).
In addition, the court decided that Lufthansa must pay the costs of the proceedings for the western German state 
and the European Commission.
The airport received aid from 2009 until 2011, which was given the okay in Brussels in 2014.
Lufthansa had already taken its complaint to the Court of Justice of the European Union but was unsuccessful 
there.
The airline has never flown regularly to the airport. It is critical of the subsidies because low-cost competitor Ryanair 
takes off from Frankfurt-Hahn.
The ECJ ruled that the lower court's ruling had been correct and had rightfully noted that Lufthansa was not 
individually impacted by the aid for the regional airport.
Lufthansa has won - and lost - a number of other lawsuits regarding whether state support for Frankfurt-Hahn 
Airport distorted competition.
Meanwhile, the former military airport filed for insolvency in October 2021.
Lufthansa loses ECJ lawsuit in dispute over airport state aid
In 2017, the Chinese conglomerate HNA acquired 82.5 per cent of the airport from the state of Rhineland-Palatinate 
for around 15 million euros. The remaining 17.5 per cent is still held by the neighbouring state of Hesse, where the 
city of Frankfurt is located.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 20, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair gives up base at Frankfurt airport
Ryanair gives up base at Frankfurt airport
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 7, 2022 Friday 11:17 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 95 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's largest low-cost airline Ryanair is giving up its base at Frankfurt Airport, the company announced on 
Friday.
The five aircraft still stationed there will be redistributed to cheaper airports as of March 31, it said.
Ryanair gave as a reason for the decision the rise in take-off and landing fees at Germany's largest airport at the 
turn of the year.
Passengers with tickets already booked are to be notified in the coming days and receive refunds.
Ryanair said it is offering alternative positions for the affected crews within its rapidly growing European network.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 7, 2022
End of Document
Ryanair 's passenger traffic surges in December
Ryanair's passenger traffic surges in December
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 5, 2022 Wednesday 10:12 AM GMT
Copyright 2022 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 106 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, said that traffic for the month of December surged to 9.5 million 
passengers from last year's 1.9 million.
The Dublin-based airline group's load factor was 81 per cent compared to 73 per cent a year ago.
Ryanair operated more than 62,200 flights last month, a typically busy time thanks to year-end holidays.
In the preceding month of November traffic was 10.2 million passengers, with 86 per cent load factor.
More broadly, airlines are still struggling to cope with the reduction in customers due to travel restrictions and 
coronavirus fears, with Omicron now wreaking new havoc on the industry.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 5, 2022
End of Document
Lufthansa cancels flights as pilots call in sick
Lufthansa cancels flights as pilots call in sick
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 23, 2021 Thursday 2:41 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 428 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
German airline Lufthansa has had to cancel several intercontinental flights during the Christmas period because a 
number of its pilots are off sick, a company spokesperson said on Thursday.
Particularly affected are services flying to Boston, Houston and Washington through December 26, with only a few 
volunteers able to jump in and take over routes. The representative said those flights could, at least, be more easily 
rebooked. There were also flights to Japan that had to be cancelled.
The company planned "a very large buffer. But that is not sufficient considering the extremely high sickness rate," 
he added.
The spokesperson would not be drawn on whether the high sickness rate was linked to the coronavirus outbreak, 
which is currently being driven by the new Omicron variant. He said he was not aware of the nature of the illness 
among pilots.
Many of the absences are hitting crews for long-distance flights on Airbus A330s and A340s through early January.
Aero.de, a website focusing on German aviation, posted excerpts from a letter circulated by Lufthansa officials 
warning that the shortages could be severe.
"We don't see ourselves in the position to staff all routes because of increased sickness rates. Crew planners are 
working on scenarios that involve thinning out flight plans."
The airline's problems don't end with staff calling in sick. Several crew members have also had to go into quarantine 
due to the pandemic, further complicating flight planning.
Lufthansa cancels flights as pilots call in sick
The wave of sick calls comes amid talks between Cockpit, a pilots' union, and Lufthansa about corporate 
reorganizations that might cut certain high-paid piloting jobs. There is the possibility of strikes in the summer.
The cancellations have also called into question Lufthansa's promises to come up with emergency plans amid the 
coronavirus crisis. It had promised to keep reserve crew on hand and to introduce more flexibility into planning.
This Christmas travel season is shaping up to be a strong one for carriers operating in Europe. Some are reporting 
double-digit growth in flights offered, including Easyjet, which is operating 41 per cent more flights than two weeks 
ago, and Wizz Air, which has 75 per cent more flights this week than a week ago, according to data from flight 
safety organization Eurocontrol.
Ryanair, SAS and Wizz are also offering more connections than they did for the same time period in 2019, before 
the pandemic had hit Europe. Meanwhile, Lufthansa is down 21 per cent relative to 2019, though it recently 
managed a 1-per-cent improvement compared to two weeks prior.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: December 23, 2021
End of Document
Ryanair revises down its forecast in the wake of Omicron
Ryanair revises down its forecast in the wake of Omicron
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 22, 2021 Wednesday 7:12 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 172 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
The Irish low-cost airline Ryanair has lowered its forecast for the current business year, announcing in Dublin on 
Wednesday that it was now expecting an even higher loss due to the spread of the Omicron variant and the 
associated travel restrictions.
Ryanair is now forecasting a net loss of between 250 million and 450 million euros (283 million and 510 million 
dollars) for the financial year that runs until the end of March 2022. Previously the airline was expecting to make a 
loss of between 100 million and 200 million euros.
In terms of passenger volume, the group says it now expects to transport fewer than 100 million passengers this 
year. The figures depended heavily on the further course of the pandemic, it said.
Ryanair has reduced its flights by 33 per cent for January, while a decision on its schedule has yet to be made for 
February and March.
The company said it hoped to have more clarity on the impact of the Omicron variant on European travel 
restrictions when it presents its third quarter figures on January 31.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Tom Masters, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: December 22, 2021
End of Document
Poland : Belarusian KGB forced landing from air-traffic control tower
Poland: Belarusian KGB forced landing from air-traffic control tower
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 9, 2021 Thursday 7:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 221 words
Dateline: Warsaw (dpa) - 
Body
An officer of the Belarusian KGB was in the air-traffic control tower of Minsk Airport when a Ryanair flight with 
dissident blogger Roman Protasevich on board was diverted earlier this year, the Polish government said on 
Thursday.
"He gave instructions to the staff member who had the contact with the pilot," a statement from Poland's ABW 
secret service and the attorney general said.
Investigators also established that there was no bomb threat for the flight, contrary to the warning given to the pilot 
by air-traffic control. The threat was communicated before an email purporting that explosives were on board had 
even been sent, according to the statement.
The findings are based on interviews with passengers and airline representatives, as well as examinations of the 
aircraft and analysis of recorded conversations.
The Ryanair plane is registered in Poland so Warsaw initiated investigations.
On May 23, Belarusian authorities forced a Ryanair passenger plane on its way from Athens to Vilnius to land in 
Minsk, claiming that a bomb threat had been received.
Protasevich, co-founder of the opposition Telegram channel Nexta, and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega were on the 
flight. Both were arrested after landing.
The European Union, Britain and the United States imposed renewed sanctions against Belarus following the 
incident.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, <international@dpa.com;
Poland : Belarusian KGB forced landing from air-traffic control tower
Load-Date: December 9, 2021
End of Document
Ryanair returns to Nuremberg as base with 13 new destinations
Ryanair returns to Nuremberg as base with 13 new destinations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 8, 2021 Wednesday 7:45 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 233 words
Dateline: Nuremberg, Germany (dpa) - 
Body
Irish low-cost airline Ryanair is returning to Nuremberg airport with a base.
Two aircraft are to be stationed in the southern German city in the summer of 2022 and 13 new destinations will be 
served, mainly in southern, south-eastern and eastern Europe, the airline announced in Nuremberg on Wednesday.
"We never wanted to leave in the first place and now we're back," Ryanair chief executive Eddie Wilson said.
Ryanair had closed its base in Nuremberg in 2019. At the time, the airline had justified its withdrawal, among other 
things, with the flight ban at the time following crashes of the Boeing 737-800 aircraft that were based there.
Since then, there have been fewer Ryanair flights from Nuremberg and no aircraft stationed there.
In total, Ryanair will be able to reach 27 destinations with 85 flights per week from March 2022, including the 
Estonian capital Tallinn, the Bulgarian capital Sofia, Chania on Crete, Venice in Italy and Faro in Portugal.
Nuremberg's Lord Mayor Marcus Koenig spoke of a balanced mix of European city connections, tourist destinations 
around the Mediterranean and opportunities for family visits in Central and Eastern Europe.
According to Ryanair, it plans to invest 200 million dollars in the new base.
More than 60 direct jobs will be created, and around 970 jobs are expected to be created in the region as a result of 
the increased number of flights in the area.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair returns to Nuremberg as base with 13 new destinations
Load-Date: December 8, 2021
End of Document
Lufthansa data shows return to black on stronger summer demand
Lufthansa data shows return to black on stronger summer demand
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 3, 2021 Wednesday 10:30 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 409 words
Byline: Steffen Weyer, dpa-AFX and Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Frankfurt-based air carrier Lufthansa made a small operating profit in the summer on the back of strong demand for 
its air freight services and a recovery in ticket sales, chief executive Carsten Spohr said on Wednesday.
During the year as a whole, Spohr is aiming to at least halve the operating loss - adjusted earnings before interest 
and tax - that the airline incurred during 2020, the year of the pandemic.
Last year, Lufthansa saw an operating loss of almost 5.5 billion euros (6.4 billion dollars).
"With rising demand for business travel and a record result of Lufthansa Cargo we have mastered another 
milestone on our way out of the crisis: We are back to black. We confirm our leading position among the world's 
largest airline groups," Spohr said.
For 2022, Lufthansa is planning to increase its service to around 70 per cent of pre-crisis levels.
During the third - summer - quarter, Lufthansa almost doubled turnover compared to the same quarter last year to 
5.2 billion euros. Despite costs related to reducing staff, the airline booked an operating profit of 17 million euros for 
the quarter, against a loss last year of almost 1.3 billion euros.
Analysts had expected a small loss.
The net loss came in at 72 million euros, contrasted with a net loss of 1.97 billion euros in the third quarter last year.
The company noted a significant increase in new bookings that are now back at 80 per cent of pre-crisis levels. 
Lufthansa Cargo, which came through the pandemic largely unscathed, posted a renewed record with adjusted 
operating profit at 301 million euros.
Lufthansa data shows return to black on stronger summer demand
Lufthansa's budget subsidiary Eurowings posted pre-tax profits of 108 million euros, while Lufthansa Technik, the 
maintenance unit, lifted adjusted pre-tax profits to 155 million euros for the quarter
Catering subsidiary LSG Sky Chefs also posted a profit.
The network airlines - Austrian, Swiss and Brussels - were able to cut their losses by comparison with a year ago.
Lufthansa said that new bookings on its transatlantic routes had returned to around 80 per cent of 2019 levels 
following the announcement of a planned opening of the United States to travellers from Europe from next week.
The airline is continuing to cut staff. At the end of September, it had a total complement of 107,000. German staff 
have been cut this year by 4,000, with a further 3,000 to go.
On Monday, Ryanair, Europe's largest budget carrier, posted operating profits for the third quarter at 245 million 
euros.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 3, 2021
End of Document
German airport Frankfurt-Hahn GmbH files for insolvency
German airport Frankfurt-Hahn GmbH files for insolvency
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 19, 2021 Tuesday 3:46 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 292 words
Byline: Jens Albes in Koblenz and Christian Schultz in Frankfurt
Dateline: Hahn, Germany (dpa) - 
Body
Frankfurt-Hahn GmbH, the company which operates an airport some 100 kilometres west of Frankfurt, has filed for 
insolvency, operations manager Christoph Goetzmann told dpa on Tuesday.
Hahn Airport is 82.5-per-cent owned by the Chinese conglomerate HNA. The company acquired the shares from 
the state of Rhineland-Palatinate - where the airport is located - in 2017 for around 15 million euros (17.5 million 
dollars). The remaining 17.5 per cent is held by the state of Hesse.
Most recently, the arrest of the top management of the financially troubled HNA Group caused a stir.
At the time, the airport company emphasized that this would have no effect on Frankfurt-Hahn. The airport was on a 
good course, it said at the beginning of October.
The airport, which was once a US military airport and subsequently a hub for budget carrier Ryanair, has benefited 
from a boom in airfreight resulting from online purchases and bottlenecks in sea freight.
However, even before the coronavirus pandemic hit, passenger traffic had declined from highs of around 4 million a 
year. Dublin-based Ryanair has cut its flights and shifted traffic to larger airports in the region.
In its report for 2020, the airport management acknowledged it would not be making a profit, but predicted that it 
could go into the black by 2024.
Earlier this year, the European Court of Justice (ECJ) threw out an application from Lufthansa targeting the state 
aid that Frankfurt-Hahn had received. The legal action turned on subsidies paid since 1997 and contracts with 
Ryanair on airport fees.
German airport Frankfurt-Hahn GmbH files for insolvency
Tuesday's insolvency application was filed with the district court in the town of Bad Kreuznach, with the court 
appointing Frankfurt lawyer Jan Markus Plathner as provisional insolvency administrator.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 19, 2021
End of Document
Lukashenko threatened with new EU sanction on re-election anniversary
Lukashenko threatened with new EU sanction on re-election anniversary
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 8, 2021 Sunday 4:26 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 403 words
Byline: Ansgar Haase in Brussels, Hannah Wagner, Christian Thiele and Ulf Mauder in Moscow
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
On the eve of the anniversary of his re-election, widely believed to have been rigged, Belarusian ruler Alexander 
Lukashenko was threatened by the European Union with additional sanctions.
"The EU stands ready to consider further measures in light of the regime's blatant disregard of international 
commitments," EU foreign policy chief Josep Borrell said on Sunday.
With the "forced and unlawful" landing of a Ryanair flight in May and the instrumentalization of migrants for political 
purposes, the regime has "further challenged international norms," Borrell added.
Borrell was alluding, among other things, to the fact that more than 2,000 illegal crossings were registered at the 
border of EU member Lithuania with Belarus in July alone.
From the EU's point of view, this is being done deliberately by the government in Minsk. Lukashenko had openly 
threatened to allow people from countries such as Iraq, Afghanistan or Syria to cross the border in response to the 
EU sanctions.
The EU statement was published on the anniversary of the presidential election in Belarus on August 9 last year. 
Lukashenko was declared the winner with 80.1 per cent of the votes despite massive accusations of electoral fraud.
Mass protests following the elections were put down with violence.
The EU no longer recognizes him as president and has already imposed sanctions in recent months due to the 
repression of civil society and the democratic opposition in Belarus.
Most recently, there were also economic sanctions following the arrest of the anti-government blogger Roman 
Protasevich.
Lukashenko threatened with new EU sanction on re-election anniversary
Authorities in Belarus forced a Ryanair passenger plane on its way from Athens to Vilnius in Lithuania to make a 
stopover in Minsk in order to arrest the Lukashenko critic.
Lukashenko's opponent Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who claims victory in the August 2020 election, again called for 
greater pressure on Minsk.
"At the moment, nobody can feel safe, including me," the 38-year-old, who now lives in exile in Lithuania, told dpa. 
She mentioned the case of Belarusian activist Vitaly Shishov, who was recently found dead in Ukraine, where he 
lived in exile.
The situation of Belarusian Olympic athlete Kristina Timanovskaya also showed that anyone could be a victim of 
Lukashenko's "repressive apparatus".
The track and field athlete fled to Poland after she said she was to be kidnapped from the Tokyo Olympics for 
criticizing Belarusian sports officials. 
Editorial contactsEditing by: Nathalia Araujo, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 8, 2021
End of Document
Lufthansa to report on difficult second quarter
Lufthansa to report on difficult second quarter
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 5, 2021 Thursday 7:15 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 235 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
German airline Lufthansa is due to report on Thursday on its business in the second quarter, which continued to be 
strongly influenced by the coronavirus pandemic.
Lufthansa planes continue to take off far less frequently and with fewer passengers than before the crisis began.
The continuing ban on EU citizens entering the US is particularly painful. New losses are likely unavoidable for 
Lufthansa in the second quarter.
According to an evaluation by the air safety organization Eurocontrol, Lufthansa was able to increase the number of 
its flights recently, but in the last week of July it was still 46 per cent behind the same week of 2019.
Other airlines such as Ireland's Ryanair, down 17 per cent on the year, or the direct competitor Air France, down 25 
per cent, were already much more present in the skies again.
In the first quarter, the state-backed and highly indebted MDax group had flown in another loss of 1.05 billion euros 
(1.24 billion dollars) after the record loss of 6.7 billion euros in the first coronavirus year 2020.
Chief executive Carsten Spohr and the rest of the management are therefore focused primarily on liquidity, which 
was 10.6 billion euros at the end of March, in part thanks to various tranches of state aid.
According to the company, the main priority of raising 5.5 billion euros of new equity, a move shareholders have 
now approved, is to repay state investments in the company.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Lufthansa to report on difficult second quarter

Belarusian Timanovskaya tells IOC she is safe, gets Polish visa
Belarusian Timanovskaya tells IOC she is safe, gets Polish visa
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 2, 2021 Monday 1:20 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 374 words
Byline: Lars Nicolaysen in Tokyo and Hannah Wagner in Moscow
Dateline: Tokyo (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian runner Kristina Timanovskaya is "safe and secure" after an alleged kidnapping attempt, the International 
Olympic Committee (IOC) said Monday.
The country's opposition on Sunday accused Belarusian authorities of trying to kidnap the athlete and force her to 
fly home from the Tokyo Olympics after the 24-year-old criticized Belarusian officials.
Timanovskaya had been due to compete in Monday's 200 metre heats.
IOC spokesman Mark Adams said she had spent Sunday night in a hotel at Tokyo's Haneda airport in a "safe 
environment."
She is now in the hands of authorities and the IOC has asked the Belarusian Olympic Committee for a written report 
on the matter.
IOC representatives spoke to her directly and she assured them she felt safe, Adams said.
On Monday she was photographed entering Poland's embassy in Tokyo, with media reports saying she is seeking 
asylum there and could fly to Warsaw as early as Wednesday.
Poland, as well as the Czech Republic and Slovenia, had offered to help and she has now received a visa from 
Poland.
"Poland will do everything necessary to help her continue her sporting career," deputy foreign minister Marcin 
Przydacz wrote on Twitter.
Belarusian Timanovskaya tells IOC she is safe, gets Polish visa
Olympic officials became aware of her situation after she turned to Japanese police at the airport, Tokyo Olympics 
spokesman Masa Takaya said.
The Belarusian Olympic Committee said in a statement that the runner had been examined by a doctor and would 
not take part in the 200m heats because of her "emotional-psychological condition."
Timanovskaya called that a lie in an Instagram post and told the radio station Euroradio in an interview: "They just 
told me to pack my things and fly home."
Tensions between the international community and Belarus are running high due to the ongoing repression of civil 
society and peaceful protests that were unleashed a year ago after disputed elections, which long-time ruler 
Alexander Lukashenko says he won.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who many in the European Union believe won the election, 
has welcomed the IOC's help with Timanovskaya.
The athletes' plight is the latest international scandal to hit Belarus after the country forced a Ryanair flight to land in 
Minsk in May and arrested an opposition figure.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Meadows, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 2, 2021
End of Document
IOC: Belarusian Olympic runner Timanovskaya is safe
IOC: Belarusian Olympic runner Timanovskaya is safe
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 2, 2021 Monday 9:59 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 386 words
Byline: Lars Nicolaysen in Tokyo and Hannah Wagner in Moscow
Dateline: Tokyo (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian runner Kristina Timanovskaya is "safe and secure" after an alleged kidnapping attempt, the International 
Olympic Committee (IOC) said Monday.
The country's opposition on Sunday accused Belarusian authorities of trying to kidnap the athlete and force her to 
fly home from the Tokyo Olympics.
IOC spokesman Mark Adams said she had spent the night in a hotel at Tokyo's Haneda airport in a "safe 
environment."
She is now in the hands of authorities and the IOC has asked the Belarusian Olympic Committee for a written report 
on the matter.
IOC representatives spoke to her directly during the night and she assured them she felt safe, Adams said.
They planned to speak to her again on Monday to understand what steps she wants to pursue next and give her 
support in that decision.
Olympic officials became aware of her situation after she turned to Japanese police at the airport, Tokyo Olympics 
spokesman Masa Takaya said.
Timanovskaya had been due to compete in Monday's 200-metre heats.
However, the Belarusian Olympic Committee said in a statement that the runner had been examined by a doctor 
and would not take part because of her "emotional-psychological condition."
IOC: Belarusian Olympic runner Timanovskaya is safe
Timanovskaya called that a lie in an Instagram post and told the radio station Euroradio in an interview: "They just 
told me to pack my things and fly home."
Independent Belarusian media reported the 24-year-old was taken to the airport after making critical remarks about 
Belarusian sports officials in Tokyo.
Poland and the Czech Republic have both said they are willing to offer the athlete a humanitarian visa.
"She has the free choice to continue her sporting career in Poland if she so chooses," Poland's Deputy Foreign 
Minister Marcin Przydacz said on Twitter.
Tensions between the international community and Belarus are running high due to the ongoing repression of civil 
society and peaceful protests that were unleashed a year ago after disputed elections, which long-time ruler 
Alexander Lukashenko says he won.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who many in the European Union believe won the election, 
has welcomed the IOC's help with Timanovskaya.
The athletes' plight is the latest international scandal to hit Belarus after the country forced a Ryanair flight to land in 
Minsk in May and arrested an opposition figure.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Meadows, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 2, 2021
End of Document
Belarusian Timanovskaya tells IOC she is safe, Poland asylum expected
Belarusian Timanovskaya tells IOC she is safe, Poland asylum expected
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 2, 2021 Monday 11:53 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 377 words
Byline: Lars Nicolaysen in Tokyo and Hannah Wagner in Moscow
Dateline: Tokyo (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian runner Kristina Timanovskaya is "safe and secure" after an alleged kidnapping attempt, the International 
Olympic Committee (IOC) said Monday.
The country's opposition on Sunday accused Belarusian authorities of trying to kidnap the athlete and force her to 
fly home from the Tokyo Olympics after the 24-year-old criticized Belarusian officials.
Timanovskaya had been due to compete in Monday's 200 metre heats.
IOC spokesman Mark Adams said she had spent the night in a hotel at Tokyo's Haneda airport in a "safe 
environment."
She is now in the hands of authorities and the IOC has asked the Belarusian Olympic Committee for a written report 
on the matter.
IOC representatives spoke to her directly during the night and she assured them she felt safe, Adams said.
On Monday she was photographed entering Poland's consulate in Tokyo, with media reports saying she is seeking 
asylum there and could fly to Warsaw as early as Wednesday.
Poland, as well as the Czech Republic, has said it is willing to offer the athlete a humanitarian visa.
"She has the free choice to continue her sporting career in Poland if she so chooses," Poland's Deputy Foreign 
Minister Marcin Przydacz said on Twitter.
Olympic officials became aware of her situation after she turned to Japanese police at the airport, Tokyo Olympics 
spokesman Masa Takaya said.
Belarusian Timanovskaya tells IOC she is safe, Poland asylum expected
The Belarusian Olympic Committee said in a statement that the runner had been examined by a doctor and would 
not take part in the 200m heats because of her "emotional-psychological condition."
Timanovskaya called that a lie in an Instagram post and told the radio station Euroradio in an interview: "They just 
told me to pack my things and fly home."
Tensions between the international community and Belarus are running high due to the ongoing repression of civil 
society and peaceful protests that were unleashed a year ago after disputed elections, which long-time ruler 
Alexander Lukashenko says he won.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who many in the European Union believe won the election, 
has welcomed the IOC's help with Timanovskaya.
The athletes' plight is the latest international scandal to hit Belarus after the country forced a Ryanair flight to land in 
Minsk in May and arrested an opposition figure.

Sports court denies Belarusian sprinter's application to run in race
Sports court denies Belarusian sprinter's application to run in race
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 2, 2021 Monday 5:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 473 words
Byline: Lars Nicolaysen, Eric Dobias and Christian Hollmann in Tokyo and Hannah Wagner in Moscow
Dateline: Tokyo (dpa) - 
Body
The international Court of Arbitration for Sport (CAS) rejected an urgent appeal by Belarusian runner Kristina 
Timanovskaya to be allowed to compete in the 200-metre heats at the Olympic Games on Monday, after her 
exclusion by her country's authorities.
The runner had called on the court to overturn the decision made by the Belarusian Olympic Committee, which 
prevented Timanovskaya from taking part in the race.
However, Timanovskaya's application was turned down on the grounds that she had not been able to prove her 
case, the court said.
Earlier on Monday, the runner was granted a humanitarian visa by Poland's embassy in Tokyo, following what she 
described as an attempted kidnapping to forcibly repatriate her after she criticized Belarusian sports officials.
She was photographed entering Poland's embassy in Tokyo, with media reports saying she was seeking asylum 
there and could fly to Warsaw as early as Wednesday.
Poland, the Czech Republic and Slovenia had all offered to help.
"Poland will do everything necessary to help her continue her sporting career," deputy foreign minister Marcin 
Przydacz wrote on Twitter.
Olympic officials became aware of Timanovskaya's situation after she turned to Japanese police at the airport, 
Tokyo Olympics spokesman Masa Takaya said.
The 24-year-old athlete is now "safe and secure" after the alleged kidnapping attempt, the International Olympic 
Committee (IOC) said.
Sports court denies Belarusian sprinter's application to run in race
The country's opposition on Sunday accused Belarusian authorities of trying to kidnap the runner and force her to 
fly home from the Tokyo Olympics after she had criticized Belarusian officials.
IOC spokesman Mark Adams said she had spent Sunday night in a hotel at Tokyo's Haneda airport in a "safe 
environment."
The IOC has asked the Belarusian Olympic Committee for a written report on the matter.
IOC representatives spoke to her directly and she assured them she felt safe, Adams said.
The Belarusian Olympic Committee had said in a statement that the runner had been examined by a doctor and 
would not take part in the 200m heats because of her "emotional-psychological condition."
Timanovskaya called that a lie in an Instagram post and told the radio station Euroradio in an interview: "They just 
told me to pack my things and fly home."
Tensions between the international community and Belarus are running high due to the ongoing repression of civil 
society and peaceful protests that were unleashed a year ago after disputed elections, which long-time ruler 
Alexander Lukashenko says he won.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who many in the European Union believe won the election, 
has welcomed the IOC's help with Timanovskaya.
The athlete's plight is the latest international scandal to hit Belarus after the country forced a Ryanair flight to land in 
Minsk in May and arrested an opposition figure on board.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, <international@dpa.com;

After court ruling, EU Commission reapproves German aid for Condor
After court ruling, EU Commission reapproves German aid for Condor
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 27, 2021 Tuesday 12:44 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 274 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission has approved an updated state bailout package of 525 million euros (618 million 
dollars) for German airline Condor following a court ruling last month that found the previous authorization decision 
lacked necessary detail.
The German plan, comprising loans and aid in the form of debt relief, should compensate the firm for coronavirus-
related damages and help finance a restructuring that will help it get back on solid footing, the EU executive said in 
a press release on Tuesday.
"The aviation sector has been hit particularly hard by the various travel restrictions necessary to contain the spread 
of the coronavirus," EU executive branch vice-president Margrethe Vestager, in charge of competition policy, said in 
a written statement.
In June, the EU General Court annulled commission decisions from April 2020 approving coronavirus-related state 
aid to Condor: the airline was granted two loans of 550 million euros.
The EU's competition watchdog had not given enough reasons why it allowed the money to be paid out, the court 
ruled.
Condor managed to avert insolvency last year and left "protective shield" proceedings in December. In May, the 
company found a new investor and a way to hold on the remaining 4,050 jobs.
Budget carrier Ryanair took the commission to court in a slew of cases this year, arguing that its approving a host of 
state aid measures to airlines across Europe distorted competition in the bloc.
The company won certain cases in first instance, for example related to state aid to Dutch KLM and Portuguese 
TAP, but lost others, such as a complaint against aid given to Scandinavian SAS and Finnair.
After court ruling, EU Commission reapproves German aid for Condor
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 27, 2021
End of Document

Jailed Belarusian journalist and girlfriend moved into house arrest
Jailed Belarusian journalist and girlfriend moved into house arrest
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 25, 2021 Friday 10:43 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 319 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
The Belarusian dissident journalist Roman Protasevich and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega, who were arrested during a 
forced landing of a Ryanair flight, have been transferred to house arrest, his mother and the Belarus' opposition 
leader said on Friday.
Natalia Protasevich, who lives in exile in Poland, told dpa that her daughter, who lives in Minsk, drove to an address 
given to her on Thursday evening where she met her brother and handed him food and clothes.
But the mother said neither the family nor the lawyers have received official updates from Belarusian authorities on 
the status of Roman. Instead, the family is relying on private channels for information.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya said Friday that Protasevich and Sapega were now under 
house arrest.
The Russian embassy in Minsk confirmed the house arrest for Sapega, a Russian national. But the authorities in 
the Belarusian capital have yet to comment.
Tikhanovskaya called it "good news"' but added: "House arrest - that is not freedom."
Protasevich and Sapega still faced charges and were "hostages" of the system under Belarusian President 
Alexander Lukashenko, she said.
"We are in contact with Roman's parents - they are not given any information regarding their son, and they have no 
possibility to talk to him themselves. They are convinced that the regime is playing a game, using the lives of 
Roman and Sofia."
Over 500 further prisoners were also currently being held in Belarusian prisons, Tikhanovskaya said.
Jailed Belarusian journalist and girlfriend moved into house arrest
On May 23, Belarusian authorities forced a Ryanair passenger plane on its way from Athens to Vilnius to stop over 
in Minsk and detained government critic Protasevich and Sapega who were on board.
Strongman Lukashenko, who has ruled Belarus for around 27 years and is often dubbed "Europe's last dictator," 
has faced criticism for a dangerous encroachment on airspace after the operation, which included a fighter jet.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Elena Radwan, <international@dpa.com;

EU sanctions Belarusian economy to squeeze Lukashenko
EU sanctions Belarusian economy to squeeze Lukashenko
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 24, 2021 Thursday 1:47 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union imposed its toughest sanctions yet on Belarus on Thursday, taking aim at petroleum and 
tobacco-manufacturing products plus potash - three sectors that the bloc sees as lining the pockets of Alexander 
Lukashenko's government.
Access to EU capital markets is also to be restricted, an EU press release announcing the implementation of the 
measures stated.
EU banks can no longer sell insurance or re-insurance to Belarusian government or public bodies, according to the 
press release, and the European Investment Bank is to stop transferring funds to public sector projects. Trading in 
certain surveillance technology or software to anyone in Belarus is also prohibited.
EU foreign ministers signed off on the move earlier this week. 
It is the bloc's latest response to Belarusian authorities' ongoing crackdown on pro-democratic forces following a 
contested August 2020 election, as well as the forced diversion of a Ryanair flight to detain a government critic and 
his girlfriend last month.
The EU already adopted several packages of sanctions targeting Lukashenko's supporters last year, as well as the 
president himself.
Then, shortly after the flight incident, the bloc sealed off its airspace to carriers from its eastern neighbour.
The 66-year-old Lukashenko has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states 
Poland, Lithuania and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;
EU sanctions Belarusian economy to squeeze Lukashenko
Load-Date: June 24, 2021
End of Document
EU ministers agree on major Belarusian economic sanctions package
EU ministers agree on major Belarusian economic sanctions package
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 21, 2021 Monday 3:39 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 591 words
Byline: Ella Joyner in Luxembourg
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
EU foreign ministers agreed on Monday to slap their toughest punitive measures yet on Belarus, a package of 
economic sanctions targeting sectors that benefit the government of President Alexander Lukashenko.
The agreement, struck at a meeting in Luxembourg and confirmed to dpa by two diplomatic sources, follows weeks 
of tough negotiations over which economic actors to hit.
Luxembourg's Foreign Minister Jean Asselborn said a total of seven cash cow areas will be hit, including tobacco, 
potash - a potassium-rich salt used in fertilizer - petroleum products and financial services.
"I think these are sanctions that will hurt. And I hope they hurt so much that they bring the regime to its knees," 
Asselborn told journalists before the meeting.
German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said the move would "contribute to financially drying out the regime."
It is the bloc's latest response to the forced landing of a Ryanair flight and the arrest of a Belarusian dissident 
blogger last month. The EU already sealed off its airspace to carriers from its eastern neighbour.
The punitive measures - which aim to tighten the vice on the authoritarian government of Lukashenko and 
strengthen his opponents - must still be formally adopted, but their basic remit is now fixed.
However, it is unclear exactly they will be implemented, according to Asselborn. "We need a bit of time to translate 
this into reality."
The bloc is also set to blacklist dozens more individuals or organizations that support Lukashenko on Monday, 
adding to the close to 90 targets already subject EU travel bans or asset freezes.
EU ministers agree on major Belarusian economic sanctions package
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who has been calling for tough EU measures, also spoke 
with the ministers in Luxembourg.
"Sanctions aren't a silver bullet, but they can help to end violence and release people," she tweeted.
Tikhanovskaya currently lives in exile in Lithuania. She is considered by many to be the winner of the disputed 
presidential election of August 9, 2020, after which Lukashenko had himself proclaimed president again.
The EU no longer recognizes him as head of state and claims the poll was neither nor fair.
The bloc has been calling for the release of Roman Protasevich and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega, both of whom were 
detained after being hauled off the Vilnius-bound Ryanair flight, along with hundreds of political prisoners.
Most of the targets to be added to the EU blacklist immediately on Monday are accused of helping to repress 
demonstrators, opposition figures or journalists, but others were chosen for a link to the flight diversion.
Due to the ongoing repression of the democracy movement in Belarus, the EU already adopted several packages 
of sanctions targeting Lukashenko's supporters last year, as well as the president himself.
UN Human Rights Commissioner Michelle Bachelet voiced concern on Monday about a continued deterioration in 
the country highlighting "severe restrictions" to freedom of expression and assembly, worrisome raids on civil 
society and media and judicial persecution of activists and journalists.
"We continue to receive numerous allegations of arbitrary arrests and detentions, torture and ill-treatment," she said 
in a statement.
The 66-year-old Lukashenko has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states 
Poland, Lithuania and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
Minsk has grown closer to Moscow in recent years. But Lukashenko has also maintained relations with EU partners 
in his almost 27 years in power.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 21, 2021
End of Document
EU settles on economic sanctions to squeeze Belarusian leader
EU settles on economic sanctions to squeeze Belarusian leader
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 21, 2021 Monday 7:18 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 640 words
Byline: Ella Joyner in Luxembourg and Leonie Kijewski in Brussels
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
EU foreign ministers have resolved to impose their toughest punitive measures yet on Belarus, a package of 
economic sanctions targeting sectors that benefit the government of President Alexander Lukashenko.
The bloc's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, announced the decision following a Monday meeting in Luxembourg, and 
said he believed they would "put pressure" on Lukashenko. "Certainly, we believe we can influence behaviour."
Luxembourg's foreign minister, Jean Asselborn, said a total of seven cash cow areas will be hit, including tobacco, 
potash - a potassium-rich salt used in fertilizer - petroleum products and financial services.
It is the bloc's latest response to Belarusian authorities ongoing crackdown on pro-democratic forces. Tensions 
have spiked further since the forced diversion of a Ryanair flight to detain a government critic and his girlfriend last 
month. The EU already sealed off its airspace to carriers from its eastern neighbour.
"We want the end of violence against protesters and opposition figures and an inclusive dialogue that ultimately 
leads to free and fair elections," German Foreign Minister Heiko Maas told reporters.
The new measures - which aim to tighten the vice on the authoritarian government of Lukashenko and strengthen 
his opponents - must still be formally adopted, but their basic remit is now fixed.
It is unclear exactly when they will be implemented.
The bloc also imposed fresh sanctions on high-ranking officials and key companies on Monday, coordinating a 
package of measures along with the United States, Canada and Britain.
In total, the EU added 78 individual names to its Belarus blacklist, plus eight institutions or organizations, taking the 
total to 166 persons and 15 entities.
EU settles on economic sanctions to squeeze Belarusian leader
Among the companies affected - according to the entry published in the official EU legal journal - is state-owned 
company BelAZ - one of the biggest manufacturers of large trucks and dumper trucks in the world.
The list also includes the company responsible for controlling air traffic over Belarus.Lukashenko's son Dmitry, 
Defense Minister Viktor Khrenin, other members of the government, and a number of judges are targeted too.In a 
separate statement, London said it had sanctioned, together with the other parties, senior-ranking Belarusian 
officials plus the British-based company BNK, which exports Belarusian oil products.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who has been calling for tough EU measures, also met with 
the foreign ministers.
"It's impossible that nothing will change after these sanctions," she told journalists in Brussels.
Tikhanovskaya currently lives in exile in Lithuania. She is considered by many to be the winner of the disputed 
presidential election of August 9, 2020, after which Lukashenko had himself proclaimed president again.
The EU no longer recognizes him as head of state and claims the poll was neither nor fair.
The underlying aim of EU punitive measures is to try and force fresh elections in Belarus.
"They have to understand that there is no other way out," Tikhanovskaya said at a Brussels press conference.
Most of the targets added to the EU blacklist on Monday are accused of helping to repress demonstrators, 
opposition figures or journalists, but others were chosen for a link to the diverted Ryanair flight.
Due to the ongoing repression of the democracy movement in Belarus, the EU already adopted several packages 
of sanctions targeting Lukashenko's supporters last year, as well as the president himself.
The 66-year-old Lukashenko has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states 
Poland, Lithuania and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
Minsk has grown closer to Moscow in recent years. But Lukashenko has also maintained relations with EU partners 
in his almost 27 years in power.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 21, 2021
End of Document
EU foreign ministers set to slap fresh sanctions on Belarus
EU foreign ministers set to slap fresh sanctions on Belarus
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 21, 2021 Monday 4:25 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 304 words
Byline: Ella Joyner in Luxembourg
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
EU foreign ministers meeting Monday in Luxembourg are set to blacklist dozens more supporters of Belarusian 
President Alexander Lukashenko in a bid to tighten the vice on his government and strengthen its opponents.
Seventy-eight individuals are to be hit with measures like EU travel bans or having assets located in the bloc frozen, 
EU sources told dpa last week. At least seven entities such as state institutions or companies are also to be 
targeted, according to the same sources.
The 27 ministers are also to discuss a larger, harder-hitting set of economic sanctions taking aim at cash cow 
sectors. An EU diplomat speaking on condition of anonymity said they expect the ministers to come to a "clear 
political agreement" on what these should cover.
Options floated so far have included potash - a potassium-rich salt used to make fertilizer - oil products and 
financial services.
But these won't be ready to implement on Monday, a senior EU official said.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who has called for tough EU measures, is also to speak with 
the ministers in Luxembourg.
Due to the ongoing repression of the democracy movement in Belarus, the EU has already sanctioned close to 90 
people, including the president himself.
There have been mass protests against Lukashenko ever since an August 2020 presidential election that the EU 
believes was neither free nor fair.
EU foreign ministers set to slap fresh sanctions on Belarus
Last month, Belarusian authorities diverted a Ryanair flight and arrested the government critic Roman Protasevich 
and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega.
As a result, Belarusian airlines are banned from EU airspace as of early June.
Most of the targets in the sanctions package to be adopted on Monday are accused of helping to repress 
demonstrators, opposition figures or journalists, but others were chosen for a link to the flight diversion.

The EU states have agreed on another extensive package of sanctions to be slapped on supporters of Belarusian 
President Alexander Lukashenko.Seventy-eight individuals are to be hit with measures like EU travel bans or 
having assets located in the bloc frozen following an agreement by representatives of member states on 
Wednesday, EU sources told dpa.At least seven entities such as state institutions or companies, are also to be 
targeted, according to the same sources.
Due to the ongoing repression of the democracy movement in Belarus, the EU had already adopted several 
packages of sanctions targeting Lukashenko's supporters last year, as well as the president himself.
There have been mass protests against Lukashenko ever since an August 2020 presidential election that the EU 
believes was neither free nor fair.
Last month, Belarusian authorities forced a Ryanair passenger plane on its way from Athens to Vilnius to make a 
stopover in Minsk and arrested the government critic Roman Protasevich and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega on board.
The EU then imposed fresh sanctions on the former Soviet republic, and since early June, Belarusian airlines are 
no longer allowed to fly into EU airspace.
Most of the targets in the sanctions package agreed on Wednesday are accused of helping to repress 
demonstrators, opposition figures or journalists, but others were chosen for a link to the Ryanair flight diversion.

Jailed Belarusian journalist tells sceptical media he feels 'great'
Jailed Belarusian journalist tells sceptical media he feels 'great'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 14, 2021 Monday 5:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 285 words
Dateline: Kiev (dpa) - 
Body
Three weeks after his arrest, the Belarusian dissident journalist Roman Protasevich made another public 
appearance on Monday, although many fear he is being forced to speak under duress.
"I feel great," Protasevich said at a surprise press conference in Minsk. "Nobody has beat me or even touched me," 
the 26-year-old said, laughing and seeming relaxed at the Foreign Ministry-organized event.
Protasevich also addressed his parents, who have been appealing to world leaders for his release and expressing 
fears over his treatment: "Mum, dad, don't worry, everything is fine with me."
Protasevich said while he did not support long-time ruler Alexander Lukashenko, "I respect him as a person."
A journalist who was at the press conference echoed the sentiment of many observers, including Protasevich's 
parents, that she didn't believe one word he was saying.
In the days after his arrest, Protasevich gave an interview to state TV in which he seemed distressed and made 
what appeared to be a coerced confession to instigating mass anti-government protests.
In an incident that sparked international outrage almost three weeks ago, Belarusian authorities forced a Ryanair 
passenger plane on its way from Athens to Vilnius to stop over in Minsk.
Government critic Protasevich and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega, who were on board the plane, were taken into 
custody at the airport.
On Monday, a court in Minsk dismissed a complaint by Sapega against her detention, the Russian news agency 
TASS reported.
Her lawyers have announced an appeal of the decision, arguing that Belarus was bound by international law to let 
air travellers reach their destination.
Jailed Belarusian journalist tells sceptical media he feels 'great'
Criminal proceedings are under way against both Protesevich and Sapega.

Mother of Belarus blogger asks Germany 's Merkel to help release him
Mother of Belarus blogger asks Germany's Merkel to help release him
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 12, 2021 Saturday 9:14 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 256 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
The mother of Roman Protasevich, a government critic imprisoned in Belarus, has asked German Chancellor 
Angela Merkel to help secure the release of her son and other prisoners in the country.
"We ask you very much to help us so that all innocent people are released from prison," Natalia Protasevich told the 
Bild newspaper on Saturday.
"They need urgent help because they are exposed to sadism and violence every day," she said.
She called for Belarusian strongman Alexander Lukashenko, who has faced protests since a disputed election last 
year, to be stopped.
"Every more day, no, every more hour that passes costs innocent people, including children, their lives," she said.
Almost three weeks ago, Belarusian authorities forced a Ryanair passenger plane on its way from Athens to Vilnius 
to stop over in Minsk and detained government critic Roman Protasevich and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega who were 
on board.
The EU then reimposed sanctions against the former Soviet republic.
The blogger's father, Dmitri Protasevich, told Bild that their letters would not be delivered to their son. "Even his 
lawyer cannot talk to us freely on the phone," he said.
"Instead, two videos have already been released by the state in which forced confessions are made." In these, he 
said, one can see clear signs of torture.
One of these signs was bruises on his neck. "An expert told us that these were strangulation marks," he said.
Protasevich's parents live in exile in Poland.
Mother of Belarus blogger asks Germany 's Merkel to help release him
On Thursday, the European Parliament called for further sanctions against Belarus.
