EU Parliament calls for further sanctions on Belarus
EU Parliament calls for further sanctions on Belarus
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 11, 2021 Friday 2:09 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 291 words
Dateline: Strasbourg (dpa) - 
Body
Following the forced landing of a plane travelling between two EU capitals and the arrest of blogger Roman 
Protasevich in Belarus, the European Parliament has called for further sanctions on the hardline regime in Minsk.
Punitive measures should be taken against the crude oil-processing industry, the production of petroleum products, 
and the potash, steel and wood-processing industries, it said in a resolution adopted on Thursday.
In addition, cooperation with state-owned Belarusian banks should be stopped. Consideration should also be given 
to temporarily excluding Belarus from the Swift payment system.
Josep Borrell, the EU's foreign affairs commissioner, said during Tuesday's plenary debate that he hoped EU 
member states would adopt further punitive measures on Belarus at the next summit. For the first time, targeted 
economic sanctions had been agreed upon.
Almost three weeks ago, Belarusian authorities forced a Ryanair passenger plane on its way from Athens to Vilnius 
to make a stopover in Minsk and arrested the government critic Protasevich and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega on 
board.
The EU then reimposed sanctions on the former Soviet republic. Since last Saturday, Belarusian airlines are no 
longer allowed to fly into EU airspace.
Due to the ongoing repression of the democracy movement in Belarus, the EU had already adopted several 
packages of sanctions targeting President Alexander Lukashenko's supporters last year.
Russia's possible role in the case should be investigated and, if necessary, sanctions imposed on those 
responsible, they said.
EU Parliament calls for further sanctions on Belarus
MEPs also backed a call by Belarusian opposition activist Svetlana Tikhanovskaya for the establishment of an 
international criminal court to hold the leadership in Minsk accountable.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;

Ryanair secures partial win against Condor in state aid case
Ryanair secures partial win against Condor in state aid case
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 9, 2021 Wednesday 12:47 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair on Wednesday won an EU court case against German state aid given to its competitor 
Condor.
The General Court of the EU court annulled the European Commission's decisions approving coronavirus-related 
state aid to Condor: the airline was granted two loans of 550 million euros (760 million dollars) last year.
The EU's competition watchdog had not given enough reasons why it allowed the money to be paid out, the court 
ruled on Wednesday.
However, the effects of the annulment - including the order to pay back the aid - are suspended until the 
commission submits a new decision.
Effectively, this means that the EU General Court's judges are giving the commission a chance to issue a more 
detailed decision. It therefore annulled the commission's decision.
Ryanair has taken the commission to court in a slew of cases, arguing that its approving a host of state aid 
measures to airlines across Europe distorted competition in the bloc.
While it won certain cases in first instance, for example related to state aid to Dutch KLM and Portuguese TAP, it 
lost others, such as a complaint against aid given to Scandinavian SAS and Finnair.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 9, 2021
Ryanair secures partial win against Condor in state aid case
End of Document
Lithuania 's president warns of threat posed by neighbouring Belarus
Lithuania's president warns of threat posed by neighbouring Belarus
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 8, 2021 Tuesday 6:01 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 266 words
Dateline: Vilnius (dpa) - 
Body
Lithuania's defences need to be bolstered in light of the rising threat posed by neighbouring Belarus, President 
Gitanas Nauseda said on Tuesday, less than a week before a NATO summit.
"Beyond Lithuania's eastern borders there is an unstable space where inherent human rights and the rules of the 
free world are disrespected, where dictators ... step into the role of terrorists and hijack passenger planes. Where 
border and nuclear security becomes a tool of blackmail," said the EU and NATO country's leader.
Belarus' long-time leader, Alexander Lukashenko, re-inflammed tensions with the EU last month after a Ryanair 
passenger flight from Athens to Vilnius was forced to land in Minsk and an opposition journalist and his partner 
were taken into custody. Leaders in the West had described it as a "state hijacking."
It's been nearly a year since Belarus hit the headlines following presidential elections in August that spurred 
protests against Lukashenko, who claimed victory. Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, whom the opposition claims as the 
true winner, is in exile in Lithuania.
Lukashenko's latest threat is to allow migrants to move through his country on their way to the EU. Lithuania has a 
nearly 680-kilometre border with Belarus, which is part of the EU's external border.
The government in Vilnius reported a sharp increase in illegal border crossings by migrants the previous week. 
Interior Minister Agne Bilotaite suspected a targeted action by the leadership in Minsk.
A controversial Belarusian nuclear power plant only about 50 kilometres from the Lithuanian capital also weighs on 
relations.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;
Lithuania 's president warns of threat posed by neighbouring Belarus
Load-Date: June 8, 2021

Body
The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, in a break with usual diplomatic practice, called Belarusian leader Alexander 
Lukashenko "a dictator" in the European Parliament on Tuesday.
"I agree with all of you, we are facing a dictator," Borrell told parliamentarians during a plenary debate in 
Strasbourg. He also stressed the need to continue exerting pressure on Lukashenko.
The European Union has adopted several sanctions packages against Lukashenko and his supporters, most 
recently over the forced landing in Minsk of a Ryanair passenger flight between Athens and Vilnius and subsequent 
arrest of a dissident journalist and his partner.
Belarusian airlines have in response not been allowed to fly into European Union airspace since the weekend.
The Minsk government's attempts to suppress ongoing protests in the former Soviet republic had earlier led the 
bloc to sanctions.
Less than a week before a NATO summit, Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda said on Tuesday his country's 
defences need to be bolstered in light of the rising threat posed by neighbouring Belarus.
"Beyond Lithuania's eastern borders there is an unstable space where inherent human rights and the rules of the 
free world are disrespected, where dictators ... step into the role of terrorists and hijack passenger planes. Where 
border and nuclear security becomes a tool of blackmail," said the EU and NATO country's leader.
It's been nearly a year since Belarus hit the headlines following presidential elections in August that spurred 
protests against Lukashenko, who claimed victory. Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, whom the opposition claims as the 
true winner, is in exile in Lithuania.
EU's top diplomat Borrell calls Belarus ' Lukashenko 'dictator'

Belarusian opposition leader welcomed as 'president' in Prague visit
Belarusian opposition leader welcomed as 'president' in Prague visit
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 7, 2021 Monday 3:08 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 294 words
Dateline: Prague (dpa) - 
Body
Exiled Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya was introduced by the head of the Czech Senate as 
the "elected president of Belarus" during a visit to Prague on Monday.
In his remarks, Czech Senate President Milos Vystrcil denounced Belarusian strongman Alexander Lukashenko for 
refusing to give up power following August's presidential election, which was slammed by the European Union, the 
United States and others as marred by fraud, repression and state violence.
The elections in the authoritarian country were "unfree, unfair, unjust and illegitimate," Vystrcil said.
The opposition believes Tikhanovskaya, 38, was the true winner in August, which prompted them to organize 
months of mass protests that were met by a fierce police crackdown and widespread arrests. Tikhanovskaya fled to 
neighbouring Lithuania.
Tikhanovskaya thanked the Czech Republic for its support in, among other things, providing medical treatment to 
supporters of the Belarusian opposition.
Tikhanovskaya once again condemned the arrest of activist journalist Roman Protasevich, whose Ryanair plane 
was forced to land in Minsk two weeks ago so that he could be taken into custody along with girlfriend, Sofia 
Sapega.
The incident threw the plight of the Belarus' opposition back into the spotlight.
No one can still be in doubt that the Belarusian leadership are "terrorists" and must be ousted, Tikhanovskaya said. 
A new wave of protests was being prepared, she added.
Her agenda also includes meetings with Prime Minister Andrej Babis, Foreign Minister Jakub Kulhanek and 
President Milos Zeman.
Belarusian opposition leader welcomed as 'president' in Prague visit
Tikhanovskaya has been trying to get EU states to put greater pressure on Lukashenko to enter into a dialogue with 
the opposition so that a democratic political transition can take place.

EU's Michel accuses Putin of 'illegal' activities in phone call
EU's Michel accuses Putin of 'illegal' activities in phone call
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 7, 2021 Monday 6:51 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 246 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
European Council President Charles Michel accused Moscow of "illegal, provocative and disruptive activities 
against the European Union, its member states and others" in a phone call with Russian President Vladimir Putin 
on Monday.
"EU-Russia relations are at a low," an EU press release outlining Michel's message to Putin stated. "This situation 
or its further deterioration is in neither side's interest."
Relations between Moscow and Brussels have long been strained. The EU imposed sanctions on Moscow following 
both the imprisonment of Russian dissident Alexei Navalny and the annexation of the Crimean peninsula in 
Ukraine. Moscow responded with countermeasures.
According to the statement, Michel - one of the bloc's most senior officials - raised the issue of Ukraine and also of 
Belarus, an increasingly close ally of Moscow and also the subject of recent EU sanctions.
Michel "reiterated the EU's assessment of the forced landing of the Ryanair flight by the Belarusian authorities," the 
press release continued, referring to an incident last month that triggered the introduction of an EU flight ban for 
Belarusian airlines.
Belarus must release political prisoners and stop domestic repression, Michel said, repeating previous EU 
statements.
"Russia can play an important role in supporting a peaceful settlement of the crisis," he urged.
EU leaders are in the process of reviewing their joint policy towards Russia, with the next debate set for a summit 
later this month.
EU's Michel accuses Putin of 'illegal' activities in phone call

NATO warns Moscow, Minsk against threatening its allies
NATO warns Moscow, Minsk against threatening its allies
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 6, 2021 Sunday 7:59 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 268 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
NATO's head has warned Russia and Belarus against threatening the alliance's allies, following the forced landing 
of a passenger plane within the EU by Belarusian authorities, in comments published on Sunday.
"We are of course ready, in an emergency, to protect and defend any ally against any kind of threat coming from 
Minsk and Moscow," NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg told the Welt am Sonntag newspaper.
"We are vigilant and we are following what is happening in Belarus very closely," he said.
Belarus is becoming "more and more dependent" on Russia, he added.
Stoltenberg said NATO was seriously concerned about the closer cooperation between Moscow and Minsk in 
recent months. "We have had to learn in the past that Russia has massively violated the territorial integrity of states 
such as Ukraine, Georgia and Moldova," he said.
He did not want to speculate too much, Stoltenberg said, noting, "NATO is a defensive alliance."
Lithuania, Latvia and Poland, all members of NATO, share borders with Belarus.
Two weeks ago, Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko forced a Ryanair commercial flight between two 
EU capitals, Athens and Vilnius, to make an emergency landing in Minsk.
Dissident journalist Roman Protasevich and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega, passengers on the plane, were arrested 
and are being held in custody.
While the EU responded with sanctions on Belarus, Russian President Vladimir Putin hosted Lukashenko for talks 
and said Moscow would support Belarus with 500 million dollars in credit.
Putin also underlined his continuing support for Lukashenko in his confrontation with the West.
NATO warns Moscow, Minsk against threatening its allies

Belarusian political scientist flees after being named in interview
Belarusian political scientist flees after being named in interview
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 5, 2021 Saturday 6:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 254 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian political scientist Artyom Shraibman, who was named by the dissident journalist detained after the forced 
landing of a passenger flight in Minsk, announced on Saturday that he has fled the country out of fear of also being 
imprisoned.
The journalist, 26-year-old Roman Protasevich, had said in an interview aired on Belarusian state media on 
Thursday, which was likely conducted under duress, that he had worked for the opposition abroad and gave names 
of several people he said were also involved.
However, Shraibman - one of those named - said that he had not worked for the Belarusian opposition and was 
only an observer and analyst.
He added that he saw Protasevich as a "hostage" taken by President Alexander Lukashenko and thus could not 
condemn him for the accusations. State media celebrated the news of Shraibman's "escape."
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who is also in exile, described Protasevich's interview as the 
result of torture and met with the journalist's parents in Poland on Saturday.
She has repeatedly called for the release of all political prisoners.
As of midnight on Saturday, the European Union is to seal off its skies and runways to Belarusian airlines in 
response to the forced diversion of a Ryanair flight and the detention of Protasevich.
Even before the sanctions decision, all airlines based in the bloc had been asked to avoid flights into Belarusian 
airspace.
Air travellers will probably only be able to reach Belarus now through detours, for example via Russia.
Belarusian political scientist flees after being named in interview

Belarusian television shows interview with imprisoned blogger
Belarusian television shows interview with imprisoned blogger
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 4, 2021 Friday 10:31 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 230 words
Dateline: Minsk (dpa) - 
Body
In Belarus, state television has shown a long interview with imprisoned government critic Roman Protasevich for the 
first time.
In the interview with the broadcaster ONT, which was aired on Thursday evening, the 26-year-old blogger admitted 
to having organized protests against strongman ruler Alexander Lukashenko. At the same time, he said that he 
admired Lukashenko.
His mother Natalia Protasevich, who lives in Poland, described the interview on Friday as the result of torture in 
prison.
"I can't even imagine the torture methods - both psychological and physical - that my son is being subjected to at 
the moment," the 46-year-old told dpa. "You probably can't suffer a greater torture as a mother."
In the one-and-a-half-hour conversation, Protasevich also made accusations against other members of the 
Belarusian opposition, sometimes in a trembling voice.
Protasevich's parents had already expressed the suspicion that their son was being mistreated in prison and forced 
to make statements.
Lukashenko had forced a passenger plane to reroute and land in Minsk almost a fortnight ago and had Protasevich 
and his girlfriend arrested.
The incident - involving a Ryanair commercial flight between the two EU capitals of Athens and Vilnius - has 
intensified the conflict between the former Soviet republic and the West. The EU and the US imposed new 
sanctions on Belarus as a result.
Belarusian television shows interview with imprisoned blogger

Appalled response as Belarus shows interview with imprisoned blogger
Appalled response as Belarus shows interview with imprisoned blogger
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 4, 2021 Friday 3:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 510 words
Byline:  Hannah Wagner in Moscow and Krzysztof Bastian and Doris Heimann in Warsaw, Carsten Hoffmann und 
Joerg Ratzsch in Berlin, Benedikt von Imhoff in London
Dateline: Minsk (dpa) - 
Body
A long interview on Belarusian TV with imprisoned government critic Roman Protasevich has provoked an angry 
reaction from several European countries.
In the interview with the broadcaster ONT, which was aired on Thursday evening, the 26-year-old blogger admitted 
to having organized protests against strongman ruler Alexander Lukashenko. At the same time, he said that he 
admired Lukashenko.
German government spokesman Steffen Seibert described it as "a completely undignified and implausible 
confession interview" that was probably obtained under psychological and physical duress.
"Mr Protasevich's disturbing interview last night was clearly under duress and in detention," British Foreign 
Secretary Dominic Raab wrote on Twitter.
"Those involved in the filming, coercion and direction of the interview must be held accountable," he said.
Protasevich and his girlfriend were arrested in Minsk a fortnight ago after Lukashenko forced a passenger plane to 
reroute and land in the Belarusian capital.
The incident - involving a Ryanair commercial flight between the two EU capitals of Athens and Vilnius - has 
intensified the conflict between the former Soviet republic and the West.
The EU and the US imposed fresh sanctions on Belarus as a result; some sanctions had already been in place 
since elections last year that have been discredited by many countries.
Moscow has however stood by Minsk in the dispute.
Appalled response as Belarus shows interview with imprisoned blogger
Protasevich's mother Natalia Protasevich, who lives in Poland, described the interview on Friday as the result of 
torture in prison.
"I can't even imagine the torture methods - both psychological and physical - that my son is being subjected to at 
the moment," the 46-year-old told dpa. "You probably can't suffer a greater torture as a mother."
She pointed to her son's wrists which she said showed dark spots and inflammation.
The blogger's mother called for independent doctors to be allowed to examine her son. "They should also do blood 
analysis of what he is being injected with." Protasevich's lawyer had been denied access to him this week, she said.
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, referring to the interview, said Protasevich was surely 
tortured and the international community should not pay heed to such extorted statements.
"All such videos are done under pressure," Tikhanovskaya said at a press conference in Warsaw on Friday. 
"[Through using violence] you can make a person say whatever you want."
When a person is in a political prison, the aim is to survive: "We don't have to pay attention" to such statements, the 
Belarusian opposition leader said.
In the one-and-a-half-hour conversation, Protasevich also made accusations against other members of the 
Belarusian opposition, sometimes in a trembling voice.
The European Union is to seal off its skies and runways to Belarusian airlines as of Saturday in response to the 
forced diversion of Protasevich's flight.
EU ambassadors kicked off the necessary written legal procedure to implement the move on Friday, diplomatic 
sources told dpa, with completion considered a formality.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 4, 2021
End of Document
EU bans Belarus airlines from its airspace after journalist's arrest
EU bans Belarus airlines from its airspace after journalist's arrest
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 4, 2021 Friday 4:35 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 245 words
Byline: Ella Joyner and Ansgar Haase in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union will seal off its skies and runways to Belarusian airlines as of Saturday in response to the 
forced diversion of a Ryanair flight and detention of a dissident journalist and his girlfriend last month.
The 27 countries are obliged "to deny permission to land in, take off from or overfly their territories to any aircraft 
operated by Belarusian air carriers," the bloc announced on Friday after member states envoys in Brussels formally 
signed off the move.
Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich and Sofia Sapega were on board a commercial flight between EU 
countries Greece and Lithuania that was rerouted to Minsk shortly before it reached Vilnius due to an alleged bomb 
threat. No bomb was found, but both were detained.
The bloc slammed the act as an affront to both air safety and freedom of the press.
The EU has also called on all EU-based carriers to avoid flying over Belarusian territory.
The International Air Transport Association (IATA) condemned Minsk's behaviour but also criticized the EU.
"Two wrongs do not make a right. Politics should never interfere with the safe operation of aircraft and politicians 
should never use aviation safety as a cover to pursue political or diplomatic agendas," Willie Walsh, IATA's director 
general, said in a statement.
The bloc is also preparing a package of economic sanctions on individuals involved in the incident, but this could 
still take some time to finalize, according to dpa's diplomatic sources.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
EU bans Belarus airlines from its airspace after journalist's arrest
Load-Date: June 4, 2021
End of Document
EU flight ban for Belarusian carriers to take effect on Saturday
EU flight ban for Belarusian carriers to take effect on Saturday
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 4, 2021 Friday 2:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 243 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union is to seal off its skies and runways to Belarusian airlines as of Saturday in response to the 
forced diversion of a Ryanair flight and detention of a dissident journalist and his girlfriend last month.
EU ambassadors kicked off the necessary written legal procedure to implement the move on Friday, diplomatic 
sources told dpa, with completion considered a formality.
Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich and Sofia Sapega were on board a commercial flight between EU 
countries Greece and Lithuania that was rerouted to Minsk shortly before it reached Vilnius due to an alleged bomb 
threat. No bomb was found, but both were detained.
The bloc slammed the move as an affront to both air safety and freedom of the press.On May 24, EU leaders 
agreed to block access to their country's airspace and airports, and also called on all EU-based carriers to avoid 
flying over Belarusian territory.The International Air Transport Association (IATA) condemned Minsk's behaviour but 
also criticized the EU move in a statement.
"Two wrongs do not make a right. Politics should never interfere with the safe operation of aircraft and politicians 
should never use aviation safety as a cover to pursue political or diplomatic agendas," Willie Walsh, IATA's director 
general, said.
The bloc is also preparing a package of economic sanctions on individuals involved in the incident, but this could 
still take some to finalize, according to dpa's diplomatic sources.

Russian court jails activist Pivovarov for two months pending trial
Russian court jails activist Pivovarov for two months pending trial
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 2, 2021 Wednesday 5:08 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 460 words
Byline:  Krzysztof Bastian in Warsaw; Hannah Wagner in Moscow
Dateline: Moscow/Warsaw (dpa) - 
Body
A court in southern Russia ruled on Wednesday that prominent dissident Andrei Pivovarov should be kept in 
custody for two months pending trial.
The court in Krasnodar said the 39-year-old, who until recently led the group Open Russia, was being investigated 
for involvement in an "undesirable organization."
The designation was given to Open Russia, which had been openly critical of the Kremlin, just days ago.
Pivovarov was detained Monday evening while attempting to leave for Poland.
He was taken off a flight operated by Poland's LOT airline before departure in St Petersburg. Police officers had 
stopped the plane, which was already taxiing down the runway, Pivovarov wrote on his Telegram channel.
He was then transferred to the southern city of Krasnodar because, his lawyer explained, Pivovarov had published 
several Facebook posts from Krasnodar about a year ago and they were now being investigated.
The European Union and Amnesty International called for Pivovarov's immediate release.
Polish officials, meanwhile, criticized Russia for the action taken on board one of its planes.
"This is clearly an unacceptable situation," Polish government spokesperson Piotr Mueller told public radio 
broadcaster Polskie Radio on Wednesday.
Pawel Mucha, advisor to Polish President Andrzej Duda, said that Poland's civil aviation authority will analyse the 
data from the flight in question, provided by LOT airline, and that "appropriate and adequate" reactions will be taken 
on the basis of international and aviation law.
Russian court jails activist Pivovarov for two months pending trial
If found guilty, Pivovarov may face up to six years in prison.
Pivovarov had announced he would disband Open Russia, which has also been supported by Mikhail 
Khodorkovsky, a powerful critic of President Vladimir Putin, after it was deemed an "undesirable organization."
The fact that he was still detained anyway was a sign of "complete lawlessness," wrote Pivovarov.
Pivarov's lawyer linked the imprisonment to her client's intention to run in the parliamentary elections in September. 
That had scared Putin's United Russia party, Tatyana Usmanova said.
"You don't love Putin? Then they'll poison you, lock you up and torture you in prison," wrote the team of well-known 
imprisoned Kremlin critic Alexei Navalny, who narrowly survived a poison attack last year.
Navalny, who is being held in a prison camp, expressed solidarity with Pivovarov and other detained opposition 
figures. "These are honest people who are being persecuted precisely for this," Navalny wrote on Instagram.
Khodorkovsky's team said Pivovarov had been taken off the plane "Belarusian style," referring to last month's 
forced landing of a Ryanair plane in Minsk so that authoritarian ruler Alexander Lukashenko could jail one his 
opponents, the activist journalist Roman Protasevich.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 3, 2021
End of Document
Flight approval dispute briefly halts German - Russian air traffic
Flight approval dispute briefly halts German-Russian air traffic
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 2, 2021 Wednesday 9:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 360 words
Byline: Sascha Meyer in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Air traffic between Germany and Russia was briefly disrupted on Wednesday due to a dispute over flight approvals 
that left passengers stranded.
The two sides started locking horns on Wednesday morning, when two Lufthansa flights departing from Frankfurt 
had to be scrapped because Russian authorities had failed to issue the necessary permits.
In response, the German Federal Aviation Office said it would not issue any further permits for incoming flights by 
Russian airlines until the Russian authorities had approved flights from Germany.
Consequently, flights by Russian airlines Aeroflot and S7 could not take place on Wednesday.
The quarrel appeared to be resolved by Wednesday evening, when German carrier Lufthansa said it had received 
permission to land in Moscow and St Petersburg for the entire month of June.
The Transport Ministry in Berlin confirmed that permission had been granted to Lufthansa and so Russian airlines 
were once again allowed to land in Germany.
According to ministry sources, the row has its origins in March 2020.
At that time, Russia unilaterally suspended bilateral flight agreements due to the coronavirus pandemic.
As a result, the overall number of flights were reduced and the journeys had to be approved on a monthly basis.
But other tensions over flights erupted in the wake of last month's forced diversion to Belarus of a Ryanair plane, 
which was travelling from Greece to Lithuania.
Flight approval dispute briefly halts German - Russian air traffic
Once at the airport in Minsk, Belarusian activist journalist Roman Protasevich was taken into custody along with his 
girlfriend.
The incident was described as a "state hijacking" by Greece and led to widespread outrage at Belarus' long-time 
authoritarian ruler Alexander Lukaschenko, who is backed by Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The European Union urged airlines based in the bloc to avoid Belarus airspace. That led air carriers to draw up 
revised flight paths to Russia, but in some cases Russia denied the new applications, including for Air France and 
Austrian Airlines.
The Russian aviation authority said that it could not keep pace with the large number of such applications that 
needed to be processed, leading to the cancellations.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 3, 2021

German police examine plane in unscheduled stop at Berlin airport
German police examine plane in unscheduled stop at Berlin airport
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 31, 2021 Monday 7:15 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 237 words
Byline: Simon Sachseder and Christophe Gateau in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
German police examined a Ryanair passenger jet on the tarmac at Berlin Airport for several hours late on Sunday 
after an unscheduled landing, police confirmed.
Why the plane en route from Dublin to Cracow stopped in Berlin around 8 pm (1800 GMT) was not immediately 
disclosed for operational reasons, a police spokesperson said.
The aircraft was taken to a parking spot away from the terminal. The 160 passengers were taken inside.
The jet was surrounded by numerous police vehicles with flashing lights.
Police aided by sniffer dogs examined the passengers' luggage assembled near the plane. The luggage was taken 
inside the terminal building later.
The police search operation went on into the early hours of Monday with no end in sight.
It was unclear if and when the plane would be allowed to resume its journey.
Airport authorities lifted the night flight ban for the Ryanair flight as a precaution.
The Berlin tabloids B.Z. and Bild had first reported on the incident and mentioned a potential bomb scare.
Last summer, a Ryanair plane had to make a safety landing on its way from Dublin to Krakow because of an 
anonymous bomb threat. Irish media reported that nothing was found during the search in London Stansted.
Sunday's incident in Berlin comes a week after Belarusian authorities dispatched a fighter jet to force another 
Ryanair flight to divert to Minsk, where a dissident journalist who was on board was then arrested.
German police examine plane in unscheduled stop at Berlin airport
Editorial contactsEditing by: Thomas Cronenberg, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 31, 2021
End of Document
Ryanair says plane was diverted to Berlin due to potential threat
Ryanair says plane was diverted to Berlin due to potential threat
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 31, 2021 Monday 1:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 216 words
Byline: Burkhard Fraune, Simon Sachseder and Christophe Gateau in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
A Ryanair plane made an unscheduled landing in Berlin due to information received about a possible security threat 
on board, the Irish airline said on Monday.
The flight from the Irish capital Dublin to Krakow in Poland was diverted to the German capital around 8 pm (1800 
GMT) on Sunday because that was the closest airport, the company said.
The Boeing 737-800 was met by a group of police vehicles with lights flashing as it parked in a spot away from the 
main terminal.
The 165 passengers and their luggage were taken off the plane and examined with the help of sniffer dogs, in an 
operation that lasted until 4 am.
After eight hours, passengers then continued on with their journey using a replacement aircraft.
German federal police said on Monday morning they had determined there was no danger to the aircraft but have 
yet to release details on the purported threat, saying only that it was a telephone call that had raised alarm.
German tabloids Bild and BZ said that there had been a bomb threat, but neither the police nor Ryanair confirmed 
those reports.
Sunday's incident in Berlin comes a week after Belarusian authorities dispatched a fighter jet to force another 
Ryanair flight to divert to Minsk, where a dissident journalist who was on board was then arrested along with his 
girlfriend.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair says plane was diverted to Berlin due to potential threat

NATO restricts Belarusian officials' access to Brussels headquarters
NATO restricts Belarusian officials' access to Brussels headquarters
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 31, 2021 Monday 6:36 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 198 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
NATO is to more strictly control access to its headquarters in the Belgian capital for Belarusian officials, according 
the alliance's secretary general, in the wake of a forced Ryanair flight diversion that stoked international outrage.
"We have decided to restrict the access of Belarusian personnel to the NATO headquarters based on our 
assessment of security measures," defence alliance chief Jens Stoltenberg told reporters on Monday.
The decision comes after the forced rerouting to Minsk of a passenger jet travelling between two NATO member 
countries - Greece and Lithuania - earlier this month in order to detain a dissident Belarusian journalist and his 
girlfriend.
NATO's 30 member states condemned the move and called for the immediate release of Roman Protasevich and 
Sofia Sapega in a joint statement last week.
Minsk's envoy in Brussels is Aleksandr Mikhnevich, who represents the former Soviet republic - bordering 
several EU states and Russia - at both NATO and the European Union.
Belarus has participated in NATO partnership programmes since the 1990s. However, in view of the government's 
crackdown on political opposition, relations with Minsk have been strained for years.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 31, 2021
End of Document
Russia to support Belarus with 500 million dollars in credit
Russia to support Belarus with 500 million dollars in credit
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 30, 2021 Sunday 3:29 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 333 words
Byline:  Hannah Wagner in Moscow and Stefan Heinemeyer in Berlin
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Russia is to support Belarus with 500 million dollars in credit over the coming weeks, the leaders of the two 
countries have agreed.
During a meeting, Russian President Vladimir Putin and Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko agreed the 
sum would be paid out by the end of June, Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov said on Saturday, according to 
news agency Interfax.
This is the second tranche of a credit package that was agreed before the controversial forced landing of a 
passenger aeroplane in Minsk last Sunday in order to arrest a dissident blogger, Roman Protasevich, and his 
girlfriend Sofia Sapega.
During their meeting in the Black Sea resort city of Sochi, Putin and Lukashenko spoke about trade and economic 
cooperation, Peskov said.
Belarus' economy is weak, and it has already borrowed billions of dollars from Moscow.
During the opening of the meeting on Friday, both leaders complained about pressure from Western countries on 
Belarus.
After the incident with the plane - a Ryanair commercial flight between the two EU capitals of Athens and Vilnius 
that was forced to reroute and land in Minsk - the European Union and the United States imposed fresh sanctions 
on Belarus, which the Kremlin slammed as an emotional reaction.
Peskov emphasized that the fate of Sapega, who is a Russian national, mattered to the Russian authorities, but 
said the 23-year-old had a residency permit in Belarus.
Russia to support Belarus with 500 million dollars in credit
Meanwhile the president of the EU Parliament, David Sassoli, said he wants to keep up pressure Belarus in order 
secure the release of the blogger and his girlfriend.
Sassoli suggested that photos of Protassevich be exhibited at all airports in the EU and in the European Parliament.
"We will keep the attention and the pressure up and hope that this will lead to the release of Roman Protasevich 
and his girlfriend Sofia Sapega," he said in remarks to Germany's Funke media group.
Sassoli called the EU's initial reaction to the forced landing of a passenger jet in Minsk as "strong and unified."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Laura Dubois and Thomas Cronenberg <international@dpa.com;

Belarus opposition leader calls for protests
Belarus opposition leader calls for protests
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 29, 2021 Saturday 2:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 247 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya called for the world to stand with political prisoners on the 
one-year anniversary of her husband's jailing.
From her exile in Lithuania, Tikhanovskaya urged rallies to take place and once again demanded that Roman 
Protasevich, an opposition journalist and vocal critic of the Belarusian regime, be released.
Protasevich was arrested in Belarus after being taken off a diverted Ryanair flight from Greece to Lithuania nearly a 
week ago.
The incident triggered international condemnation and put the spotlight once again on the plight of journalists and 
activists in the authoritarian Eastern European country.
Tikhanovskaya's husband Sergei had wanted to run against long-time leader Alexander Lukashenko in the 
presidential election held in August, but was arrested at the end of last May. He faces years in prison.
His wife ran in his place. According to the official results, she lost the election, which was widely regarded as rigged.
The country's pro-democracy movement, however, sees her as the true winner and for weeks stage mass post-
election rallies, often resulting in hundreds of people detained. Tikhanovskaya fled to Lithuania for her safety.
The United States and the European Union no longer recognize Lukashenko as president and said they will impose 
sanctions in the wake of Protasevich's plane arrest.
Protasevich's girlfriend, Sofia Sapega, was also taken into custody after the Ryanair plane was forced to land in 
Minsk.
Belarus opposition leader calls for protests

Need some cash? Crowdfund offers fee for jailing Belarus ' Lukashenko
Need some cash? Crowdfund offers fee for jailing Belarus' Lukashenko
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 28, 2021 Friday 11:29 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 265 words
Dateline: Minsk (dpa) - 
Body
One of Belarus' most famous entrepreneurs is willing to pull together top dollar for an important job, but anyone 
hoping to cash in has to be willing to put Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko behind bars.
Valeri Tsepkalo campaigned for the presidency in last year's elections, but fled Belarus before the polls after he 
grew concerned for his safety.
Now he's released a video on YouTube stating his intent to raise 11 million euros (13.4 million dollars) in a 
crowdfunding venture.
The money would be given to any member or members of the security forces who ensure that Lukashenko is put 
behind bars.
As of Friday, the effort has raised 60,000 euros.
But Tsepkalo says he's optimistic the gambit will work, arguing that there are still upstanding people in power in 
Belarus who are not willing to cooperate any longer with "criminal number one," as he calls Lukashenko.
Tsepkalo is one of many who have accused Lukashenko of fixing the election last year, as well as charges of 
murder and kidnapping.
Multiple sanctions have been slapped on the country since the widely panned elections, which the European Union 
and other democracies have failed to recognize.
Tensions with Belarus have ratcheted up after a Ryanair flight heading from Greece to Lithuania was forced to land 
in Minsk at the weekend because of an alleged bomb on board.
No bomb was found, but Belarusian authorities took advantage of the situation to arrest dissident blogger Roman 
Protasevich.
Need some cash? Crowdfund offers fee for jailing Belarus ' Lukashenko
The 66-year-old Lukashenko has led Belarus, a former Soviet republic, for more than a quarter of a century, 
tolerating little dissent.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 28, 2021
End of Document
3 billion euros for democracy: EU executive tables funds for Belarus
3 billion euros for democracy: EU executive tables funds for Belarus
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 28, 2021 Friday 4:54 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 266 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission has suggested providing 3 billion euros (3.6 billion dollars) to Minsk "once Belarus 
embarks on a democratic transition," it announced, five days after a dissident was arrested when his commercial 
flight was forced to land.
The proposal, which EU countries still have to assess, should be seen as the bloc's commitment "to support the 
Belarusian people's wishes for a peaceful democratic transition in the country," according to a press release.
Belarus has been rocked by protests following the disputed presidential election in August last year, in which long-
term leader Alexander Lukashenko claims victory. The EU considers the elections neither free nor fair.
Relations between the EU and Belarus soured further over the weekend when Belarusian authorities forced a 
Ryanair flight, heading from Athens to Vilnius, to land in Minsk, and arrested a journalist and his girlfriend who were 
on board.
"It should be a genuine incentive for the regime to change its course," EU foreign affairs chief Josep Borrell said. 
"The EU remains truly committed to a democratic Belarus."
The money would be distributed in the form of grants and loans. It would be used to stabilize the country's economy 
and create jobs, as well as to "reform its institutions to make them more democratic," the press release said.
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said the bloc supported democratic change in the country.
"When - and we believe it is a case of when, not if - Belarus starts its peaceful democratic transition, the EU will be 
there to accompany it," she said in a press release.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, <international@dpa.com;
3 billion euros for democracy: EU executive tables funds for Belarus
Load-Date: May 28, 2021
End of Document
Belarus ' Lukashenko meeting with Putin to discuss Western sanctions
Belarus' Lukashenko meeting with Putin to discuss Western sanctions
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 28, 2021 Friday 11:47 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 272 words
Byline: Ulf Mauder in Moscow
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko, who's under increasing pressure from the West and EU sanctions, is 
heading to Russia on Friday to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The two leaders will discuss further developing their countries' ties when they get together in the Black Sea resort of 
Sochi, according to the Kremlin. Friday's meeting will be the third between the two leaders already this year.
Lukashenko says that he will also discuss the consequences of EU and US sanctions, which are currently hitting 
Belarus especially hard.
Minsk already owes Moscow billions, but Putin has recently repeatedly emphasized that the Kremlin would continue 
to support Lukashenko.
The meeting is taking place less than a week after Belarus forced a passenger plane to make an emergency 
landing in Minsk, saying there was a bomb threat aboard, which turned out to be an unfounded claim, and sending 
a fighter jet to accompany the Ryanair flight.
Roman Protasevich, a 26-year-old dissident journalist, and his partner were taken into custody after the landing, 
prompting a raft of measures by the EU, including restricted access to the bloc's airspace for Belarusian carriers.
It was unclear on Friday whether airlines that were following the EU's recommendation were being blocked from 
landing in Russia.
Some airlines, such as Air France, reportedly had to cancel flights after alternative routes that avoided Belarus were 
not approved.
Belarus ' Lukashenko meeting with Putin to discuss Western sanctions
The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, said that he did not know yet if Russian authorities were making the decision 
case-by-case or had implemented a general rule, and would wait before taking any action.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;

Western sanctions weigh as Belarus ' Lukashenko meets with Putin
Western sanctions weigh as Belarus' Lukashenko meets with Putin
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 28, 2021 Friday 6:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 389 words
Byline: Ulf Mauder in Moscow
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko, who's under increasing pressure from the West and EU sanctions, is 
heading to Russia on Friday to meet with Russian President Vladimir Putin.
The two leaders will discuss further developing their countries' ties when they get together in the Black Sea resort of 
Sochi, according to the Kremlin. Friday's meeting will be the third between the two leaders already this year.
Lukashenko says that he will also discuss the consequences of EU and US sanctions, which are currently hitting 
Belarus especially hard.
Minsk already owes Moscow billions, but Putin has recently repeatedly emphasized that the Kremlin would continue 
to support Lukashenko.
The meeting is taking place less than a week after Belarus forced a passenger plane to make an emergency 
landing in Minsk, saying there was a bomb threat aboard, which turned out to be an unfounded claim. During the 
incident, Belarus sent a fighter jet to accompany the Ryanair flight.
Roman Protasevich, a 26-year-old dissident journalist, and his partner were taken into custody after the landing, 
prompting a raft of measures by the EU, including restricted access to the bloc's airspace for Belarusian carriers.
Lithuanian authorities announced on Friday that they have questioned the crew and 90 per cent of the passengers 
who were on board at the time. The investigation of the plane, which remains at the airport in Vilnius, is still 
ongoing, according to the BNS news agency.
There had been more than 100 passengers on the plane at the time. They were delayed more than eight hours due 
to the plane diversion.
Western sanctions weigh as Belarus ' Lukashenko meets with Putin
It was unclear on Friday whether airlines that were following the EU's recommendation were being blocked from 
landing in Russia.
Some airlines, such as Air France, reportedly had to cancel flights after alternative routes that avoided Belarus were 
not approved.
The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, said that he did not know yet if Russian authorities were making the decision 
case-by-case or had implemented a general rule, and would wait before taking any action.
Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov spoke of "technical problems" after the EU's decision, but said authorities 
were working to sort them out.
The Rosaviazia aviation authority said it was taking longer than usual to approve requests because more than usual 
had been coming in.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;

End of Document
Belarus ' Lukashenko complains to Putin about pressure from the West
Belarus' Lukashenko complains to Putin about pressure from the West
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 28, 2021 Friday 7:59 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 600 words
Byline: Alexander Welscher in Riga, Hannah Wagner and Ulf Mauder in Moscow, Christiane Oelrich in Geneva and 
Marek Majewsky and Leonie Kijewski in Brussels
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Belarusian leader Alexander Lukashenko complained to Russian President Vladimir Putin about increasing 
pressure from the West and EU sanctions during talks held in Sochi on Friday.
After a dissident's commercial flight between two EU capitals - Athens and Vilnius - was forced to reroute and land 
in Minsk, Brussels imposed sanctions that penalized state-owned airline Belavia, although it had nothing to do with 
the incident, Lukashenko said.
Regime critic Roman Protasevich was detained after landing in Minsk, sparking international condemnation.
At the leaders' meeting, Putin criticized an incident in 2013 when the Bolivian president's plane was diverted, 
without the EU's objections in what he called a US operation.
Lukashenko said he could prove that there had been attempts to destabilize Belarus since the contested elections 
in August that led to massive protests.
The presidential election was widely regarded as manipulated and hundreds of thousands of people called for 
Lukashenko's resignation.
Putin emphasized his support for Lukashenko, saying trade between the two countries had increased.
Their meeting came five days after Belarus claimed the plane had to make an emergency landing in Minsk due to a 
bomb threat, a claim which proved unfounded. During the incident, Belarus sent a fighter jet to accompany the 
Ryanair flight.
Belarus ' Lukashenko complains to Putin about pressure from the West
Protasevich, a 26-year-old dissident journalist, and his partner were then taken into custody, prompting a raft of 
measures by the EU, including restricted access to the bloc's airspace for Belarusian carriers.
On Friday, further information emerged about the forced landing, suggesting that the plane had been diverted 
before an email alleging the threat had been sent.
"We can see when the email was sent, and we can confirm that the email in question was sent after the plane had 
been diverted," the Proton email service in Geneva told dpa.
"We have not seen credible evidence that the Belarusian claims are true," the service wrote.
Belarus had claimed that Hamas had sent the threat, a suggestion Hamas repudiated as "absurd" shortly 
afterwards.
Earlier on Friday, Lithuanian authorities announced that they had questioned the crew and 90 per cent of the 
passengers who were on board at the time. The investigation of the plane, which remains at the airport in Vilnius, is 
still ongoing, according to the BNS news agency.
Meanwhile it was unclear on Friday whether airlines that were following the EU's recommendation were being 
blocked from landing in Russia.
Some airlines, such as Air France, reportedly had to cancel flights after alternative routes that avoided Belarus were 
not approved.
The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, said that he did not know yet if Russian authorities were making the decision 
case-by-case or had implemented a general rule, and would wait before taking any action.
Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov spoke of "technical problems" after the EU's decision, but said authorities 
were working to sort them out.
Later, Lithuania expelled two Belarusian diplomats for activities that were "not compatible with their status," the 
Foreign Ministry said. Belarus responded by expelling two Lithuanian diplomats.
Looking to the future, the European Commission suggested providing billions in aid to support democratic change in 
Belarus.
It could make 3 billion euros (3.6 billion dollars) available to Minsk "once Belarus embarks on a democratic 
transition," the commission said in a press release.
The move should be seen as the bloc's commitment "to support the Belarusian people's wishes for a peaceful 
democratic transition in the country."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 28, 2021
End of Document

Body
Lithuania wants to host the European Track Cycling Championships, which were stripped from Minsk in reaction to 
the forced landing of a passenger plane by Belarus.
European cycling body UEC took the June 23-27 event off Belarus after a Ryanair plane was forced to land in 
Minsk on Sunday and government critic Roman Protasevich was arrested on board.
"Infrastructure, experience, friendly fans and financial contribution - this is our pledge to UEC cycling and the 
athletes of 50 cycling federations," tweeted Lithuania Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte.
In a reply, the UEC showed an open mind tweeting: "Dear Prime Minister we would be delighted to develop your 
proposition."

European track cycling championships in Minsk cancelled
European track cycling championships in Minsk cancelled
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 27, 2021 Thursday 2:54 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 210 words
Dateline: Leipzig, Germany (dpa) - 
Body
The European track cycling championships planned for the end of June in Minsk have been cancelled due to the 
tense political situation in Belarus, ruling body UEC said on Thursday after a meeting in Lausanne.
"We have recently been monitoring the situation with the Belarus Cycling Federation which has now developed into 
an international debate and today during the Management Board meeting, we have decided to cancel the event in 
Minsk," UEC president Enrico Della Casa said.
"We are already working on finding an alternative solution," he added.
The German cycling federation had decided not to participate in the tournament in response to the forced landing of 
a plane in Minsk. The championships were to take place from June 23-27.
On Sunday a Ryanair passenger plane was forced to land in Minsk and authorities used it to have dissident 
Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich arrested at the airport.
The European Union has imposed new sanctions on the power apparatus in Belarus because of the action, 
including a landing ban for the former Soviet republic's airlines and sanctions on the leadership.
In January, Belarus' capital of Minsk had already been removed as co-host of this year's ice hockey world 
championships due to political unrest in the country.

Belarus' Lukashenko defends decision on forced plane landing
Belarus' Lukashenko defends decision on forced plane landing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 26, 2021 Wednesday 11:39 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 213 words
Dateline: Minsk (dpa) - 
Body
Belarus' long-time president, Alexander Lukashenko, on Wednesday defended his internationally slammed decision 
to force the landing of a passenger plane with a dissident journalist on board.
"I acted lawfully by protecting people - according to all international rules," Lukashenko told the parliament in Minsk.
Authorities used Sunday's landing to have dissident Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich arrested at the airport 
in Minsk.
Lukashenko initially said, without elaborating, that Belarus had received information that there was an explosive 
device on the plane.
Therefore, he said, the plane, which was on its way to Lithuania from Greece, was diverted to Minsk with the 
assistance of a fighter jet.
The European Union has launched new sanctions against the power apparatus in Belarus because of the action, 
including a landing ban for former Soviet republic's airlines and sanctions on leadership.
"That the plane was forced to land by a MiG-29 fighter jet is an absolute lie!" said Lukashenko. Belarus acted for 
safety reasons, he said, because the plane flew over the country's nuclear power plant.
More than 100 people were on board the Ryanair flight that was forced to land, including Protasevich and his 
partner, Sofia Sapega. Both were arrested. Their fate is uncertain.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;
Belarus' Lukashenko defends decision on forced plane landing

Belarus ' Lukashenko: Activist on plane forced to land was 'terrorist'
Belarus' Lukashenko: Activist on plane forced to land was 'terrorist'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 26, 2021 Wednesday 2:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 322 words
Byline: Ulf Mauder in Moscow
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Belarus' long-time president, Alexander Lukashenko, on Wednesday defended his internationally slammed decision 
to force the landing this weekend of a passenger plane with a dissident journalist on board.
"I acted lawfully by protecting people - according to all international rules," Lukashenko told the parliament in Minsk.
Authorities used Sunday's landing to have dissident Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich arrested at the airport 
in Minsk.
Protasevich is a "terrorist," added Lukashenko, who said the 26-year-old blogger was planning a "bloody uprising" 
in Belarus.
"There was a terrorist on board the plane," he said, claiming that it was his country's sovereign right to detain its 
own citizens.
Lukashenko initially said, without elaborating, that Belarus had received information that there was an explosive 
device on the plane.
Therefore, he said, the plane, which was on its way to Lithuania from Greece, was diverted to Minsk with the 
assistance of a fighter jet.
The European Union has launched new sanctions against the power apparatus in Belarus because of the action, 
including a landing ban for former Soviet republic's airlines and sanctions on leadership.
"That the plane was forced to land by a MiG-29 fighter jet is an absolute lie!" said Lukashenko. Belarus acted for 
safety reasons, he said, because the plane flew over the country's nuclear power plant.
Belarus ' Lukashenko: Activist on plane forced to land was 'terrorist'
More than 100 people were on board the Ryanair flight that was forced to land, including Protasevich and his 
partner, Sofia Sapega. Both were arrested. Their fate is uncertain.
Lukashenko made other claims about Protasevich's past, including that he had fought on the side of government 
forces in eastern Ukraine and had "a lot of experience as a mercenary."
Protasevich had reported from Ukraine in 2014, when the war between pro-Russian forces and the central 
government in Kiev was breaking out. However, it has never been proven that he engaged in combat.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;

End of Document
Fears grow that detained Belarusian journalist subject to torture
Fears grow that detained Belarusian journalist subject to torture
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 26, 2021 Wednesday 4:44 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 718 words
Byline: Christian Thiele in Moscow and Doris Heitmann in Warsaw
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Fears grew on Tuesday that the Belarusian dissident journalist Roman Protasevich, who was detained in Minsk 
after his plane was forcibly rerouted, has been subject to torture while in custody.
Natalia Protasevich, the mother of the journalist, said there was clear evidence that her son had been subject to 
violence, referring to footage released a day earlier from the Minsk pre-trial detention centre where he is being held.
He was arrested on Sunday after Belarusian authorities alerted the crew of his Ryanair flight from Athens to Vilnius 
of a possible security threat and directed it to land at an airport near Minsk.
President Alexander Lukashenko also ordered a MiG-29 fighter jet to be scrambled to accompany the plane, 
according to the state news agency.
Authorities in Minsk then detained Protasevich and his girlfriend, who was also on board.
"I am not a surgeon, but it is certain that they hit his nose and may have broken it," Protasevich's mother said of the 
video that was circulated by the authorities.
She also said her son's left cheek was swollen and sagging. "Even under the make-up, you can see a yellowish 
tinge - probably bruises were covered with powder."
She said she also saw signs of strangulation on the neck of her son. "From the looks of it, they choked him to beat 
evidence out of him."
In the video, Protasevich, 26, said he was being treated in accordance with the law and confessed to having 
organized riots.
Fears grow that detained Belarusian journalist subject to torture
Her son was forced to make the statement, Protasevich said. "He either read it off the page or was forced to 
memorize it."
Her son is a very strong person, said Protasevich, who lives with her husband in exile in Poland. However, she said 
she feared the authorities might abuse his girlfriend in order to break her son.
Her fears were echoed by opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who said the international community must 
act in concert to prevent a repeat of Belarus' actions at the weekend.
Now is the time to discuss joint steps "to bring the perpetrators to justice," Tikhanovskaya, who lives in exile in 
Lithuania, wrote on the Telegram messaging app.
The US should launch an investigation into the flight's forced landing and Protasevich's detention, she said after a 
phone call with US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan.
"All of this is a result of the regime's impunity and the lack of a decisive response from the international community," 
she added.
On Tuesday, Russian newspaper RBK said Sofia Sapega, Protasevich's girlfriend, had been remanded in custody 
for two months, citing a lawyer.
In a video circulated by Belarusian state media, 23-year-old Sapega said she had also worked as an editor of an 
opposition Telegram channel and disseminated information about Belarusian security forces.
Belarusian blogger Stepan Putilo, the founder of the Nexta portal on Telegram along with Protasevich, told a Polish 
newspaper that he has been receiving death threats since Protasevich's arrest.
"They write to me that it's our turn next, that we won't be kidnapped to Belarus but shot in Warsaw," he told the 
Rzeczpospolita.
Nexta, the Belarusian opposition's main source of information during massive protests against long-time ruler 
Lukashenko, is based in Warsaw. Protasevich left Nexta at the end of 2020.
On Monday, the EU agreed to a package of sanctions, including the sealing-off of Belarusian airspace and a 
landing ban on its airlines in response to the forced landing of the plane.
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg welcomed the sanctions.
"This is a state hijacking and demonstrates how the regime in Minsk attacks basic democratic rights and cracks 
down on freedom of expression and independent media," he said, adding that an urgent international investigation 
was needed.
Lufthansa, Air France and Finnair are the latest airlines to announce that they would be avoiding flying over Belarus 
for the time being.
Some 339 flights pass over Belarus per day to and from Europe, according to aviation authority Eurocontrol.
Belarus' state-owned airline said on Tuesday that it had suspended flights to London and Paris until the end of 
October in response to a landing ban by those countries, saying it regretted the situation.
Lukashenko was already under international pressure after disputed elections last year and a violent clampdown on 
widespread protests.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams <international@dpa.com;
Fears grow that detained Belarusian journalist subject to torture
Load-Date: May 25, 2021
End of Document
Opposition: Lack of response led to Belarusian activist's arrest

dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2021 Tuesday 11:12 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 272 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
The international community must act in concert against Belarus' weekend gambit to arrest a dissident journalist by 
forcing the passenger plane he was on to land in Minsk, says Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana 
Tikhanovskaya.
Now is the time to discuss joint steps "to bring the perpetrators to justice," wrote Tikhanovskaya, who lives in exile 
in Lithuania, on the Telegram messaging app on Tuesday.
The US should launch an investigation into the forced landing of the Ryanair flight and journalist Roman 
Protasevich's detention, she said after a phone call with US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan.
"All of this is a result of the regime's impunity and the lack of a decisive response from the international community," 
she added, noting that she thinks Protasevich is being tortured.
In videos circulated in Belarus, Protasevich said he wanted to make further confessions about organizing mass 
unrest - statements the opposition said were made under duress, pointing to signs of beating.
Belarusian authorities alerted the crew of a Ryanair flight from Athens to Vilnius of a possible security threat on 
Sunday and directed it to land at an airport near Minsk; long-time President Alexander Lukashenko also ordered a 
MiG-29 fighter jet to be scrambled to accompany the plane, according to the state news agency.
Authorities in Minsk then arrested Protasevich and his girlfriend, who was also on board, sparking international 
condemnation, sanctions and the sealing-off of Belarusian airspace by the EU.

time being.

Eagerly awaited Biden-Putin summit set for June 16 in Geneva
Eagerly awaited Biden-Putin summit set for June 16 in Geneva
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2021 Tuesday 8:52 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 426 words
Byline: Ulf Mauder and Christian Thiele in Moscow, and Can Merey in Washington
Dateline: Moscow/Washington (dpa) -  
Body
US President Joe Biden and Russian President Vladimir Putin will meet on June 16 in Geneva for an eagerly 
anticipated face-to-face session that comes at a time of worsening tensions between the rival powers.
The White House and the Kremlin announced the date on Tuesday. The idea was proposed by Biden in a phone 
call to Putin in April, but until now the Kremlin has been cagey about whether or not Putin would accept the 
invitation.
The Kremlin said the two would discuss bilateral relations, strategic stability, settlement of regional conflicts and 
anti-pandemic cooperation, Russia's TASS news agency reported.
"The leaders will discuss the full range of pressing issues, as we seek to restore predictability and stability to the 
US-Russia relationship," read a White House statement.
For Biden, the meeting in the Swiss city will likely come at the end of his first overseas trip in office. He is already 
scheduled to attend the G7 summit in Cornwall, England from June 11 to 13, then travel to the NATO summit in 
Brussels on June 14.
Biden has raised the stakes in US relations with Putin, who has been in power more than two decades, since taking 
office in January.
US-Russia ties have nose-dived over Washington's allegations of election interference and cyberattacks, the 
treatment of jailed Russian dissident Alexei Navalny and the conflict in eastern Ukraine.
The two sides have imposed a wave of sanctions and counter-sanctions and expelled each other's diplomats.
Eagerly awaited Biden-Putin summit set for June 16 in Geneva
The recent forced diversion of a Ryanair flight by Belarus - whose longtime authoritarian leader Alexander 
Lukashenko is backed by Putin - has provided the latest point of contention.
During an interview in March, Biden responded affirmatively when asked if he thought Putin was "a killer" - an 
answer that outraged the Kremlin - and warned Putin would "pay a price" for the election interference.
"President Biden is meeting with Vladimir Putin because of our countries' differences, not in spite of them. It's an 
opportunity to raise concerns where we have them and to move toward a more stable and predictable relationship," 
said White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki.
"We're not suggesting that at the end of this it's going to be easy breezy from here," she said.
In recent days, US and Russian officials have been laying the groundwork for the summit.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken and his Russian counterpart Sergei Lavrov met in Iceland last week, while 
US National Security Advisor Jake Sullivan and Russian Security Council Secretary Nikolai Patrushev met in 
Geneva on Monday.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 25, 2021
End of Document
Opposition: Concerted global action needed to take on Belarus rulers
Opposition: Concerted global action needed to take on Belarus rulers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2021 Tuesday 12:36 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 494 words
Byline: Christian Thiele in Moscow
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
The international community must act in concert to prevent a repeat of Belarus' weekend gambit - in which it 
arrested a dissident journalist by forcing the passenger plane he was on to land in Minsk - says opposition leader 
Svetlana Tikhanovskaya.
Now is the time to discuss joint steps "to bring the perpetrators to justice," wrote Tikhanovskaya, who lives in exile 
in Lithuania, on the Telegram messaging app on Tuesday.
The US should launch an investigation into the forced landing of the Ryanair flight and journalist Roman 
Protasevich's detention, she said after a phone call with US National Security Adviser Jake Sullivan.
"All of this is a result of the regime's impunity and the lack of a decisive response from the international community," 
she added, noting that she thinks Protasevich is being tortured.
In videos circulated in Belarus, Protasevich said he wanted to make further confessions about organizing mass 
unrest - statements the opposition said were made under duress, pointing to signs of beating.
The founder of the Nexta portal on Telgram along with Protasevich, blogger Stepan Putilo, told a Polish newspaper 
on Tuesday that he has been receiving death threats since Protasevich's arrest.
"They write to me that it's our turn next, that we won't be kidnapped to Belarus but shot in Warsaw," he told the 
Rzeczpospolita.
Nexta, the Belarusian opposition's main source of information during massive protests against long-time ruler 
Alexander Lukashenko, is based in Warsaw. Protasevich left Nexta at the end of 2020.
Opposition: Concerted global action needed to take on Belarus rulers
Belarusian authorities alerted the crew of a Ryanair flight from Athens to Vilnius of a possible security threat on 
Sunday and directed it to land at an airport near Minsk; Lukashenko also ordered a MiG-29 fighter jet to be 
scrambled to accompany the plane, according to the state news agency.
Authorities in Minsk then detained Protasevich and his girlfriend, who was also on board, sparking international 
condemnation as well as a package of measures by the EU that include sanctions, the sealing-off of Belrusian 
airspace and a landing ban on its airlines.
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg welcomed sanctions the EU imposed on Belarus following the forced 
landing of a Ryanair flight.
"This is a state hijacking and demonstrates how the regime in Minsk attacks basic democratic rights and cracks 
down on freedom of expression and independent media," he said, adding that an urgent international investigation 
was needed.
NATO members will meet later on Tuesday to discuss the issue.
Lufthansa, Air France and Finnair are the latest airlines to announce that they would be avoiding flying over Belarus 
for the time being.
Some 339 flights pass over Belarus per day to and from Europe, according to aviation authority Eurocontrol.
Belarus' state-owned airline said on Tuesday that it had suspended flights to London and Paris until the end of 
October in response to a landing ban by those countries, saying it regretted the situation.

End of Document
EU to seal off skies to Belarusian air traffic after flight diversion
EU to seal off skies to Belarusian air traffic after flight diversion
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2021 Tuesday 1:53 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 682 words
Byline: Leonie Kijewski, Ella Joyner, Verena Schmitt-Roschmann, Ansgar Haase, Michel Winde and Marek 
Majewsky in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union is readying to seal off its airspace and airports to Belarusian airlines after a passenger flight 
between two EU states was forcibly diverted to Minsk in order to detain a dissident Belarusian journalist.
"This outrageous behaviour needs a strong answer," European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said, 
slamming the "state hijacking" as an attack on democracy, freedom of expression and European sovereignty.
In a joint statement signed off at a summit in Brussels, the bloc's leaders instructed relevant officials to "adopt 
necessary measures to ban overflight of EU airspace by Belarusian airlines and prevent access to EU airports."
The 27 premiers also urged all EU-based carriers to avoid flying over Belarusian territory, which von der Leyen said 
was no longer safe.
Once implemented, state airline Belavia will not be able to fly to a host of cities, including to Berlin, Paris and 
Brussels. It will also likely have to re-route its flights to, for example, Tunisia, as the most direct flight path crosses 
EU air space.
The member states also demanded the immediate release of opposition journalist Roman Protasevich and his 
partner Sofia Sapega.
Both were on board a Ryanair flight between EU countries Greece and Lithuania on Sunday that was rerouted to 
the Belarusian capital shortly before it reached Vilnius due to an alleged bomb threat. No bomb was found.
The 26-year-old journalist had been taken into pre-trial detention, Belarusian authorities confirmed on Monday.
EU to seal off skies to Belarusian air traffic after flight diversion
The incident leapt onto the summit's agenda at the last minute and soured relations with the authoritarian 
government even further.
The EU also decided to sanction Belarusian individuals involved in the plane's diversion and economic actors that 
finance the country's regime, von der Leyen said. A list of individuals and companies will be drawn up at a later 
stage.
The punitive measures were agreed on relatively quickly after leaders headed into their meeting on Monday 
evening, with multiple premiers having publicly voiced their support for sanctions throughout the day.
Lithuania's President Gitanas Nauseda called the forced landing "abhorrent." Similarly, Irish Prime Minister Micheal 
Martin called the diversion "appalling, reckless and unacceptable."
The incident also has implications for the country's EU funds. A 3-billion-euro (3.7-billion-dollar) EU investment and 
economic package planned for Belarus is frozen until the country "turns democratic," von der Leyen said.
The EU member states also called on the International Civil Aviation Organization to "urgently investigate" the 
incident.
US President Joe Biden welcomed the EU calls for "targeted economic sanctions and other measures" and said he 
had asked his team to work on options to hold those responsible accountable in close coordination with the EU and 
other partners. He also called for an international investigation to ascertain the facts of the case.
Prior to the EU leaders' meeting, Belarus said it is open to an international investigation into the forced landing. 
Foreign Ministry spokesperson Anatoly Glass rejected EU criticism, and said that Minsk had fully complied with 
international regulations.
But German Chancellor Angela Merkel said all of Minsk's explanations for the manoeuvre so far had been "totally 
unbelievable."
Belarus has seen months of protests - matched by a dogged crackdown - after authoritarian President Alexander 
Lukashenko claimed victory in an election in August last year that the opposition sees as rigged.
Since the poll, which the EU maintains was neither free nor fair, the bloc has imposed sanctions over several 
rounds for human rights breaches. The total of targeted individuals is currently 88, including Lukashenko himself, 
plus seven entities.
The 66-year-old has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states Poland, Lithuania 
and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
Minsk has grown closer to Moscow in recent years. But Lukashenko has also maintained relations with EU partners 
in his almost 27 years in power.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Chiara Palazzo, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 24, 2021
End of Document
NATO chief welcomes EU sanctions on Belarus for forced plane landing
NATO chief welcomes EU sanctions on Belarus for forced plane landing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2021 Tuesday 12:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 110 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg welcomed sanctions that the European Union imposed on Belarus 
following the forced landing of a Ryanair flight.
"The forced landing of a passenger flight by Belarus was dangerous and unacceptable," he said after a meeting 
with Estonian Prime Minister Kaja Kallas.
"This is a state hijacking and demonstrates how the regime in Minsk attacks basic democratic rights and cracks 
down on freedom of expression and independent media. I welcome the additional measures agreed by the 
European Union," he said, adding that an urgent international investigation was needed.
NATO members will meet later on Tuesday to discuss the issue.
