Germany 's Lufthansa stops flying through Belarusian airspace
Germany's Lufthansa stops flying through Belarusian airspace
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2021 Tuesday 12:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 119 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
German airline Lufthansa says it will not fly planes through Belarusian airspace, after the forced landing of a 
Ryanair plane over the weekend and the subsequent arrest of a dissident journalist.
Flights to Moscow, among others, will have to take an alternative route, the firm said.
The airline said it had not decided whether to allow a flight from Frankfurt to Minsk scheduled for Wednesday to go 
ahead.
In Minsk on Monday, boarding for a Lufthansa flight bound for Frankfurt was stopped and all passengers had to 
undergo further security checks. Later, the flight landed in Frankfurt with a two-hour delay.
Some 339 flights pass over Belarus per day to and from Europe, according to aviation authority Eurocontrol.

German track cycling team withdraws from Minsk Euros over plane drama
German track cycling team withdraws from Minsk Euros over plane drama
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 25, 2021 Tuesday 5:50 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 183 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
The German track cycling team has withdrawn from the European Championships due to take place in Belarus after 
Minsk forced an aircraft to land there and arrested a dissident.
The German Cycling Federation (BDR) said in a statement on Tuesday it had "contacted the European Cycling 
Union (UEC) after the events of the weekend and made it clear that under these circumstances it is not possible for 
the German national track cycling team to take part."
The European Championships are scheduled for Minsk from June 23-27 but the BDR said it had urged the UEC "to 
find an alternative solution".
At a meeting in Lausanne on Thursday, the UEC will discuss whether it should relocate the championships, with 
Minsk a controversial choice even before the plane drama due to allegations long-time ruler Alexander Lukashenko 
rigged last year's election.
Belarus forced a Ryanair plane flying from Athens to Vilnius to land in Minsk on Sunday and arrested government 
critic Roman Protasevich, who had been on board.
The European Union has imposed sanctions, including a ban on Belarusian airlines landing in the EU.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Meadows; <international@dpa.com; 
Load-Date: May 25, 2021
End of Document
Belarus activist arrested after fighter jet intercepts Ryanair flight
Belarus activist arrested after fighter jet intercepts Ryanair flight
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 2:50 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 749 words
Byline: Alexia Angelopoulou and Takis Tsafos in Athens; Ulf Mauder in Moscow; Steffen Trumpf in Copenhagen; 
Fabian Nitschmann in Berlin; and Michael Winde in Brussels
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
European nations were demanding answers after Belarusian authorities dispatched a fighter jet to force a Ryanair 
flight to divert to Minsk, where a dissident journalist who was on board was then arrested.
Ryanair said its plane was flying from Greece to Lithuania on Sunday when it was notified of "a potential security 
threat on board" by air traffic controllers in Belarus and told to divert to Minsk for an emergency landing.
The airline said the plane landed safely in Belarusian capital and "nothing untoward was found" after passengers 
were offloaded and an inspection took place.
But authorities at the airport used the opportunity to arrest Roman Protasevich, a Belarusian journalist and 
opposition activist, who was a passenger, according to state media and the rights group Viasna.
The opposition news outlet Nexta also confirmed the arrest of Protasevich, the organization's co-founder and 
former editor who has been living in exile.
Governments across Europe reacted with the outrage, suggesting authoritarian Belarus used the pretext of a safety 
threat to conduct a "state hijacking" of a civilian airliner in order to go after a critic.
Belarusian state media reported that the plane's diversion came on the personal instructions of long-time President 
Alexander Lukashenko after he had purportedly been alerted to a possible bomb on board and was concerned 
about the plane's safety.
He also ordered a MiG-29 fighter jet be scrambled to accompany the Ryanair plane, according to the Belta state 
news agency.
Belarus activist arrested after fighter jet intercepts Ryanair flight
Lukashenko, 66, has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states Poland, 
Lithuania and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
Mass protests against his rule erupted after a presidential election last year that was widely seen as unfair and rife 
with electoral fraud.
Belarus calls Nexta an extremist organization and Protasevich has been wanted by authorities. Nexta had urged on 
the protests against Lukashenko.
Lukashenko has long considered Protasevich to be an enemy. The country's KGB secret service had reportedly put 
his name on a list of people accused of alleged terrorism and he faces years in prison if convicted.
Condemnation of Belarus came swiftly on Sunday, with NATO Secretary General Jens Stoltenberg calling for an 
international investigation and European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen saying the "utterly 
unacceptable" incident "must bear consequences."
The United States demanded Protasevich be immediately released. Secretary of State Antony Blinken strongly 
condemned the forced diversion and Protasevich's arrest.
"This shocking act perpetrated by the Lukashenka regime endangered the lives of more than 120 passengers, 
including U.S. citizens," Blinken said in a statement.
The 27 EU leaders will discuss Belarus during a previously scheduled summit in Brussels on Monday, including the 
possibility of imposing sanctions on Minsk, a spokesperson for EU Council President Charles Michel said.
Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda tweeted that Belarus had committed an "abhorrent action" and demanded 
the release of Protasevich.
The Lithuanian Prosecutor-General's Office said the country has launched a preliminary investigation into the jet's 
forced diversion.
The Greek Foreign Ministry said it "strongly condemns the state hijacking," while Britain, Germany, France, Poland, 
Austria, Norway, Sweden, and the Netherlands were among the chorus denouncing Minsk.
Ryanair Flight FR4978 was en route from Athens to the Lithuanian capital Vilnius when it was ordered to land in 
Minsk.
Former Belarusian culture minister Pavel Latushko, who lives in exile in the EU, said, citing his contacts, that the 
flight control centre in Minsk threatened the pilots with shooting down the plane if they did not land.
Greece and Lithuania put the number of passengers on board at 171, although Ryanair has not provided a figure. 
Lithuania said most of the passengers were Lithuanian nationals. Belarus had said the plane had 123 passengers.
The Irish low-cost airline said the plane spent seven hours on the ground in Minsk undergoing security checks 
before it was allowed to depart at 8:50 pm (1750 GMT). It landed in Vilnius a little over 30 minutes later.
Ryanair made no mention of Protasevich in its statement.
Exiled Belarusian opposition leader Svetlana Tikhanovskaya, who many in Belarus consider the true winner of the 
2020 presidential election, urged the international community to punish Lukashenko.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman and Thomas Cronenberg, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 23, 2021
Belarus activist arrested after fighter jet intercepts Ryanair flight

Whereabouts of activist taken off diverted plane in Minsk unknown
Whereabouts of activist taken off diverted plane in Minsk unknown
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 10:37 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 279 words
Dateline: Minsk (dpa) - 
Body
The whereabouts of dissident Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich, who was taken into custody after a 
passenger plane he was on was forced to land in Minsk at the weekend, remain unknown on Monday.
Protasevich, a 26-year-old blogger and activist who was wanted in his homeland for inciting protests against long-
time leader Alexander Lukashenko, among other charges, was arrested after his Ryanair flight from Greece to 
Lithuania made an emergency landing on Sunday.
His father, Dmitry, said in an interview with Belarusian radio broadcaster Radio Svoboda that he was convinced that 
the careful operation did "not only involve" the country's secret service.
Russia is a close ally of Belarus.
"The operation was of a large enough scale to spit on the entire international community and their opinion," added 
the dissident's father, who called the forced landing "an act of terrorism."
"We are very worried about our son," said Dmitry Protasevich. "Unfortunately, we don't know where he is and how 
he's doing."
Governments across Europe reacted with outrage, suggesting authoritarian Belarus used the pretext of a safety 
threat to conduct a "state hijacking" of a civilian airliner to go after a critic.
Belarusian state media reported that the plane's diversion came on Lukashenko's personal instructions, after he 
had purportedly been alerted to a possible bomb on board. He also ordered a MiG-29 fighter jet be scrambled to 
accompany the Ryanair plane, according to the Belta news agency.
Lukashenko, 66, has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states Poland, 
Lithuania and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
Whereabouts of activist taken off diverted plane in Minsk unknown

Calls to block Belarus ' airspace grow as activist's location unknown
Calls to block Belarus' airspace grow as activist's location unknown
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 12:35 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 570 words
Byline: Ulf Mauder in Moscow
Dateline: Minsk (dpa) - 
Body
Calls to create a no-fly zone over Belarus' airspace and ban its planes from landing grew louder on Monday as 
European countries looked for ways to express how angry they were at the forced landing of a Ryanair flight with a 
dissident onboard in Minsk.The whereabouts of dissident Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich, who was taken 
into custody after the passenger plane he was on was forced to land in Belarus' capital at the weekend, remain 
unknown.
Protasevich, a 26-year-old blogger and activist who was wanted in his homeland for inciting protests against long-
time leader Alexander Lukashenko, among other charges, was arrested after his Ryanair flight from Greece to 
Lithuania made an emergency landing on Sunday.
Governments across Europe have reacted with outrage, suggesting authoritarian Belarus used the pretext of a 
safety threat to conduct a "state hijacking" of a civilian airliner to go after a critic.
The European Union was considering punitive measures, including sanctions on those responsible for the incident, 
as well as a landing ban for the Belarusian airline Belavia at all airports in the bloc and the declaration of the 
airspace over Belarus as a no-fly zone.
Leaders in Latvia and France are already pushing to close off Belarusian airspace to international flights. Airlines 
including Wizz Air and Air Baltic are rerouting their flights accordingly.
British Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab said the International Civil Aviation Organisation council should meet "to 
consider the regime's flouting of the international rules safeguarding civil aviation."
EU leaders will discuss possible measures at a summit later on Monday.
Calls to block Belarus ' airspace grow as activist's location unknown
Belarusian state media reported that the plane's diversion came on Lukashenko's personal instructions, after he 
had purportedly been alerted to a possible bomb on board. He also ordered a MiG-29 fighter jet be scrambled to 
accompany the Ryanair plane, according to the Belta news agency.
Lukashenko, 66, has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states Poland, 
Lithuania and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
Protasevich's father, Dmitry, said in an interview with Belarusian radio broadcaster Radio Svoboda that he was 
convinced that the operation did "not only involve" the country's secret service, hinting at Moscow's involvement.
"The operation was of a large enough scale to spit on the entire international community and their opinion," added 
the dissident's father, who called the forced landing "an act of terrorism."
Russia is a close ally of Belarus.
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary believes that KGB agents were aboard the passenger flight that was 
forced to land in Minsk.
"It appears the intent of the authorities was to remove a journalist and his travelling companion," the head of the 
Irish budget airline told radio broadcaster Newstalk on Monday. "We believe there were some KGB agents 
offloaded at the airport as well," he added.
O'Leary praised the flight crew for handling the situation well and said the incident was frightening for passengers 
and staff, who were detained for hours by gunmen in Belarus after the emergency landing.
Dmitry Protasevich expressed worry about his son: "Unfortunately, we don't know where he is and how he's doing."
The EU's top diplomat, Josep Borrell, and Amnesty International are among those who have called for 
Protasevich's immediate release.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 24, 2021
End of Document
EU leaders to discuss sanctions, other measures against Belarus
EU leaders to discuss sanctions, other measures against Belarus
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 3:18 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 285 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The EU could decide to sanction Belarus on Monday evening when the 27 premiers meet in Brussels following the 
forced landing of a Ryanair flight and the arrest of a journalist.
On the table are, among other measures, targeted sanctions against people responsible for the forced landing of 
the commercial flight between Athens and Vilnius.
Dissident journalist Roman Protasevich, who had been on board, was taken into custody after the flight was 
diverted to the Belarusian capital, Minsk, on allegations of a bomb threat.
The manoeuvre caused international outrage. The bloc's foreign affairs chief Josep Borrell called it "yet another 
blatant attempt by the Belarusian authorities to silence all opposition voices."
"In carrying out this coercive act, the Belarusian authorities have jeopardised the safety of passengers and crew," 
he said, calling for an international investigation and for Protasevich to be released.
"The EU will consider the consequences of this action, including taking measures against those responsible."
Other options include banning national airline Belavia from landing at EU airports or ordering EU airlines to avoid 
Belarusian airspace, although this is legally more complicated than targeting individuals.
The EU summoned Belarusian ambassador Aleksandr Mikhnevich, during which he "was informed of the firm 
condemnation by the EU institutions," according to a statement.
The meeting in Brussels was initially scheduled to focus on debates on the bloc's strategy towards Russia, for 
example, and was expected to be relatively uneventful.
However, with Belarusian authorities having forced an EU airline flight between two EU countries to land, the 
premiers might feel forced to react strongly.
EU leaders to discuss sanctions, other measures against Belarus
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 24, 2021
End of Document
EU leaders weigh Belarus sanctions after forced landing 'scandal'
EU leaders weigh Belarus sanctions after forced landing 'scandal'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 9:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 537 words
Byline: Leonie Kijewski, Ella Joyner, Verena Schmitt-Roschmann, Ansgar Haase, Michel Winde and Marek 
Majewsky in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union could decide to sanction Belarus once again on Monday evening after the country forced a 
Ryanair flight to land and detained a Belarusian opposition journalist on board.
The incident, which interrupted a flight between two EU countries, has leapt onto the agenda of a Brussels summit 
at the last minute, souring relations between Minsk and the bloc even further.
European Council President Charles Michel slammed the move by Minsk as an "international scandal" that put the 
lives of European civilians at risk.
EU officials were drafting a variety of punitive measures for the bloc to consider, Michel said. "I hope tonight we can 
make a decision on that," he told journalists before the summit.
One possibility is targeted sanctions against people responsible for what EU governments and officials said was a 
state "hijacking" of a commercial flight between Athens and Vilnius on Sunday.
This would be the fourth round of punitive measures since October.
The member states could also ban national airline Belavia from landing at EU airports or order EU airlines to avoid 
Belarusian airspace. This is legally more complicated than targeting individuals, however.
Dissident journalist Roman Protasevich, who had been on board, was taken into custody after the flight was 
diverted to the Belarusian capital on allegations of a bomb threat.
The manoeuvre caused international outrage. The bloc's foreign affairs chief Josep Borrell called it "yet another 
blatant attempt by the Belarusian authorities to silence all opposition voices."
EU leaders weigh Belarus sanctions after forced landing 'scandal'
"In carrying out this coercive act, the Belarusian authorities have jeopardised the safety of passengers and crew," 
he said, calling for an international investigation and for 26-year-old Protasevich to be released.
Belarus said it is open to an international investigation into the forced landing. Foreign Ministry spokesperson 
Anatoly Glass rejected EU criticism saying Minsk had had fully complied with international regulations.
Belarus has seen months of protests - matched with a dogged crackdown - after authoritarian President Alexander 
Lukashenko claimed victory in an election in August last year that the opposition sees as rigged.
Since the poll, which the EU maintains was neither free nor fair, the bloc has imposed sanctions over several 
rounds. The total of targeted individuals is currently 88, including Lukashenko himself, plus seven entities.
The 66-year-old has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states Poland, Lithuania 
and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
NATO ambassadors were set to discuss the matter on Tuesday. Britain is also weighing sanctions.
The EU summoned Belarusian ambassador Aleksandr Mikhnevich, during which he "was informed of the firm 
condemnation by the EU institutions," according to a statement. Several member states also hauled in Belarusian 
envoys bilaterally.
The Brussels summit was initially scheduled to focus on debates on the bloc's strategy towards Russia, for 
example, and was expected to be relatively uneventful.
Minsk has grown closer to Moscow in recent years. But Lukashenko has also maintained relations with EU partners 
in his almost 27 years in power.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 24, 2021
End of Document
EU could seal off skies to Belarusian airlines after forced landing
EU could seal off skies to Belarusian airlines after forced landing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 10:07 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 635 words
Byline: Leonie Kijewski, Ella Joyner, Verena Schmitt-Roschmann, Ansgar Haase, Michel Winde and Marek 
Majewsky in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union could decide on Monday evening to seal off its airspace off to Belarusian airlines after the 
country forced a Ryanair flight to land and detained a Belarusian opposition journalist on board.
According to a draft document seen by dpa, EU leaders could also call on all EU-based airlines to avoid flying over 
the state's territory following what several officials and governments have slammed as either "state hijacking" or 
even "terrorism."
If implemented, state airline Belavia would have to cancel its flights to a host of cities, including to Berlin, Paris, and 
Brussels. It would also likely have to re-route its flights to for example Tunisia, as the most direct flight path crosses 
EU air space.
The incident, which interrupted a flight between EU countries Greece and Lithuania on Sunday, leapt onto the 
agenda of a Brussels summit at the last minute and soured relations with the authoritarian government even further.
The 27 leaders are now examining various sanctions options, which according to European Commission President 
Urusla von der Leyen include targeting the Belarusian aviation sector, businesses that support the country's 
"regime" and people involved in the diversion.
Dissident journalist Roman Protasevich, who had been on board, was taken into custody after the flight was 
diverted to the Belarusian capital on allegations of a bomb threat. No bomb was found.
The 26-year-old has been taken into pre-trial detention, Belarusian authorities confirmed on Monday.
Lithuania's president Gitanas Nauseda calling the forced landing "abhorrent" and said that Belarusian airspace 
could be declared unsafe.
EU could seal off skies to Belarusian airlines after forced landing
Similarly, Irish Prime Minister Micheal Martin called the diversion "appalling, reckless and unacceptable."
If the draft leaders' statement seen by dpa is adopted, the bloc will also call on the International Civil Aviation 
Organization to "urgently investigate" the incident.
One EU diplomat told dpa they believed all member states supported the statement.
Von der Leyen was among those calling for Protasevich's release. "We will put pressure on the regime as long as it 
finally respects the freedom of media ... and the freedom of opinion," she told reporters before the summit.
A 3-billion-euro (3.7-billion-dollar) EU investment and economic package planned for Belarus is frozen until the 
country "turns democratic," she added.
German Chancellor Angela Merkel also demanded the release of Protasevich's partner, Sofia Sapega, who is 
believed to have been detained along with him.
No bomb was found aboard and Merkel said all of Minsk's explanations for the manoeuvre so far had been "totally 
unbelievable."
Belarus said it is open to an international investigation into the forced landing. Foreign Ministry spokesperson 
Anatoly Glass rejected EU criticism, and said that Minsk had fully complied with international regulations.
Belarus has seen months of protests - matched by a dogged crackdown - after authoritarian President Alexander 
Lukashenko claimed victory in an election in August last year that the opposition sees as rigged.
Since the poll, which the EU maintains was neither free nor fair, the bloc has imposed sanctions over several 
rounds for human rights breaches. The total of targeted individuals is currently 88, including Lukashenko himself, 
plus seven entities.
The 66-year-old has led Belarus - a former Soviet republic in Eastern Europe bordering EU states Poland, Lithuania 
and Latvia - for more than a quarter of a century, tolerating little dissent.
The Brussels summit was initially scheduled to focus on debates on the bloc's strategy towards Russia, for 
example, and was expected to be relatively uneventful.
Minsk has grown closer to Moscow in recent years. But Lukashenko has also maintained relations with EU partners 
in his almost 27 years in power.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams <international@dpa.com;

"It appears the intent of the authorities was to remove a journalist and his travelling companion," the head of the

O'Leary praised the flight crew for handling the situation well and said the incident was frightening for passengers

Kremlin backs international probe after Belarus ' Ryanair incident
Kremlin backs international probe after Belarus' Ryanair incident
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 12:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 120 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
An international probe into the weekend incident in which a Ryanair jet was forced to land in Belarus - after which a 
dissident on board was detained - would be in order, says Russia.
"There are international air travel guidelines, and it is the international air travel authorities that should assess 
whether these international standards were followed or not," said Kremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov in 
comments to the Interfax news agency.
He also urged a "sober assessment" of the incident, noting that there are already calls for sanctions after a 
procedure which, he says, went according to international guidelines.
"We don't want to get involved in this race of condemning someone or supporting something," he said.

US demands release of Belarusian journalist after jet diversion
US demands release of Belarusian journalist after jet diversion
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 2:39 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 181 words
Dateline: Riga (dpa) - 
Body
The United States has demanded the "immediate release" of dissident journalist Roman Protasevich, who was 
arrested when Belarusian authorities diverted a Ryanair plane flying to Minsk.
Ryanair said its plane was flying from Greece to Lithuania on Sunday when it was notified of "a potential security 
threat on board" by air traffic controllers in Belarus and told to divert to Minsk for an emergency landing.
US Secretary of State Antony Blinken strongly condemned the forced diversion and Protasevich's arrest. Belarusian 
state media earlier reported that the country's President Alexander Lukashenko ordered the diversion.
"This shocking act perpetrated by the Lukashenka regime endangered the lives of more than 120 passengers, 
including U.S. citizens," Blinken said in a statement.
"Initial reports suggesting the involvement of the Belarusian security services and the use of Belarusian military 
aircraft to escort the plane are deeply concerning and require full investigation."
The US said it was coordinating its response with partners including the EU and Lithuanian and Greek officials.

"The explanations given so far by the Belarusian government for the forced landing of a Ryanair plane in Minsk are

Maas said Belarus needed to give clarity on the welfare of Roman Protasevich and his partner and called on Minsk

"I am sure that we are able to ensure full transparency in this matter," Glass said, adding that Belarus was ready to

Body
Belgium and the Czech Republic have summoned their Belarusian ambassadors over the forced landing of a 
Ryanair flight by Minsk at the weekend, according to each country's Foreign Ministry.
Belgian Foreign Minister Sophie Wilmes wrote on Twitter that Belarus' unjustified and unacceptable actions would 
not remain without consequences and called for the release of Belarusian journalist Roman Protasevich, who was 
taken into custody after the landing.
A spokeswoman for the Foreign Ministry in Prague also warned that such a violation of international law would not 
go without response.

Lithuania launches investigation into diversion of airliner
Lithuania launches investigation into diversion of airliner
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 00:46:04+02:00Invalid date found for VDI: (VDI not available) XCEDOCID: 0 LNI: 62RP-
1J91-JB0G-F2XH-00000-00. Date output 'as-is'. GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 141 words
Dateline: Riga (dpa) - 
Body
Lithuania has launched a preliminary investigation into the forced diversion of a commercial flight to Belarus, the 
Lithuanian Prosecutor-General's Office has said.
Passengers and crew of the diverted aircraft which finally landed in Vilnius on Sunday evening are to be among 
those interviewed by Lithuanian police.
"We expect them to work with law enforcement authorities and provide our officers with all the information they 
know," Prime Minister Ingrida Simonyte said after a meeting with passengers at Vilnius airport.
The Lithuanian government strongly condemned the diversion of the Ryanair flight and spoke of an "act of state 
terrorism" directed against the security of citizens of the EU and other countries.
The government in Vilnius vowed that it will work with international partners to block Belarusian airspace for 
international flights.

Body
A Russian woman was also detained when a Ryanair flight headed to Lithuania was required to land in Minsk this 
weekend - for what EU officials say was a "hijacking" so Belarus could detain a dissident journalist on the plane - 
says a Kremlin spokesperson.
The unnamed woman was accompanying the now-missing dissident, Roman Protasevich, said Russian Foreign 
Minister Sergei Lavrov in comments to the Interfax news agency. Multiple media outlets have reported that the 
woman is Protasevich's girlfriend.
Russia's embassy has reached out to the Foreign Ministry in Minsk to seek consular access to the woman and had 
also contacted the woman's father.
Belarusian human rights organization Viasna says the missing woman is a student at a university in Vilnius, in 
Lithuania. There has been no official comment from Belarus.

Discount airlines slammed by Italian competition authority
Discount airlines slammed by Italian competition authority
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 11:42 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 166 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
A trio of discount airlines were fined on Monday by Italian authorities because they only offered credits - not cash 
back - for flights that had to be cancelled last year amid the pandemic.
The fines affect Irish airline Ryanair, British airline Easyjet and Spanish airline Volotea and pertain to flights 
cancelled after June 3, 2020.
The AGCM competition authority said the businesses had employed confusing practices and provided confusing 
information to customers that left them unclear about their rights.
The decision to hand out credits, which could be used for subsequent flight purchases, made it harder for 
passengers to decide to seek cash reimbursement.
The authority's decision will require Ryanir to pay a 4.2-million-euro fine, while Easy jet will be on the hook for 2.8 
million euros and Volotea for 1.4 million euros.
The AGCM also noted that passengers on some airlines were not given the option of using a toll-free phone 
number if they wanted to call in to redeem the flight credits.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 24, 2021

Lufthansa : Warning notice for Lufthansa plane at Minsk airport
Lufthansa: Warning notice for Lufthansa plane at Minsk airport
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 3:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 113 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Boarding for a Lufthansa flight from Belarus' capital, Minsk, bound for Frankfurt was cancelled due to a warning 
notice, the German airline confirmed to dpa on Monday.
According to the statement, all passengers will be subjected to another security check before departure, and the 
plane will be searched again as well, meaning all cargo will also be unloaded.
Fifty-one passengers, including five crew members, are affected.
The additional caution follows the forced landing of a Ryanair flight from Greece to Lithuania by Belarus this 
weekend that led to the arrest of a dissident journalist. Several airlines have cancelled their flights in Belarusian 
airspace following the incident.

Latvian airline Air Baltic avoiding Belarus ' airspace for time being
Latvian airline Air Baltic avoiding Belarus' airspace for time being
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 11:19 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 159 words
Dateline: Riga (dpa) - 
Body
Latvian airline Air Baltic announced on Monday that it will avoid Belarusian airspace until further notice, after a 
Ryanair passenger flight was forced to land in Minsk the previous day, apparently so authorities could detain a 
dissident on board.
The airline said that it would stay out of Belarus' airspace until the situation became clearer or authorities issue a 
decision.
Latvia's Civil Aviation Authority is expected to make a recommendation soon, according to Transport Minister Talis 
Linkaits.
"It is clear that the situation in principle is unacceptable when a country can decide whether it likes or dislikes one or 
another passenger on the plane," Linkaits told a Latvian radio broadcaster.
Foreign Minister Edgars Rinkevics broached the idea of a ban on flights by Belarusian airlines, in addition to 
economic sanctions and the closing of Belarusian airspace to international flights.
However, no official decision has been made so far, says Linkaits.

EU could seal off its airspace to Belarusian airlines
EU could seal off its airspace to Belarusian airlines
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 24, 2021 Monday 8:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 175 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union could seal off its airspace and all airports to Belarusian airlines and call for all EU-based 
carriers to avoid flying over the country, according to a draft document seen by dpa.
If the 27 EU leaders agree to a draft brought forward by European Council President Charles Michel during their 
meeting on Monday, they will "strongly" condemn the forced landing of a Ryanair flight in Minsk.
According to the draft, which was confirmed as authentic by several EU diplomats, the European Council "calls on 
all EU-based carriers to avoid overflight of Belarus."
The leaders would also call on the relevant EU body to "to adopt the necessary measures to ban overflight of EU 
airspace by Belarusian airlines and prevent access to EU airports of flights operated by such airlines."
If adopted, the premiers will also call on the International Civil Aviation Organization to "urgently investigate" the 
incident. They also want to sanction additional Belarusian individuals.
One EU diplomat said they believed all EU member states supported the draft.
Load-Date: May 24, 2021
End of Document
Ryanair confirms flight diverted to Belarus amid worry about blogger
Ryanair confirms flight diverted to Belarus amid worry about blogger
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 23, 2021 Sunday 7:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 432 words
Byline: Ulf Mauder in Moscow and Steffen Trumpf in Copenhagen
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
European leaders are demanding answers after a Ryanair flight was diverted to an airport in Belarus on Sunday, 
apparently so authorities in Minsk could detain a blogger who had been travelling from Athens to Vilnius in the 
plane.
The Irish airline Ryanair confirmed the incident. Crew on the plane had been alerted to a possible security threat by 
Belarusian authorities and directed to land at an airport near Minsk, the company said. "Nothing untoward was 
found," it said.
"Ryanair has notified the relevant national and European safety and security agencies and we apologise sincerely 
to all affected passengers for this regrettable delay, which was outside Ryanair's control," read a statement.
According to Belarusian media, Minsk used the opportunity to detain Roman Protasevich, a blogger critical of the 
government who was on the plane.
According to Viasna, a Belarusian human rights group, Protasevich was detained after the plane landed.
Nexta, another opposition news channel, and one that was founded by Protasevich, confirmed that he had been 
detained.
Belarus calls Nexta an extremist organization. It had repeatedly called for mass protests against Lukashenko's rule 
after Lukashenko claimed victory in disputed elections in August.
Lukashenko has long considered Protasevich to be an enemy. The country's KGB secret service had put his name 
on a list of people accused of alleged terrorism, according to the tut.by internet portal, in a report released via the 
Telegram messaging app.
Ryanair confirms flight diverted to Belarus amid worry about blogger
Speaking to local media, airport officials confirmed that a fighter jet had intercepted the plane, which then asked for 
permission to land. Furthermore, they said that the bomb scare proved to be a hoax and that the other 123 
passengers on board are waiting at the airport so they can continue their journey.
Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda demanded Protasevich's immediate release.
"Unprecedented event!" he wrote on Twitter. "Belarusian regime is behind the abhorrent action."
So far, Ryanair says the plane is now expected to continue with its journey at 1600 GMT. But there was no word on 
Protasevich.
Lithuania demanded that Belarus release all passengers and crew. Foreign Minister Gabrielius Landsbergis said 
there were 171 passengers on the flight and that Lithuania had gathered details on 149 of them. It said most of the 
passengers were Lithuanian nationals, but there were multiple citizens from other EU countries on board.
Condemnation came in quickly from a variety of countries, such as Austria, Germany and Sweden, as well as the 
European Union. There were demands for an investigation.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 23, 2021

Report: Belarusian blogger detained after flight forced from sky
Report: Belarusian blogger detained after flight forced from sky
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 23, 2021 Sunday 5:18 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 305 words
Dateline: Moscow (dpa) - 
Body
Belarus' military required a civilian plane flying over its territory to land on Sunday, after which officials arrested a 
blogger wanted by the government and had him taken away, according to Belarusian media.
Roman Protasevich, the blogger, was on a Athens-to-Vilnius flight from Ryanair when a fighter jet intercepted the 
plane's path, at which point the airliner asked permission to land, according to Belarusian media reports.
Other reports said that Belarusian President Alexander Lukashenko had ordered the action after a report of a bomb 
on the plane. There was no immediate comment from Ryanair.
According to Viasna, a Belarusian human rights group, Protasevich was detained after the plane landed. Opposition 
groups said the act was an unparalleled move by Minsk into international airspace.
Nexta, another opposition news channel, and one that was founded by Protasevich, confirmed that he had been 
detained.
Belarus calls Nexta an extremist organization. It had repeatedly called for mass protests against Lukashenko's rule 
after Lukashenko claimed victory in disputed elections in August.
Lukashenko has long considered Protasevich to be an enemy. The country's KGB secret service had put his name 
on a list of people accused of alleged terrorism, according to the tut.by internet portal, in a report released via the 
Telegram messaging app.
Speaking to local media, airport officials confirmed that a fighter jet had intercepted the plane, which then asked for 
permission to land. Furthermore, they said that the bomb scare proved to be a hoax and that the other 123 
passengers on board are waiting at the airport so they can continue their journey.
Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda has demanded Protasevich's immediate release.
Report: Belarusian blogger detained after flight forced from sky
"Unprecedented event!" he wrote on Twitter. "Belarusian regime is behind the abhorrent action."

from Athens to Vilnius.
Crew on the plane had been alerted to a possible security threat by Belarusian authorities and directed to land at an 
airport near Minsk, the company said. "Nothing untoward was found," it said.
"Ryanair has notified the relevant national and European safety and security agencies and we apologise sincerely 
to all affected passengers for this regrettable delay, which was outside Ryanair's control," read a statement.
The company says the plane was now expected to continue with its journey at 1600 GMT.

Ryanair flight lands in Vilnius after seven-hour detour to Minsk
Ryanair flight lands in Vilnius after seven-hour detour to Minsk
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 23, 2021 Sunday 9:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 123 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
A Ryanair passenger jet landed in Vilnius on Sunday night after a seven-hour detour to Minsk that has prompted 
international condemnation.
Ryanair Flight FR4978 had been en route to the Lithuanian capital from Athens when Belarusian authorities ordered 
it to turn around and land in Minsk, saying there was a potential security threat on board.
No such threat was found on the plane. But prominent Belarusian opposition journalist Roman Protasevich, who 
was a passenger on board, was arrested.
The passengers and crew spent approximately seven hours on the ground in Minsk before the plane departed for 
Vilnius, Ryanair said in a statement. The plane landed at 9:25 pm (1825 GMT).
The Irish airline's statement made no mention of Protasevich.

Germany demands answers from Belarus on diverted Ryanair flight
Germany demands answers from Belarus on diverted Ryanair flight
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 23, 2021 Sunday 7:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 130 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
The German Foreign Ministry is demanding an explanation from Belarus as to why a Ryanair passenger plane 
flying from Greece to Lithuania was forced to divert to Minsk.
Miguel Berger, state secretary at the Foreign Ministry, wrote on Twitter that Belarus needed to answer allegations 
that the plane was forced to make a detour in order to arrest an opposition blogger.
According to Belarusian media, Minsk used the opportunity to detain Roman Protasevich, a blogger critical of the 
government who was on the plane. According to the Viasna human rights group, Protasevich was detained after the 
plane landed.
"We need an immediate explanation by the Government of Belarus on the diversion of a Ryanair flight within the EU 
to Minsk and the alleged detention of a journalist," Berger wrote.

Greece blasts Belarus for 'state hijacking' of Ryanair plane
Greece blasts Belarus for 'state hijacking' of Ryanair plane
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 23, 2021 Sunday 7:26 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Dateline: Athens (dpa) - 
Body
The Greek Foreign Ministry has slammed the forced diversion of a Ryanair passenger flight to Minsk and the arrest 
of an opposition blogger who was on board.
"Greece strongly condemns the state hijacking that took place today, which resulted in the forced landing of Ryanair 
FR 4978, which operated the Athens-Vilnius route, in Minsk, Belarus," a ministry statement said.
"The plane had a total of 171 passengers, 11 of whom are Greek citizens. This act, which endangered the lives of 
all passengers, is unacceptable."
The Foreign Ministry condemned the arrest of Belarusian activist Roman Protasevich at the Minsk airport.
Protasevich was part of a delegation in Greece that participated in the international "Delphi Forum" last week, the 
Foreign Ministry added.
Every year, the Delphi Forum invites experts and politicians to discuss political and economic issues.
"Mr Protasevich was part of a delegation led by Belarusian opposition leader Sviatlana Tsikhanouskaya, who 
recently attended the Delphi Forum.
"For Greece, defending fundamental values such as democracy, the rule of law, and human rights is a matter of 
principle," the ministry statement said.

German foreign minister calls for 'clear consequences' against Minsk
German foreign minister calls for 'clear consequences' against Minsk
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 23, 2021 Sunday 8:53 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 152 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Germany's foreign minister has condemned the forced landing of a Ryanair passenger jet in Belarus and the 
subsequent arrest of a prominent opposition activist who was on board.
"The fact that a flight between two EU states was forced to make a stopover under the pretext of a bomb threat is a 
serious interference in civil air traffic in Europe," Foreign Minister Heiko Maas said in a statement, calling for "clear 
consequences" to be taken against the government in Minsk.
"We are very concerned about reports that journalist Roman Protasevich was arrested this way," Maas said of the 
activist.
He urged the issue to be taken up at a previously scheduled meeting of EU leaders on Monday in Brussels.
The Ryanair plane was en route from Athens to the Lithuanian capital Vilnius on Sunday when it was ordered to 
land in Minsk by air traffic controllers who said they had identified a potential security threat on board.

Ryanair wins case at EU court challenging aid for competing airlines
Ryanair wins case at EU court challenging aid for competing airlines
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 19, 2021 Wednesday 2:46 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 289 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union's second highest court dealt a blow to the European Commission on Wednesday, ruling that a 
complaint by Ryanair about state aid to other airline companies was justified.
The court annulled the commission's decisions approving coronavirus-related state aid to Dutch KLM and 
Portuguese airline TAP. The EU's competition watchdog had not given enough reasons why it allowed the money to 
be paid out, the court ruled on Wednesday.
However, the effects of the annulment - including the order to pay back the aid - are suspended until the 
commission submits a new decision. Effectively, this means that the EU General Court's judges are giving the 
commission a chance to issue a more detailed decision.
The commission had green-lighted state support of 3.4 billion euros (4.15 billion dollars) for KLM and 1.2 billion 
euros for TAP.
Ryanair took the commission to court in a slew of cases, arguing that this move distorted competition in the bloc.
While the court sided with Ryanair in the cases of KLM and TAP, it ruled that 10-billion-euro aid to "strategic 
Spanish undertakings experiencing temporary difficulties due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic" was 
appropriate.
Ryanair also lost similar cases related to Scandinavian SAS and Finnair last month, which a spokesperson said the 
company would appeal.
A Ryanair spokesperson welcomed Wednesday's decisions on TAP and KLM.
"Unless halted by the EU courts in line with today's rulings, this state aid spree will distort the market for decades to 
come," the spokesperson said.
Ryanair wins case at EU court challenging aid for competing airlines
European Commission spokesperson Daniel Ferrie said his institution would "carefully study" the judgement.
The judgement can be appealed to the bloc's highest court - the European Court of Justice.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 19, 2021
End of Document
Ryanair wins cases at EU court challenging aid for competing airlines
Ryanair wins cases at EU court challenging aid for competing airlines
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 19, 2021 Wednesday 3:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 349 words
Byline: Leonie Kijewski in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union's second highest court dealt a blow to the European Commission on Wednesday, ruling that 
two complaints by Ryanair about state aid to other airline companies was justified.
The court annulled the commission's decisions approving coronavirus-related state aid to Dutch KLM and 
Portuguese airline TAP. The EU's competition watchdog had not given enough reasons why it allowed the money to 
be paid out, the court ruled on Wednesday.
However, the effects of the annulment - including the order to pay back the aid - are suspended until the 
commission submits a new decision. Effectively, this means that the EU General Court's judges are giving the 
commission a chance to issue a more detailed decision.
The court gave the commission two months to do so, unless it reopens a formal investigation procedure - in which 
case the bloc's executive branch would get "a further reasonable period."
The commission had green-lighted state support of 3.4 billion euros (4.15 billion dollars) for KLM and 1.2 billion 
euros for TAP.
Ryanair took the commission to court in a slew of cases, arguing that this move distorted competition in the bloc.
While the court sided with Ryanair in the cases of KLM and TAP, it ruled that 10-billion-euro aid to "strategic 
Spanish undertakings experiencing temporary difficulties due to the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic" was 
appropriate.
Ryanair also lost similar cases related to Scandinavian SAS and Finnair last month, which a spokesperson said the 
company would appeal.
Ryanair wins cases at EU court challenging aid for competing airlines
A Ryanair spokesperson welcomed Wednesday's decisions on TAP and KLM.
"Unless halted by the EU courts in line with today's rulings, this state aid spree will distort the market for decades to 
come," the spokesperson said. "If Europe is to emerge from this crisis with a functioning single market, airlines must 
be allowed to compete on a level playing field."
European Commission spokesperson Daniel Ferrie said his institution would "carefully study" the judgement and 
decide on next possible steps.
The judgement can be appealed to the bloc's highest court - the European Court of Justice.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 19, 2021
End of Document
Ryanair reveals huge annual loss but expects vaccine-fuelled rebound
Ryanair reveals huge annual loss but expects vaccine-fuelled rebound
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 17, 2021 Monday 10:03 AM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 205 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, landed deep in the red in the past fiscal year due to the impact of the 
coronavirus pandemic on passenger numbers.
Ryanair posted a loss of 815 million euros (989 million dollars) over the 12 months that ended March 31, compared 
to a profit of just over 1 billion euros in the same period a year earlier, chief executive Michael O'Leary said in a 
presentation on Monday.
The airline's passenger traffic fell 81 per cent over the previous year, to 27.5 million.
For the current fiscal year, management believes in a result close to the break-even point, but would not risk a 
concrete forecast due to continuing uncertainty around the pandemic.
However, the overall expectation was that vaccination campaigns will be successful in Europe and governments will 
lift travel restrictions in time for the all-important summer season starting in July.
Looking forward to the next 12 months, Ryanair sees a rebound in traffic in the second half of the year and expects 
total passenger numbers for the period to be at the lower end of its issued target range of 80 million to 120 million 
passengers.
In the current first fiscal quarter to the end of June, the figure is expected to be just 5 to 6 million.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, <international@dpa.com; 
Load-Date: May 17, 2021

MONDAY, MAY 17

restaurants can host guests inside, subject to social distancing rules; and entertainment venues such as cinemas, 
museums and concerts can reopen to limited numbers

nightly shutdowns

in China's Xinjiang region

Ryanair loses EU court challenge to state aid for competitor airlines
Ryanair loses EU court challenge to state aid for competitor airlines
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 14, 2021 Wednesday 1:08 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 196 words
Dateline: Luxemburg (dpa) - 
Body
The Irish budget flight company Ryanair was handed a duo of defeats at the European Union's General Court in 
lawsuits against state bailouts for competitor airlines on Wednesday.
The millions of euros in coronavirus-related economic aid provided to Scandinavian airline SAS by Sweden and 
Denmark, and to Finnair by the Finnish government was in line with EU law, judges at the Luxembourg-based court 
found.
Ryanair immediately announced it would appeal the two rulings at the bloc's highest court, the European Court of 
Justice.
The company had challenged decisions by the European Commission - which oversees competition in the single 
market - to approve the aid packages.
But the EU judges found that the measures taken to prop up SAS were proportionate.
In the case of Finnair, they noted above all that a possible default would have had a considerable impact on 
Finland's economic health.In both cases, the state aid was found to be appropriate to achieve the objective 
pursued.In recent months, Ryanair has taken several state aid cases to the bloc's high court Court of Justice. In 
February, the company already failed in legal action against aid granted by France and Sweden.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: April 14, 2021
Ryanair loses EU court challenge to state aid for competitor airlines
End of Document

Ryanair pledges 2,300 flights a week during the summer holidays
Ryanair pledges 2,300 flights a week during the summer holidays
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 24, 2021 Wednesday 4:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 228 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair vowed on Wednesday to return to a near-normal summer schedule this year by flying 2,300 flights a week 
from Britain to Europe.
The Irish discount airline said it will be running the flights across 480 routes and is also launching 26 new routes, 
including from London to the Greek islands of Santorini and Zakynthos, this summer.
The schedule means that Ryanair would be running at about 80 per cent of its usual capacity.
Chief executive Michael O'Leary said that, because of the government's successful vaccine roll-out, Britain is "on 
track" for a reopening of European short-haul flights.
He also said passengers may be asked to wear face masks on Ryanair flights until 2022.
"I would imagine at this point in time, we're planning to continue to require mandatory face mask-wearing on board 
our aircraft through the remainder of this summer schedule and next winter's schedule," he said.
But while Britons may be keen to book a summer getaway, the British prime minister has been more cautious.
Boris Johnson has repeatedly been cagey regarding whether or not people should book overseas holidays, stating 
it is "too early" to tell.
In a briefing to journalists on Tuesday, he said "things certainly look difficult for the time being" and added that more 
detail would be revealed on April 5 - the next review date of whether England can lift restrictions as planned.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair pledges 2,300 flights a week during the summer holidays
Load-Date: March 24, 2021
End of Document
Irish human rights commission says Covid curbs raise serious concerns
Irish human rights commission says Covid curbs raise serious concerns
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 25, 2021 Thursday 12:45 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 288 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Ireland's Human Rights and Equality Commission on Thursday accused the government of having "persistently 
blurred the boundary between legal requirements and public health guidance in its Covid-19 response."
In a report co-authored with academics from Dublin's Trinity College, the commission said that "parliamentary 
oversight of Ireland's emergency legislation has been lacking."
On Tuesday the government announced that a third lockdown, imposed in late December to stem what became 
a record-breaking spike in novel coronavirus cases, will be extended until at least April 5.
While not giving any end date for restrictions, Prime Minister Micheal Martin said "the end is in truly in sight," citing 
vaccinations.
The commission, an independent public body, said that the government's "making and presentation of regulations 
raises serious rule-of-law concerns."
Sinead Gibney, the chief commissioner, criticized "the systems that implement and scrutinize these decisions," 
while Trinity College's Oran Doyle accused the government of blurring legal obligations and public health advice.
Ireland's police said last week around 8,000 fines had been issued for alleged breaches of the restrictions. The 
commission said "public health guidance" should not be enforced "as if it were law."
Ireland's pandemic restrictions are among the harshest anywhere, according to a University of Oxford 
database. Non-essential travel is limited to within 5 kilometres of a person's home, most pubs have been closed 
since March last year, and public religious services are banned.
Airline Ryanair last year lost a court case challenging the government's travel restrictions. A case filed against the 
worship ban was adjourned for a fourth time this week.
Irish human rights commission says Covid curbs raise serious concerns
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: February 25, 2021
End of Document

Ryanair 'Jab and Go' advert is 'misleading and irresponsible'
Ryanair 'Jab and Go' advert is 'misleading and irresponsible'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 3, 2021 Wednesday 00:01:01+01:00Invalid date found for VDI: (VDI not available) XCEDOCID: 4 LNI: 
61X7-7BW1-JB0G-F30W-00000-00. Date output 'as-is'. GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 257 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
An advertisement published by Irish airline Ryanair which said people could have a "jab" and then "go" on holiday 
has been pulled by Britain's advertising watchdog.
The Advertising Standards Agency (ASA) said it received 2,370 complaints about Ryanair's advert, aired between 
December 26 and January 3, making it the third most complained about advertisement of all time.
The ad was broadcast on television and depicted a syringe with a text saying "vaccines are coming."
A voiceover followed, stating: "Covid vaccines are coming. So book your Easter and summer holidays today with 
Ryanair. One million seats on sale from 19.99 pounds (27 dollars) to sunshine destinations in Spain, Italy, Portugal, 
Greece and many more. So you could jab and go!" 
Viewers who complained said that the advertisement implied most of the population would be successfully 
vaccinated against Covid-19 by the spring or summer of 2021 and would be able to travel.
They added the adverts were misleading, irresponsible and found the phrase "jab and go" offensive.
After an investigation, the ASA upheld the claims the advert was misleading and irresponsible but said it was not 
offensive under its rules.
Ryanair told dpa it "respectfully disagrees" with the ASA's decision, describing the advert as "factual and accurate" 
as vaccines were being rolled out.
"The ASA's ruling flies in the face of the UK's successful vaccine rollout, however even though this ruling is 
baseless, Ryanair will comply with it and the Jab & Go adverts will not run again," a spokesperson added.
Ryanair 'Jab and Go' advert is 'misleading and irresponsible'
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: February 2, 2021
End of Document

EU flight safety agency to approve Boeing 's 737 Max jet
EU flight safety agency to approve Boeing's 737 Max jet
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 19, 2021 Tuesday 2:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 408 words
Byline: Steffen Weyer, dpa-AFX, and Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) is expected to approve Boeing's crisis-ridden 737 Max jet, 
enabling it to return to the skies in the coming days.
The approval was expected next week, after changes made to the plane model fulfilled flight safety conditions, 
EASA executive director Patrick Ky said in an online press conference on Tuesday.
The fleet of medium-haul jets was grounded in March 2019, after two 737 Max crashes due to faulty steering 
software in which a total of 346 people died.
The 737 Max has since been approved again in the United States and Brazil.
In Canada, the grounding of the aircraft is to be lifted this Wednesday, following an announcement by the local 
aviation authority Transport Canada. The airline Air Canada has said it will begin using the jet again from February 
1.
Before the 737 Max returns to Europe, pilot training has to be completed, Ky said.
The special 737 Max 200 ordered by low-cost carrier Ryanair will be certified in the coming weeks and be ready for 
the summer, he added.
Boeing had aimed to fix the problems following the first of the two crashes.
However, further defects were uncovered, meaning that it ultimately took around 20 months for the US Federal 
Aviation Administration (FAA) to lift the flight ban for that country in mid-November.
Ky said there had been full transparency from the FAA and Boeing after the accidents.
EU flight safety agency to approve Boeing 's 737 Max jet
The EASA chief said the European regulator had also tested the jet without the controversial MCAS software. The 
737 Max would be "a plan that flies safely without MCAS," he said.
The first of the two crashes occurred shortly after take-off from Jakarta on October 29, 2018, and killed all 189 
people on board.
The second occurred in March the following year, shortly after take-off from Addis Ababa. That crash killed all 157 
people on board.
In both cases, a sensor provided incorrect data to the software, prompting the nose to dive. Pilots were unable to 
override the automatic settings.
The new version of the software is to be fed data from two sensors. In addition, pilots are to receive training on how 
to recognize when faulty data is being delivered, Ky said.
EASA had also demanded the installation of a third sensor known as a synthetic sensor, which is yet to be 
developed.
In the long version of the jet series, the 737 Max 10, which has not yet been certified, this is to be mandatory from 
the outset. In other models, it is to be retrofitted at a later date.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 19, 2021
End of Document
European air traffic controllers predict slow recovery over 2021
European air traffic controllers predict slow recovery over 2021
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 4, 2021 Monday 5:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2021 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 237 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
European air traffic controllers are anticipating a slow recovery from the coronavirus pandemic in the aviation sector 
this year, according to an analysis published in Brussels on Monday.
The European Organization for the Safety of Air Navigation (EUROCONTROL) predicts flights and passengers at 
just 51 per cent of pre-crisis levels, following the cancellation of around 6.1 million flights and the loss of 1.7 billion 
passengers last year.
While airlines were the main beneficiaries of state assistance over the course of 2020, airports would be heavily 
reliant on state subsidies over the year ahead, the organization said.
"We're confident that the recovery will start to firm up in 2021 as the vaccine rolls out across the globe. However, 
it's clear that the entire aviation sector will continue to need financial support in the years ahead," EUROCONTROL 
director general Eamonn Brennan said.
According to the analysis, the Lufthansa Group had to cancel 67 per cent of its flights, as had Easyjet. IAG, which 
operates British Airways and Iberia, lost 65 per cent of its flights.
Ryanair flew 59 per cent fewer flights than in 2019 and Air France/KLM 55 per cent fewer.
Frankfurt lost its top spot in handling flights to Amsterdam, where the decline was lower.
At the end of the year, some 51 per cent of European airlines' fleets were grounded, totalling 4,118 of 8,048 planes. 
In April, the figure reached a peak of 87 per cent.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
European air traffic controllers predict slow recovery over 2021
Load-Date: January 4, 2021
End of Document
Ryanair strikes crisis deal with German flight attendants
Ryanair strikes crisis deal with German flight attendants
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 23, 2020 Wednesday 2:43 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 213 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair has struck a deal with German flight attendants regarding pay cuts during the coronavirus crisis, the Irish 
budget airline and the German trade union Verdi said on Wednesday.
Ryanair said the deal encompasses moderate pay cuts to preserve jobs in Germany, following a similar agreement 
with German pilots.
Verdi representative Susana Pereira spoke of a very difficult decision for employees, although they ultimately 
consented.
The deal between Verdi and Ryanair's subsidiary Malta Air shields cabin employees from being fired due to 
operational reasons for the duration of the short-time work scheme.
Short-time work means employees are forced to reduce their hours and accept lower pay, while the government 
usually makes up part of the lost wages.
The 500 concerned employees agreed to renounce a planned increase in pay rates, a Verdi spokesperson said.
Both sides also agreed to extend a social plan until after the crisis.
The duration of the deal was left open, as well as the question of state subsidies.
Malta Air reiterated its calls for government support for its employees while they are on short-time work.
A row regarding state support of Malta Air's employees has been going on for half a year, as it is disputed whether 
Malta Air has business activity in Germany.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Laura Dubois, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair strikes crisis deal with German flight attendants
Load-Date: December 23, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair orders additional 75 Boeing 737 Max aircraft
Ryanair orders additional 75 Boeing 737 Max aircraft
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 4, 2020 Friday 4:08 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 255 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair on Thursday signed a deal with Boeing for 75 of the manufacturer's MAX-8200 aircraft, 
increasing a previous order for the aircraft from 135 to 210.
The Irish airline said the deal was worth a total of 22 billion dollars.
"Now that the Boeing MAX aircraft has been certified by the FAA to return to service, Ryanair expects to take the 
first deliveries of these new fuel efficient and environmentally friendly aircraft from early 2021," the budget airline 
said.
The order is set to be delivered over a 4-year period ending in December 2024.
The EU's Aviation Safety Agency (EASA) last week announced Boeing's troubled 737 MAX will be allowed to take 
to the skies over Europe again from mid-January.
The decision follows the green light given to the aircraft by the US Federal Aviation Administration (FASA).
EASA is leaving open a window of four weeks for public comment on its decision, with a final ruling expected from 
the middle of January next year.
The decision follows numerous hardware and software changes and the retraining of pilots on the 737 MAX.
The aircraft was grounded in March 2019 following the death of 346 people in two accidents, one in Indonesia in 
October 2018 and another in Ethiopia in March 2019.
The main cause of the accidents was considered to be faulty control software that directed the jets towards the 
ground. Pilots were unable to overpower the automatic settings.
Ryanair orders additional 75 Boeing 737 Max aircraft
During the relicensing procedure, EASA acted in concert with the FAA and Boeing, but took its own independent 
decision.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Helen Corbett, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: December 3, 2020
End of Document

Ryanair posts 226-million-euro loss in Q2 as pandemic wears on
Ryanair posts 226-million-euro loss in Q2 as pandemic wears on
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 2, 2020 Monday 11:04 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 141 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair has posted a 226-million-euro (263-million-dollar) net loss for the second quarter of the 
financial year as the coronavirus pandemic continued to weigh on passenger numbers.
The announcement on Monday marks a sharp contrast to the same July-to-September period the previous year, 
when Ryanair record a profit of 910 million euros.
Ryanair's chief exectuve Michael O'Leary said that overall losses for the first half of the financial year - 411 million 
euros - were less red ink than the airline expects for the second half of the financial year.
O'Leary added that though the company currently expects passenger volume to reach 38 million during the entire 
financial year, it was impossible to give a prognosis considering the measures that are being imposed by national 
governments to contain the second wave of the pandemic.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 2, 2020
End of Document
Berlin's long-delayed BER airport to open as pandemic bites
Berlin's long-delayed BER airport to open as pandemic bites
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 31, 2020 Saturday 6:05 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 254 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
The German capital is set to launch its new Berlin-Brandenburg Airport on Saturday, but without much fanfare as 
the coronavirus crisis presents the long-delayed project with its biggest challenge yet.
The airport, known by its three-letter code BER, is intended to overhaul the city's ageing air transport infrastructure.
The opening comes nine years behind schedule, while the budget has roughly tripled to 5.96 billion euros (7.04 
billion dollars) over the course of the new airport's already long history of setbacks and construction gaffes.
The pandemic has also added to spiralling costs for the state-backed operator of the airport.
The company is getting an additional 300 million euros from federal and state governments to get the airport 
through this crisis year, with another loan of around 550 million euros promised for next year.
Due to the economic uncertainty unleashed by the crisis, it remains unclear when the airport will become profitable.
Saturday's launch will apply only to Terminal 1; a recently finished Terminal 2 will not be needed initially after 
passenger numbers plunged to just 20 per cent of the 100,000 flyers that usually pass through Berlin's airports 
daily.
BER has incorporated Schoenefeld Airport, also located on the south-eastern outskirts of Berlin, as its Terminal 5.
Berlin's other airport, Tegel, located north-west of the city centre, is scheduled to close on November 8.
Two planes, from Easyjet and Ryanair, are set to become the first to land at the new airport at around 2 pm (1300 
GMT).
Editorial contactsEditing by: Josie Le Blond, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Berlin's long-delayed BER airport to open as pandemic bites
Load-Date: October 31, 2020

Italy regulator: Ryanair agrees to reimburse cancelled flights
Italy regulator: Ryanair agrees to reimburse cancelled flights
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 23, 2020 Friday 10:24 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 105 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Italian regulators said on Friday they had convinced four low-cost airlines, including Ryanair, to give refunds - rather 
than just vouchers - for flights cancelled due to the coronavirus.
The Italian competition authority (AGCM) said it would no longer pursue an antitrust probe against Ryanair, 
easyJet, Vueling and Blue Panorama, since they complied with its requests.
As well as giving the option of a refund, the four airlines also agreed to allow free-of-charge access to their 
customer services and increase staffing at their call centres, the authority said.
AGCM had started proceedings against the carriers in late September.

Ryanair cuts winter schedule due to drop in bookings
Ryanair cuts winter schedule due to drop in bookings
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 15, 2020 Thursday 10:30 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 170 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair is to reduce its winter flight schedule due to coronavirus travel restrictions and a significant 
drop in bookings.
Ryanair plans to take down its capacity to 40 per cent between November and March compared to last year, the 
carrier announced in a statement on Thursday.
Ryanair had originally planned to reduce its capacity to only 60 per cent, but a further drop in bookings prompted 
the additional cut, the company said.
It added it was expecting to operate at 70-per-cent capacity, compared to 95-per-cent capacity in 2019.
"While the Covid situation remains fluid and hard to predict, we must now cut our full year traffic forecast to 38 
million guests," Ryanair's CEO Michael O'Leary said in a statement.
Last year, Ryanair and its subsidiaries carried 149 million passengers.
O'Leary accused EU governments of mismanaging air travel during the coronavirus crisis. He urged them to 
implement the European Union's traffic-light system, which allows for travel between regions with low infection 
rates.
