Despite losing, Ryanair welcomes Irish court ruling on pandemic rules
Despite losing, Ryanair welcomes Irish court ruling on pandemic rules
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 2, 2020 Friday 4:56 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 463 words
Byline: Simon Roughneen in Dublin
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Airline Ryanair has endorsed a Friday judgement by Ireland's High Court that the government's pandemic travel 
measures are advisory rather than mandatory.
Despite losing the case, Ryanair said in a statement it "welcomes" the decision as it "confirms there is no legal 
requirement for the current travel restrictions."
Backed by Aer Lingus, formerly Ireland's state airline, Ryanair sued the government in July over travel guidelines it 
claimed were presented as "mandatory" and were imposed without parliamentary oversight.
Ruling that the guidelines are neither compulsory nor an abuse of power, Justice Garrett Simons said on Friday 
that "advice to avoid non-essential travel and to restrict movement on entry to the state is just that: advice."
According to the Department of the Taoiseach, or prime minister, anyone travelling from countries other than those 
on the government's "green list" are "requested" to "restrict their movements for 14 days" by "staying indoors in one 
location." 
The list of exempted countries is down to effectively three - Cyprus, Finland, Latvia. Liechtenstein, which does not 
have an airport, is also on the list, which was last changed in late September with the removal of Germany, Poland, 
Lithuania and Iceland.
The rules do not apply to Northern Ireland, which is part of the UK and where authorities on Friday announced a 
daily record of 934 cases of the coronavirus.
Ryanair has announced two 20-percent capacity cuts since August and on Friday repeated a warning that it will 
close two Irish bases, including in the second-biggest city Cork, unless the government ditches its list and "adopts 
the EU 'traffic light' system," which would exempt 15 countries from the self-isolation request.
Despite losing, Ryanair welcomes Irish court ruling on pandemic rules
"The Irish government needs to open back up," Ryanair CEO Eddie Wilson told Dublin broadcaster Newstalk ahead 
of Friday's court ruling. 
Ryanair previously accused the government of keeping Ireland "locked up like North Korea."
Some of Ireland's domestic restrictions have dragged on for longer than elsewhere in Europe, with all pubs only 
allowed to reopen on September 21, and a ban on attending religious services reintroduced in Dublin after a recent 
rise in daily case numbers.
Official figures show 117 people in hospital after testing positive for the virus, an increase from 10 two months ago.
With travel slow to pick up after lockdowns were mostly ended across Europe in May and June, Ryanair said 
separately on Friday that its September traffic dropped by 64 per cent year-on-year, with only 5.1 million "guests" 
flying last month and only half of scheduled flights taking off.
Data collated by the World Tourism Organization, a United Nations agency, show tourism in Europe to be the 
second-worst hit after the Asia-Pacific by pandemic-related curbs.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 2, 2020
End of Document
Court rules against Ryanair challenge to Irish pandemic travel curbs
Court rules against Ryanair challenge to Irish pandemic travel curbs
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 2, 2020 Friday 2:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair's claim that Ireland's pandemic-related travel measures are illegal was dismissed by the country's High 
Court on Friday.
Backed by the airline Aer Lingus, Ryanair had argued that the measures were imposed without parliamentary 
approval and were presented by the Irish government as "mandatory."
However the court ruled that the framework was neither mandatory nor an abuse of power.
"The advice to avoid non-essential travel and to restrict movement on entry to the state is just that: advice," said 
Justice Garrett Simons.
According to the Department of the Taoiseach, or prime minister, inbound travellers from countries other than those 
on the government's "Green List" are advised to "restrict their movements for 14 days" by "staying indoors in one 
location."
The list was on Monday cut to just Cyprus, Finland, Latvia and Liechtenstein.
With travel slow to pick up after lockdowns were mostly ended in Europe in June, Ryanair, the continent's biggest 
airline, said on Friday that September traffic dropped by 64 per cent, compared to last year, to 5.1 million guests. 
Only half of scheduled flights were operated.
On Thursday, Ryanair warned of the imminent closure of two Irish bases, including in the second-biggest city Cork, 
if the government did not align its rules with the rest of the European Union by October 13.
"The Irish government needs to open back up," Ryanair CEO Eddie Wilson told broadcaster Newstalk ahead 
of Friday's court ruling.
Court rules against Ryanair challenge to Irish pandemic travel curbs

Low-cost airlines investigated in Italy for Covid-19 cancellations
Low-cost airlines investigated in Italy for Covid-19 cancellations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 25, 2020 Friday 11:12 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 155 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Four low-cost airlines, including Ryanair, are facing an antitrust probe in Italy for failing to reimburse flights 
cancelled on account of the coronavirus pandemic.
The carriers offered vouchers rather than full refunds, in a "possible breach" of EU regulations on air passengers' 
rights, the Italian competition authority (AGCM) said in a statement on Friday.
Vueling, easyJet and Blue Panorama are the three other airlines targeted by AGCM's investigation.
The authority noted that even though the pandemic was given as the reason for cancellations, the flights in question 
were scheduled for after the end of Italy's lockdown period.
The airlines were also accused of failing to inform customers about their cancellation rights, and providing "onerous 
and poor" customer service via an expensive and "hard-to-reach" phone helpline.
ACGM said it launched similar investigations in July against two other airlines, Alitalia and Volotea.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 25, 2020
End of Document
UN data shows Asia-Pacific tourism worst-hit by pandemic travel curbs
UN data shows Asia-Pacific tourism worst-hit by pandemic travel curbs
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 24, 2020 Thursday 4:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 286 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
International travel has plummeted during the pandemic, with nowhere worse affected than the Asia-Pacific region, 
data released by the United Nations tourism body showed on Thursday.
International tourist arrivals across the region dropped 72 per cent in 2020, according to data compiled by the World 
Tourism Organization (UNWTO), the worst decline seen around the world.
In the month of June, international tourist arrivals to the region plummeted 99 per cent year-on-year in the wake of 
pandemic era travel bans, UNWTO's new Tourism Recovery Tracker shows.
China, Japan and South Korea were worst hit by the drop in global travel, with North-East Asia seeing an 83 per 
cent drop in tourist arrivals as most countries prohibited all but essential travel.
South-East Asia, where countries remain largely closed to foreign tourists -  and some, such as Malaysia, have 
effectively barred citizens from leaving - saw arrivals fall by 64 per cent. 
Around 7 per cent of Malaysia's 2019 gross domestic product (GDP) was derived from international tourism. In 
neighbouring Thailand, that figure usually tops 10 per cent, whereas Cambodia's is nearer to 20.
Europe ranks as the second-worst hit region on the UNWTO tracker, registering a 66-per-cent decline in arrivals 
despite an uptick after many restrictions were eased in June.
The UNWTO last month slammed governments for "timid" efforts to revive tourism despite worldwide losses 
estimated at 460 billion dollars - equivalent to Austria's GDP - in the period to June alone.
Airlines have echoed UNWTO criticisms, with Ryanair, Europe's biggest carrier, last week saying pandemic-related 
travel rules had forced it to cut capacity by 20 per cent for the second time in two months.
UN data shows Asia-Pacific tourism worst-hit by pandemic travel curbs
Editorial contactsEditing by: Josie Le Blond, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 24, 2020
End of Document
Worst-hit by pandemic travel curbs, Asia sees domestic tourism grow
Worst-hit by pandemic travel curbs, Asia sees domestic tourism grow
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 24, 2020 Thursday 6:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 418 words
Byline: Simon Roughneen in Dublin
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
International travel has plummeted during the pandemic, with nowhere worse affected than the Asia-Pacific region, 
according to United Nations tourism body data.
International arrivals across the Asia-Pacific have dropped 72 per cent so far in 2020, according to the data, which 
was compiled for the Madrid-based World Tourism Organization's (UNWTO) new Tourism Recovery Tracker.
The region's June arrivals were down 99 per cent year-on-year, a standstill that came after countries imposed strict 
lockdowns and holiday bans aimed at slowing the spread of the novel coronavirus.
China, Japan and South Korea were among the worst affected, with the UNWTO tracker showing an 83-per-cent 
drop in tourist arrivals across north-east Asia as most countries prohibited all but essential travel.
South-east Asia, where countries remain largely closed to foreign tourists - and some, such as Malaysia, have 
effectively barred citizens from leaving - saw arrivals fall by 64 per cent. 
Around 7 per cent of Malaysia's 2019 gross domestic product (GDP) was derived from international tourism. In 
neighbouring Thailand, that figure usually tops 10 per cent, whereas Cambodia's is nearer to 20.
Asian governments are now promoting internal travel in an attempt to shore up the sector, with Singapore earlier 
this month offering 100-dollar domestic tourism vouchers to residents.
Tony Fernandes, chief executive of Air Asia, one Asia's biggest low-cost airlines, said on Thursday that "our 
domestic routes like in Thailand and Malaysia, we are at about 70 per cent load capacity."
"Business travel, intercontinental travel, first-class travel is going to take longer to rebound," Fernandes said during 
a press conference in Kuala Lumpur.
Worst-hit by pandemic travel curbs, Asia sees domestic tourism grow
After the Asia-Pacific, Europe was the second worst-hit region, UNWTO data show. A 66-per-cent overall decline in 
arrivals was registered - though a revival began after restrictions were eased around the continent in June.
No region has seen tourism fall by less than half, the UNWTO tracker shows, with South America registering the 
least-worst performance to date with a 56 per cent decline.
The UNWTO last month slammed governments for their "timid" efforts to revive tourism, citing worldwide losses 
estimated at 460 billion dollars - equivalent to Austria's GDP - for the first half of 2020.
Airlines have echoed UNWTO's criticism, with Ryanair, Europe's biggest carrier, last week saying pandemic-related 
travel rules had forced it to cut capacity by 20 per cent for the second time in two months.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 24, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair to cut capacity by 20 per cent, blames pandemic travel rules
Ryanair to cut capacity by 20 per cent, blames pandemic travel rules
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 18, 2020 Friday 1:16 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 188 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair said on Friday that it will slash capacity by 20 per cent in October, blaming coronavirus travel curbs 
introduced at short notice.
Dublin-based Ryanair, Europe's biggest airline, said "EU government travel restrictions and policies" aimed at 
stopping the spread of the novel coronavirus "undermine consumers' willingness to make forward bookings."
Announcing its second 20 per cent capacity reduction since August, Ryanair accused the Irish government of 
keeping the country "locked up like North Korea" and of operating "a defective" quarantine system that 
means arrivals from most countries, some with lower infection rates than Ireland, are expected to self-isolate for 14 
days.
Supported by Aer Lingus, Ireland's flag carrier airline, Ryanair has taken the government to court over the curbs, 
which will not be aligned with EU guidelines until mid-October.
On Wednesday, lawyers representing the government told Ireland's High Court that the measures are not 
mandatory.
The government on Thursday cut Italy and Greece from its "green list" of countries from where arrivals are not 
expected to self-isolate but added Germany.

EU officials green-light 200-million-euro Italian grant for Alitalia
EU officials green-light 200-million-euro Italian grant for Alitalia
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 4, 2020 Friday 5:30 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission gave its blessing on Friday to a grant worth just under 200 million euros (236 million 
dollars) from the Italian state for ailing flight company Alitalia to compensate damages arising from the coronavirus.
The measure is in line with the European Union's state aid rules, the bloc's executive arm - which acts as an 
antitrust watchdog - said in a press release.
"The aviation industry is one of the sectors that has been hit particularly hard by the coronavirus outbreak," EU 
Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager said in the statement.
The size of the grant corresponds to losses sustained by the embattled company between March 1 and June 15 
due to Covid-19 restrictions, according to the commission, which added that the measure reflected the 
extraordinary circumstances and was proportionate.
"Our investigations into past support measures to Alitalia are ongoing and we are in contact with Italy on their plans 
and compliance with EU rules," Vestager said.
The commission is already looking into 900 million euros in loans granted by Italy to the company in 2017, and a 
separate loan of 400 million euros from 2019.
State support for hard-hit aviation companies during the pandemic has raised eyebrows among competing firms 
such as Ryanair, but also among environmentalists, who argue polluting industries should not be propped up.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, +49 30 285231472, international@dpa.com
Load-Date: September 4, 2020
EU officials green-light 200-million-euro Italian grant for Alitalia

British police have detained two men on suspicion of terrorism at London's Stansted airport after their arrival on 
Sunday.

police said.
Two RAF Typhoon jet fighters were scrambled to intercept the passenger jet.
A Ryanair spokesman quoted by the Press Association news agency said the flight crew had been alerted to a 
"potential security threat on board."
Monday's Daily Express reported that "suspicious objects" were found in an onboard toilet, but did not offer further 
details.

British police release two after mobile phone found in plane toilet
British police release two after mobile phone found in plane toilet
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 31, 2020 Monday 4:42 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 151 words
Byline: Silvia Kusidlo in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Two men have been released without charge following a security scare after a mobile phone was found in an 
airplane toilet, British police said on Monday.
The two - a 34-year-old Kuwaiti national and a 48-year-old Italian - were arrested after their arrival on Sunday on a 
Ryanair flight from Vienna at London's Stansted airport.
They were initially arrested on suspicion of terrorism.
The suspicious object that triggered the scare was a mobile phone, the Press Association news agency reported.
"We understandably take any reports of suspicious objects or behaviour on flights very seriously and thankfully on 
this occasion there was no cause for concern," said Andy Waldie of the Counter Terrorism Policing unit, PA 
reported.
Two RAF Typhoon jet fighters were scrambled to intercept the passenger jet.
A Ryanair spokesman had earlier said the flight crew had been alerted to a "potential security threat on board."

Ryanair cuts 20 per cent of autumn flights amid new quarantine rules
Ryanair cuts 20 per cent of autumn flights amid new quarantine rules
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 17, 2020 Monday 4:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 191 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair on Monday said it plans to cut 20 per cent of regular flights in September and October after 
several European nations reimposed Covid-19 quarantine rules for arrivals.
The reduction in flight capacity comes after forward bookings "notably weakened over the last 10 days, given 
continuing uncertainty over recent Covid case rates in some EU countries," the airline said.
Most of the cuts will be reductions in frequency rather than suspension of routes, it said.
They will focus on countries including Spain, France, Sweden and Ireland.
Ireland has imposed a "uniquely restrictive Green List" that requires visitors from most other EU nations, including 
those with lower recent infection rates, Ryanair said.
"Proper testing at airports, and effective tracing - as is being conducted in Germany and Italy - is the only realistic 
and proportionate method of supervising safe intra-EU air travel while effectively limiting the spread of the Covid-19 
virus," a spokesperson said.
Britain, one of Ryanair's biggest markets, has reimposed a 14-day self-isolation requirement for arrivals from 
countries including Spain, France and Sweden.

Amsterdam, Brussels airports introduce mobile coronavirus testing
Amsterdam, Brussels airports introduce mobile coronavirus testing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 13, 2020 Thursday 4:20 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 378 words
Byline: Leonie Kijewski in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The main airports in Amsterdam and Brussels are rolling out mobile coronavirus testing points for passengers in an 
effort to curb the pandemic.
In Amsterdam, passengers on some flights returning from countries deemed high risk in terms of infections can be 
tested for free as of Thursday.
This includes passengers without symptoms, the public health authority announced. The test results are to be 
available within 48 hours.
Testing capacity is currently limited at the Dutch airport, but the health authority plans to offer up to 600 tests a day 
as soon as possible, it said in a press release.
People are not required to undergo testing on returning to the Netherlands for legal reasons, the health authority 
said.
In a similar approach, Brussels Airport in neighbouring Belgium announced on Thursday that it would roll out mobile 
testing in early September.
Passengers returning from countries or areas designated as belonging to a red zone - meaning they are deemed 
high risk by the Belgian authorities - can be tested at the airport.
At the mobile testing stations, "passengers returning from a red zone can be tested immediately upon arrival at 
Brussels Airport," Arnaud Feist, who heads Brussels Airport Company, said in a press release.
Unlike in the Netherlands, people returning to Belgium from high-risk areas are required to undergo testing.
Amsterdam, Brussels airports introduce mobile coronavirus testing
Passengers returning from high-risk areas are to be charged 47 euros (56 dollars) for the virus test.
Departing passengers can also be tested, but would pay higher fees. Those undergoing standard testing, with the 
results available some nine hours later, would pay 67 euros. Faster testing is also to be offered, with the results 
available in three hours, for 135 euros.
Charleroi Airport, Brussels' second airport with flights mainly offered by Ryanair and Wizzair, has not announced 
similar measures.
More and more airports are offering mobile testing for the virus. While some places such as Singapore introduced 
testing for passengers with symptoms as early as March, Germany started offering tests free of charge for 
passengers on Saturday.
While international flights ground to a halt in March and April, Europe's summer holiday season has seen an 
increase in air travel - and a corresponding rise in the number of cases.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams Tel: +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 13, 2020
End of Document
Brussels Airport to introduce mobile coronavirus testing
Brussels Airport to introduce mobile coronavirus testing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 13, 2020 Thursday 2:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 154 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Brussels Airport will introduce mobile labs for coronavirus tests for passengers at the beginning of September, it 
announced on Thursday.
Passengers returning from a red zone - countries or regions that Belgium deems to carry a high risk for coronavirus 
infections - will be able to get tested at the airport.
"There passengers returning from a red zone can be tested immediately upon arrival at Brussels Airport," Arnaud 
Feist, the boss of Brussels Airport Company, said in a press release.
The test for arriving passengers that must be tested will cost about 47 euros (56 dollars).
Departing passengers can also get tested, albeit at a higher cost: 67 euros for a standard test for which results will 
be available within about 9 hours, or 135 euros for a rapid test with results being available within 3 hours.
Charleroi Airport, Brussels second airport that caters mainly to Ryanair and Wizzair, has not announced similar 
measures.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell  Tel: +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 13, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair sinks into the red in 'most challenging' quarter
Ryanair sinks into the red in 'most challenging' quarter
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 27, 2020 Monday 9:59 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 260 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost Irish carrier Ryanair on Monday reported a first quarter net loss in a business period it said was "the most 
challenging in Ryanair's 35-year history," the wake of the coronavirus pandemic.
The net loss of 185 million euros (216 million dollars) in the April-to-June period, compared with a net profit of 243 
million euros in the corresponding period a year ago.
Revenue plunged 95 per cent to 125 million euros in the quarter that ended on June 30. Cost-saving measures 
could not offset the revenue loss. A year ago, the airline's revenues were 2.31 billion euros.
The company noted that more than 99 per cent of its fleet was grounded from mid-March to the end of June amid 
travel bans introduced across Europe due to the pandemic. It flew 500,000 passengers, compared to last year's 
41.5 million passengers. 
Ryanair on July 1 resumed flights across most of its route network, and expected demand to slowly rise in the 
coming months, saying it hoped to reach 70 per cent of its normal schedule in September.
The airline expected a "very challenging year," adding that "a second wave of Covid-19 cases across Europe in late 
autumn (when the annual flu season commences) is our biggest fear right now."
Ryanair also repeated recent criticism of various European government bailout schemes to flag carriers, including 
Alitalia, Air France/KLM, and Lufthansa.
The low-cast carrier, which has not received similar financial support, said the schemes "distort competition and 
allow unsustainable flag carriers to engage in below cost selling for many years to come."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair sinks into the red in 'most challenging' quarter
Load-Date: July 27, 2020

Hundreds of job cuts planned at Berlin airports due to virus
Hundreds of job cuts planned at Berlin airports due to virus
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 22, 2020 Wednesday 4:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 327 words
Byline: Burkhard Fraune and Rachel More in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
The state-owned operator of Berlin's airports plans to cut 400 jobs, as the aviation industry reels from the effects of 
the coronavirus pandemic.
Significant cuts are necessary in the areas of administration and operations, according to a letter to employees 
seen by dpa on Wednesday.
"We estimate that 400 jobs will be cut in the next few years," airport chief Engelbert Luetke Daldrup and head of 
human resources Michael Halberstadt wrote.
The company currently employs around 2,170 people.
Dismissals for operational reasons are to be avoided "under all circumstances," the letter states, adding that senior 
executives and managing directors are to waive 10 per cent of their salary in a bid to cut costs.
Talks on job cuts are to get under way with the supervisory board, the works council and the Verdi union. A video 
conference is planned for Friday to give employees the opportunity to ask questions.
The Berlin airport operator, Flughafen Berlin Brandenburg GmbH, is not the only company in the air travel industry 
tightening its belt.
The operator of Frankfurt Airport, Germany's biggest air hub, expects to reduce its workforce of 22,500 by 3,000-
4,000 in the coming years.
Many airlines are also downsizing, including EasyJet, the biggest client for Berlin airports.
EasyJet intends to cut 30 per cent of its workforce worldwide and pull its aircraft out of Berlin.
Hundreds of job cuts planned at Berlin airports due to virus
On Tuesday, an internal memo seen by dpa said budget airline Ryanair plans to close its base at Frankfurt Hahn 
Airport and is considering doing the same in Berlin Tegel.
"Aviation and in turn airports are in the midst of the worst crisis in their history since World War II," the letter to 
Berlin airport employees said.
The German capital's two currently operating airports - a new one is scheduled to open after a long delay in 
October - are operating well below their usual capacity. Tegel and Schoenefeld airports have seen passenger 
numbers plummet to about 20-25 per cent of pre-crisis levels.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 22, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair to close Frankfurt Hahn hub, threatens further closures
Ryanair to close Frankfurt Hahn hub, threatens further closures
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 21, 2020 Tuesday 9:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 243 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair will shutter its base at Frankfurt Hahn Airport and is considering doing the same in Berlin 
Tegel and Weeze Airport near the Dutch border, Ryanair division Malta Air said in an internal memo seen by dpa on 
Tuesday.
The move comes after majority of German pilots voted against a proposed deal of savings including paycuts that 
Ryanair said were required because of disruption caused by the coronavirus pandemic.
"We must move on to deliver savings in other ways and adjust our German operations to tackle the unsustainable 
cost base at our German airports," the Malta Air memo said.
German pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) said late Tuesday that as many as 170 pilots could be affected by 
the decision, adding that negotiations with the airline had not been concluded.
The airline's British-based pilots accepted pay cuts of up to 20 per cent on July 8, with a similar deal announced in 
Ireland five days earlier.
Last week Ryanair announced it would cut "up to 1,000 flights" between Ireland and Britain during August and 
September, blaming the Irish government for its requirement that arrivals self-isolate for 14 days.
Described as Europe's largest airline, Ireland's Ryanair said in May that it would cut 3,000 jobs due to the 
pandemic, which has brought international travel to a near-standstill.
The virus has infected almost 15 million people and killed over 610,000, according to official figures collated by 
Johns Hopkins University.

Ryanair to close Frankfurt Hahn hub, threatens further closures

Passengers evacuated after bomb scare on Norwegian train
Passengers evacuated after bomb scare on Norwegian train
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 18, 2020 Saturday 2:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 96 words
Dateline: Copenhagen (dpa) - 
Body
A piece of paper that refereed to a bomb threat was found on a train about 60 kilometres north-east of Oslo, police 
in Norway said on Saturday.
The train, which was parked at a station in the municipality of Eidsvoll, was evacuated. Following a search, police 
found no evidence of any danger.
A similar threat occurred a day before on a Ryanair flight from London to the Norwegian capital.
The scare was prompted by a note found by crew on the flight. The plane landed safely, and a 51-year British 
citizen suspected of being behind the threat was arrested, but then later released.

A Ryanair flight has received a bomb threat while on its way to Norway, police said on Friday.
The flight has safely landed at Oslo airport, Norwegian police wrote on Twitter.
All passengers of the flight from London to Norway disembarked safely and were on their way to the terminal,

Ryanair group's Lauda closes Stuttgart base as pilots reject wage cut
Ryanair group's Lauda closes Stuttgart base as pilots reject wage cut
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 16, 2020 Thursday 8:52 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 257 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Budget carrier Lauda is giving up its German hub in Stuttgart and will terminate the contracts of all employees there 
after a majority of pilots opposed wage reductions, according to a company document obtained by dpa on 
Thursday.
The loss-making subsidiary of Irish-based Ryanair plans to close this base after the summer travel season on 
October 30.
While nearly all co-pilots and flight attendants in Stuttgart had agreed to a new collective labour contract that was 
drawn up in reaction to the pandemic-related aviation crisis, less than half of the captains gave their approval, the 
document said.
"Since there are no positions available elsewhere, we will not be able to offer any crew transfers" to other hubs, 
Lauda's Vienna-based management said in the paper that was initially made public by Austrian newspaper Der 
Standard.
A negotiator for the German labour union Verdi, Sven Bergelin, said Lauda would hopefully reconsider and would 
enter into talks to save jobs.
"Pilots and cabin crews want to be treated fairly and want to continue their work under acceptable standards," he 
said in a statement.
While Stuttgart is to be shuttered, a majority of pilots, co-pilots and flight attendants have accepted wage cuts in 
Lauda's other German base in Dusseldorf. Those who did not agree face possible lay-offs, according to Verdi.
Ryanair and Lauda's management had also threatened to lay off all staff in Vienna, but employees there agreed to 
a new wage deal in early June after Austrian unionists had managed to negotiate better conditions.
Ryanair group's Lauda closes Stuttgart base as pilots reject wage cut

European air traffic on the rise again after coronavirus lockdown
European air traffic on the rise again after coronavirus lockdown
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 13, 2020 Monday 1:44 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 122 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
More aeroplanes are flying in the skies above Europe as the air travel industry recovers from the coronavirus 
lockdown that almost brought it to its knees earlier in the year.
Over the course of the week ending on Sunday, the Eurocontrol organization for European aviation counted 90,549 
flights, up to 36.6 per cent of the levels seen during the same period last year.
Eurocontrol director general Eamonn Brennan spoke of "sustained traffic growth" in a tweet on Monday, noting that 
there was a rolling daily average of just under 13,000 flights.
That was 1,383 more than seen last week.
Irish budget airline Ryanair contributed significantly to the rise in traffic, offering on average 1,045 flights per day 
over the course of last week.

False fire alarm on Ryanair flight prompts emergency landing
False fire alarm on Ryanair flight prompts emergency landing
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 4, 2020 Saturday 4:04 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 117 words
Dateline: Athens (dpa) - 
Body
A Ryanair flight en route from Berlin to Athens had to make an unscheduled stop in Thessaloniki after a false fire 
alarm on Friday.
All passengers were well, according to Greek state radio ERT.
The pilot of the flight announced an emergency landing after a fire alarm went off in the cockpit while the aircraft 
was flying over the Greek port city of Thessaloniki.
An alarm was signalled at Thessaloniki airport and the plane landed without problems, the local news portal in the 
city reported.
The Irish airline Ryanair resumed around 40 per cent of its flights on July 1 after operating on a skeleton schedule 
since mid-March, due to the drop in demand and restrictions imposed from the coronavirus pandemic.

easyJet plans to close three British hubs, cut 4,500 jobs
easyJet plans to close three British hubs, cut 4,500 jobs
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 30, 2020 Tuesday 7:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline easyJet on Tuesday said it had opened consultations on the closure of three British hubs and cuts 
of around 30 per cent in its staff.
The airline said it had begun talks with trade unions on cuts affecting "all of its UK-based pilots and crew," following 
an announcement last month that it could cut up to 4,500 of its 15,000 staff.
The proposals include closing three of easyJet's 11 airport hubs in Britain: Stansted and Southend, both close to 
London in south-eastern England; and Newcastle in the north-east.
The consultations are designed "with the aim of minimizing job losses as far as possible," it said, citing expectations 
that passenger demand will not recover to 2019 levels until 2023.
"These are very difficult proposals to put forward in what is an unprecedented and difficult time for the airline, and 
the industry as a whole," said Johan Lundgren, easyJet's chief executive.
"We are focused on doing what is right for the company and its long-term health and success so we can protect 
jobs going forward," Lundgren said.
Other British-based airlines have announced possible staff cuts, including 12,000 at British Airways and 3,000 at 
Ryanair.
An airport industry group also warned last week that more than 20,000 jobs could be lost in Britain, with tens of 
thousands more at risk in businesses that indirectly depend upon airports.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee MurrayTel +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
easyJet plans to close three British hubs, cut 4,500 jobs

Unions slam 'over-reaction' as easyJet opens talks on 4,500 job cuts
Unions slam 'over-reaction' as easyJet opens talks on 4,500 job cuts
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 30, 2020 Tuesday 8:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 461 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Trade unions criticized low-cost airline easyJet on Tuesday as it opened consultations on the closure of three 
British hubs and cuts of around 30 per cent in its staff.
The airline said it had begun talks with trade unions on cuts affecting "all of its UK-based pilots and crew," following 
an announcement last month that it could cut up to 4,500 of its 15,000 staff.
The proposals include closing three of easyJet's 11 airport hubs in Britain: Stansted and Southend, both close to 
London in south-eastern England; and Newcastle in the north-east.
Brian Strutton, general secretary of pilots' trade union BALPA, accused the airline of "an excessive over-reaction" to 
the financial problems brought by the coronavirus pandemic.
Unite, which represents many easyJet cabin crew, said the announcement was a "massive blow."
EasyJet said the consultations are designed "with the aim of minimizing job losses as far as possible," citing 
expectations that passenger demand will not recover to 2019 levels until 2023.
"These are very difficult proposals to put forward in what is an unprecedented and difficult time for the airline, and 
the industry as a whole," said Johan Lundgren, easyJet's chief executive.
"We are focused on doing what is right for the company and its long-term health and success so we can protect 
jobs going forward," Lundgren said.
Oliver Richardson, a Unite national officer, said the cuts were "yet another massive blow to the aviation industry" 
and his thoughts are "with workers who face losing their jobs through no fault of their own."
Unions slam 'over-reaction' as easyJet opens talks on 4,500 job cuts
"There is no need for this announcement at this time, especially since easyJet has taken a multimillion-pounds 
government loan which it ought to be putting to use defending UK jobs," Richardson said.
Strutton said BALPA had been expecting easyJet to announce "temporary measures to help the airline through to 
recovery."
"But this seems an excessive over-reaction and easyJet won't find a supply of pilots waiting to come back when the 
recovery takes place over the next two years," he said.
"EasyJet paid 174 million pounds (214 million dollars) out to shareholders, got agreements to furlough staff to 
protect cash, got 600 million pounds from the government ... so why the panic?" Strutton asked.
"This is more evidence that aviation in the UK is caught in a death spiral of despair, and individual airlines are 
flailing around without direction," he said, urging the government to intervene in the industry.
Other British-based airlines have announced possible staff cuts, including 12,000 at British Airways and 3,000 at 
Ryanair.
An airport industry group also warned last week that more than 20,000 jobs could be lost in Britain, with tens of 
thousands more at risk in businesses that indirectly depend upon airports.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 30, 2020
End of Document
Lufthansa shareholders give OK to German government bailout
Lufthansa shareholders give OK to German government bailout
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 25, 2020 Thursday 6:34 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 158 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
The German government will take a 20-per-cent stake in Germany's top air carrier, Lufthansa, clearing the way for 
9 billion euros (10 billion dollars) in state aid for the crisis-hit airline.
Shareholders approved the move on Thursday following a day of deliberations in which company executives asked 
for assistance to stay in business, after the coronavirus pandemic grounded the company.
Valued at around 300 million euros, that stake is only a small part of the total package - but it has irked investors, 
who will see their own shares diluted as a result of the state intervention. It has also angered competitors, who see 
a national champion being bailed out despite EU rules against just that.
"This is a spectacular case of a rich EU member state ignoring the EU treaties to the benefit of its national industry 
and the detriment of poorer countries," Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said in a statement before the 
decision was announced.
Load-Date: June 25, 2020

British airports say 20,000 jobs at risk; Swissport plans cuts
British airports say 20,000 jobs at risk; Swissport plans cuts
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 24, 2020 Wednesday 5:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 416 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
An airport industry group on Wednesday said more than 20,000 jobs could be lost in Britain due to the economic 
impact the coronavirus pandemic, amid reports that Swissport plans to cut more than 4,000 jobs.
The Airport Operators' Association called for government help after its analysis suggested that 20,000 airport jobs 
are at risk in Britain "as the full effects of the [coronavirus] pandemic on the global airline community begin to be 
felt."
More than 110,000 jobs could be lost if firms providing services to airports or indirectly dependent upon them are 
included, the AOA said.
Trade unions and British media reported on Wednesday that Swissport has told staff that it plans consultations on 
cutting about half of its 9,000 jobs in Britain.
AOA chief executive Karen Dee said Britain's commercial aviation sector had "weathered the worst three months in 
its history."
Dee urged the government to drop its "arbitrary quarantine policy, which has unnecessarily stifled the sector's 
restart and recovery plans."
"These [AOA] jobs figures clearly show that a key component of the UK's infrastructure is on its knees, with no relief 
to the current crisis expected," she added.
The government has imposed a 14-day quarantine on all international arrivals in Britain, which airlines warned 
could bring "economic disaster."
British airports say 20,000 jobs at risk; Swissport plans cuts
It later announced planned exemptions for arrivals from European nations popular with British holidaymakers, 
including Spain and Portugal.
Airlines said the government had effectively banned people from travelling to countries with lower coronavirus 
infection rates than Britain.
Broadcaster Sky News quoted a memo to Swissport's 8,500 staff in Britain and Ireland, from Jason Holt, its chief 
executive for Western Europe, as saying the company had to "adapt to this new reality" in which air traffic was not 
forecast to recover to pre-pandemic levels until as late as 2024.
Holt said Swissport, which provides baggage handling and other services at most British regional airports, planned 
to start consultations on the possible cutting of 4,556 positions.
Trade unions GMB and Unite, which represent many Swissport staff, said the plan to cut jobs was "devastating 
news."
The unions urged the government to provide "a bespoke financial package ... to support the aviation industry and 
save thousands of jobs as the economy continues to reopen."
Major British airlines have also announced possible staff cuts, including 12,000 at British Airways, 4,500 at easyJet 
and 3,000 at Ryanair.

Swissport to cut 4,000 British jobs; airports warn many more at risk
Swissport to cut 4,000 British jobs; airports warn many more at risk
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 24, 2020 Wednesday 8:18 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 468 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Airport operator Swissport on Wednesday announced plans to cut more then 4,000 staff in Britain and Ireland, as 
an industry group warned that tens of thousands of airport-linked jobs are at risk following the coronavirus 
pandemic.
Jason Holt, chief executive for western Europe, told Swissport's 8,500 staff in Britain and Ireland that the company 
had to "adapt to this new reality" in which air traffic was not forecast to recover to pre-pandemic levels until as late 
as 2024.
Holt said in a memo that Swissport, which provides baggage handling and other services at most British regional 
airports, planned to start consultations on the possible cutting of 4,556 positions.
In a later statement, Holt said the pandemic had "hit [Swissport] hard, beginning with the collapse of [regional 
airline] Flybe back in March."
The company had lost about 75 per cent of its revenue during the pandemic, he said.
"We now must adapt to the unfortunate reality that there simply aren't enough aircraft flying for our business to 
continue running as it did before Covid-19; and there won't be for some time to come," Holt said.
"We expect upwards of 4,000 will leave us, comprising around 50 per cent of our workforce," he said, adding that 
the entire aviation industry is facing "very challenging, existential times."
The Airport Operators' Association (AOA) said its analysis suggested that more than 20,000 jobs could be lost in 
Britain, or more than 110,000 jobs if firms providing services to airports or indirectly dependent upon them are 
included.
Swissport to cut 4,000 British jobs; airports warn many more at risk
Trade unions GMB and Unite, which represent many Swissport staff, said the plan to cut jobs was "devastating 
news."
The unions urged the government to provide "a bespoke financial package ... to support the aviation industry and 
save thousands of jobs as the economy continues to reopen."
Major British airlines have also announced possible staff cuts, including 12,000 at British Airways, 4,500 at easyJet 
and 3,000 at Ryanair.
AOA chief executive Karen Dee said Britain's commercial aviation sector had "weathered the worst three months in 
its history."
Dee urged the government to drop its "arbitrary quarantine policy, which has unnecessarily stifled the sector's 
restart and recovery plans."
"These [AOA] jobs figures clearly show that a key component of the UK's infrastructure is on its knees, with no relief 
to the current crisis expected," she added.
The government has imposed a 14-day quarantine on all international arrivals in Britain, which airlines warned 
could bring "economic disaster."
It later announced planned exemptions for arrivals from European nations popular with British holidaymakers, 
including Spain and Portugal.
Airlines said the government had effectively banned people from travelling to countries with lower coronavirus 
infection rates than Britain.

Poll: Support for Britain 's coronavirus response falls to 30 per cent
Poll: Support for Britain's coronavirus response falls to 30 per cent
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 14, 2020 Sunday 3:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 260 words
Dateline: London (dpa)- 
Body
Only 30 per cent of voters are satisfied with the British government's response to the coronavirus pandemic, which 
has seen the country record Europe's highest death toll, according to a poll published on Sunday.
The Opinium poll for The Observer found that "discontent at the government's corona handling continues to steadily 
rise," reaching a high of 48 per cent, while approval of the government's approach fell from 34 per cent earlier this 
month.
"This gives the government a net approval rating of minus 18 in responding to one of the greatest threats this 
country has faced," Opinium said.
In another poll published by ORB International on Friday, 52 per cent disagreed with the statement that the 
government was "handling the coronavirus well," while 40 per cent agreed with it.
Britain's official death toll linked to the coronavirus pandemic is more than 40,000, but health data analysts estimate 
the true death toll at up to 70,000, based on seasonal excess deaths.
Health experts and opposition politicians have accused Johnson's government of a slow response to the crisis, and 
criticized Britain's low level of testing and poor preparation for a pandemic.
Johnson is also under pressure from critics who want him to lift Britain's lockdown more quickly to reduce the 
anticipated severe economic impact.
British Airways, Ryanair and easyJet launched legal action on Friday against his requirement for all international 
arrivals to self-isolate for 14 days to curb the spread of coronavirus, warning that it will have "a devastating effect" 
on the economy.
Poll: Support for Britain 's coronavirus response falls to 30 per cent
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 14, 2020
End of Document
Airlines launch legal action on Britain 's Covid quarantine rule
Airlines launch legal action on Britain's Covid quarantine rule
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 12, 2020 Friday 12:00 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 273 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Three major airlines launched legal action on Friday against the British government's requirement for all 
international arrivals to self-isolate for 14 days to curb the spread of coronavirus.
British Airways, Ryanair and easyJet demanded an urgent judicial review of the quarantine rule, which will have "a 
devastating effect on British tourism and the wider economy and destroy thousands of jobs."
"The airlines have not yet seen any evidence on how and when proposed 'air bridges' between the UK and other 
countries will be implemented," they wrote in a joint statement.
The "air bridges" would create exemptions allowing tourists to return from countries such as Spain, Portugal and 
Greece without needing to self-isolate.
Ireland is currently the only nation exempt from the quarantine rule, which the government imposed on Monday.
Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the measure, initially only in place until June 28, was necessary so that "those 
arriving from abroad ... don't unknowingly spread the virus."
The airlines urged the government to switch back to a previous rule requiring quarantine for arrivals from "high risk" 
countries, "bringing the UK in line with much of Europe, which is opening its borders mid-June."
They said there was "no consultation and no scientific evidence provided for such a severe policy," adding that the 
government was effectively banning people from travelling to countries with lower coronavirus infection rates than 
Britain.
Britain has reported Europe's highest total of deaths of people infected with coronavirus, at about 41,000. Its 
estimated infection rate remains higher than in most European nations.
Airlines launch legal action on Britain 's Covid quarantine rule
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 12, 2020
End of Document
Airlines protest as Britain begins Covid-19 quarantine for arrivals
Airlines protest as Britain begins Covid-19 quarantine for arrivals
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 8, 2020 Monday 12:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 256 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Airlines threaten legal action as all arrivals to Britain must self-isolate for 14 days to curb the spread of coronavirus 
starting on Monday.
Michael O'Leary, group chief executive of low-cost airline Ryanair, said "millions of jobs" could be lost as a result of 
the quarantine rule, which applies to arrivals, including British citizens, from all countries except Ireland.
Conservative Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the quarantine requirement, initially until June 28, was necessary 
so that "those arriving from abroad ... don't unknowingly spread the virus."
Britain has reported Europe's highest death toll linked to the coronavirus pandemic and its estimated infection rate 
remains higher than in most European nations.
"We have got the situation where - weeks ago - other countries put quarantine in and we didn't. Now, as 
everybody's lifting it, we're putting it in," opposition Labour leader Keir Starmer told London radio station LBC.
Ryanair, easyJet and British Airways owner IAG wrote to the government threatening legal action to stop the 
"disproportionate and unfair" measure, warning that it would have "a devastating effect on UK's tourism industry."
"We're seeing thousands of British families booking their holidays in Portugal, in Spain and Italy, but there's almost 
a collapse of inward bookings ... bringing those Europeans here to the UK, on which Britain's tourism industry 
depends," O'Leary told broadcaster ITV.
"What's irrational about it is all of those countries have a much lower Covid rate than the UK," he added.

Travel firms call for 'roadmap' as Britain begins arrivals quarantine
Travel firms call for 'roadmap' as Britain begins arrivals quarantine
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 8, 2020 Monday 8:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 422 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
British travel firms called for an urgent "roadmap" for the resumption of tourism as the government imposed 
quarantine rules on all international arrivals from Monday.
Mark Tanzer, chief executive of travel trade association ABTA, said the quarantine plan to prevent the spread of the 
coronavirus would affect the British economy "beyond the wider transport and tourism industries."
"We must restart international travel as soon as it is safe to do so, and businesses and customers would benefit 
from the government outlining when this is likely to happen," Tanzer said.
"There are many livelihoods at stake, and bookings will only start to pick up in earnest when people and businesses 
have a better idea as to what the government's plan is to open up the UK and access to international destinations."
Three major British-based airlines earlier threatened legal action over the requirement for all arrivals to Britain to 
self-isolate for 14 days.
Ryanair, easyJet and British Airways owner IAG wrote to the government demanding the end of the 
"disproportionate and unfair" measure, warning that it would have "a devastating effect on UK's tourism industry."
Michael O'Leary, group chief executive of low-cost airline Ryanair, said "millions of jobs" could be lost as a result of 
the quarantine rule, which applies to arrivals, including British citizens, from all countries except Ireland.
Conservative Prime Minister Boris Johnson said the quarantine requirement, initially until June 28, was necessary 
so that "those arriving from abroad ... don't unknowingly spread the virus."
Britain has reported Europe's highest death toll of more than 40,000 linked to the coronavirus pandemic and its 
estimated infection rate remains higher than in most European nations.
Travel firms call for 'roadmap' as Britain begins arrivals quarantine
"We have got the situation where - weeks ago - other countries put quarantine in and we didn't. Now, as 
everybody's lifting it, we're putting it in," opposition Labour leader Keir Starmer told London radio station LBC.
Health Secretary Matt Hancock rejected the idea that the government had been forced into a "trade-off" between 
damage to the economy and the impact of the pandemic on health.
"If we don't have control of this virus then the economy will suffer yet more," Hancock told reporters.
"For those who aren't able to go abroad for a holiday, I know the impact that that will have this summer," he said.
"I just hope that we will be able to get to a position where people will be able to go on holiday - including 
domestically - safely, carefully and in a Covid-secure way."

Ryanair subsidiary Lauda avoids shutdown with last-minute deal
Ryanair subsidiary Lauda avoids shutdown with last-minute deal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 8, 2020 Monday 7:08 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 200 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair will not carry out its plan to shutter its loss-making subsidiary Lauda in Vienna, the Austrian 
carrier announced on Monday after employees agreed to a last-minute wage deal.
The management of Ireland-based Ryanair had set several deadlines for Lauda staff to agree to wage cuts and 
threatened to cut all 500 job at the Lauda base in Vienna as the subsidiary would be moved to a new hub.
However, unionists blocked Ryanair's proposal, arguing that the new entry-level wages were below the poverty line.
After union representatives and Austria's chamber of commerce agreed on a new wage cut deal last week, Lauda 
staff approved it in a poll on the weekend.
However, some jobs will be cut, and the number of Lauda's Airbus aircraft in Vienna will be reduced from 16 to 10, 
the Austrian low-cost carrier said in a statement.
"We will need these cost efficiencies if we are to successfully compete against the state subsidised Lufthansa 
subsidiary," Lauda chief executives Andreas Gruber and David O'Brien said, in a stab against the government 
bailout of Austrian Airlines.
The Lauda fleet that was grounded because of the coronavirus pandemic will gradually start flying again on July 1.

Load-Date: June 8, 2020
Ryanair subsidiary Lauda avoids shutdown with last-minute deal
End of Document
Ryanair slams German government bailout plan for rival Lufthansa
Ryanair slams German government bailout plan for rival Lufthansa
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 26, 2020 Tuesday 4:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 278 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) -  
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair on Tuesday slammed a bailout plan for German rival Lufthansa, saying it "distorts 
competition" with other airlines across Europe.
The criticism came the day after the German government and Lufthansa said they had agreed on a deal providing 
aid and equity measures worth 9 billion euros (9.8 billion dollars).
The deal was yet to be approved by Lufthansa's supervisory board and the European Commission's competition 
watchdog.
The status of some 138,000 employed by the airline and its many subsidiaries, including Austrian and Brussels, 
was a major factor.
Ryanair claimed the move would "further strengthen Lufthansa's monopoly-like grip on the German air travel 
market."
Ryanair group chief executive Michael O'Leary said it was "deeply ironic that the German government, which 
lectures all other EU countries about respecting EU rules, has no difficulty breaking the state aid rules when it 
comes to Lufthansa."
Ryanair will "appeal against this latest example of illegal state aid to Lufthansa," he added.
Germany has not yet officially notified the EU executive branch about the Lufthansa deal, a spokesperson for the 
European Commission said on Tuesday, declining to make any specific comment on the case.
In general, large recapitalizations of more than 250 million euros comes with stricter conditions than other state aid 
initiatives, Arianna Podesta said.
Meanwhile, Bavarian state premier Markus Soeder warned against making too many concessions for EU approval.
Ryanair slams German government bailout plan for rival Lufthansa
If Lufthansa were to be forced to give up airport slots in the main cities of Frankfurt and Munich to other airlines, it 
would be an "incomprehensible constraint," he said in Munich.

Ryanair subsidiary Lauda to shut down Vienna base
Ryanair subsidiary Lauda to shut down Vienna base
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 22, 2020 Friday 12:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 214 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair subsidiary Lauda is to close its base at Vienna's airport following a dispute with a trade union, the company 
said on Friday.
Some 300 jobs will be affected, the airline said. It had recently given the Vida union an ultimatum to sign a new 
collective agreement with significant wage cuts for employees due to the coronavirus crisis.
As the union refused, the base will be closed on May 29, the statement said.
"In a shameful way, the union Vida ignored the wishes of more than 95 per cent of the pilots and 70 per cent of the 
cabin crew at Lauda's A320 base in Vienna and destroyed more than 300 well-paid jobs," Lauda bosses Andreas 
Gruber and David O'Brien were quoted as saying.
Vida on the other hand described Ryanair and Austria's Economic Chamber as "gravediggers" of living wages. The 
chamber had spoken out in favour of signing the wage deal.
According to the airline, the new agreement would have given junior cabin crew an average annual income of 
24,450 euros (26,650 dollars), a captain would have earned about 117,000 euros. Vida talked about a monthly net 
wage of 848 euros for newly hired flight attendants.
The Vienna base is by far the largest base of the Ryanair subsidiary, which currently has a fleet of 26 aircraft. The 
aircraft are grounded due to the pandemic.

Load-Date: May 22, 2020
Ryanair subsidiary Lauda to shut down Vienna base
End of Document
Berlin to close Tegel Airport on June 15, perhaps for good
Berlin to close Tegel Airport on June 15, perhaps for good
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 20, 2020 Wednesday 2:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 407 words
Byline: Burkhard Fraune and Rachel More in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Berlin's Tegel Airport is unlikely to survive the coronavirus pandemic, after the operator decided at a meeting on 
Wednesday to close the ageing facility provisionally from June 15, a city finance ministry spokeswoman said.
It is unclear whether the airport will ever reopen. It had already been set for closure towards the end of the year, as 
the German capital prepares for the long-delayed launch of its new BER Airport.
Following Paris' example - Orly Airport was closed on April 1 and flights moved to Charles de Gaulles - Berlin's 
most centrally located and until now busiest airport will be taken offline for two months if passenger numbers don't 
drastically improve in the coming weeks.
Berlin's meagre air traffic will then be consolidated to Schoenefeld Airport, on the capital's south-eastern outskirts.
Last year, over 24 million people flew via Tegel in the city's north-west, making it Germany's fourth-busiest aviation 
hub after Frankfurt, Munich and Dusseldorf before the crisis. Schoenefeld served over 11 million people last year.
But the novel coronavirus outbreak and resulting global travel restrictions caused a steep fall in demand. Recently, 
Berlin's two functioning airports have been flying around 2,000 passengers per day - a tiny fraction of the usual 
capacity.
The coronavirus-induced closure from June is likely to be the end for Tegel Airport, given that reopening for a mere 
matter of months before BER comes online is considered unlikely.
"If I had 50,000 guests, Tegel would go back online immediately," said Engelbert Luetke Daldrup, chief executive of 
the Berlin Brandenburg Airport operator.
"But to be honest, I am not very optimistic that we will be back up to 50,000 guests in a few months."
Berlin to close Tegel Airport on June 15, perhaps for good
Nine years late and beset by a string of scandals, the new BER airport is set to open on a plot adjacent to 
Schoenefeld on October 31. Under the current plans, Tegel is to close for good a week later.
The move to close Tegel prematurely next month was met with criticism from Germany's flagship airline.
"Such a last-minute change of location is complex and costly," a spokeswoman for the Lufthansa Group said.
"In the current crisis, which already poses an enormous challenge to us, this is a further strain."
Lufthansa operates flights from Tegel to its hubs in Munich and Frankfurt.
Subsidiary Eurowings maintains a base at Tegel and is one of the Berlin airport operator's biggest clients, alongside 
Easyjet and Ryanair.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;Editing by: Stephen 
Lowman, +49 30 2852 31472, <Lowman.Stephen@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 20, 2020
End of Document

Ryanair to resume 40 per cent of flights from July
Ryanair to resume 40 per cent of flights from July
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 12, 2020 Tuesday 1:52 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 248 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair on Tuesday said it plans to restore 40 per cent of its regular flights from July 1, subject to 
the lifting of Covid-19-related restrictions on flights within the European Union.
Ryanair said it also requires "effective public health measures" to be implemented at airports before it begins a daily 
schedule of about 1,000 flights, restoring 90-percent of its routes.
The airline said it is currently operating only 30 flights on a "skeleton daily schedule," after governments across 
Europe imposed social distancing measures and severe restrictions on international travel.
Ryanair said it plans to resume operations at most of its 80 bases in Europe but will operate fewer flights on its 
major routes.
It said it will change ticketing, check-in and baggage services to improve social distancing and reduce the risk of 
spreading the novel coronavirus.
The airline said it wants passengers to undergo temperature checks at airport entrances and wear face masks at all 
times, including during the flights.
"After four months [of lockdown], it is time to get Europe flying again so we can reunite friends and families, allow 
people to return to work, and restart Europe's tourism industry, which provides so many millions of jobs," said Eddie 
Wilson, Ryanair's chief executive.
Ryanair group head Michael O'Leary told the BBC that a 14-day quarantine requirement for arrivals to Britain, 
where the airline does much of its business, was "unimplementable and unenforceable."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair to resume 40 per cent of flights from July
Load-Date: May 12, 2020
End of Document
Lufthansa to double schedule in June, including holiday destinations
Lufthansa to double schedule in June, including holiday destinations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 8, 2020 Friday 3:16 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 158 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Germany's Lufthansa is to roughly double its schedule in June, putting 160 planes into the air to carry passengers 
to 106 domestic and foreign destinations, the airline announced from its Frankfurt headquarters on Friday.
Lufthansa, along with its subsidiaries Swiss and Eurowings, will include many traditional holiday destinations in the 
schedule, including Crete and Majorca in the Mediterranean and Sylt and Rostock on the northern German 
coastline.
Around 600 planes that belong to the group will remain grounded.
On Thursday, the Lufthansa Group, Europe's second largest airline after Ryanair, confirmed that it was in talks with 
the German government regarding a bailout package of 9 billion euros (9.7 billion dollars).  
In exchange for the stabilization package, the government has proposed taking a stake in the company of up to 25 
per cent plus one share, the airline stated in a regulatory release, as well as one seat on the supervisory board.

End of Document
Airlines, governments weigh costs as pandemic keeps planes idling
Airlines, governments weigh costs as pandemic keeps planes idling
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 7, 2020 Thursday 5:30 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 989 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London, Albert Otti in Vienna, Alvise Armellini in Rome, Christian Ebner in Frankfurt, Rachel 
More in Berlin, Pol O Gradaigh in Paris, Helen Maguire in Brussels, Krzysztof Bastian in Warsaw, and Lennart 
Simonsson in Lahti, Finland
Dateline: Stockholm (dpa) - 
Highlight: Airline after airline across the globe is reporting drastic falls in passengers and revenue amid the 
coronavirus pandemic that has brought domestic and international air travel to a virtual standstill. Businesses and 
governments are just coming to terms with the true costs of saving them.
Body
Airline after airline across the globe is reporting drastic falls in passengers and revenue amid the coronavirus 
pandemic that has brought domestic and international air travel to a virtual standstill. Businesses and governments 
are just coming to terms with the true costs of saving them.
The global air travel industry had been expected to grow by more than 3 per cent this year, but that was prior to the 
standstill caused by the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Instead of demand for global passenger seats growing by 67 million passengers in 2020, the International Civil 
Aviation Authority (ICAO) estimates that demand will drop by between 805 million and almost 1.5 billion passenger 
seats as country after country introduces travel bans to stem the spread of the virus.
Europe is particularly hard-hit, the UN body said. Travel restrictions are expected to cripple the traditionally busy 
summer travel season.
Millions of jobs hang in the balance warns the International Air Transport Association (IATA), which represents 
about 290 airlines. According to IATA, the aviation industry supports 65.5 million jobs around the world, including 
10.5 million people who work at airports and airlines.
Airline after airline has presented dismal quarterly reports and plans to cut jobs. 
Airlines, governments weigh costs as pandemic keeps planes idling
That includes Virgin Atlantic, which this week said 3,150 jobs could go. Chief executive Shai Weiss said the airline 
was forced to cut costs to "safeguard [its] future and emerge a sustainably profitable business" by next year.
Last week, British Airways announced plans for up to 12,000 redundancies, while low-cost carrier Ryanair warned 
that it could cut up to 3,000 jobs.
Normal services are not expected to resume any time soon.
The owner of British Airways said on Thursday it expects the impact of the pandemic on the aviation industry to last 
at least three years, with no "meaningful return" to normal services until July at the earliest.
IATA this week warned that leaving middle seats free to reduce infection risk would either lead to soaring ticket 
prices or to bankrupt airlines. Such measures would push the maximum passenger load in aircraft below the break-
even level of 77 per cent, according to the industry umbrella group.
"Eliminating the middle seat will raise costs. If that can be offset with higher fares, the era of affordable travel will 
come to an end," IATA chief Alexandre de Juniac said.
IATA's safety proposals include temperature screenings, safe boarding procedures and increased aircraft cleaning.
John Holland-Kaye, the chief executive of Heathrow airport, told British lawmakers on Wednesday that the 
government needs to agree on common international standards by the end of May, especially with the EU and the 
US.
"The key issue [for passengers] is whether they will be allowed into the country that they will be going to, and 
whether they will be allowed back," Holland-Kaye said, adding that continuing quarantine will "kill the [aviation] 
industry."
Airlines across Europe have also sought and received state support, including loans and credits to weather the 
storm. 
The Polish government was on Thursday among the latest to announce plans to back LOT, the country's flagship 
airline.  
"The interventions of the various national states, aimed at safeguarding individual flag carriers, have a perverse 
effect, which is to distort the market. There should be aid for the industry, but it must be coordinated by the 
European Union," wrote Andrea Giuricin, an Italian airline analyst, in the Il Foglio daily.
Some carriers were already in trouble before the standstill, having racked up huge debts. Those include low-cost 
Norwegian Air and its expansion plans or Italy's near-bankrupt Alitalia, which saw revenue in the April 1-23 period 
fall by 97 per cent.
Carsten Spohr, head of airline German Lufthansa, Europe's largest carrier, this week warned against incurring high 
debts amid negotiations about a huge state bailout.
German airports are losing half a billion euros (539.2 million dollars) in revenue every month due to the coronavirus 
crisis, an industry body warned on Thursday, calling for state aid.
"Air travel does not happen without the infrastructure on the ground," Stefan Schulte, president of the ADV airport 
association, said.
The European Commission this week approved French loans worth 7 billion euros to help Air France, noting that 
the aviation giant would otherwise face the risk of bankruptcy.
French Economy Minister Bruno Le Maire said Paris wanted environmental commitments from Air France - part of 
the Air France-KLM group - in return for the backing.
Airlines, governments weigh costs as pandemic keeps planes idling
"When you can travel by train in less than two and a half hours, there is no justification for taking a plane," he said.
The trend with growing state involvement was "interesting" as it marked a shift from previous privatization waves, 
said Jean-Marie Skoglund, senior advisor with the Swedish Transport Agency.
He added that, when air travel eventually resumes, it was "important that the same restrictions apply for all airlines, 
at least within tbe EU."
Scandinavian airline SAS also received the EU executive's blessing for a three-year credit guarantee for 335 million 
dollars, mainly guaranteed by its main shareholders - the Swedish and Danish governments.
Sweden, however, did not wish to use the funding to target a single company, Tomas Eneroth, minister of 
infrastructure, told Stockholm daily Dagens Nyheter.
He said the airline sector as a whole should become more environmentally friendly. Possible measures include 
promoting bio fuel and investments in electric-powered aircraft. 
Meanwhile, Greenpeace and pressure groups like Transport & Environment that track emissions generated by air 
travel have called for governments to use state support as leverage. 
"Injecting taxpayers' money into one of the world's most polluting industries - with no strings attached - makes no 
sense at all," said Lorelei Limousin, Greenpeace EU climate campaigner.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;

Virgin Atlantic to cut 3,150 jobs as airlines face 'death spiral'
Virgin Atlantic to cut 3,150 jobs as airlines face 'death spiral'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 5, 2020 Tuesday 4:17 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 250 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Virgin Atlantic airline announced plans to cut 3,150 jobs on Tuesday, in the latest blow to an industry rocked by the 
severe impact of global efforts to curb the novel coronavirus pandemic.
Virgin Atlantic chief executive Shai Weiss said the airline was forced to cut costs to "safeguard [its] future and 
emerge a sustainably profitable business" by next year.
"This will mean taking steps to reshape and resize Virgin Atlantic in line with demand," Weiss said in a statement.
"We have weathered many storms since our first flight 36 years ago, but none has been as devastating as Covid-19 
and the associated loss of life and livelihood for so many," he said.
Virgin's move followed British Airways' announcement last week of plans for up to 12,000 redundancies, and a 
warning from low-cost carrier Ryanair that it could cut up to 3,000 jobs.
"Why is the government sitting on its hands while aviation plunges further towards a death spiral?" Brian Strutton, 
general secretary of pilots' trade union BALPA, said following Virgin's announcement.
BALPA wrote an open letter to the government on Monday, calling for urgent action to mitigate the "crisis in 
aviation."
Weiss noted that Virgin had taken similar action after the "9/11" terrorist attacks on the United States in 2001 and 
the 2008 global financial crisis, but many redundant staff were "back flying with us within a couple of years."
Virgin group founder Richard Branson warned last month that the airline needed government loans to keep 
operating.
Virgin Atlantic to cut 3,150 jobs as airlines face 'death spiral'
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 5, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair warns it could cut up to 3,000 jobs
Ryanair warns it could cut up to 3,000 jobs
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 1, 2020 Friday 11:33 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 241 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost Irish carrier Ryanair warned on Friday that it could cut up to 3,000 jobs, as global efforts to curb the novel 
coronavirus pandemic continue to have a severe impact on airlines.
Ryanair said it plans talks with trade unions on a "restructuring and job loss programme" to be launched in July.
It said the cost-cutting programme "may result in the loss of up to 3,000 mainly pilot and cabin crew jobs, unpaid 
leave, and pay cuts of up to 20 per cent, and the closure of a number of aircraft bases across Europe until traffic 
recovers."
Ryanair's head office staff and support teams will also be subject to job cuts and pay cuts, the airline said.
Ryanair expects to operate just 1 per cent of its flight programme from April to June, and a maximum of 50 per cent 
of flights in its July to September financial quarter.
"As a direct result of the unprecedented Covid-19 crisis, the grounding of all flights from mid-March until at least 
July, and the distorted state aid landscape in Europe, Ryanair now expects the recovery of passenger demand and 
pricing will take at least two years," it said.
Ryanair group chief executive Michael O'Leary has agreed to a 50-per-cent salary reduction until March, it added.
The owner of British Airways announced plans on Tuesday for up to 12,000 redundancies.
BA has written to staff warning that it might not resume operations at Britain's second-busiest airport, Gatwick, the 
Financial Times reported on Thursday.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair warns it could cut up to 3,000 jobs
Load-Date: May 1, 2020
