European airlines slash flights by 90 per cent as demand nosedives
European airlines slash flights by 90 per cent as demand nosedives
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 16, 2020 Monday 1:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 553 words
Byline: Julia Naue in Paris, Bill Smith in London, Mark Corrigan in Berlin, and Lennart Simonsson in Stockholm
Dateline: Paris/London (dpa) - 
Body
Several major European airlines on Monday said they would reduce their flights by up to 90 per cent amid the sharp 
fall in demand for air travel over the coronavirus pandemic.
Air France-KLM noted that "some countries have imposed constraints on the movement of travellers from France, 
the Netherlands or more broadly from Europe," affecting travel opportunities.
Air France would ground its Airbus 380 fleet, while KLM was to ground its Boeing 747 fleet.
The airline said it would reduce the number of available seat kilometres (ASK) - a measure for passenger carrying 
capacity - by 75 to 90 per cent in the coming two months.
Talks were also to open with employee representatives due to the "expected decline in activity."
Air France-KLM Group welcomed statements by the French and Dutch governments on means to support the 
group.
The parent company of British Airways, IAG, said it would reduce capacity in April and May by at least 75 per cent.
Willie Walsh, IAG's chief executive, said he expected demand to "remain weak until well into the summer."
"We will continue to monitor demand levels and we have the flexibility to make further cuts if necessary," Walsh 
said.
Low-cost airline easyJet said it has made "further significant cancellations."
European airlines slash flights by 90 per cent as demand nosedives
The suspension of flights "will continue on a rolling basis for the foreseeable future and could result in the grounding 
of the majority of the easyJet fleet," the airline said.
"European aviation faces a precarious future and it is clear that coordinated government backing will be required to 
ensure the industry survives and is able to continue to operate when the crisis is over," said easyJet CEO Johan 
Lundgren.
Budget carrier Ryanair also said it expected to ground most of its fleet across Europe over the next seven to 10 
days.
"For April and May, Ryanair now expects to reduce its seat capacity by up to 80 per cent, and a full grounding of the 
fleet cannot be ruled out," it said.
German holiday airline Condor meanwhile said that is has cancelled a number of flights to favourite tourist 
destinations to which German citizens are no longer allowed to travel.
Flights to the United States, the Dominican Republic, Turkey and Morocco are affected, to varying degrees. Condor 
is to send empty planes to affected destinations in the next few days to bring back holidaymakers.
"We'll fly empty to Turkey to bring the people back home," a Condor spokeswoman said in Frankfurt, adding that 
the airline was in close cooperation with travel agents who have cancelled a large number of package holidays.
Finnish flag carrier Finnair said it will slash its capacity by 90 per cent from April 1. As of Monday until end of March 
up to 2,000 flights would be cancelled.
The airline aimed to "maintain the most critical air connections for Finland also in this exceptional situation," said 
Topi Manner, chief executive.
Scandinavian carrier SAS said Sunday it would temporarily lay off 90 per cent of its staff, about 10,00 employees, 
and halt most of its flights.
Last week the Lufthansa Group - whose airlines include Lufthansa, Swiss, Austrian, Eurowings and Brussels - 
announced services would be cut worldwide by up to half of the average of 3,200 flights a day.
Lufthansa said it was in talks with several European governments about state support to help it through the air 
travel crisis.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 16, 2020
End of Document
Global airline alliances plea for state help, carriers slash flights
Global airline alliances plea for state help, carriers slash flights
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 16, 2020 Monday 4:09 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 681 words
Byline: Julia Naue in Paris, Bill Smith in London, Mark Corrigan and Rachel More in Berlin, Albert Otti in Vienna, 
and Lennart Simonsson in Stockholm
Dateline: Paris/London (dpa) - 
Body
Three airline alliances that group almost 60 carriers called on Monday for governments to come to the aviation 
sector's rescue, while a growing number of airlines announced drastic flight reductions due to plummeting air travel 
demand over the coronavirus pandemic.
Governments must consider "all possible means" to aid the airline industry that is suffering from the coronavirus 
crisis, the airline alliances Oneworld, SkyTeam and Star Alliance said in a joint statement.
The three groups account for more than half of the global market. They said the current industry forecast of 113 
billion dollars in lost revenues this year is still too optimistic, given the most recent US restrictions for European 
travellers.
The Lufthansa Group announced further reductions to its already stripped-back service, under which just one in 10 
long-haul flights will now operate and one in five short and medium-haul flights.
The German airline says it will continue running flights to bring holidaymakers back to their home country. Together 
with its Eurowings subsidiary, Lufthansa returned around 6,000 passengers with more than 20 flights at the 
weekend.
"Now it is no longer about the economic issues, but rather the responsibility which airlines carry as part of the 
critical infrastructure in their home countries," Lufthansa chief executive Carsten Spohr said.
Last week the group - whose airlines include Lufthansa, Swiss, Austrian, Eurowings and Brussels - announced 
services would be cut worldwide by up to half of the average of 3,200 flights a day.
Meanwhile, Lufthansa Cargo said it has successfully been able to continue operating cargo flights amid the crisis.
Global airline alliances plea for state help, carriers slash flights
Earlier, Air France-KLM said it would reduce seat capacity by 75 to 90 per cent in the coming two months. Air 
France would ground its Airbus 380 fleet, while KLM was to ground its Boeing 747 fleet.
Talks were also to open with employee representatives due to the "expected decline in activity," the airline said.
The parent company of British Airways, IAG, said it would reduce capacity in April and May by at least 75 per cent.
Willie Walsh, IAG's chief executive, said he expected demand to "remain weak until well into the summer."
"We will continue to monitor demand levels and we have the flexibility to make further cuts if necessary," Walsh 
said.
Low-cost airline easyJet said it has made "further significant cancellations."
The suspension of flights "will continue on a rolling basis for the foreseeable future and could result in the grounding 
of the majority of the easyJet fleet," the airline said.
"European aviation faces a precarious future and it is clear that coordinated government backing will be required to 
ensure the industry survives and is able to continue to operate when the crisis is over," said easyJet CEO Johan 
Lundgren.
Budget carrier Ryanair also said it expected to ground most of its fleet across Europe over the next seven to 10 
days.
"For April and May, Ryanair now expects to reduce its seat capacity by up to 80 per cent, and a full grounding of the 
fleet cannot be ruled out," it said.
German holiday airline Condor meanwhile said that is has cancelled a number of flights to favourite tourist 
destinations to which German citizens are no longer allowed to travel.
Flights to the United States, the Dominican Republic, Turkey and Morocco are affected, to varying degrees. Condor 
is to send empty planes to affected destinations in the next few days to bring back holidaymakers.
In the Nordic region, Finnair, Scandinavian carrier SAS, and low-cost Norwegian Air also announced they would 
slash capacity by 90 per cent.
Finnish flag carrier Finnair aimed to "maintain the most critical air connections for Finland also in this exceptional 
situation," said Topi Manner, chief executive.
Norwegian Air said on Monday it would cancel most flights and temporarily lay off about 90 per cent of its staff, 
about 7,300 employees, over "stagnating demand and enforced travel restrictions."
SAS said on Sunday it would temporarily lay off 90 per cent of its staff, about 10,00 employees, and halt most of its 
flights.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 16, 2020
End of Document
Two Austrian carriers stop all regular flights
Two Austrian carriers stop all regular flights
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 16, 2020 Monday 1:57 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 81 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Lufthansa subsidiary Austrian Airlines and Ryanair group carrier Lauda say they are ceasing all regular flights as 
the coronavirus pandemic has slashed demand and triggered travel restrictions.
Austrian Airlines says that two of its 83 aircraft will remain on standby to repatriate Austrians from abroad if needed 
during the flight suspension that is scheduled to end on March 28.
Vienna-based budget carrier Lauda has grounded all of its aircraft and plans to resume operations on April 9.

End of Document
Europe imposes new travel bans after Italy 's national lockdown
Europe imposes new travel bans after Italy's national lockdown
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 11, 2020 Wednesday 2:35 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 805 words
Byline: Ergin Hava in Istanbul, Krzysztof Bastian in Warsaw, Bertrand Borg in Valletta, Rachel More in Berlin, 
Christoph Thanei in Bratislava, Boris Babic in Belgrade, Albert Otti in Vienna, Julia Naue in Paris, Roland Siegloff in 
Brussels, Steffen Trumpf in Copenhagen, Alvise Armellini in Rome, Bill Smith in London, Pol O Gradaigh in Paris, 
Chiara Palazzo in Sydney
Dateline: Berlin/Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
European countries attempted to block a severe coronavirus outbreak in Italy from spreading any further on 
Tuesday with travel bans and warnings, as they introduced ever stricter measures to contain their own domestic 
epidemics.
Speaking during a video conference of European Union leaders late on Tuesday, European Council President 
Charles Michel urged the continent to coordinate its response to the crisis.
"The virus is spreading in all member states," said Michel. "I think therefore we should try to coordinate as much as 
possible and see where we can do more together."
His remarks were echoed by French President Emmanuel Macron on Tuesday evening, who tweeted that Europe 
should prevent instability and do everything necessary to protect people's health and the economy.
Their comments came as the World Trade Organization cancelled all meetings through March 20 after learning that 
one of its employees has become infected with the new coronavirus.
As the virus spreads, multiple countries - including Austria, Malta, Serbia and Spain - banned flights from Italy, 
which has seen by the worst outbreak in Europe, with more than 460 deaths and has gone into nationwide 
lockdown.
Denmark said it had banned flights from badly affected areas, including parts of Italy, while Austrian Airlines 
stopped flights to the northern Italian cities of Venice, Milan and Bologna.
Europe imposes new travel bans after Italy 's national lockdown
Serbia, which now has five confirmed cases, on Tuesday refused to permit 10 travellers to disembark from their 
plane from Bergamo and returned them to Italy. Croatia, with 14 cases, said it would quarantine all arrivals from 
Italy.
Spain raised its own concerns after registering a sharp jump in cases to 1,600, up 400 from the day before, and 
announced it would close its parliament until further notice.
The virus has now been reported in all 27 member states. France confirmed 372 new coronavirus cases in the last 
24 hours, taking the total to 1,784, with 33 deaths. Britain confirmed an additional 54 cases, taking the country's 
total to 373, including six deaths.
Nadine Dorries, Britain's minister for patient safety, suicide prevention and mental health, also tested positive to the 
virus, Health Secretary Matt Hancock has said.
Swiss authorities confirmed the number of cases in the country rose to 476, an increase of 52 per cent on the 
previous day.
A German woman on vacation in Northern Cyprus was diagnosed with coronavirus, state news agency Anadolu 
reported, the first such case in the Turkish-administered part of the divided island.
Turkish Health Minister Fahrettin Koca also confirmed the first case in Turkey on Tuesday night, saying that a male 
citizen who recently returned from Europe tested positive, according to Anadolu.
Airlines joined the efforts to limit the spread from Italy, with British Airways announcing it was cancelling all 
Tuesday's flights to and from the country.
Other airlines went one step further, with Ryanair suspending flights to and from Italy until April 8 and Air France 
and Easyjet until April 3.
Airlines have been badly hit by travel bans, with Norwegian the latest to announce flight cancellations. The carrier 
said it was cancelling an estimated 3,000 flights until mid-June - about 15 per cent of its flying capacity.
On the Spanish island of Mallorca, hoteliers said they were eyeing a dramatic slump in Easter bookings with 
concern.
Germany confirmed on Tuesday that the virus had reached all 16 of its federal states, after authorities in Saxony-
Anhalt announced their first infections.
The outbreak originated in central China in December and has spread rapidly, with about 110,000 people infected 
worldwide, according to the World Health Organization, of which over 3,800 have died.
Throughout Europe, cultural and sporting life ground to a standstill in more places, as Poland and Slovakia joined 
Italy in banning all sports and cultural events. Austria and the Czech Republic stopped all indoor events with more 
than 100 participants.
Slovakia's measures are in place for 14 days, whereas the ban in Poland did not have an end date, and spans 
professional football games and concerts, among others. However, theatres, opera houses, philharmonic concert 
halls or art galleries are exempt.
Pop star Madonna announced she was cancelling two Paris concerts on March 10 and 11 after the French 
government banned gatherings of more than 1,000 people.
Berlin's Senate said it was cancelling all state-owned theatre, opera and concert events until the end of the Easter 
break.
In the Vatican, St Peter's Square and St Peter's Basilica have been closed to the public due to the crisis.
Europe imposes new travel bans after Italy 's national lockdown
Greece is set to temporarily close its schools. In Poland, several universities cancelled classes and other events 
while President Andrzej Duda said he would refrain from organising large gatherings as he campaigned ahead of 
May's election.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Helen Corbett, +61 2 9322 8064, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 10, 2020
End of Document
EU executive probes France 's Beziers airport over competition rules
EU executive probes France's Beziers airport over competition rules
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 2, 2020 Monday 1:42 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 209 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission opened an investigation on Monday into France's regional Beziers airport on suspicion 
that its operators had breached EU competition rules.
Beziers airport, in the southern French region of Occitane, served more than 250,000 passengers last year, 
according to the commission.
The airport operations changed hands in 2011 from the local chamber of commerce to a syndicate composed of 
local and regional public authorities.
The commission - which acts as the European Union's competition watchdog - received a complaint about public 
funds granted to the successive operators from 2007 until now, as well as deals they struck with Ryanair.
The operational aid may have granted Beziers airport an unfair competitive benefit, while the agreements with 
Ryanair may have given it "an undue economic advantage vis-a-vis its competitors that might amount to 
incompatible aid," the commission wrote.
The EU executive has investigated several funding arrangements aimed at keeping airlines operating at certain 
regional airports, cracking down in recent years on schemes in France, Germany, Austria and Italy.
In 2018, meanwhile, French authorities impounded a Ryanair plane to recoup state aid to the airline that Brussels 
had found to be illegal.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin PowellTel: +49 30 2852-31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 2, 2020
EU executive probes France 's Beziers airport over competition rules
End of Document
Virus figures keep ticking up as Europe seeks ways to control spread
Virus figures keep ticking up as Europe seeks ways to control spread
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 2, 2020 Monday 8:39 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 891 words
Byline: Steffen Weyer and Florian Bamberg in Frankfurt, Carsten Hoefer in Munich, Pol O Gradaigh in Paris, 
Lennart Simonsson in Stockholm, Alvise Armellini in Rome, Ella Joyner in Brussels, Basil Wegener, Sebastian 
Fischer, Michael Zehender, Matthias Roeder in Vienna, Sophia-Caroline Kosel and Holger Mehlig in Berlin and 
Martin Oversohl in Karlsruhe
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Against the steady rise of infections, European businesses and governments on Monday sought ways to control the 
spread of the coronavirus.
The risk level for people in the European Union due to the spreading coronavirus has been raised from low-to-
moderate to moderate-to-high in the European Centre for Disease Prevention and Control's latest assessment, 
European Commission President Ursula von der Leyen said in Brussels.
The European Commission launched a coronavirus response team on Monday, scrutinizing medical risks as well as 
the implications for transport and mobility in the European Union, and the bloc's economy.
"While we should not give in to panic, the situation is likely to still get worse," EU Crisis Management Commissioner 
Janez Lenarcic said at a Brussels press conference on Monday.
Early on Monday, 2,100 cases had been confirmed in the 18 EU member states, with 38 deaths, EU Health 
Commissioner Stella Kyriakides said.
Eighteen EU states have launched a joint procurement process to buy protective equipment, she added.
No EU country has so far indicated plans to introduce border checks within the Schengen free movement area.
EU finance ministers are to discuss the situation in a teleconference, Eurogroup president Mario Centeno said on 
Monday, to review recent developments and coordinate national responses.
Virus figures keep ticking up as Europe seeks ways to control spread
Nevertheless, some businesses took things into their own hands.
British Airways cancelled hundreds of flights to Germany, Italy, France, Austria, Ireland and Switzerland, between 
March 17 to 28, citing the outbreak.
Ryanair also scaled back flights to Italy between March 17 and April 8.
Lufthansa and its subsidiaries likewise reduced flights to Italian and Asian destinations, the Frankfurt-based airline 
said on Monday.
Lufthansa and its subsidiaries, Swiss and Austrian Airlines, have already cancelled all flights to and from Chinese 
mainland destinations. The new move is a reaction to the spread of the virus and affects flights scheduled for March 
and April to Italy, Hong Kong and South Korea.
Flights to mainland China have been cancelled until April 24 and to Tehran until April 30.
LATAM Airlines Brasil also decided to suspend flights between Sao Paulo and Milan from March 2 to April 16.
The number of cases also continued to tick up. Portugal became the latest country to report its first case.
In Germany, cases rose to 150, the official disease control institute reported on Monday.
The Robert Koch Institute estimates the risk of the epidemic to be "moderate." Its head, Lothar Wieler, noted the 
situation continued to be extremely dynamic.
In the southern states of Baden-Wuerttemberg and Bavaria, pupils were ordered to stay home from school after last 
week's Carnival holiday if they had been in a high-risk area.
Several public events have been cancelled, most recently Munich's international craft trades fair (IHM). The federal 
government said it did not believe the epidemic would end soon.
In France, the Paris book fair was cancelled due to government restrictions on indoor events involving more than 
5,000 people.
In Italy, the first coronavirus case linked to the current outbreak was reported in Rome, affecting a policeman who 
came into contact with someone from Lombardy.
Italy now has 2,036 infections, a 20-per-cent increase compared to the previous day, the Italian Civil Protection 
Agency said. The new figure includes 52 dead and 149 recoveries - up from 34 and 83 on Sunday - and 908 
patients in hospital, with 166 in intensive care.
The outbreak remains concentrated in northern Italy, with 1,077 cases in Lombardy, 324 in Emilia-Romagna, 271 in 
Veneto, 51 in Piedmont and 34 in the Marche.
In the Nordic region, the number of reported coronavirus cases increased with four in Denmark, seven in Finland, 
three in Iceland, 25 in Norway and 15 in Sweden on Monday evening.
The king and queen of Sweden postponed an official dinner this week due to the cases, the palace said on 
Monday.
The Swedish Foreign Ministry advised against all travel to Iran, also on Monday.
And after a government meeting addressing the outbreak, Swedish Prime Minister Stefan Lofven cancelled a visit to 
South Africa.
France has now confirmed 191 cases of coronavirus infection, up 61 from Sunday, national health director Jerome 
Salomon said.
Virus figures keep ticking up as Europe seeks ways to control spread
In Austria, Viennese authorities set up a quarantine area for tourists infected with the virus, but with milder 
symptoms than would require a hospital stay, although no one yet fulfils this criterion.
In Poland, where no cases have been confirmed, a special parliamentary session was convened so lawmakers 
could discuss measures to allow firms to order their employees to work remotely, and exempt from rules of public 
tender the purchase of medical equipment. The bill would also broaden the prerogatives of the country's Chief 
Sanitary Inspectorate in case of an epidemic.
As the virus spreads, the UN health chief Tedros Adhanom Ghebreyesus urged countries to take decisive action.
Of the 88,900 cases worldwide, 90 per cent were reported from China, most in Hubei, the epicentre of the outbreak, 
Tedros said.
Outside China, 8,700 cases have been reported to the World Health Organization (WHO) and four countries 
account for 81 per cent of this figure, he said, naming South Korea, Italy, Iran and Japan. "This is not a one-way 
street. We can push this virus back," Tedros said. 
Editorial contactsEditing by: Allison Williams, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 2, 2020
End of Document
Ryanair boss calls for extra airport security checks on Muslim men
Ryanair boss calls for extra airport security checks on Muslim men
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 22, 2020 Saturday 5:24 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 228 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary called for profiling of Muslim men at airports because "that is where the 
threat is coming from," in an interview with the Times newspaper.
The budget airline boss told the British newspaper that checks for families should be less stringent, while calling for 
the focus to shift to Muslim men travelling on their own.
"Who are the bombers? They are going to be single males travelling on their own," the Irishman said in comments 
published on Saturday.
"If you are travelling with a family of kids, on you go; the chances you are going to blow them all up is fucking zero.
"You can't say stuff, because it's racism, but it will generally be males of a Muslim persuasion. Thirty years ago it 
was the Irish," the 58-year-old said. "If that is where the threat is coming from, deal with the threat."
Labour parliamentarian Khalid Mahmood said the Ryanair boss was "encouraging racism."
"In Germany this week a white person killed eight people. Should we profile white people to see if they're being 
fascists?" the Times cited Mahmood as saying. "He's being very blinkered and is actually encouraging racism."
O'Leary is famous for his controversial statements. He once called for a fat-tax on overweight passengers and 
famously considered a "pay-per-pee" plan on board Ryanair flights, though the Irish airline never carried out the 
plans.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Thomas Cronenberg, +61 2 9322 8064,  <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair boss calls for extra airport security checks on Muslim men
Load-Date: February 22, 2020
End of Document
Outrage as Ryanair boss calls for extra security checks on Muslim men
Outrage as Ryanair boss calls for extra security checks on Muslim men
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 22, 2020 Saturday 2:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 326 words
Byline: Chiara Palazzo in Sydney
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary called for profiling of Muslim men at airports because "that is where the 
threat is coming from," in an interview with the Times newspaper.
The budget airline boss told the British newspaper that checks for families should be less stringent, while calling for 
the focus to shift to Muslim men travelling on their own.
"Who are the bombers? They are going to be single males travelling on their own," the Irishman said in comments 
published on Saturday.
"If you are travelling with a family of kids, on you go; the chances you are going to blow them all up is fucking zero.
"You can't say stuff, because it's racism, but it will generally be males of a Muslim persuasion. Thirty years ago it 
was the Irish," the 58-year-old said. "If that is where the threat is coming from, deal with the threat."
British Labour parliamentarian Khalid Mahmood said the Ryanair boss was "encouraging racism."
"In Germany this week a white person killed eight people. Should we profile white people to see if they're being 
fascists?" the Times cited Mahmood as saying. "He's being very blinkered and is actually encouraging racism."
The Muslim Council of Britain called the comments "racist and discriminatory." A spokeswoman said it was a 
scandal that such racism was expressed "so openly and brazenly."
Scotland's Justice Minister, Humza Yousaf, condemned the comments on Twitter, writing, "awful from Michael 
O'Leary suggesting racial profiling to be introduced at airports."
Outrage as Ryanair boss calls for extra security checks on Muslim men
Nasir Ahmad, a German muslim blogger pointed out that O'Leary's remarks came shortly after a stabbing attack at 
London Central Mosque on Thursday, and a right-wing mass shooting in Hanau targetting Muslims and people of 
foreign descent.
O'Leary is famous for his controversial statements. He once called for a fat-tax on overweight passengers and 
famously considered a "pay-per-pee" plan on board Ryanair flights, though the Irish airline never carried out the 
plans.

Ryanair boss expresses confidence in Boeing despite accidents
Ryanair boss expresses confidence in Boeing despite accidents
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 22, 2020 Saturday 4:51 AM GMT
Copyright 2020 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 263 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary has said that Boeing aircraft will be the "safest, most checked planes" once the 
manufacturer overcomes its issues with its 737 MAX models following two deadly crashes.
Speaking to the British newspaper the Times, the Irish businessman criticized the United States manufacturer for 
doing a "seriously bad job of explaining their new planes," but also cast a vote of confidence in the company's new 
aircraft.
"People will love the plane when it's back, but we have a customer confidence issue," the budget airline boss told 
the Times in the interview published on Saturday.
"We will deal with that by hopefully having lower fares onboard the plane while trying it out.
"And if someone decides they don't want to fly for a period of time we will say, 'Fine, you can offload yourself and 
we will refund you.' That's how much confidence we have in the plane," the famously refund-averse O'Leary said.
The Irish budget airline did not cancel a contract with Boeing to order up to 210 of its 737s, including MAX models, 
despite the US company's grounding of the 737 MAX series last March after crashes in Ethiopia and Indonesia 
killed 346 people.
The primary cause of the crashes in October 2018 and March 2019 is thought to be a fault in the flight control 
software, which Boeing had wanted to fix with an update more than a year ago.
In the most recent setback for Boeing, whose grounded 737 MAX airliners created a backlog in orders, foreign 
object debris was found in fuel tanks of some of the aircraft during maintenance work, the aviation giant said on 
Tuesday.
Ryanair boss expresses confidence in Boeing despite accidents

Budget carrier battle boosts Vienna Airport's profit
Budget carrier battle boosts Vienna Airport's profit
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 14, 2019 Thursday 2:07 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 194 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Vienna Airport's net profit rose by 14.4 per cent year-on-year in the first three quarters, as budget airlines are 
seeking to expand market share in this major hub for Central and Eastern European destinations.
Net profit reached 152 million euros (167 million dollars), while revenues rose by 7.8 per cent to 643 million euros in 
the period between January and September, the airport reported on Thursday.
Lufthansa subsidiaries Austrian Airlines and Eurowings, as well as budget carriers Lauda, Wizz Air and Level have 
increased their passenger volumes and the number of flights in Vienna.
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary announced in September that his company's subsidiary Lauda plans to 
overtake Austrian Airlines as Vienna's dominant carrier in five years, as part of his battle plan against Lufthansa.
While the airport is profiting from the competition, Austrian Airlines has been suffering and announced last week 
that it would cut its workforce by up to 800 until 2021.
Austrian Airlines chief executive Alexis von Hoensbroech said that the number of available budget carrier seats in 
Vienna would rise from 4.5 million this year to 7 million next year.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 15, 2019
End of Document
Lufthansa 's shares surge amid new cost-cutting drive
Lufthansa's shares surge amid new cost-cutting drive
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 7, 2019 Thursday 1:11 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 240 words
Body
Berlin/Vienna (dpa) - German airline Lufthansa plans to step up its cost-cutting programme, as a result sending the 
group's shares surging amid better-than-forecast net quarterly profit.
With the cost-cutting drive already under way at its European budget airline Eurowings, Lufthansa announced on 
Thursday that it was launching a new drive to boost profit at its Brussels Airlines, Austrian Airlines and Lufthansa 
Cargo offshoots.
Austrian Airlines said it was slashing its workforce by about 10 per cent in the face of stiff competition from low-cost 
carriers, including Ireland-based Ryanair group and the Hungarian Wizz Air, which are also using Vienna as a hub.
The step is part of a new plan to slash annual costs at Austrian by 90 million euros (100 million dollars) a year, the 
airline's management said. Between 700 and 800 jobs are set to be cut by the end of 2021.
"We have to reposition ourselves to be able to survive the brutal competition against budget carriers," chief 
executive Alexis von Hoensbroech told a press conference in Vienna.
Cologne-based Lufthansa said group third-quarter net profit climbed 4 per cent to 1.154 billion euros compared with 
the same period last year after sales rose 2 per cent to about 10.177 billion euros.
Analysts had expected net profit to drop to 890 million euros in the three months to end of the September.

Load-Date: November 8, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair has no Condor takeover plans but doesn't rule out investment
Ryanair has no Condor takeover plans but doesn't rule out investment
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 26, 2019 Thursday 4:46 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 264 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair is not interested in buying Thomas Cook subsidiary Condor but would consider acquiring 
parts of the German holiday carrier if it is split up to guarantee competition, Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary 
said Thursday.
The head of Europe's largest budget carrier charged that the German government's recent 380-million-euro (420-
million-dollar) bridge loan for Condor was in preparation for Lufthansa buying another German airline and gaining 
market dominance.
"This is yet another fattening up of a German turkey," O'Leary told a press conference in Vienna, the base of 
Ryanair's Austrian subsidiary Laudamotion.
British tour operator Thomas Cook collapsed and filed for liquidation on Monday, leaving tens of thousands of 
holidaymakers stranded. Unlike its parent company, Condor is solvent and continues to operate, but has obtained a 
bridging loan to guard against potential liquidity shortages.
O'Leary said European Competition Commissioner Margrethe Vestager should not only look at US giants like 
Amazon and Google, but at Germany's Lufthansa. He pointed to the German carrier's past acquisition of troubled 
Air Berlin.
If Lufthansa ended up swallowing Condor, "we would expect there to be competition divestments" that might be of 
interest to Ryanair, the head of Ireland-based airline said.
Lufthansa made a non-binding offer for Condor in May but has not confirmed this week whether it is still interested. 
However, Lufthansa has never officially withdrawn its bid.

British-based Ryanair pilots call off strike
British-based Ryanair pilots call off strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 21, 2019 Saturday 00:10:08+02:00Invalid date found for VDI: (VDI not available) XCEDOCID: 188 LNI: 
5X3G-NY61-DXFJ-5270-00000-00. Date output 'as-is'. GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
British-based pilots for Irish budget airline Ryanair have called off a planned five-day strike, the British Airline Pilots 
Association said Friday.
"This comes despite the fact that the relationship between Ryanair and its pilots in the UK and elsewhere remains 
acrimonious. Instead of engaging in negotiations Ryanair has reverted to type, electing to punish pilots by 
withdrawing their travel benefits," the association said in a statement.
UK pilot representatives had agreed to suspend any further strikes in order to pave the way for "meaningful 
negotiations under the auspices of the UK conciliation service, ACAS."
"Despite a strong turnout for strike action and a high level of commitment among pilots in Ryanair, the pilot 
representatives took the decision to allow a breathing space in the hope that constructive negotiations could get 
underway," the statement added.
The pilots association said it retained the ability to set new strike dates should it be necessary.
Strikes were due to be held on September 21, 23, 25, 27 and 29.
British-based Ryanair pilots launched strike action last month due to disagreements over pay structure, pensions, 
license insurance and other benefits.
Last year, strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of 
this year's summer holiday season in August and September.

British-based Ryanair pilots call off strike

Ryanair boss expects Boeing 737 MAX delays to further disrupt growth
Ryanair boss expects Boeing 737 MAX delays to further disrupt growth
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 19, 2019 Thursday 9:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 260 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
The head of Ryanair said he fears that the budget airline's growth plans will be further disrupted by delays in 
deliveries of aircraft from US manufacturer Boeing, which is still grappling with its 737 MAX planes being banned 
from the air.
Boeing 's 737 MAX series was grounded in March after two crashes involving the MAX 8 variants, one in March in 
Ethiopia that killed 157 people and another in Indonesia in October that killed 189.
The cause of the crashes appears to be linked to a software malfunction.
The delivery of planes ordered by Ryanair could be delayed into 2020, said Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary at the 
annual general meeting of the flight company on Thursday in Dublin.
Ryanair might not receive the first aircraft in the delivery until March or April, O'Leary said, adding that Ryanair has 
stopped its payments to Boeing and is in negotiations with the US manufacturer to receive compensation.
Ryanair will have to curb its growth plans even further if there are extended delays, O'Leary said.
The Irish airline has a contract with Boeing to order up to 210 of its Boeing 737s, including MAX models.
O'Leary already announced plans to tone down the company's growth strategy in response to the Boeing MAX 
crisis and Britain's imminent exit from the European Union. The company is also dealing with potential strike action 
from pilots in Britain and Spain.
He also talked about job cuts mentioned earlier this year. Around 500 to 700 roles are expected to be slashed.

Ryanair boss expects Boeing 737 MAX delays to further disrupt growth

No disruption to Ryanair 's British flights despite pilots strike
No disruption to Ryanair's British flights despite pilots strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 22, 2019 Thursday 8:30 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 230 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair was able to operate a normal schedule in Britain on Thursday morning in spite of a strike by 
pilots, local media reported.
There had been fears of delays after Ryanair lost a court bid on Wednesday to stop its British pilots from taking part 
in strike action.
However, the airline on Thursday reported a 97 per cent punctuality rate for its first departures and arrivals at British 
airports, according to a statement carried by the PA news agency.
"We do not expect any disruptions to our flights to or from ourUK airports today," Ryanair said.
A judge in London on Wednesday rejected Ryanair's application for an injunction against the British Airline Pilots' 
Association (Balpa), which was planning labour action on Thursday and Friday as well as on a series of dates in 
September.
The High Court in Dublin earlier ruled in favour of a similar request by Ryanair to block a strike by its pilots in 
Ireland.
The airline is also facing problems with its staff in Portugal, where the union for cabin crew members has called a 
five-day strike this week, though no considerable disruptions were expected there.
Last year, strikes by Ryanair staff across Europe resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of 
the summer holiday season in August and September.

Portuguese employees walk out as Ryanair wins strike ban in Ireland
Portuguese employees walk out as Ryanair wins strike ban in Ireland
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 21, 2019 Wednesday 5:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 276 words
Byline: Angelika Engler in Berlin, Christoph Meyer in London
Dateline: Lisbon (dpa) - 
Body
A Portuguese labour union announced a strike at Ryanair as a court in Ireland approved a request by the Ireland-
based budget airline to prevent labour action there.
In Portugal, the union for cabin crew members called a five-day strike starting on Wednesday, Portuguese news 
agency Lusa reported.
Last year, strikes by Ryanair staff across Europe resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of 
the summer holiday season in August and September.
The High Court in Dublin ruled on Wednesday in favour of the airline's request to prevent a strike by pilots based in 
the country on Thursday and Friday.
The presiding judge was quoted by British news agency PA as saying he was preventing pilots' union Forsa "from 
directly or indirectly, organizing, directing or endorsing their members to participate in a strike on August 22 or 23."
British pilots are also seeking to take part in labour action on Thursday and Friday as well as on a series of dates in 
September, but face a similar injunction request by Ryanair.
A judge in London is set to hear an application by Ryanair to block the strike by its Britain-based pilots later 
Wednesday, British news agency PA reported.
Strikes could cause flight cancellations or delays in Europe, the airline said.
For Portugal, Ryanair does not expect any considerable disruptions because the airline has already arranged a 
minimal flight plan, which is required by the government, Lusa reported.
Portuguese employees walk out as Ryanair wins strike ban in Ireland
The SNPVAC union criticized the required minimal service as an attempt by the government to undermine the right 
to strike.

In Portugal, the union for cabin crew members called a five-day strike starting on Wednesday, Portuguese news 
agency Lusa reported.
Last year, strikes by Ryanair staff across Europe resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of 
the summer holiday season in August and September.
On Thursday and Friday Irish and British pilots are also seeking to take part in labour action in an effort to obtain 
better pay and work conditions.
A judge in London is set to hear an application by Ryanair to block the strike by its Britain-based pilots later 
Wednesday, British news agency PA reported.
The British pilots also plan to strike on a series of dates in September.
Similarly, a High Court ruling is due in Ireland on Wednesday, according to Irish public broadcaster RTE.
The airline is also seeking an injunction there to prevent pilots based in Ireland from striking on Thursday and 
Friday.
Strikes could cause flight cancellations or delays in Europe, the airline said.
For Portugal, Ryanair does not expect any considerable disruptions because the airline has already arranged a 
minimal flight plan, which is required by the government, Lusa reported.

Ryanair loses bid to block British pilots strike
Ryanair loses bid to block British pilots strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 21, 2019 Wednesday 9:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 326 words
Byline: Angelika Engler in Berlin, Christoph Meyer in London
Dateline: London/Lisbon (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair lost a court bid on Wednesday to stop its British pilots from taking part in strike action, after a 
similar request to block strikes in Ireland was approved.
British pilots are planning labour action on Thursday and Friday as well as on a series of dates in September.
A judge in London rejected Ryanair's application for an injunction against the British Airline Pilots' Association 
(Balpa), Britain's PA news agency reported.
Paul Gott, representing Ryanair, said strike action could be "enormously disruptive" and Ryanair would suffer 
"significant reputational" damage, the report said.
The judge said she had rejected Ryanair's "various technical and legal arguments," that the union had acted 
lawfully and that the strike could proceed.
The High Court in Dublin earlier ruled in favour of Ryanair's request to prevent a strike by pilots based in the 
country on Thursday and Friday.
The presiding judge in Dublin was quoted by PA as saying he was preventing pilots' union Forsa "from directly or 
indirectly organizing, directing or endorsing their members to participate in a strike on August 22 or 23."
The airline is also facing problems with its staff in Portugal, where the union for cabin crew members has called a 
five-day strike starting on Wednesday, Portuguese news agency Lusa reported.
Last year, strikes by Ryanair staff across Europe resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of 
the summer holiday season in August and September.
Ryanair loses bid to block British pilots strike
Strikes could cause flight cancellations or delays in Europe, the airline said.
For Portugal, Ryanair does not expect any considerable disruptions because the airline has already arranged a 
minimal flight plan, which is required by the government, Lusa reported.
The SNPVAC union criticized the required minimal service as an attempt by the government to undermine the right 
to strike.

Lufthansa head calls for slower, sustainable growth in aviation
Lufthansa head calls for slower, sustainable growth in aviation
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 20, 2019 Tuesday 11:43 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 206 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
The head of German airline Lufthansa, Carsten Spohr, said the aviation industry needs to slow down its growth and 
stop pushing forward with fare wars, and instead invest in more efficient and better quality air travel.
Speaking in Frankfurt late Monday, Spohr criticized the "unique fare war" that was waged on the Austrian and 
German market for short distance flights this summer, without explicitly naming competitor Ryanair, which is known 
for its extremely low fares.
"Five-euro (5.5-dollar) tickets don't only clog up the system, they also make us more vulnerable to criticism - and 
the many sustainable things we do as an industry are put into question," he said.
Spohr said Lufthansa stood by its responsibility as regards climate change and that it was constantly investing in 
newer, more efficient aircraft.
The airline chief also said long-distance flights would continue to be powered by fossil fuels in the future, but that jet 
fuel could be created synthetically if a climate-neutral primary energy source was available.
Spohr said the aviation tax paid by airlines and airports should be used to conduct research that would benefit the 
industry.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Amy Walker, +49 30 2852-31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 21, 2019
End of Document
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for AUGUST 19-25, 2019
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for AUGUST 19-25, 2019
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 19, 2019 Monday 4:00 AM GMT

Irish -based Ryanair pilots mull strike
Irish-based Ryanair pilots mull strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 9, 2019 Friday 5:37 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 256 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Irish-based pilots for Irish budget airline Ryanair warned on Friday of plans to strike, a union said.
The Irish union Forsa is required to give at least one week's strike notice and said it would notify management early 
next week unless the airline agrees to union pay proposals by Monday.
"At this stage, only a substantive counter-proposal, which properly addresses all areas of our claim, will be enough 
to prevent us serving notice of industrial action next week," Forsa assistant general secretary Ian McDonnell said in 
a statement.
A ballot on the strike saw 94 per cent of the union's members vote in favour. It was open for the about 180 directly-
employed Ryanair pilots based in Ireland who are members of the Irish Air Line Pilots' Association (IALPA). Ryanair 
pilots employed by agencies were not balloted.
The pilots are requesting wage hikes and better work conditions.
Ryanair countered that the labour action was supported by less than 25 per cent of Ryanair's Irish pilots, adding 
that "this disruption of customers' holiday plans has no valid mandate from Ryanair's Irish Pilots."
Earlier this week, British-based Ryanair pilots said they would strike for five days, August 22 and 23 as well as 
September 2-4, according to the British Airline Pilots Association (BALPA).
Last year, strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of 
the summer holiday season in August and September.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852-31470, <international@dpa.com;
Irish -based Ryanair pilots mull strike
Load-Date: August 10, 2019
End of Document
British-based Ryanair pilots to strike for five days
British-based Ryanair pilots to strike for five days
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 7, 2019 Wednesday 8:14 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 176 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
British-based pilots for Irish budget airline Ryanair plan to strike for a total of five days at the end of August and 
early September, a union said Wednesday.
The strike will take place on August 22 and 23 as well as September 2-4, the British Airline Pilots Association 
(BALPA) said in a statement.
Last year, strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of 
this year's summer holiday season in August and September.
"We have had no formal offer from Ryanair and it is imperative that we resolve this dispute urgently to avoid strike 
action," BALPA general secretary Brian Strutton said.
"No pilot wants to spoil the public's travel plans but at the moment it seems we have no choice."
A ballot on the strikes saw 80 per cent of the union's members vote in favour, with a member turnout of 72 per cent.
The strike was called due to disagreements over pay structure, pensions, license insurance and other benefits.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 8, 2019
End of Document
EU: Ryanair must repay 8.5 million euros of French state aid
EU: Ryanair must repay 8.5 million euros of French state aid
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 2, 2019 Friday 4:50 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 209 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair must pay back 8.5 million euros (9.4 million dollars) of illegal aid received from the French state, the 
European Commission said on Friday.
Ryanair and its subsidiary AMS received funds to promote on its website Montpellier and its environs as a tourist 
destination from the publicly-funded French tourism association APFTE, the commission found.
Between 2010 and 2017, these payments "gave Ryanair an unfair and selective advantage over its competitors" 
and also harmed other airports, EU competition commissioner Margrethe Vestager said.
The investigation into Ryanair's marketing activities for Montpellier Airport, which saw a footfall of close to 1.9 
million in 2019, was launched last year after a complaint from a competitor. As of April, the Irish airline no longer 
flies from Montpellier.
Last November, French authorities briefly impounded a Ryanair plane at Bordeaux airport to force the airline to pay 
another fine.
In 2014, the commission ordered Ryanair to repay approximately 868,000 euros in the case of the Angouleme 
airport near to Bordeaux, 2.4 million euros in the case of the Pau airport, and 6.4 million euros in the case of the 
Nimes airport.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 3, 2019
EU: Ryanair must repay 8.5 million euros of French state aid
End of Document
EU top court carves out exceptions for air passenger compensation
EU top court carves out exceptions for air passenger compensation
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 26, 2019 Wednesday 12:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 241 words
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
An airline may cite "extraordinary circumstances" in denying passengers compensation if a fuel leak on the runway 
causes a long delay, the top EU court said on Wednesday.
Passenger rights have become increasingly contested in Europe's crowded skies, and countries such as Germany 
have seen a sharp increase in complaints.
At issue is a case filed against Ryanair, which denied a passenger compensation of 250 euros (285 dollars) after a 
a flight from Italy to Belgium was delayed for four hours due to a fuel leak on the runway.
Under EU regulations, passengers may claim compensation after a delay of three hours, barring special 
circumstances.
In this case, it was aircraft fuel from another plane that had leaked on to the runway, causing a delay that "could not 
have been avoided even if all reasonable measures had been taken within the meaning of that provision," the 
European Court of Justice (ECJ) wrote in a non-binding summary.
Such a case should be considered an extraordinary circumstance, the Luxembourg judges wrote.
The court took a similar line in April in a ruling concerning the budget airline Germanwings.
The judges concluded that passengers may be denied compensation for flight delays caused by a screw on the 
runway, if the carrier proves that it did everything possible to try to stick to the timetable - another example of a 
special circumstance.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
EU top court carves out exceptions for air passenger compensation
Load-Date: June 27, 2019
End of Document
Lufthansa shares slip after profit warning
Lufthansa shares slip after profit warning
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 17, 2019 Monday 3:21 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 201 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Lufthansa's shares dropped Monday more than 12 per cent from Friday's price after the Frankfurt-based airline 
issued a profit warning.
Operating profit is now forecast to come in at between 2.0 and 2.4 billion euros (2.2 - 2.7 billion dollars), down from 
the previous estimate of between 2.4 and 3 billion euros.
Management is seeking to build up reserves of 340 million euros to cover increased tax payments over recent years 
following a new ruling by the Federal Finance Court.
According to a weekend statement by the company, the long-haul business continues to be profitable. But 
Lufthansa's budget subsidiary, Eurowings, is thought likely to make a loss in the current year.
Eurowings, which absorbed large parts of Air Berlin following its bankruptcy, is to take additional cost-cutting 
measures, which will be announced shortly.
The subsidiary is feeling the heat from competitors Ryanair and Easyjet. Lufthansa also pointed to a rise in fuel 
costs.
Lufthansa's airfreight unit, Lufthansa Cargo, is also not performing as expected. It has grounded three older 
machines and is predicting stagnant turnover for the year.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 18, 2019
Lufthansa shares slip after profit warning
End of Document
Ryanair buys Maltese start-up, expanding presence in the country
Ryanair buys Maltese start-up, expanding presence in the country
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 11, 2019 Tuesday 6:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 204 words
Dateline: Valletta (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair signed a deal with the Maltese government on Tuesday to buy Malta Air, a Maltese start-up, 
expanding its presence on the Mediterranean island.
Malta Air will operate out of Malta using a fleet of six aircraft, increasing to 10 over the next three years. 
The deal will see Ryanair aircraft from France, Italy and Germany move to the Maltese aircraft register.
The investment will allow Ryanair to grow its already sizeable presence in Malta, and access non-EU markets like 
North Africa from Malta, according to a statement.
The deal was signed in Valletta between Ryanair CEO Michael O'Leary and Maltese government officials, in the 
presence of Prime Minister Joseph Muscat. 
Muscat said Malta Air will complement the services of Air Malta, the country's flagship carrier.
"Despite the scaremongering, Air Malta has not just survived but registered its first surplus in two decades. 
Welcome Malta Air and long live Air Malta," Muscat told reporters.
Last month, Ryanair announced that its annual net profit had slumped by almost one third as overcapacity in the 
European short-haul sector caused it to cut ticket prices.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Femke Colborne, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 12, 2019
Ryanair buys Maltese start-up, expanding presence in the country
End of Document
Austria commemorates national sport and business icon Lauda
Austria commemorates national sport and business icon Lauda
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 21, 2019 Tuesday 12:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 372 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Austria's political leaders and sports figures mourned Niki Lauda as a national icon and commemorated his strong 
personality after the three-time Formula One world champion died on Monday, aged 70.
"One of the greatest and colourful characters has left us - an idol and ambitious fighter who never gave up," 
Austrian President Alexander Van der Bellen said in a statement.
Chancellor Sebastian Kurz also remembered Lauda as an airline entrepreneur.
"The race tracks were his home and aviation was his love," Kurz said, stating that "the entire country and the world 
of motorsports mourn one of the greatest Austrians."
"He is an example of courage, discipline and straightforwardness," the chancellor said of the Formula One legend 
who had achieved sports and business comebacks from an almost lethal racing accident and from the crash of a 
large passenger aircraft.
"Niki Lauda was an inspiration and visionary for the entire airline industry," Laudamotion airline said in a tribute.
Lauda, who was known as a tough businessman, originally founded the airline, sold it, bought it back, and sold it 
again to Irish budget carrier Ryanair last year.
"He was incredibly egoistic," said Helmut Marko, the Austrian advisor of the Red Bull Formula One team.
However, Lauda's personality had softened after he met his second wife Birgit, and after she gave birth to his two 
youngest children, Marko told broadcaster Oe24.
"He became more considerate, which had not been his strength," Marko said about his friend Lauda, who served as 
non-executive chairman of the Mercedes Formula One team.
Austria commemorates national sport and business icon Lauda
Lauda was friends with various Austrian top athletes, including Annemarie Moser-Proell, who ranks among the most 
successful athletes in Alpine skiing history.
"His fighting spirit after his accident, and the way he fought back - what he achieved is incredible," she said.
The former racer also fondly remembered how Lauda had picked her up with his private jet after one of her overall 
World Cup victories.
Retired Austrian tennis great Thomas Muster said he liked Lauda's "direct manner, and his way of tackling issues 
head-on."
"That's what made him special," Muster said.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Derek WilsonTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 22, 2019
End of Document
Austrian Formula One legend Niki Lauda dies at 70
Austrian Formula One legend Niki Lauda dies at 70
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 21, 2019 Tuesday 3:38 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 226 words
Byline: Holger Mehlig in Berlin
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Austrian Formula One legend Niki Lauda has died at age 70, his doctor Walter Klepetko told dpa early Tuesday.
Lauda died peacefully in his sleep on Monday surrounded by family, a family spokeswoman said in a statement.
"His unique achievements as an athlete and entrepreneur are and will remain unforgettable," the statement added.
The three-time world champion received a lung transplant last year, and was hospitalized with the flu in January. He 
had in previous years received two kidney transplants.
Lauda's head was badly burned in a fiery crash at the German Grand Prix in 1976 and his lungs were damaged by 
toxic smoke.
Following his first Formula One world title in 1975, Lauda won two more times in 1977 and 1984.
By the end of his racing career in 1985, he had competed in 171 Formula One races, won 25 of them and stood on 
the podium 54 times.
Before retiring, the racer launched Lauda Air in 1979 which he sold in the 1990s.
In 2003, he founded another airline, Niki, which he sold to Air Berlin in 2011. He bought it back in January 2018 to 
run it under the Laudamotion brand, only to sell it quickly to Irish budget carrier Ryanair.
In later years, Lauda became an adviser for the Ferrari race team, before becoming non-executive chairman of the 
Mercedes F1 team in 2012.
Austrian Formula One legend Niki Lauda dies at 70
Editorial contactsEditing by: Peter Godfrey, +61 2 9322 8064, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 21, 2019
End of Document
Niki Lauda, legendary Formula One survivor, dies at 70
Niki Lauda, legendary Formula One survivor, dies at 70
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 21, 2019 Tuesday 3:27 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 568 words
Byline: Martin Moravec in Munich, Albert Otti in Vienna and Christiane Oelrich in Geneva
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Highlight: The Austrian world champion was known for his red cap, shrewd business sense and will to survive.
Body
The Austrian world champion was known for his red cap, shrewd business sense and will to survive.
Formula One legend Niki Lauda was not a quitter.
After a horrific car crash that disfigured him for life he went on to win races, and he weathered the crash of a 
passenger jet during his time as an airline entrepreneur.
On Monday, the Austrian triple world champion died at the age of 70 less than a year after receiving an emergency 
lung transplant.
The surgery was performed almost exactly 42 years after Lauda crashed into a fence at the German Nuerburgring 
track at a speed of 200 kilometres an hour during a race.
"The impact was so hard that the helmet was ripped off my head," he said of the crash.
His Ferrari went up in flames, and it took 55 seconds to pull him out of the car.
At the hospital, a priest gave him the last rites, in light of his serious burns and damaged lung.
"But I did not want to die. I wanted to go on living," Lauda said four decades after the crash.
Lauda did not only go on living, he went on fighting.
Just 42 days after the crash, Lauda was again behind the wheel and took fourth place in the Italian Grand Prix in 
Monza, ending the championship season as runner-up to British rival James Hunt.
Niki Lauda, legendary Formula One survivor, dies at 70
"Coming back quickly was part of my strategy of not sitting at home and thinking about why this had happened to 
me," he said.
Apart from lingering health problems, the crash also left Lauda with his signature red sports cap.
His physiotherapist initially gave it to him to keep his head bandages in place, but he kept wearing it so that people 
would look him in the eye rather than at his scarred scalp.
Following his first Formula One world title in 1975, Lauda won two more times in 1977 and 1984.
By the time the Austrian ended his racing career in 1985, he had competed in 171 Formula One races, winning 25 
of them and standing on the podium 54 times.
Before retiring from the track, the racer launched Lauda Air in 1979.
In May 1991, one of his aircraft crashed after takeoff from Bangkok. All 223 passengers and crew members died.
"I was deeply shocked," Lauda said of the accident, admitting that he felt guilty until an investigation showed a 
technical problem caused the tragedy.
Lauda, known as a tough businessman, sold the airline in the 1990s.
In 2003, he founded another airline, Niki, which he sold to Air Berlin in 2011. He bought it back in January 2018 to 
run it under the Laudamotion brand, only to sell it quickly to Irish budget carrier Ryanair.
The son of an industrialist family proved his shrewdness when he started his racing career.
He lied to his grandmother to get money for his first racing car, saying he needed it to buy real estate, according to 
a book he co-authored on his business outlook.
He also faked his high school diploma in order to get parental approval to begin car racing.
In later years, Lauda became an adviser for the Ferrari race team, before becoming non-executive chairman of the 
Mercedes F1 team in 2012.
Since then, Mercedes have dominated the hybrid era with three drivers' world titles with Lewis Hamilton and one 
from the now retired Nico Rosberg alongside four constructors' championships.
Lauda was also known to motorsport fans as a television commentator over 20 years.
"Red cap, clear and direct words," Mercedes team chief Toto Wolff said in summarizing the man.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Derek Wilson, +4930285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 21, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair recognizes strikes as reason for compensation in Germany
Ryanair recognizes strikes as reason for compensation in Germany
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 13, 2019 Monday 9:29 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 263 words
Dateline: Hamburg (dpa) - 
Body
Dublin-based budget carrier Ryanair has paid damages to individual passengers whose flights did not reach their 
destinations on time due to strikes, a Hamburg court said Monday.
In at least five legal proceedings, Ryanair recognized the demands of the plaintiff, a Hamburg court spokesman 
said.
Ryanair declined to comment on the proceedings.
Ryanair has previously refused to compensate passengers whose flights were cancelled due to strikes by Ryanair 
staff.
Under EU legislation for flight cancellations, an airline should pay 250 euros (293 dollars) to each passenger, 
unless they are informed at least two weeks in advance or are offered alternative flights arriving at their destination 
the same day.
An airline can withhold compensation if it can show that the cancellation is "caused by extraordinary circumstances 
which could not have been avoided even if all reasonable measures had been taken," according to the rules.
Last year, Ryanair argued that no compensation is payable "when the union is acting unreasonably and totally 
beyond the airline's control."
Air travel legal service provider Flightright, which has submitted lawsuits on behalf of hundreds of clients, disagrees, 
saying the company has provoked strikes with years of low wages and could have avoided an escalation of the 
labour action.
Flightright legal expert Oskar de Felice said the airline's behaviour was tactical: Ryanair wants to prevent the 
Hamburg court from pushing the issue on to the European Court of Justice.
Ryanair recognizes strikes as reason for compensation in Germany
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: May 14, 2019
End of Document
Construction of new Frankfurt Airport terminal starts amid protest
Construction of new Frankfurt Airport terminal starts amid protest
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 29, 2019 Monday 4:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 259 words
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
The foundation stone for a major extension to Frankfurt Airport in the form of a third terminal was laid on Monday in 
the face of protest from local residents fearing an increase in noise and emissions.
As the official ceremony was held with 700 invited guests, opponents of the terminal held a vigil at the airport's 
Terminal 1.
The first phase, to be completed in 2021, will take some of the load off the current two terminals, which handled 70 
million passengers last year. By 2023, the new terminal is intended to handle 21 million passengers.
When complete, up to 25 million passengers a year will pass through it.
Fraport, the company that operates Germany's main hub, is planning to invest some 4 billion euros (4.5 billion 
dollars) in the project - one of the largest private infrastructure undertakings in Europe.
While the company has not identified potential clients, speculation was that the new gates available from 2021 
would be well suited to the needs of budget carriers, such as Dublin-based Ryanair.
Speaking for the protestors opposed to the new terminal, Thomas Scheffler said the foundation stone was a 
gravestone for the region. The protestors are calling for a halt to the project and an extension of the overnight 
period during which no flights are allowed.
They are also demanding a cut in the number of flight movements to 380,000 a year. Last year the airport saw more 
than 512,000 flight movements and is aiming at capacity for more than 700,000.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Monica Raymunt, +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Construction of new Frankfurt Airport terminal starts amid protest
Load-Date: April 30, 2019
End of Document
EU court dismisses Lufthansa action on subsidy for German airport
EU court dismisses Lufthansa action on subsidy for German airport
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 12, 2019 Friday 6:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Dateline: Luxembourg (dpa) - 
Body
An EU court on Friday dismissed a legal action by German airline Lufthansa that contested subsidies to Frankfurt-
Hahn Airport and contracts it entered into with Dublin-based budget carrier Ryanair.
Lufthansa, which does not use the airport, had failed to show that its business had been negatively affected enough 
to justify its complaint, the European Union's General Court ruled.
At issue are subsidies worth millions of euros paid out in previous years. Lufthansa - Europe's largest airline if all its 
subsidiaries are included - alleged unfair competition.
It challenged a 2014 decision by the European Commission to approve the subsidies, on the basis that they were 
not in breach of EU competition rules.
Hahn lies some 120 kilometres from Frankfurt, where Lufthansa has its main hub.
The 2014 decision allowed payments to Hahn airport by Fraport, which operated both Hahn and Frankfurt Airport at 
the time, as well as two German states.
Of the three, only one of the German states - Hesse - still holds a minority share in Hahn. In 2017, China's HNA 
took over 82.5 per cent of the airport.
The commission decided in 2014 that the support for Hahn airport was either not state subsidies or was compliant 
with EU subsidy rules.
Lufthansa said it would consider whether to challenge the decision before the European Court of Justice, the bloc's 
top tribunal.
EU court dismisses Lufthansa action on subsidy for German airport

German union strikes deal with Ryanair on cabin crew pay
German union strikes deal with Ryanair on cabin crew pay
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 27, 2019 Wednesday 11:09 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 191 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Agreement has been reached with Dublin-based budget carrier Ryanair on a pay deal for 1,100 cabin crew 
stationed in Germany, services union Verdi announced in Berlin on Wednesday.
Cabin crew are to receive an additional 600 euros (680 dollars) a month in basic pay, additional supplements of up 
to 250 euros and social arrangements on being transferred, the union said.
There was no immediate comment from Ryanair, which has traditionally been hostile to unionization among its staff.
German labour law was being implemented on behalf of the Germany-based staff for the first time, Verdi executive 
member Christine Behle said. She noted there was as yet no agreement on setting up a works council of the kind 
usual in larger German companies.
In December, Ryanair and Germany's Cockpit pilots' union (VC) agreed on the major points of a settlement in their 
pay dispute, averting strike action ahead of the Christmas holiday season.
The more than 400 Ryanair pilots stationed in Germany had previously gone on strike, stopping work three times 
over the course of 2018.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 28, 2019
End of Document
Ryanair found in 'serious violation' of Italian labour laws
Ryanair found in 'serious violation' of Italian labour laws
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 6, 2019 Wednesday 2:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 165 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair has breached Italian labour laws by evading social security and bonus payments for its airport staff, 
according to Italy's labour inspection agency.
"Serious violations" were documented during the course of 2014 at more than a dozen Italian airports served by the 
low-cost Irish airline, the agency said in a statement.
Ryanair was accused of having made "illicit recourse" to about 600 third-party workers to save on insurance, 
pension and bonus payments it would have had to pay to in-house staff.
The illegal conduct took place at airports in Bari, Bergamo, Pisa, Rome, Brindisi, Cagliari, Catania, Lamezia Terme, 
Milan Malpensa, Palermo, Pescara, Alghero and Trapani, according to the agency.
The airline was asked to pay 9.2 million euros (10.4 million dollars) in unpaid labour charges and fines, and 
investigators said they are now probing Ryanair's labour practices in the years following 2014.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin PowellTel: +49 30 2852-31472; <international@dpa.com;

Ryanair moves spare parts from Britain to EU countries before Brexit
Ryanair moves spare parts from Britain to EU countries before Brexit
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 2, 2019 Saturday 5:45 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 144 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's biggest budget airline is taking precautions in case of a no-deal Brexit by shifting some of its spare parts 
from a British central storage unit to other EU locations.
Ryanair's director of maintenance and engineering told dpa that Britain's unregulated departure from the European 
Union could make moving parts around difficult because of customs restrictions, for example.
"We're concerned that it could take longer to get spare parts to airports where we need them quickly from the 
central storage in Stansted," Karsten Muehlenfeld said, referring to a London airport.
Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary is an outspoken critic of Brexit, though he says his Irish airline, which is registered in 
the EU and not in Britain, will not be as badly affected as some British-based airlines.

EU report calls for improved labour standards in aviation
EU report calls for improved labour standards in aviation
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 1, 2019 Friday 5:09 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 256 words
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Union needs to better protect aviation workers from exploitation, the European Commission said 
Friday.
The bloc's executive released a report outlining proposals to strengthen labour conditions for pilots and cabin crew, 
including tighter regulation of non-contractual labour and undeclared work, which typically do not grant benefits or 
protections.
Among the proposals was convening a group of labour and aviation experts that will advise the commission and 
member states on how to better implement labour laws.
The report comes at a time of rising labour unrest in the industry, most notably seen in a series of strikes by Ryanair 
pilots and cabin crew since mid-2018.
"Increased competition, automation and digitalization [have] also had an impact on the workforce, notably through 
the development of atypical forms of employment," the commission said in a press release.
"This has led to legal uncertainty and the risk of disrupting the level playing field among airlines," it added.
Two million workers in the EU are directly employed in the aviation industry, while it supports 9.4 million jobs in total 
and contributes 110 billion euros (125.4 billion dollars) to the bloc's economy, the commission release noted.
Meanwhile, the number of daily flights has jumped from under 10,000 in 1992 to around 25,000 in 2017.
The German pilots association Vereinigung Cockpit welcomed the commission announcement as a "long-awaited 
wake-up call."
EU report calls for improved labour standards in aviation
Editorial contactsEditing by: Femke Colborne, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 2, 2019
End of Document
Italy regulator fines Ryanair , Wizz Air for hand-luggage restrictions
Italy regulator fines Ryanair, Wizz Air for hand-luggage restrictions
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 21, 2019 Thursday 9:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 116 words
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Low cost airlines Ryanair and Wizz Air were fined by Italy's antitrust regulator on Thursday for their hand-luggage 
restrictions.
The Italian Competition Authority (AGCM) said extra charges for larger carry-on bags, which the two airlines 
introduced last year, represented an unfair trade practice.
Being able to take on board a reasonably sized bag as part of the standard air fare is an "essential service" that 
should not be subject to additional fees, AGCM said.
It fined Ryanair 3 million euros (3.4 million dollars) and Wizz Air 1 million euros. Both companies were given 60 
days to change their luggage policy.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;

Ryanair reports Q3 loss of 20 million euros, blames lower fares
Ryanair reports Q3 loss of 20 million euros, blames lower fares
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 4, 2019 Monday 7:50 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 133 words
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair on Monday reported a third quarter net loss of 20 million euros (23 million dollars), blaming 
a decline in average fare prices.
The airline said it carried 32.7 million passengers in the three months ending on December 31, an 8-per-cent 
increase on the same period last year, while revenue increased by 9 per cent to 1.53 billion euros.
However the increases were offset by rises in fuel, staff and compensation costs.
"While a 20-million-euro loss in Q3 was disappointing, we take comfort that this was entirely due to weaker than 
expected air fares so our customers are enjoying record low prices, which is good for current and future traffic 
growth," Ryanair boss Michael O'Leary said.
