Ryanair completes takeover of Austria 's Laudamotion
Ryanair completes takeover of Austria's Laudamotion
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 29, 2019 Tuesday 12:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 218 words
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Irish budget carrier Ryanair has taken complete control over Laudamotion, the Austrian airline announced Tuesday.
Ryanair bought the remaining 25 per cent of the shares from the Niki Lauda Holding at the end of December, in 
addition to the 75 per cent it had previously held.
Despite the takeover, former Formula One champion Niki Lauda will retain a seat on Laudamotion's company 
board, chief executive Andreas Gruber told a press conference at Vienna International Airport.
Lauda, who also serves as non-executive chairman of the Mercedes Formula One team, originally founded the 
airline under the name Niki in 2003 and sold it to the Air Berlin group in 2011.
Following Air Berlin's bankruptcy, he bought it back last year and re-established it as Laudamotion, only to sell it 
quickly to Ryanair.
Laudamotion made a loss of about 140 million euros (160 million dollars) last year.
Gruber said he expects the loss to narrow to 50 million euros in 2019, and to start making profits next year.
Laudamotion, which mainly connects European airports, also announced plans Tuesday to double its fleet to 40 
aircraft until the 2021/2022 financial year.
Annual passenger numbers are to rise to 10 million by then, from 4 million last year.

Ryanair completes takeover of Austria 's Laudamotion

No-deal Brexit: Total chaos or free-trade bonanza?
No-deal Brexit: Total chaos or free-trade bonanza?
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 15, 2019 Tuesday 11:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 734 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Extreme doomsday scenarios for a no-deal Brexit - often based on loosely-defined scenarios - forecast grounded 
passenger planes, enormous queues at customs points and businesses crippled by bureaucratic chaos.
Pro-Brexit lawmakers from Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party, many of whom prefer no deal to her 
deal, insist that there is little to worry about.
The truth probably lies somewhere in between these two extremes.
If British lawmakers do not accept May's withdrawal deal and fail to ratify it before March 29, Britain would be on 
track for an unregulated Brexit.
Britain could seek an extension of the two-year Brexit negotiating process triggered by May in March 2017.
Otherwise, EU rules would cease to apply in Britain, which would drop out of shared arrangements such as 
common air-traffic rules or trade deals with third countries.
The land border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland poses a particular problem. Efforts to keep 
that border open have been at the heart of Brexit negotiations.
British citizens living in the EU and EU citizens in Britain could also face uncertainty over their status.
The Confederation of British Industry (CBI) warned on Friday that the economic consequences of a no-deal Brexit 
"would be profound, widespread and lasting."
"Businesses would face new costs and tariffs," CBI director-general Carolyn Fairbairn said in a speech. "Our ports 
would be disrupted, separating firms from the parts they need to supply their customers."
Eurosceptics say such predictions are part of a "project fear" to persuade people to accept May's deal.
No-deal Brexit: Total chaos or free-trade bonanza?
They say the two sides would be able to implement a series of rapid, sectoral mini-deals to minimize disruption 
before they negotiate an alternative, perhaps Canada-style deal after Brexit.
In their favour, two of the largest budget airlines operating in Britain - Ryanair and easyJet - have both said in recent 
weeks that they anticipate relatively little disruption from a no-deal Brexit.
Jean-Marc Puissesseau, head of the French ports of Boulogne-Calais, told the BBC last week that he had been 
preparing for a no-deal Brexit for a year and "will be ready" in case Britain leaves the EU without a deal.
"We will not check the trucks more than we are doing today with the migrants," Puissesseau said, referring to 
checks for illegal migrants trying to reach Britain from France.
In parliament on Wednesday, Environment Secretary Michael Gove, a senior member of May's cabinet, said there 
had been "some exaggerated claims about the impact of a no-deal Brexit, and the British economy is resilient."
In answer to a question on the potential impact of a no-deal Brexit on agriculture, however, Gove agreed that 
"farmers in some of [Britain's] most vulnerable sectors ... would be significantly adversely affected in the short term."
The Brexiteers argue that any short-term damage would be more than offset by the long-term, liberal trade deals 
Britain plans to sign with major non-EU economies such as the United States, China and India.
May announced plans last month to make planning for a no-deal Brexit an "operational priority" for the government.
She told parliament that a no-deal Brexit would bring risks to "the jobs, services and security of the people we serve 
by turning our backs on an agreement [with the EU]."
May highlighted preparations for potential post-Brexit problems "such as the flow of traffic into different ports here in 
the UK."
But she stopped short of earlier forecasts of doom issued by her government and the central bank.
Under her withdrawal agreement, Britain's economy would be 3.9 per cent smaller in 15 years' time than it would be 
if the country remained in the EU, according to a government forecast in late November.
A no-deal Brexit would see GDP fall even further, by 9.3 per cent over the same period, it said.
The Bank of England forecast the same day that the pound would depreciate by 25 per cent against the US dollar in 
a "disorderly" scenario.
In that case, inflation could skyrocket to 6.5 per cent, and unemployment to 7.5 per cent, while GDP could fall by 
nearly 8 per cent, the bank said.
Angry Brexiteers dismissed the two reports, while even pro-EU economist Andrew Sentance, a former Bank of 
England adviser, tweeted that both forecasts appeared to "support political objectives."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 16, 2019
End of Document
Passengers rate Ryanair as worst airline in Britain in annual survey
Passengers rate Ryanair as worst airline in Britain in annual survey
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
January 5, 2019 Saturday 4:35 AM GMT
Copyright 2019 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 162 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget carrier Ryanair has been rated the worst airline in Britain for the sixth year in a row in the Which Travel 
annual airline survey, the consumer satisfaction and advice firm said Saturday.
Passengers gave the airline the survey's lowest possible rating for boarding, seat comfort, cabin environment and 
food and drink.
Ryanair achieved a customer score of 40 per cent, behind other short-haul companies Thomas Cook Airlines (52 
per cent) and Wizz Air (54 per cent), which mainly fly to destinations in Eastern and Central Europe.
Passengers cited frustration with cancelled flights, ever-changing luggage rules and the airline's declining 
punctuality record as factors in their negative assessment.
Thousands of respondents told Which "that they would never again fly Ryanair, even if it was cheaper than its 
rivals."
Which Travel annually rates airlines based on customer satisfaction.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Benjamin Cooper, +61 2 9322 8064,  <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: January 5, 2019
End of Document
Gatwick reopens after drone sightings, but delays expected
Gatwick reopens after drone sightings, but delays expected
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 21, 2018 Friday 12:34 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 350 words
Byline: Chiara Palazzo in Sydney, Christoph Meyer in London and Lennart Simonsson in Lahti, Finland
Body
London (dpa) - London's Gatwick Airport - Britain's second-busiest - reopened Friday after a 36-hour shutdown 
caused by drone sightings.
The disruption since Wednesday affected tens of thousands of passengers and caused hundreds of flights to be 
cancelled.
Military equipment has also been deployed as part of attempts to prevent further disruption.
Transport Minister Chris Grayling told the BBC that the protective measures included "military capabilities," but did 
not offer details.
He said there had been around 40 drone sightings while the airport was closed.
Military experts have joined police units, including snipers and a helicopter. Police officers were also sighted on the 
roof of a building at the airport on Friday.
Authorities were also searching for the drone operators after the multiple drone sightings began late on 
Wednesday.
Flying a drone within 1 kilometre of an airport or airfield boundary was made illegal in Britain in July, but aviation 
officials and lawmakers have called for a 5-kilometre exclusion zone.
Although flights have resumed, the airport cautioned on its Twitter account that there were "knock-on delays and 
cancellations to flights."
The airport said 765 flights were scheduled for departure and arrival on Friday, while about 140 have been 
cancelled.
Gatwick reopens after drone sightings, but delays expected
"We are now operating at almost normal runway conditions and the challenge for the airlines, as the result of this 
disruption, [is that] their planes are not all in the right place," Gatwick's chief operating officer Chris Woodroofe said, 
according to the BBC.
Passengers were advised to check the status of their flight before heading off for the airport.
Low-cost airline Ryanair for instance said its planes would use London's third largest airport, Stansted. Passengers 
have been informed, Ryanair said.
EasyJet, another no-frills carrier, meanwhile advised passengers to check its designated flight checker app rather 
than tweet for flight information "due to the unprecedented volume of tweets we're receiving at the moment."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: December 22, 2018
End of Document
Gatwick works on 'contingency plans' as drone sightings continue
Gatwick works on 'contingency plans' as drone sightings continue
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 20, 2018 Thursday 11:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 531 words
Byline: Chiara Palazzo in Sydney and Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
London's Gatwick Airport is working on "contingency plans" for Friday, after the drone sightings that have caused 
hundreds of flights to be cancelled continued for a second night late Thursday.
Britain's second-busiest airport would remain closed for the rest of Thursday, chief operating officer Chris 
Woodroofe said, adding that it was considering cancelling all flights the following day.
"I think what's clear from the last 24 hours is that drones are a UKaviation issue, or even an international aviation 
issue," Woodroofe told reporters.
"We have had the police, we have had the military seeking to bring this drone down for the last 24 hours and to 
date that has not been successful."
"So Gatwick Airport is still closed, it's closed for the rest of this evening and our intention is to review on an ongoing 
basis whether we can open tomorrow.
"But we are working up contingency plans all the way through to no flights tomorrow."
He said he felt "terribly sorry" for the 120,000 passengers whose flights had been disrupted by "this criminal 
activity."
Ryanair said it was rerouting its Friday flights from Gatwick out of Stansted Airport.
Military experts joined police units, including snipers and a helicopter on Thursday in the search for the operators of 
drones but with no success.
Gatwick works on 'contingency plans' as drone sightings continue
Prime Minister Theresa May earlier told reporters that the government would work with airport authorities to "bring 
this to a close such that people will be able to get on to the travel that they were expecting over the Christmas."
"The activity we have seen is illegal and those who are caught endangering aircraft can face up to five years in 
prison," she added.
Defence Secretary Gavin Williamson declined to say how the military would help, while his ministry tweeted only 
that it would provide "specialist equipment" to help the police.
Flights were suspended after reports of multiple sightings of drones flying over the airport in the southern English 
county of Sussex from 9 pm on Wednesday.
Sussex Police said officers believed "the Gatwick devices used are of an industrial specification."
British media published photographs of a police helicopter flying over the runway and armed officers carrying rifles 
near the airport.
The police said there was no indication of terrorism.
Superintendent Justin Burtenshaw, head of armed policing for Sussex, told the BBC it was "challenging" to find the 
drone operators.
"Each time we believe we get close to the operator, the drone disappears; when we look to reopen the airfield, the 
drone reappears," Burtenshaw said.
Flying a drone within 1 kilometre of an airport or airfield boundary was made illegal in Britain in July, but aviation 
officials and lawmakers have called for a 5-kilometre exclusion zone.
The British Airline Pilots Association (BALPA) said the first 11 months of 2018 saw 117 "near misses," compared to 
93 for the whole of 2017.
"The public needs to understand that drones are not just toys and could have catastrophic consequences if they 
collide with an aircraft," BALPA's head of flight safety, Rob Hunter, said in a statement on the Gatwick disruption.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Helen Livingstone, +61 2 9322 8065, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: December 21, 2018

No-deal Brexit: 'Managed glidepath' or total chaos?
No-deal Brexit: 'Managed glidepath' or total chaos?
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 18, 2018 Tuesday 8:42 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 706 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Extreme doomsday scenarios for a no-deal Brexit - often based on loosely-defined scenarios - forecast grounded 
passenger planes, enormous queues at customs points and businesses crippled by bureaucratic chaos.
But pro-Brexit lawmakers from Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative party, many of whom prefer no deal to 
her deal, insist that there is little to worry about.
The truth probably lies somewhere in between these two extremes.
If British lawmakers do not accept May's withdrawal deal and fail to ratify it before March 29, Britain would be on 
track for an unregulated Brexit.
EU rules would cease to apply in Britain, which would drop out of shared arrangements such as common air traffic 
rules or trade deals with third countries.
The land border between Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland poses a particular problem. Efforts to keep 
that border open have been at the heart of Brexit negotiations.
British citizens living in the EU and EU citizens in Britain could also face uncertainty over their status.
But according to British eurosceptics, such predictions are part of a "project fear" to persuade people to accept 
May's deal.
They say the two sides would be able to agree a series of rapid, sectoral mini-deals to minimize disruption before 
they negotiate an alternative, perhaps Canada-style deal after Brexit.
No-deal Brexit: 'Managed glidepath' or total chaos?
In their favour, two of the largest budget airlines operating in Britain - Ryanair and easyJet - have both said in recent 
weeks that they anticipate relatively little disruption from a no-deal Brexit.
Penny Mordaunt, a prominent pro-Brexit minister in May's cabinet, coined an addition to the growing Brexit lexicon 
late Monday: "managed glidepath."
"The chief concern businesses have in my constituency about no deal would be the absence of a smooth and 
managed glidepath to future trading relationships," The Sun newspaper quoted Mordaunt as saying in a speech at 
a private members' club in London.
"It's in our interest, and the interest of every member state of the EU, that we have a smooth transition and that is 
what we should be focusing on in the immediate future," Mordaunt said.
The Brexiteers argue that any short-term damage would be more than offset by the long-term trade deals Britain 
plans to sign with major non-EU economies such as the United States, China and India.
"Leaving without a deal is not the end of the world," Jacob Rees-Mogg, who heads a group of dozens of 
eurosceptic Conservative lawmakers, tweeted on Tuesday, as May's cabinet announced plans to make planning for 
a no-deal Brexit an "operational priority" for the government.
Defence Secretary Gacin Williamson said 3,500 troops will be placed on standby in case they are needed by the 
government.
May admitted to parliament on Monday that a no-deal Brexit would bring risks to "the jobs, services and security of 
the people we serve by turning our backs on an agreement [with the EU]."
She said the government had already stepped up preparations for potential post-Brexit problems "such as the flow 
of traffic into different ports here in the UK."
But May stopped short of the forecasts of doom issued last month by her government and the central bank.
Under her withdrawal agreement, Britain's economy would be 3.9 per cent smaller in 15 years' time than it would be 
if the country remained in the EU, according to a government forecast.
A no-deal Brexit would see GDP fall even further, by 9.3 per cent from GDP over the same period, it said.
The Bank of England warned the same day of economic chaos from a no-deal Brexit, forecasting that the pound 
would depreciate by 25 per cent to the US dollar in a "disorderly" scenario.
In that case, inflation could skyrocket to 6.5 per cent, and unemployment to 7.5 per cent, while GDP could fall by 
nearly 8 per cent, the bank said.
Angry Brexiteers dismissed the two reports, while even pro-EU economist Andrew Sentance, a former Bank of 
England adviser, tweeted that the reputation of economic forecasts had "taken a bad blow."
Both forecasts appeared to "support political objectives," Sentance said. "Let's debate Brexit - which I strongly 
oppose - rationally without recourse to bogus forecasts."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Monica Raymunt, +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: December 19, 2018
End of Document
Britain sues Ryanair over refusal to compensate strike-hit passengers
Britain sues Ryanair over refusal to compensate strike-hit passengers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 5, 2018 Wednesday 12:36 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 245 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Britain's aviation regulator on Wednesday announced legal action against budget airline Ryanair over its refusal to 
pay compensation to passengers affected by strikes this summer.
The UK Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) said it had launched enforcement action after the airline refused to 
compensate passengers whose flights were cancelled due to strikes by Ryanair staff.
Ryanair deemed the strikes "unreasonable" and claimed this meant the tens of thousands of passengers affected 
by hundreds of flight cancellations across Europe were not entitled to compensation under EU regulations.
The CAA said it rejected the airline's claim that the industrial action, organized by trade unions, constituted 
"extraordinary circumstances" that could be exempt from the compensation provisions.
Under EU legislation for flight cancellations, an airline should pay 250 euros (293 dollars) to each passenger, 
unless they are informed at least two weeks in advance or are offered alternative flights arriving at their destination 
the same day.
An airline can withhold compensation if it can show that the cancellation is "caused by extraordinary circumstances 
which could not have been avoided even if all reasonable measures had been taken," according to the rules.
Ryanair argued in late July that no compensation was payable "when the union is acting unreasonably and totally 
beyond the airline's control."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Amy Walker, +49 30 2852-31472, <international@dpa.com;
Britain sues Ryanair over refusal to compensate strike-hit passengers
Load-Date: December 6, 2018

Ryanair averts strikes through pay deal with its German pilots
Ryanair averts strikes through pay deal with its German pilots
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
December 4, 2018 Tuesday 12:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 197 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt,
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair and Germany's Cockpit pilots' union (VC) have agreed the major points of a settlement in their pay dispute, 
averting strike action ahead of the Christmas holiday season, both sides announced in Frankfurt on Tuesday.
The pay deal, which will run to March 2023, is set to be in place by the end of February next year.
"I'm very optimistic on this," VC's Ingolf Schumacher told dpa.
The more than 400 Ryanair pilots stationed in Germany went on strike for the first time a little under a year ago and 
stopped work three times over the course of 2018.
Under the tentative agreement, starting co-pilots are to receive fixed pay of 50,000 euros (57,000 dollars), an 
effective doubling in pay, while captains will see a smaller percentage rise to 100,000 euros.
Europe's largest budget carrier is to employ its German-based pilots under German law from the end of February, 
Schumacher said.
The Dublin-based carrier flies its Boeing 737s to more than 215 airports in 37 countries, operating from 86 bases in 
Europe and North Africa.
Last month, it struck a deal with the German union Verdi on cabin crew pay.

Ryanair pays up after France impounds plane just before takeoff
Ryanair pays up after France impounds plane just before takeoff
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 9, 2018 Friday 4:46 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 220 words
Byline: Pol O Gradaigh in Paris
Dateline: Paris (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair paid French authorities 525,000 euros (596,000 dollars) Friday to release a plane seized at 
Bordeaux Airport the day before, the country's aviation authorities said.
The Irish carrier's climbdown came too late for the 149 passengers who had been forced to disembark from their 
Thursday afternoon flight to London when the jet was impounded on the tarmac.
France's civil aviation directorate earlier said it was "regrettable" the plane had to be impounded "as a last resort" in 
order to recoup state aid to Ryanair that the European Union had ruled was illegal.
The passengers experienced a five-hour delay but made it to their destination with a later Ryanair flight, the 
directorate said.
In 2014, the European Commission said Ryanair had to repay 858,000 euros' (973,000 dollars') worth of rebates 
and marketing arrangements it received at Angouleme airport, not far from Bordeaux.
The EU at the time also ordered authorities to recoup money from Ryanair and Transavia over benefits they had 
received at two other French regional airports.
Ryanair did not respond to a request for comment. The plane was released back to the airline at about 12:30 pm 
(1130 GMT) after the payment was received, authorities said.

France impounds Ryanair plane to recoup banned subsidies
France impounds Ryanair plane to recoup banned subsidies
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 9, 2018 Friday 11:44 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 187 words
Byline: Pol O Gradaigh in Paris
Dateline: Paris (dpa) - 
Body
France has impounded a plane operated by budget carrier Ryanair at Bordeaux Airport in order to recoup state aid 
paid to the Irish airline, aviation authorities said on Friday.
The plane's 149 passengers, heading to London, were already on board and had to disembark when the aircraft 
was seized on Thursday evening, the airport said.
The passengers experienced a five-hour delay but made it to their destination with a later Ryanair flight, France's 
civil aviation directorate said.
It was "regrettable" that the plane had to be impounded "as a last resort" after several efforts to get Ryanair to repay 
the subsidies had failed, the directorate said.
In 2014, the European Commission said Ryanair had to repay 858,000 euros' (973,000 dollars') worth of rebates 
and marketing arrangements it received at Angouleme airport.
The EU at the time also ordered authorities to recoup money from Ryanair and Transavia over benefits they had 
received at two other French regional airports.
Ryanair did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

Ryanair strikes deal with German cabin crew union
Ryanair strikes deal with German cabin crew union
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 8, 2018 Thursday 2:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 202 words
Byline: Christoph Zeiher and Ella Joyner in Berlin
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair has come to an agreement with the union Verdi in a dispute over wages paid to German cabin crew, the 
budget airline said on Thursday.
The deal, which according to Ryanair includes pay increases and other benefits, is yet to be approved in a cabin 
crew ballot. Ryanair expects the vote to take place in the coming week.
Verdi confirmed the deal with Ryanair without giving further details.
The company said it was "pleased" to sign the agreement, which follows similar deals in Italy, Greece and Sweden.
The Irish air carrier said these were "concrete signs of the substantial progress Ryanair is making in concluding 
agreements with our people and their unions in many different EU countries."
Verdi had been pushing for Ryanair to comply fully with German labour law - a move Ryanair says has now been 
confirmed.
Ryanair cabin staff in several European countries went on strike in September. Ryanair workers in Germany also 
took part, with Verdi saying the company's pay offer was unsatisfactory.
As a result of industrial action in August, Ryanair struck off some 400 flights in European countries, including 150 in 
Germany.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair strikes deal with German cabin crew union
Load-Date: November 9, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair sacks six staff over 'fake' photo of crew sleeping on floor
Ryanair sacks six staff over 'fake' photo of crew sleeping on floor
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 7, 2018 Wednesday 11:46 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 262 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair has sacked six cabin staff over a photograph of them appearing to sleep on the floor of an 
airport crew room, insisting that the picture was staged to back a "false claim."
The six cabin staff, who were based in Porto in Portugal, were dismissed from their jobs on Monday "for breach of 
contract on grounds of gross misconduct," Ryanair said in an emailed statement on Wednesday.
The airline said the group had staged "a fake photograph to support a false claim - widely reported in international 
media outlets - that they were 'forced to sleep on the floor' of the Malaga crew room."
It said their action had "damaged their employer's reputation and caused an irreparable breach of trust" with 
Ryanair.
After the photograph circulated on social media last month, Ryanair posted footage from a security camera in the 
room, which showed uniformed staff sitting on chairs in the room before some of them went to lie on the floor to 
pose for the picture.
Portuguese trade union SNPVAC, which represents the staff, said earlier that the photograph was "a gesture of 
protest" against the conditions they endured after they were stranded in Spain by a storm.
The Ryanair staff were not given hotel rooms and were left "without the minimum legal requirements for suitable 
accommodation," with inadequate access to food and drink, and enough seating for only one-third of them, the 
union said.
It said Ryanair's claim that the viral photograph was staged was itself "fake news."
Ryanair sacks six staff over 'fake' photo of crew sleeping on floor

US pension fund sues Ryanair and boss O'Leary for deceiving investors
US pension fund sues Ryanair and boss O'Leary for deceiving investors
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 7, 2018 Wednesday 9:07 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 154 words
Byline: Hannes Breustedt in New York
Dateline: New York (dpa) - 
Body
Irish budget airline Ryanair and its chief executive Michael O'Leary are being sued for allegedly providing 
misleading information to investors on the company's relations with some workers.
A pension fund in Alabama accuses Ryanair of deceiving investors about conflicts with pilots and other employees, 
which caused clear losses in the company's stock market value, according to a complaint lodged at a New York 
court.
Ryanair rejected the accusations levelled against it on Wednesday, saying that the "claims are doomed to fail as 
they have no basis in fact or reality."
The pension fund is seeking compensation for damages due to the decline in share prices. It wants to pursue the 
case as a class action lawsuit, hoping that other investors will follow suit.
It remains to be seen whether the court will approve or throw out the legal complaint.

Dutch court prohibits forced relocation of Dutch Ryanair pilots
Dutch court prohibits forced relocation of Dutch Ryanair pilots
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 2:27 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 228 words
Byline: Annette Birschel in Amsterdam
Dateline: Amsterdam (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair cannot relocate 16 of its pilots based in the Netherlands to other countries, a Dutch court 
has ruled.
The court in the southern city of Den Bosch stopped the planned forced relocations on Thursday.
Ryanair said it will appeal the decision. The Irish airline had notified the pilots of the relocations on October 1 
because its site in the city of Eindhoven was being closed.
The pilots fought the decision in court, saying the forced relocations were a reaction to recent strikes.
The court agreed with their position on Thursday.
"It appears as though the decision was made as a penalty for earlier strikes," the court said in a statement.
Ryanair has had a difficult year plagued by strike action across Europe. Last month, it reported a 7-per-cent fall in 
profits in the first half of its financial year, blaming "widespread damage" from the strikes, among other things.
Dutch pilots joined the biggest strike in Ryanair's history in August, which led to cancellations across Europe.
Ryanair has announced the closing of its site at Eindhoven, but the court said the company hadn't sufficiently 
proven that the closure was necessary for business reasons.
According to the law in Ireland, where Ryanair is headquartered, such forced relocations would be allowed.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Dutch court prohibits forced relocation of Dutch Ryanair pilots

Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 1:51 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 290 words
Byline: Femke Colborne in Berlin and Lena Klimkeit in Rome
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Passengers with low-cost airline Ryanair will no longer be able to take a 10-kilogram piece of hand luggage on 
board for free under a new policy introduced on Thursday.
Under the new rules, passengers who want to bring anything bigger than a "small personal bag" will be charged 
extra unless they are a priority boarding customer.
Priority boarding costs 6 euros (7 dollars). Customers who do not choose priority boarding will have to pay 10 euros 
for an extra piece of cabin baggage.
The new policy has provoked outrage on social media, with some customers claiming they will never fly with 
Ryanair again.
Italy's antitrust watchdog on Wednesday said in a statement that it was banning the new policy from taking effect in 
the country.
Bringing hand luggage on board a flight was an "essential component" of a flight, Antitrust Italia said in a statement, 
claiming that extra charges for hand luggage were misleading to customers.
The authority demanded the suspension all activities that involved charging customers extra to carry a large piece 
of hand luggage.
Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely said the airline would appeal the decision, and claimed the regulation is 
transparent and benefits customers.
Ryanair has had a difficult year plagued by strike action across Europe. Last month, it reported a 7-per-cent fall in 
profits in the first half of its financial year, blaming "widespread damage" from the strikes, among other things.
Ryanair introduces new hand luggage rules amid competition concerns
Ryanair also came under heavy criticism last month for its lacklustre response to a passenger who launched a 
racist rant at the woman sitting next to him, after a video showing the incident was circulated on social media.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: November 2, 2018

Ryanair to appeal Italy 's suspension of hand luggage regulation
Ryanair to appeal Italy's suspension of hand luggage regulation
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
November 1, 2018 Thursday 12:58 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 89 words
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair says it will appeal a decision by Italian competition authorities to suspend hand luggage 
regulations it introduced on November 1.
Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely said the regulation, which means that passengers who want to bring anything 
bigger than a "small personal bag" on board will be charged extra, is transparent and benefits customers.
The news comes after Italy's antitrust watchdog demanded the suspension of all activities that involved charging 
customers extra to carry a large piece of hand luggage.

Brussels Airport strike ends amid preliminary deal
Brussels Airport strike ends amid preliminary deal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 31, 2018 Wednesday 4:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Baggage handlers and the firm Aviapartner have reached a deal to end a strike that had disrupted operations at 
Brussels Airport, allowing normal operations to resume, the airport announced Wednesday.
"Aviapartner will gradually resume activities as of this afternoon, which will allow for a return to normal operations 
for the flights handled by Aviapartner," the airport said on its web site.
The airport added it "deplores the major impact this unannounced strike has had on passengers and airlines," 
noting that 960 flights were cancelled and almost 115,000 travellers were affected over the six-day strike.
The work stoppage came at a busy travel time in Belgium, when many schools have a term break.
Aviapartner workers had cited grievances over low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not 
fully paid, according to the news agency Belga.
Under the deal, Aviapartner will cut workloads, invest in more equipment amounting to 3.2 million euros (3.6 million 
dollars), approve new bonuses and monitor the implementation of these proposals, Belga reported, citing union 
officials.
The agreement would also see more workers hired and have more workers employed under contracts.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Brussels Airport strike ends amid preliminary deal
Load-Date: November 1, 2018
End of Document
Workers, management near deal to end Brussels Airport strike
Workers, management near deal to end Brussels Airport strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 31, 2018 Wednesday 9:51 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 167 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Baggage handlers and management are close to reaching an agreement that would end a strike that has disrupted 
operations at Brussels Airport, the news service Belga reported Wednesday.
The strike by employees of the services company Aviapartner, which started last Thursday, cited grievances over 
low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully paid.
According to union officials, strikers will review the deal at 11 am (1000 GMT), at which point some people would 
return to work, Belga reported. The deal includes bonuses and an increase in the number of contract positions.
The strike resulted in scores of flight cancellations each day and came at a busy travel time in Belgium, when many 
schools have a term break.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.

Flights cancelled at Brussels Airport amid strike by baggage-handlers
Flights cancelled at Brussels Airport amid strike by baggage-handlers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 29, 2018 Monday 4:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 184 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Brussels Airport continues to struggle with a strike by baggage handlers, cancelling a further 100 flights on Monday, 
according to the news agency Belga.
The strike by employees of the services company Aviapartner started on Thursday evening. After a pause, 
Aviapartner's management and the unions resumed talks Monday morning. But the two sides remain far apart.
The strike comes at a busy travel time. Many schools across Belgium have a term break this week to coincide with 
the All Saints' holiday on Thursday.
About 350,000 people were expected to travel via Brussels Airport during this period, according to Belga.
Among the list of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully 
paid. A trade union statement cited "a total absence of social consultation" within the company, Belga reported.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.

German airport operator under EU scrutiny for state aid breach
German airport operator under EU scrutiny for state aid breach
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 26, 2018 Friday 1:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 282 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission has started an investigation into whether the company operating a German regional 
airport violated EU rules on state aid in its treatment of Ryanair.
At issue is Germany's Frankfurt-Hahn airport, located in the state of Rhineland-Palatinate. From 2009 to 2017, the 
state controlled the firm managing the airport, Flughafengesellschaft Frankfurt-Hahn GmbH (FFHG). The HNA 
Group purchased 82.5 per cent of FFHG in 2017.
Brussels opened an investigation after receiving a complaint that the airport was giving favourable treatment to the 
budget carrier Ryanair, the commission said Friday in a statement.
The probe will look at agreements between Ryanair and the state prior to 2009, and between Ryanair and FFHG 
after 2009, to see if the carrier received preferential treatment.
The post-2009 agreements under review include deals covering airport service agreements, training aid to Ryanair 
and other projects.
The commission will also investigate whether certain land sale agreements between the state and FFHG ran afoul 
of EU competition rules.
Under these rules, states may provide assistance to regional airports if it helps local development, connectivity and 
traffic decongestion. This aid may include subsidies to budget airlines.
Publically owned airports, however, cannot extend incentives that exceed what a profit-driven airport operator would 
offer under the same conditions.
German airport operator under EU scrutiny for state aid breach
The commission has already concluded numerous other probes into airports and state aid, including cases in 
France, Germany, Austria, and Italy - all of which found instances of EU state aid violations.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Monica Raymunt, +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 27, 2018
End of Document
Brussels baggage-handler strike cancels scores of flights
Brussels baggage-handler strike cancels scores of flights
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 26, 2018 Friday 4:17 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 209 words
Byline: Helen Fessenden in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
A baggage-handler strike at Brussels Airport has caused at least 150 flights to be cancelled or rerouted and left 
hundreds of travellers stranded at the airport overnight, the Belga news service reported on Friday.
The strike began on Thursday evening to protest working conditions at Aviapartner, a services firm. It will last until 6 
am Saturday (0400 GMT), according to a tweet by the airport.
According to union representatives, the two sides are still "very far apart" on any agreement, and talks are on hold, 
Belga reported.
Among the list of strikers' grievances are low wages, understaffing and a bonus that was promised but not fully 
paid. A trade union statement cited "a total absence of social consultation" within the company, Belga reported.
Aviapartner, which handles Brussels baggage for Ryanair, EasyJet, British Airways and TUI Fly, is contracted in 37 
airports in six European countries, according to its website.
The strike comes at a busy travel time ahead of the All Saints' holiday next week, when many schools across 
Belgium have a term break. About 350,000 people are expected to travel via Brussels Airport during this period, 
according to Belga.

A baggage-handler strike at Brussels Airport has caused 42 flights to be cancelled, and left hundreds of travellers

The strike began on Thursday evening to protest working conditions at Aviapartner, a services firm. No details were 
immediately available on how long it will last.

A statement by the trade union cited "a total absence of social consultation" within the company, Belga reported.

Ryanair denies using illegal contract workers in Germany
Ryanair denies using illegal contract workers in Germany
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 25, 2018 Thursday 8:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 169 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt and Bernd Roeder in Berlin
Dateline: Dublin/Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Irish budget airline Ryanair rejected on Thursday claims that it illegally employs hundreds of contract workers in 
Germany.
Some 700 of Ryanair's 1000 flight attendants in Germany signed their employment contracts with two companies 
based in Ireland, in contradiction with German law, German parliamentarian Pascal Meiser said on Wednesday.
The accusations are not true, Ryanair communications director Robin Kiely said, adding that the company and its 
service providers comply fully with EU law.
The two companies in question, Crewlink Ireland and Workforce International Contractors, are based in Dublin.
Meiser, who belongs to the hard-left Die Linke party, says the companies lack the necessary authorization for 
contract labour.
Ryanair has in recent times confronted labour law issues in a number of European countries. Trade unions are 
calling for the application of national labour law, rather than just Irish employment rules.

Ryanair blames strikes for first-half profit slump
Ryanair blames strikes for first-half profit slump
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 22, 2018 Monday 2:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 278 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair reported a 7-per-cent fall in profits in the first half of its financial year, blaming "widespread 
damage" from strikes and disruptions to air-traffic control across Europe, as well as lower fares and higher fuel and 
pilot costs.
The carrier said its net profit dropped to 1.2 billion euros (1.4 billion dollars) in the six months ended September 30, 
as average fares fell 3 per cent amid excess capacity in Europe and many air-traffic control (ATC) problems, "which 
caused a spike in cancellations of higher fare, weekend flights."
Ryanair was also hit by strikes by its own pilots and cabin crew but said these caused minor financial impact.
"Repeated ATC strikes and staff shortages mean that 2018 will be the worst year on record for European ATC 
disruptions," Ryanair Chief Executive Michael O'Leary said.
"These have caused widespread damage to airline punctuality and schedules," O'Leary said.
He said Ryanair had "made good progress" in negotiations with trade unions since it agreed to recognize them in 
December, citing agreements with pilots or cabin crew in Ireland, Italy, Britain, Germany and Portugal.
"We continue to engage with unions in our other major markets," O'Leary said, claiming "competitor employees 
have interfered to delay agreements" in some countries.
Ryanair staff staged eight days of strikes this summer, but the airline "worked well to minimize disruptions," he said.
The Dublin-based airline is contingency planning for the "rising" risk of Britain leaving the European Union in March 
with no withdrawal deal in place, O'Leary said.
Ryanair blames strikes for first-half profit slump
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: October 23, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair to create base at Berlin's Tegel
Ryanair to create base at Berlin's Tegel
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 17, 2018 Wednesday 6:39 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 285 words
Byline: Burkhard Fraune in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Dublin-based Ryanair is to make Berlin's Tegel airport its 10th base in Germany from April next year, taking over 
four planes already stationed there by its partner airline Laudamotion, the budget carrier announced on 
Wednesday.
Making the announcement in Berlin, Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary sketched out plans to expand the 
airline's routes, but said he expected no growth in Germany, partly because of continuing conflict with German 
unions over pay and conditions.
For as long as there was no clarity with the unions, there would be no further investment in additional planes, he 
said.
Ryanair owns three quarters of Laudamotion, which has taken over take-off and landing slots at Tegel from the 
bankrupt Air Berlin subsidiary Niki.
Ryanair recently announced the closure of its base in Bremen in north-western Germany, where two planes are 
based. It also said it would withdraw two of the five planes it has at Weeze on the Dutch border, in what German 
trade union officials saw as a "declaration of war."
O'Leary denied this, insisting that fuel prices were to blame. "Oil is at 85 dollars, you idiots," said the chief 
executive, who has a reputation for combative language. Further rises in the price could lead to further closures, he 
added.
Nevertheless, O'Leary said talks with the Verdi trade union and the pilot's Cockpit association were going well, with 
meetings set for this week and next and agreement possible by Christmas.
Ryanair to create base at Berlin's Tegel
In charge at Ryanair since 1993, O'Leary has expanded the former loss-maker to being Europe's largest budget 
airline. He indicated his intention to step down within three years.

Load-Date: October 18, 2018

Germany holds aviation summit to tackle delays, cancellations
Germany holds aviation summit to tackle delays, cancellations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
October 5, 2018 Friday 6:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 221 words
Byline: Eckart Gienke in Hamburg
Dateline: Hamburg (dpa) - 
Body
German Transport Minister Andreas Scheuer is to gather politicians and aviation business figures in a bid to take on 
some of the industry's woes on Friday.
Covering German and international air travel, participants at the conference in the northern port city of Hamburg are 
looking for solutions to the growing number of delays and cancellations.
Among the reasons for the travel chaos are ageing infrastructure, the bankruptcy of airlines such as Air Berlin and 
most recently Primera Air, and strikes in a number of European countries. An increase in storms is also causing 
problems for the industry.
In a draft proposal seen by dpa ahead of Friday's meeting, the government set out plans to shift short-haul flights to 
the country's railways. The government also wants to improve transport connections to important international 
airports.
Following a wave of industrial action against budget airline Ryanair, the German union Verdi called on the 
government to take decisive action ahead of Friday's meeting.
"On several levels Ryanair does not abide by the rules of the game in Germany," Verdi board member Christine 
Behle said.
A joint declaration of intentions is expected at the the end of the two-hour meeting, set to kick off at 10 am (0800 
GMT).
Editorial contactsEditing by: Ella Joyner+49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Germany holds aviation summit to tackle delays, cancellations
Load-Date: October 6, 2018

Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 29, 2018 Saturday 1:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 260 words
Byline: Benedikt von Imhoff in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
German labour union Verdi on Saturday hailed Ryanair flight attendants and pilots in Germany for their participation 
in a 24-hour Europe-wide strike, despite increasing pressure from their employer.
The airline staff's contribution to the strike was "all the more courageous because the employees participated 
despite great pressure," a Verdi spokeswoman told dpa on Saturday in Berlin.
Airline representatives had threatened to close locations ahead of the labour action, but the cabin crew and pilots 
were not deterred. The 24-hour strike ended overnight on Friday."We hope that Ryanair has understood the signal 
and finally puts a decent offer on the table," the Verdi spokeswoman said. The airline's staff is calling for increased 
wages and better working conditions in accordance with different countries' respective national laws.
The second Europe-wide strike by Ryanair pilots and flight attendants involved not only Germany, but also 
employees from Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy and the Netherlands.
At least 250 flights were cancelled on Friday due to the strike, constituting about 10 per cent of the Ryanair's 
scheduled European routes, the Irish airline said in Dublin.The Verdi spokeswoman also emphasized the support of 
local politicians, including Labour Minister Hubertus Heil, who met striking employees in Berlin.
"This support encourages employees," she said, while adding that even some travellers have shown interest and 
understanding at affected airports.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Martin Waldman, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair employees showed courage by going on strike, union says
Load-Date: September 30, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair hampered by Europe-wide strike action
Ryanair hampered by Europe-wide strike action
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 28, 2018 Friday 12:25 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 400 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt, Bill Smith in London
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Irish budget airline Ryanair faced new strike action coordinated by unions in six European countries on Friday, with 
at least 250 flights cancelled across the continent.
Ryanair pilots and cabin crew from Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany are participating 
in the walk-out, the second Europe-wide action to hit the company.
The airline and the unions provided starkly different figures for how many flights would be affected.
Ryanair apologized on Twitter to customers "affected by this unnecessary disruption," saying 90 per cent of flights 
were operating normally.
"Despite the regrettable and unjustified strike action taking place in six of our 37 markets today, all 400 of our first-
wave aircraft departed on schedule this morning," the airline said.
The Dublin-based budget carrier had earlier this week announced the cancellation of 150 out of 2,400 European 
flights for the day.
On Friday, it said more than 2,150 Ryanair flights would operate as normal, or about 90 per cent of its usual 
schedule, "carrying 400,000 customers across Europe."
"Ryanair took every step to minimize the disruption and we notified our customers as early as possible advising 
them of their free move, refund or reroute options," the airline said.
Some 133 flights to and from Germany were cancelled, according to a tally by the flights portal Airliners.de. This 
would represent about 40 per cent of Ryanair's total flights to and from the country.
Ryanair hampered by Europe-wide strike action
On Thursday, Ryanair gave the expected number of cancellations in Germany first as 35 to 45, and then as "less 
than 100," following a decision by Germany's Cockpit pilots' union (VC) to participate in the strike.
An official from the German Verdi union gave considerably higher numbers, saying that some 250 flights would be 
struck off.
"This has been serious intimidation from the company, which has made it even more heartening that colleagues are 
taking part," said Verdi's Mira Neumaier.
A similar strike action in August led to some 400 flights being cancelled, including 150 in Germany.
Employees are striking for more pay and better conditions, in line with national law in various countries.
The company, long known for its opposition to the unionization of its workforce, has faced repeated strike action 
since the beginning of the year by pilots and cabin crew.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Robin Powell+49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 29, 2018

Fresh wave of European strikes at budget airline Ryanair

Body
Irish budget airline Ryanair is facing strike action coordinated by unions in six European countries on Friday, with 
flights expected to be cancelled across the continent.
Ryanair employees from Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany are participating in the walk-
out, the second Europe-wide action to hit the company.
It was unclear how many flights would be affected, with the company and the unions providing starkly different 
figures.
The Dublin-based budget carrier had earlier this week announced the cancellation of 150 out of 2,400 European 
flights for the day.
On Thursday, Ryanair marketing head Kenny Jacobs said the decision by Germany's Cockpit pilots' union (VC) to 
participate would result in 35 to 45 flights to and from Germany not taking off, raising the total number of 
cancellations. Ryanair later gave the figure for German cancellations as "less than 100," according to a company 
tweet.
An official from the German Verdi union gave considerably higher numbers however, saying that in Germany alone 
some 250 flights would be struck off.
"This has been serious intimidation from the company, which has made it even more heartening that colleagues are 
taking part," said Verdi's Mira Neumaier.
A similar strike action in August led to some 400 flights being cancelled, including 150 in Germany.
Employees are striking for more pay and better conditions, in line with national law in various countries.
Fresh wave of European strikes at budget airline Ryanair
The company, long known for its opposition to the unionization of its workforce, has faced repeated strike action 
since the beginning of the year by pilots and cabin crew.

Fresh wave of European strikes to hit budget airline Ryanair
Fresh wave of European strikes to hit budget airline Ryanair
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 28, 2018 Friday 12:05 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 190 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Irish budget airline Ryanair is to see strikes coordinated by unions in six European countries on Friday, set to wipe 
out almost 200 flights across the continent.
Ryanair employees from Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany are participating in the walk-
out, the second pan-European action to hit the company.
The Dublin-based budget carrier had earlier announced the cancellation of 150 out of 2,400 European flights for the 
day.
But on Thursday, Ryanair marketing head Kenny Jacobs said the decision by Germany's Cockpit pilots' union (VC) 
to participate would result in 35 to 45 flights to and from Germany not taking off, raising the total number of 
cancellations.
Employees are striking for more pay and better conditions, in line with national law in various countries.
The company, long known for its opposition to the unionization of its workforce, has faced repeated strike action 
since the beginning of the year by pilots and cabin crew.
A similar wave of strikes in August led to the cancellation of 400 flights throughout Europe.

German cabin crew urged to join Ryanair strike amid cancellations
German cabin crew urged to join Ryanair strike amid cancellations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 27, 2018 Thursday 5:07 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 512 words
Byline: Bernd Roeder in Berlin, Christian Ebner in Frankfurt and Helen Maguire in Brussels
Dateline: Frankfurt/Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
German cabin crew are being urged to join a day-long strike targeting Ryanair flights, trade union Verdi said on 
Thursday.
It called on some 1,000 Ryanair staff to join pilots on a countrywide strike on Friday in support of higher pay and 
better working conditions at the Dublin-based budget carrier.
"Europe's largest low-cost airline refuses to grant its employees a decent income and a corporate culture free of 
fear as before," Verdi executive Christine Behle said in Berlin.
Several unions across the European Union have called for a strike to halt Ryanair flights. Almost 200 flights have 
been cancelled as a result.
The company, long known for its opposition to the unionization of its workforce, has faced repeated strike action 
since the beginning of the year by pilots and cabin crew.
Employees are striking for more pay and better conditions, in line with national law in various countries.
Earlier Thursday, Ryanair marketing head Kenny Jacobs said in Dublin the decision by Germany's Cockpit pilot's 
union (VC) to participate would result in 35 to 45 flights to and from Germany not taking off.
The cancelled flights make up some 10 per cent of the Germany schedule. The Dublin-based budget carrier earlier 
announced the cancellation of 150 out of 2,400 European flights for the day.
Ryanair chief operations officer Peter Bellew noted that several workers' rallies were planned.
German cabin crew urged to join Ryanair strike amid cancellations
Ryanair employees from Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany are participating in the 
strike, the second pan-European action to hit the company.
Ryanair has laid a complaint with EU competition authorities alleging that its competitors are behind the coordinated 
action.
The company expressed disappointment that Germany's VC was joining the strike, noting progress made in talks 
with VC on Tuesday, including the appointment of a German mediator.
Bellew said Ryanair was keen to strike a deal within six weeks, with a view to concluding conditions and pay 
contracts by the end of the year.
On Tuesday, the airline said it had signed a new contract with its cabin crew in Italy that will begin on October 1 and 
run for three years.
In Belgium meanwhile, the CNE trade union accused Ryanair of acting "irresponsibly" by failing to cancel enough 
flights on Friday.
Ryanair's behaviour "could create tensions and insecurity for all staff at the airport, at Ryanair and for the 
passengers concerned," the union said in a statement.
Conditions could be particularly bad at Charleroi, Belgium's main airport for low-cost carriers, where 20,000 airline 
passengers could be expected on Friday, CNE said, warning of potential "chaos."
The European Consumer Organization, BEUC, warned that the strikes could leave many passengers without 
compensation.
"We call on Ryanair to compensate consumers caught up in the latest wave of mass cancellations according to EU 
passenger rights rules," said Monique Goyens of BEUC, arguing that many passengers had no "realistic option to 
defend their rights."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 28, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair cancels more Friday flights as strike grows
Ryanair cancels more Friday flights as strike grows
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 27, 2018 Thursday 1:41 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 470 words
Byline: Reporting by Christian Ebner in Frankfurt and Helen Maguire in Brussels
Dateline: Frankfurt/Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair announced the cancellation of additional flights to and from Germany for Friday, in addition to other 
Europe-wide cancellations caused by pilots striking.
The company, long known for its opposition to unionization of its workforce, has faced repeated strike action since 
the beginning of the year, both by pilots and cabin crew.
Employees are striking for more pay and better conditions, in line with national law in the various countries.
The decision by Germany's Cockpit pilot's union (VC) to participate in the strike will result in 35 to 45 flights to and 
from Germany not taking off, Ryanair marketing head Kenny Jacobs said in Dublin on Thursday.
The cancelled flights make up some 10 per cent of the Germany schedule. The Dublin-based budget carrier earlier 
announced the cancellation of 150 out of 2,400 European flights for the day.
Jacobs indicated that Ryanair believed that German union Verdi, representing cabin crew, would also participate in 
the strike. Verdi is set to make an announcement later in the day.
Ryanair chief operations officer Peter Bellew noted that several workers' rallies were planned.
Ryanair employees from Spain, Portugal, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands and Germany are participating in the 
strike, the second pan-European action to hit the company.
Ryanair has laid a complaint with European Union competition authorities alleging that its competitors are behind 
the coordinated action.
Ryanair cancels more Friday flights as strike grows
The company expressed disappointment that Germany's VC was joining the strike, noting progress made in talks 
with VC on Tuesday, including the appointment of a German mediator.
Bellew said Ryanair was keen to strike a deal within six weeks, with a view to concluding conditions and pay 
contracts by the end of the year.
On Tuesday, the airline said it had signed a new contract with its cabin crew in Italy that will begin on October 1 and 
run for three years.
In Belgium meanwhile, the CNE trade union accused Ryanair of acting "irresponsibly" by failing to cancel enough 
flights on Friday.
Ryanair's behaviour "could create tensions and insecurity for all staff at the airport, at Ryanair and for the 
passengers concerned," the union said in a statement.
Conditions could be particularly bad at Charleroi, Belgium's main airport for low-cost carriers, where 20,000 airline 
passengers could be expected on Friday, CNE said, warning of potential "chaos."
The European Consumer Organisation, BEUC, warned that the strikes could leave many passengers without 
compensation.
"We call on Ryanair to compensate consumers caught up in the latest wave of mass cancellations according to EU 
passenger rights rules," said Monique Goyens of BEUC, arguing that many passengers had no "realistic option to 
defend their rights."

Irish police charge late passenger who chased plane onto runway
Irish police charge late passenger who chased plane onto runway
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 27, 2018 Thursday 5:56 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 212 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
A man in his 20s was arrested on Thursday after running onto a runway in an effort to catch his flight from Dublin 
Airport.
The late passenger, Patrick Kehoe, ran across a runway in a bid to stop the Ryanair flight to Amsterdam early 
Thursday morning, Irish national broadcaster RTE and other media reported.
He had forced his way through the boarding gate and broken a door lock to access the runway, the reports said.
Kehoe ran towards the plane "with his suitcase under his arm," RTE quoted a witness as saying.
The BBC quoted an airport spokesman as saying Kehoe and a woman accompanying him had arrived late at the 
boarding gate, after the flight had closed.
"They were engaging with Ryanair staff at the gate and the male passenger was becoming agitated," the 
spokesman said.
"He was banging on the window to try and get the aircraft to wait... and made his way onto the apron, trying to flag 
the aircraft down."
The man's brash behaviour continued after an appearance in Dublin District Court later Thursday to answer a 
charge of criminal damage, when he lowered his trousers to reveal his buttocks to press photographers, according 
to RTE. He was bailed to appear again on November 8.

Ryanair to open bases in Bordeaux, Marseille with four new aircraft

dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 27, 2018 Thursday 2:46 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 100 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Dublin/Bourdeaux (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair announced Thursday that it would invest 400 million dollars to expand its offerings in 
France with the launch of two new bases in Bordeaux and Marseille.
The company said on its website that the bases would be equipped with two new aircraft each and would offer 27 
new routes connecting a dozen countries.
The plans are expected to serve 1.1 million customers per year at Bordeaux Airport and 2.4 million customers at 
Marseille Aiport, said Chief Commercial Officer David O'Brien from Bordeaux.

EU warns Ryanair to comply with EU rules as mass strike looms
EU warns Ryanair to comply with EU rules as mass strike looms
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 26, 2018 Wednesday 1:40 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 293 words
Byline: Helen Maguire in Brussels, Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission warned Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary on Wednesday that the airline must 
comply with EU rules, as cabin crew members gear up for a mass strike on Friday to demand better work 
conditions.
EU Employment Commissioner Marianne Thyssen and O'Leary had a "frank and open discussion" about 
employment conditions at Ryanair and the current social tensions, commission spokesman Margaritis Schinas said. 
Wednesday's meeting had taken place at O'Leary's request.
Thyssen called upon O'Leary to "ensure full compliance with all applicable EU rules and legislation, as it is the case 
for all EU airline companies," Schinas added.
"Respecting EU law is not something over which workers should have to negotiate, nor is it something which can be 
done differently from country to country. I made this very clear to Mr O'Leary today," Thyssen said in a statement.
"I am not against Ryanair or against the low-cost business model. But with great success also comes great 
responsibility," she added.
Staff across Europe have long been at loggerheads with Ryanair due to its practice of employing them under Irish 
labour law. Trade unions in Belgium, Italy, Portugal, Spain and the Netherlands argue that they would receive better 
conditions under their domestic laws.
Ryanair cancelled 150 European flights scheduled for this Friday due to the planned strike, which is the latest in a 
series of industrial actions.
It had originally expected 190 cancellations but issued an updated figure on Wednesday.
EU warns Ryanair to comply with EU rules as mass strike looms
The airline argues that the strike is "unnecessary" since it has improved its offer in recent weeks to pilots and cabin 
crews in Ireland, Britain, Italy and Germany.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Monica Raymunt, +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 27, 2018

Ryanair cancels 190 flights as cabin crew plan strike across Europe
Ryanair cancels 190 flights as cabin crew plan strike across Europe
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 25, 2018 Tuesday 5:50 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 257 words
Byline: Lena Klimkeit in Rome and Femke Colborne in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair has cancelled 190 European flights on Friday due to planned strikes by cabin crew in Spain, Belgium, The 
Netherlands, Portugal, Italy and Germany, the budget airline said on Tuesday.
In a statement, Ryanair described the strike action as "unnecessary," adding: "Ryanair has made significant 
progress in recent weeks with our union negotiations, which include pilot and/or cabin crew agreements in Ireland, 
UK, Italy and Germany."
Strikes by Ryanair pilots and cabin crew across Europe had already resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of 
flights this summer.
Ryanair's marketing chief Kenny Jacobs said: "We hope these unions will see common sense and work with us to 
finalize agreements for the benefit of our pilots and cabin crew over the coming weeks without further disrupting our 
customers or our flights."
Also on Tuesday, the airline said it had signed a new contract with its cabin crew in Italy.
The contract will begin on October 1 and run for three years, Ryanair said. It includes an increase in wages under a 
new compensation structure.
Ryanair agreed the terms of the contract in mid-September with the FIT CISL, ANPAC and ANPAV unions.
However, other Italian trade unions that did not participate in the negotiations criticized the contract and called for 
an emergency meeting on Tuesday with Labour Minister Luigi Di Maio.
Members of the Italian unions that rejected the deal were planning to take part in the strike action on September 28.
Ryanair cancels 190 flights as cabin crew plan strike across Europe

Ryanair chief O'Leary backed at AGM despite workforce turmoil
Ryanair chief O'Leary backed at AGM despite workforce turmoil
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 20, 2018 Thursday 2:02 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 227 words
Byline:  Steffen Weyer in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary retained his position with overwhelming backing at the budget airline's 
annual general meeting (AGM) on Thursday, despite having presided over recent pilot and crew strikes that have 
caused the cancellation of hundreds of flights.
O'Leary was backed by 98.5 per cent of shareholders at the meeting near Dublin, Ryanair confirmed on Thursday. 
"The board wants me to extend my contract," O'Leary reportedly said at the AGM. Chairman David Bonderman also 
retains his position, with 70.5-per-cent backing.
Ryanair's marketing chief Kenny Jacobs said on Tuesday that he believed O'Leary would stay in post for another 
five years, but the German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit had called on Ryanair shareholders to vote in a new 
leadership.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots and crew across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the 
height of this year's summer holiday season, with the airline's share price plummeting as a result.
Cabin-crew unions from Spain, Portugal, Belgium and the Netherlands have announced a strike over pay and 
conditions for September 28. Pilots in Italy are also set to strike, though a deal was struck last week with Italian 
cabin-crew unions after Ryanair approved better pay and conditions.
