Ryanair strikes labour agreement with Italian cabin crew unions
Ryanair strikes labour agreement with Italian cabin crew unions
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 14, 2018 Friday 2:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 273 words
Byline: Alvise Armellini in Rome
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair, which is facing an increasingly restless workforce across Europe, said on Friday it has 
agreed the terms of a comprehensive labour deal with Italian cabin crew unions.
The FIT CISL, ANPAC and ANPAV unions signed "a set of agreed principles [...] which will form the basis of a 
comprehensive Collective Labour Agreement," Ryanair said in a statement.
The airline said it agreed to grant Italian labour and pension rights - rather than less generous Irish ones - and 
"higher pay under a new pay structure" linked to a more favourable tax regime.
"This agreement follows recent cabin crew agreements in Ireland with FORSA [union] and in the UK with UNITE 
[union]," Ryanair's Chief People Officer Eddie Wilson said.
In a separate statement, the Italian unions said they also negotiated the right to be paid via Italian bank accounts 
and secured less stressful shift regimes.
The collective agreement should run for three years, until the end of 2021, the parties said, and it is due to be 
signed in the coming days.
The deal was announced a day after flight attendant unions from Spain, Italy, Portugal, Belgium and the 
Netherlands announced a strike over pay and conditions for September 28.
In August, Ryanair signed another collective labour agreement with Italian pilots. Their union ANPAC said it was the 
first of its kind in Europe, and hailed it as "historic."
However, other Italian pilot unions, Filt Cgil and Uiltrasporti, said Thursday that their members rejected that deal in 
a referendum, and would also strike on September 28.
Ryanair strikes labour agreement with Italian cabin crew unions
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 15, 2018
End of Document
Crew in five European countries to join new Ryanair strike
Crew in five European countries to join new Ryanair strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 13, 2018 Thursday 3:59 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 453 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt and Helen Maguire in Brussels
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair has confirmed that flight attendants in Spain, Italy, Portugal, Belgium and the Netherlands 
will strike over pay and conditions on September 28.
"Ryanair management chose to continue to ignore the law and [to continue] with the bullying culture that is part of 
the company for decades," said a statement signed by trade unions from the five countries.
The statement reiterates their demands to work under local contracts, bound by local standards. Many Ryanair staff 
across Europe have Irish employment contracts, which the trade unions argue give them worse conditions than 
under local law.
"We will not back down until these demands are met," the statement says, calling on Ryanair's investors and 
shareholders to take a stand at the company's annual general meeting on September 20.
The announcement came shortly after the airline resumed operations on Thursday following a 24-hour strike that 
caused the carrier to cancel 150 of its 400 flights to and from Germany the previous day.
In a statement announcing the new strike, Ryanair dismissed claims that the Wednesday strike had caused "travel 
chaos," saying that 70 per cent of its Germany-based pilots and cabin crew had reported for work despite the 
stoppage.
"Repeated false claims made by unions about 'travel chaos' have proven to be unfounded," said Ryanair's 
marketing chief Kenny Jacobs, adding that despite the "partial" September 28 strike, the airline would "carry the 
overwhelming majority of the 400,000 passengers who will be scheduled to fly with us that day."
German pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) and German workers union Verdi organized the strike in an effort to 
push for better pay and conditions for their members.
Crew in five European countries to join new Ryanair strike
Ryanair's hubs at Frankfurt (Hahn) and Berlin-Schoenefeld were most affected by the cancellations.
The airline dismissed the industrial action as unjustified, citing offers it has already put on the table. German 
Ryanair employees had also walked out for a day in August.
The airline's chief executive Michael O'Leary Wedneday said Ryanair would not "roll over" because of a one-day 
strike which he termed "somewhat unsuccessful."
O'Leary accused the unions of making a "ludicrous demand" earlier this year for a 42-per-cent pay increase.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of this 
year's summer holiday season.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;Editing by: Stephen 
Lowman, +49 30 2852 31472, <Lowman.Stephen@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 14, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair to resume normal operations after 24-hour strike action
Ryanair to resume normal operations after 24-hour strike action
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 13, 2018 Thursday 4:55 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Byline:  Christian Ebner in Frankfurt/Main
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair was set to resume operations on Thursday following a 24-hour strike that caused the carrier 
to cancel 150 of its 400 flights to and from Germany the previous day.
Operations chief Peter Bellew was optimistic that most of Ryanair's 400 flights to and from Germany would resume 
on Thursday after strike action ended at 2.59 am (0059 GMT).
German pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) and German workers union Verdi organized the strike in an effort to 
push for better pay and conditions for their members.
Ryanair's hubs at Frankfurt (Hahn) and Berlin-Schoenefeld were most affected by the cancellations.
The airline dismissed the industrial action as unjustified, citing offers it has already put on the table. German 
Ryanair employees had also walked out for a day in August.
The airline's chief executive Michael O'Leary Wedneday said Ryanair would not "roll over" because of a one-day 
strike which he termed "somewhat unsucessful."
O'Leary accused the unions of making a "ludicrous demand" earlier this year for a 42-per-cent pay increase.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of this 
year's summer holiday season.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.

150 Ryanair flights scrapped as German pilots, crew join strike
150 Ryanair flights scrapped as German pilots, crew join strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2018 Wednesday 11:06 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 205 words
Byline: Jan Petermann in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair pilots and flight attendants were taking part in a 24-hour strike on Wednesday that prompted the budget 
airline to cancel 150 of its 400 flights to and from Germany.
The strike was organized by German pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) and German workers union Verdi in an 
effort to push for better pay and conditions for their members.
The walkout was already causing delays early in the day.
"All 12 German bases have been affected, particularly the large ones in Frankfurt ... and the Berlin airports," VC's 
deputy chief Markus Wahl said. "There will be significant delays."
It was unclear how many of the 400 pilots and 1,000 flight attendants working at Ryanair's German bases were 
taking part in the stoppage.
Ryanair has dismissed Wednesday's industrial action as unjustified, citing offers it has already put on the table.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of this 
year's summer holiday season.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.

150 Ryanair flights scrapped as German pilots, crew join strike

150 Ryanair flights cancelled as German pilots, cabin crew strike
150 Ryanair flights cancelled as German pilots, cabin crew strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2018 Wednesday 4:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 437 words
Byline: Jan Petermann in Berlin, Bill Smith and Christoph Meyer in London
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair pilots and flight attendants joined a 24-hour strike Wednesday that prompted the budget airline to cancel 
150 of its 400 flights to and from Germany.
The strike was organized by German pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) and German workers' union Verdi in an 
effort to push for better pay and conditions for their members.
Michael O'Leary, the airline's chief executive, said Ryanair would not "roll over" because of a one-day strike that 
was "somewhat unsucessful."
"The majority of our flights in Germany will still operate, so your strike has been somewhat unsucessful," O'Leary 
said in comments addressed to the German unions.
"We don't doubt the vigour of the German unions," he told reporters in London. "There is nothing that we haven't 
agreed to do, and yet they still want to go off and have their strike."
"We will not roll over," O'Leary added, accusing the unions of making a "ludicrous demand" earlier this year for a 
42-per-cent pay increase.
He insisted that recent strike action across Europe by Ryanair pilots and cabin staff had caused "minimal 
disruption" to the airline's operations.
"If you threaten us with a strike and we think your reason for that is unreasonable, then we will take strikes and we 
will manage our way around those strikes, as we've done successfully in Ireland, when we had five days of strikes 
by just 25 per cent of pilots," he said.
150 Ryanair flights cancelled as German pilots, cabin crew strike
"It resulted in 20 flight cancellations a day for five days, out of a total of 300 flights that we operate daily to and from 
Ireland," he said.
"We don't want strikes but we are willing to accept strikes, put up with them, if it means defending our cost basis 
and our ability to offer low-fare air travel to our customers."
The walkout by Ryanair staff in German had already caused delays early Wednesday.
"All 12 German bases have been affected, particularly the large ones in Frankfurt ... and the Berlin airports," VC 
deputy chief Markus Wahl said. "There will be significant delays."
It was unclear how many of the 400 pilots and 1,000 flight attendants working at Ryanair's German bases were 
taking part in the stoppage.
Ryanair had earlier dismissed Wednesday's industrial action as unjustified, citing offers it has already put on the 
table.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights at the height of this 
year's summer holiday season.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 13, 2018
End of Document

No-deal Brexit could ground flights for days, Ryanair chief insists
No-deal Brexit could ground flights for days, Ryanair chief insists
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2018 Wednesday 2:04 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 172 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
The risk of Britain leaving the European Union in March without a transition agreement is being underestimated and 
could lead to flights being grounded for days or even weeks, Ryanair's chief executive said on Wednesday.
Pro-Brexit critics have said such claims are designed to create fear and persuade more people to oppose 
Conservative Prime Minister Theresa May's Brexit proposals, but Ryanair's Michael O'Leary insisted that the risks 
were growing.
"We remain concerned at the increasing risk of a hard - no-deal - Brexit in March 2019," O'Leary said.
"While we hope that a 21-month transition agreement from March 2019 will be agreed, recent events in the UK 
have added uncertainty, and we believe that the risk of a hard Brexit - which could lead to flights being grounded for 
a period of days or weeks - is being underestimated."
May is scheduled to chair a special meeting of her cabinet to discuss the possibility of a no-deal Brexit on Thursday.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 13, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair pilots, attendants strike threatens to halt German operations
Ryanair pilots, attendants strike threatens to halt German operations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 11, 2018 Tuesday 2:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 244 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
The first joint strike of Ryanair pilots and flight attendants will make it "very difficult" for the budget airline to get 
flights off the ground in Germany on Wednesday, a spokesman for the German pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit 
(VC) said Tuesday.
VC spokesman Markus Wahl said the strike would take place in coordination with workers union Verdi. Some 400 
pilots and 1,000 flight attendants are employed as part of Ryanair's German operations, and the majority of those 
could join the strike, he said.
The airline's Germany-based planes represents about one-tenth of its global fleet. Ryanair has not yet announced 
any cancellations for Wednesday, but a spokesman said the walk-outs were unjustified.
"Since we have already offered local contracts and better pay, there is no justification for further 
disruptions," Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely said Tuesday.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights this summer.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.
More recently, unions have reached agreements with the budget airline. An Irish pilots union voted to accept an 
agreement with Ryanair last week, and the Italian pilots union ANPAC voted to approve a collective labour 
agreement two weeks ago.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Ryanair pilots, attendants strike threatens to halt German operations

Ryanair cancels 150 flights to and from Germany ahead of strike
Ryanair cancels 150 flights to and from Germany ahead of strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 11, 2018 Tuesday 3:26 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 264 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair has cancelled 150 of its 400 flights to and from Germany on Wednesday due to a joint strike 
by pilots and flight attendants, marketing chief Kenny Jacobs said.
The strike has been organized by pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) and Verdi and is likely to include the 
majority of Ryanair's 400 pilots and around 1,000 flight attendants, according to a VC spokesman.
Ryanair said the industrial action is unjustified, citing improvements in pay and working conditions that have already 
been offered.
"Since we have already offered local contracts and better pay, there is no justification for further 
disruptions," Ryanair spokesman Robin Kiely said Tuesday.
Verdi warned that Wednesday's stoppage could be the first of several strikes, with board member Christine Behle 
saying: "This is a first warning strike. Anything further will depend on the process of the negotiations."
The airline's Germany-based planes represents about one-tenth of its global fleet.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights this summer.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.
More recently, unions have reached agreements with the budget airline. An Irish pilots union voted to accept an 
agreement with Ryanair last week, and the Italian pilots union ANPAC voted to approve a collective labour 
agreement two weeks ago.
Ryanair cancels 150 flights to and from Germany ahead of strike

German pilots at Ryanair to go on new 24-hour strike this week
German pilots at Ryanair to go on new 24-hour strike this week
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 10, 2018 Monday 8:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 170 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
German Ryanair pilots plan to go on strike again this week, just one month after a wave of strikes caused hundreds 
of flights across Europe to be cancelled.
Pilots union Vereinigung Cockpit has called for a new 24-hour strike to begin this Wednesday, the union said in a 
statement Monday.
As with the last round of strikes, the pilots and crew are seeking new contracts that include better pay and working 
conditions.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights this summer.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.
More recently, unions have been striking deals with the budget airline. An Irish pilots union voted to accept an 
agreement with Ryanair last week, while the Italian pilots union ANPAC has voted to approve a collective labour 
agreement two weeks ago.

Irish pilots union votes to accept Ryanair deal
Irish pilots union votes to accept Ryanair deal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 5, 2018 Wednesday 5:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 274 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
An Irish pilots union voted to accept an agreement with budget airline Ryanair on Wednesday, potentially ending a 
long-running labour dispute that resulted in several strikes this summer.
The Irish Airline Pilots' Association (IALPA) said its members voted unanimously to accept the deal, which follows 
mediated negotiations between the two sides last month.
The pilots had objected to Ryanair's plans to change seniority rules and were unhappy with its procedures for 
annual leave, transfers and promotions.
The union said the deal could be "the first step towards providing transparency and fairness for Ryanair pilots while 
also assisting Ryanair in recruiting and retaining pilots in the future."
IALPA spokesman Joe May said: "While our members fully respect Ryanair's operational model, they no longer 
accept the company's highly problematic employment model."
The union accused Ryanair of attempted "union busting" in July after the airline warned that it could cut 100 pilots 
and 200 cabin crew from its staff in Ireland as it reduces its Dublin-based fleet from 30 to 24 aircraft over the winter.
In a statement on Wednesday, Ryanair welcomed the union's vote and said it would ask the company's board to 
"reconsider their decision to re-base six aircraft away from Dublin this winter."
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights this summer.
Italy, Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries where 
Ryanair pilots and cabin staff have taken strike action.
Irish pilots union votes to accept Ryanair deal
Editorial contactsEditing by: Femke Colborne, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 6, 2018
End of Document
Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 28, 2018 Tuesday 6:31 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 242 words
Byline: Lena Klimkeit in Rome and Silvia Kusidlo in London
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
The Italian pilots union ANPAC has voted to approve a collective labour agreement reached with low-cost airline 
Ryanair following a protracted a labour dispute, both sides have announced.
The more than 300 members of Italy's largest airline pilots union approved the agreement by a large majority on 
Monday evening, the union said on Tuesday.
ANPAC called the deal an "historic event," and "the first collective agreement signed by Ryanair in Europe."
Italy is one of the Irish airline's largest markets.
The agreement, reached after eight months of negotiations and signed in Italy, ensures better protection and pay 
conditions for pilots, the union said.
Ryanair said it hopes to sign a similar deal with its Irish pilots in the near future. The airline reached an agreement 
with Irish pilots' union Forsa this week, but the pilots still have to vote to approve the deal.
Strikes by Ryanair pilots across Europe have resulted in the cancellation of hundreds of flights during the past two 
months.
Portugal, Spain, Belgium, Germany, Sweden and the Netherlands are among the other countries that have 
mounted strike actions.
Ryanair only started recognizing pilots unions last year, taking the step during negotiations to ward off a previous 
threat of strikes.
Italian pilots union votes to approve Ryanair deal
The company said on Tuesday that it has invited unions in Britain, Germany and Spain to negotiate in the coming 
days.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Femke Colborne, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 29, 2018
End of Document

dpa international (Englischer Dienst)

Length: 308 words
Byline: Christoph Meyer in London
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair has reached an agreement with its Irish pilots in a labour dispute, both sides have 
announced.
"Following a 22-hour negotiating session, which began on Wednesday morning and concluded Thursday morning, 
agreement has been reached between Forsa and Ryanair in the pilots' dispute," the pilots' trade union Forsa said 
on Thursday.
Ryanair confirmed the agreement to dpa, without giving details.
The pilots now have to vote to approve the deal, with the union recommending that they accept it.
"The mediator ... has asked both sides to refrain from further comment until the ballot has concluded and we will 
respect his wishes," Ryanair said.
In the dispute over holiday time, transfers and promotions, 100 of Ryanair's 350 Irish-based pilots took part in five 
days of strike action.
The Irish airline is in dispute with trade unions in several EU countries, which came to a head in mid-August with the 
biggest pilots' strike in Ryanair's history that affected 55,000 passengers across Europe.
German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) told dpa that it wants to wait and analyse the outcome of the 
agreement between Ryanair and its Irish pilots before continuing to negotiate with Ryanair.
"It poses the question whether mediation could come into consideration in Germany too," said VC Vice President 
Markus Wahl.
Ryanair and Irish pilots reach agreement in labour dispute
A further round of negotiations between the discount carrier and VC hasn't been started since the mid-August 
strike.
VC is asking for better pay, among other things, but Ryanair is wary of making agreements that would put its low-
cost business model at risk.
German labour union Verdi is also negotiating with Ryanair regarding better pay. Additionally it is fighting for 
measures against temporary work and short-term staff relocations.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 24, 2018
End of Document

August 23, 2018 Thursday 11:13 AM GMT

Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair has reached an agreement with its Irish pilots in a labour dispute, both sides have 
announced.
"Following a 22-hour negotiating session, which began on Wednesday morning and concluded Thursday morning, 
agreement has been reached between Forsa and Ryanair in the pilots' dispute," the pilots' trade union Forsa said 
on Thursday.
Ryanair confirmed the agreement to dpa, without giving details.
The pilots now have to vote to approve the deal, with the union recommending that they accept it.
"The mediator ... has asked both sides to refrain from further comment until the ballot has concluded and we will 
respect his wishes," Ryanair said.
In the dispute over holiday time, transfers and promotions, 100 of Ryanair's 350 Irish-based pilots took part in five 
days of strike action.
The Irish airline is in dispute with trade unions in several EU countries, which came to a head in mid-August with the 
biggest pilots' strike in Ryanair's history that affected 55,000 passengers across Europe.

Flights axed across Europe in biggest strike in Ryanair 's history
Flights axed across Europe in biggest strike in Ryanair's history
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 10, 2018 Friday 4:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 404 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt, Lennart Simonsson in Lahti, Finland, and Annette Birschel in Amsterdam
Dateline: Amsterdam (dpa) - 
Body
The biggest industrial action by pilots in Ryanair's history got under way on Friday, with nearly 400 flights across 
Europe cancelled due to the 24-hour stoppage that includes pilots in Germany, Sweden, Ireland, Belgium and the 
Netherlands.
The cancellations constitute about a sixth of the Irish budget airline's 2,400 scheduled flights on Friday, affecting 
some 55,000 passengers at the peak of the European holiday season.
The strike began at 3:01 am (0101 GMT) and is set to end on Saturday at 2:59 am.
Customers in Germany were the hardest hit, with 250 flights cancelled and 42,000 customers affected. There was 
no travel chaos at German airports, however, as passengers were notified two days in advance.
German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) said it was satisfied with the impact of the strike, adding: "We hope 
that Ryanair has understood our signal and is now willing to engage in serious negotiations."
According to the Swedish pilots' union (SPF), about 40 pilots were on strike. Ryanair cancelled 22 flights to and 
from Sweden, with most being flights to and from the regional Skvasta airport, about 100 kilometres south of 
Stockholm.
In the Netherlands, no flights were cancelled despite the decision of Dutch pilots to strike, Ryanair said on Friday, 
adding that it had hired substitutes.
A Dutch court failed to grant Ryanair's request for an injunction against the strike late Thursday.
Across the affected countries, passengers have been given the option to reschedule their flights free of charge or 
get their money back. Ryanair will not compensate passengers beyond that.
Flights axed across Europe in biggest strike in Ryanair 's history
The only people not to be affected by Ryanair cancellations in Germany are those flying to and from 
Karlsruhe/Baden-Baden airport. The pilots stationed there are not participating in the strike.
Pilots and crew are seeking new contracts that include better pay and working conditions.
In a statement late Thursday, Ryanair said it had taken "every step to minimize the disruption." It called the strike 
"regrettable and unjustified" and called on unions to continue negotiations.
Ryanair has only recognized pilots' unions since last year, taking the step during negotiations to ward off a previous 
threat of strikes.
However last month cabin crews in Portugal, Spain and Belgium went on strike for two days, causing the 
cancellation of 600 flights.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike Heine, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 11, 2018
End of Document
40 pilots in Sweden strike, Dutch flights continue
40 pilots in Sweden strike, Dutch flights continue
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 10, 2018 Friday 11:12 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 238 words
Byline: Lennart Simonsson in Lahti, Finland, and Annette Birschel in Amsterdam.
Dateline: Stockholm (dpa) - 
Body
About 40 Ryanair pilots in Sweden went on strike on Friday, the Swedish pilots' union (SPF) said.
"Today our members are on strike to demand their rights," SPF head Martin Lindgren said in a statement.
The union said it wanted its members to have basic labour rights, and the right to select its representatives in talks 
with Ryanair.
In the Netherlands, however, no flights were cancelled despite the decision of Dutch pilots to strike, Ryanair 
announced on Friday. The discount airline has hired non-striking foreign pilots as substitutes.
To date, the 24-hour stoppage also affects pilots in Belgium, Germany and Ireland.
As far as the strike's impact in Sweden is concerned, Ryanair cancelled 22 flights to and from Sweden.
The strike action affected most of Ryanair's flights to and from the regional Skvasta airport, about 100 kilometres 
south of Stockholm.
Skavsta airport was prepared to assist passengers affected by the strike, but so far only "a handful" have turned up 
and they "were easily accommodated," Skavsta airport managing director Peter Steinmetz told dpa.
The strike has been "well communicated," he added.
Ryanair had a late evening flight from Skavsta to London Stansted as well as one flight to Naples, Italy, that were 
not affected by Friday's labour action.
Ryanair said it had informed passengers affected by the cancellations.
40 pilots in Sweden strike, Dutch flights continue

The biggest industrial action by pilots in Ryanair's history got under way on Friday, with nearly 400 flights across

The cancellations constitute about a sixth of the Irish budget airline's 2,400 scheduled flights on Friday, affecting 
some 55,000 passengers at the peak of the European holiday season.

Customers in Germany were the hardest hit, with 250 flights cancelled and 42,000 customers affected. On Friday, 
the German pilots union confirmed it intends to end its strike on Saturday as planned.
Pilots in Belgium, Sweden, Ireland, and the Netherlands were also striking.
According to the Swedish pilots' union (SPF), about 40 pilots there are on strike. Ryanair cancelled 22 flights to and 
from Sweden, with most being flights to and from the regional Skvasta airport, about 100 kilometres south of

get their money back. Ryanair will not compensate passengers beyond that.
The only people not to be affected by Ryanair cancellations in Germany are those flying to and from 
Karlsruhe/Baden-Baden airport. The pilots stationed there are not participating in the strike.
Flights axed across Europe in biggest strike in Ryanair 's history
Pilots and crew are seeking new contracts that include better pay and working conditions.
In a statement late Thursday, Ryanair said it had taken "every step to minimize the disruption." It called the strike 
"regrettable and unjustified" and called on unions to continue negotiations.
Ryanair has only recognized pilots unions since last year, taking the step during negotiations to ward off a previous 
threat of strikes.
However last month cabin crews in Portugal, Spain and Belgium went on strike for two days, causing the 
cancellation of 600 flights.

German pilots to join biggest strike in Ryanair 's history
German pilots to join biggest strike in Ryanair's history
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 10, 2018 Friday 2:10 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 199 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Amsterdam (dpa) - 
Body
German Ryanair pilots are set to join the biggest industrial action by pilots in the budget airline's history on Friday.
Nearly 400 flights across Europe have been cancelled in anticipation of the 24-hour stoppage, which will also 
include pilots in Belgium, Sweden, Ireland, and The Netherlands.
The cancellations constitute about a sixth of Ryanair's 2,400 scheduled flights on Friday, affecting some 55,000 
passengers.
Most of those affected - about 42,000 - will be in Germany, where strike action begins at 03:01 am (0101 GMT) and 
comes at the height of the summer holiday season.
The affected passengers have been given the option to reschedule their flights free of charge or get their money 
back. Ryanair will not compensate passengers beyond that.
The only people not to be affected by Ryanair cancellations in Germany are those flying to and from 
Karlsruhe/Baden-Baden airport. The pilots stationed there are not participating in the strike, which was called by 
pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit earlier this week.
Pilots and crew are seeking new contracts that include better pay and working conditions.

Ryanair seeks to block Netherlands strike as pilot walk-out looms
Ryanair seeks to block Netherlands strike as pilot walk-out looms
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 9, 2018 Thursday 5:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 204 words
Byline: Annette Birschel in Amsterdam, Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Amsterdam (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair is seeking a temporary injunction in the Netherlands to block a 24-hour strike by pilots there scheduled to 
start on Friday.
A Haarlem court will rule Thursday on whether the Dutch national pilot union may join several others in carrying out 
industrial action.
One in six flights by Ryanair - Europe's largest budget airline - have been cancelled in anticipation of the strike, 
coming to about 400 in total.
Some 55,000 passengers are set to be affected, with 42,000 of those in Germany alone.
Pilots and crew want Ryanair to roll out a new contract on wages that include better working conditions, but both 
sides blame each other for a breakdown in the negotiations.
The German union announced on Wednesday that its members would join their counterparts in Belgium, Germany, 
Ireland, and Sweden in the strike. It is scheduled to take place between 3:01 am (0101 GMT) Friday and 2:59 am 
Saturday.
If the pilots' strike goes ahead as planned, it would be the biggest such action to affect the Irish company.
Ryanair has only recognized pilot unions since last year, taking the step during negotiations to ward off a previous 
threat of strikes.

Ryanair seeks to block Netherlands strike as pilot walk-out looms

Body
A 24-hour strike by pilots for budget airline Ryanair was set to go ahead on Friday, disrupting the travel plans of 
some 55,000 passengers, mostly in Germany.
A last-minute decision by a Dutch court stopped efforts by the Irish firm's management to block a strike by the 
national pilot union there.
Some 22 flights in the Netherlands will be affected by the strike. Across Europe, one in six flights by Europe's 
largest budget airline have been cancelled in anticipation of the industrial action, coming to about 400 in total.
Pilots and crew want Ryanair to roll out a new contract on wages that include better working conditions, but both 
sides blame each other for a breakdown in the negotiations.
The German union announced on Wednesday that its members would join their counterparts in Belgium, Germany, 
Ireland, and Sweden in the strike. It is scheduled to take place between 3:01 am (0101 GMT) Friday and 2:59 am 
Saturday.
Some 42,000 of the affected passengers are in Germany.
If the pilots' strike goes ahead as planned, it would be the biggest such action to affect the Irish company.
Ryanair has only recognized pilot unions since last year, taking the step during negotiations to ward off a previous 
threat of strikes.

Ryanair is seeking a temporary injunction in the Netherlands to block a strike scheduled to start on Friday.
A Haarlem court will rule Thursday on whether the national pilot union may go ahead with the strike, which is set to 
last one day.
Pilots and crew are seeking a new contract on wages that includes better working conditions.
The union announced Wednesday that its members would join their counterparts in Belgium, Germany, Ireland, and 
Sweden in the strike. It is scheduled to take place between 3:01 am (0101 GMT) Friday and 2:59 am Saturday.
The discount airline, based in Ireland, responded by filing its injunction request and wants to block strikes for the 
entire summer. Altogether, about 400 flights have been cancelled in anticipation.

Ryanair cuts nearly 400 flights ahead of pilot strike in 4 countries
Ryanair cuts nearly 400 flights ahead of pilot strike in 4 countries
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 8, 2018 Wednesday 2:47 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 335 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt, Friederike Heine in Berlin and Lennart Simonsson in Stockholm
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair has cancelled 250 flights scheduled for Friday in response to an announcement from the 
German pilots' union that its members would join a strike by Ryanair pilots in Sweden, Ireland and Belgium.
The move comes on top of 146 other cancellations announced several days ago due to the coinciding pilot strikes 
in three other countries, taking the total number of cancellations to nearly 400. It will be the biggest strike in the 
airline's history.
Ryanair's marketing chief Kenny Jacobs said passengers booked on the cancelled flights would be able to change 
their time of departure free of charge or get their money back.
The announcement came several hours after the Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) union said its members would join a 
strike taking place between 3:01 am (0101 GMT) Friday and 2:59 am Saturday and that all Ryanair flights to and 
from Germany could be affected by the action.
"Ryanair categorically ruled out any increase in pay over the course of the negotiations," said VC chief Martin 
Locher during a press conference. "At the same time, Ryanair did not give any signal as to where there may be 
leeway to find solutions."
Twenty-two of the nearly 400 cancelled flights are to and from Sweden. Most of Ryanair's flights at the regional 
Skvasta airport, about 100 kilometres south of Stockholm, will be affected, according to the head of the country's 
pilots' union.
"No talks are currently under way between Ryanair and the Swedish pilots' union (SPF)," union head Martin 
Lindgren told Swedish Radio on Wednesday. "Ryanair refuses to meet with the SPF representatives we have 
selected."
Ryanair cuts nearly 400 flights ahead of pilot strike in 4 countries
Two weeks ago, Ryanair crew in Portugal, Spain and Belgium walked off the job, forcing the budget airline to cancel 
some 600 flights over the course of two days. The action affected around 100,000 passengers.
Both pilots and crew are demanding better pay and conditions, which Ryanair has declined to grant thus far.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 9, 2018
End of Document
German pilots to join major strike action against Ryanair on Friday
German pilots to join major strike action against Ryanair on Friday
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 8, 2018 Wednesday 11:56 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 286 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt, Friederike Heine in Berlin and Lennart Simonsson in Stockholm
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
A German pilots' union called on its members to join a strike on Friday alongside other Ryanair pilots from Sweden, 
Ireland and Belgium.
The Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) union said the strike would take place between 3:01 am (0101 GMT) Friday and 2:59 
am Saturday and that all Ryanair flights to and from Germany could be affected by the action.
"Ryanair categorically ruled out any increase in pay over the course of the negotiations," said VC chief Martin 
Locher during a press conference. "At the same time, Ryanair did not give any signal as to where there may be 
leeway to find solutions."
German Ryanair pilots will join a previously announced strike by their counterparts in Sweden, Ireland and Belgium, 
which would make it the largest industrial action by pilots in the budget airline's history.
Ryanair has already cancelled 146 of its 2,400 scheduled flights on Friday.
Twenty-two of those flights are to and from Sweden. Most of Ryanair's flights at the regional Skvasta airport, about 
100 kilometres south of Stockholm, will be affected, according to the head of the country's pilots' union.
"No talks are currently under way between Ryanair and the Swedish pilots' union (SPF)," union head Martin 
Lindgren told Swedish Radio on Wednesday. "Ryanair refuses to meet with the SPF representatives we have 
selected."
Two weeks ago, Ryanair crew in Portugal, Spain and Belgium walked off the job, forcing the budget airline to cancel 
some 600 flights over the course of two days. The action affected around 100,000 passengers.
Both pilots and crew are demanding better pay and conditions, which Ryanair has declined to grant thus far.
German pilots to join major strike action against Ryanair on Friday

WORLD-ENVIRONMENT-SAND
After a day at the beach, it's hard to imagine that the world is running out of sand. Yet this natural raw material is 
quickly being depleted by the construction industry, so much so that experts are now sounding the alarm over the 
consequences of its disappearance.
FEATURE: Hard to believe, but the planet is quickly running out of sand. By Carola Frentzen, 853 words, moving 
shortly
Load-Date: August 9, 2018
End of Document
German pilots to join major strike action against Ryanair on Friday
German pilots to join major strike action against Ryanair on Friday
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 8, 2018 Wednesday 11:23 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 118 words
Byline: Friederike Heine
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) has called on its members to join a strike on Friday alongside other 
Ryanair pilots from Sweden, Ireland and Belgium.
The union announced on Wednesday that the strike would take place between 3:01 am (0101 GMT) Friday and 
2:59 am Saturday and that all Ryanair flights to and from Germany could be affected by the action.
German Ryanair pilots will join a previously announced strike by their counterparts in Sweden, Ireland and Belgium, 
which would make it the largest industrial action by pilots in the budget airline's history.
Ryanair has already cancelled 146 of its 2,400 scheduled flights on Friday.
Editorial contactsTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 9, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair cancels 250 flights after German pilots join Friday strike
Ryanair cancels 250 flights after German pilots join Friday strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 8, 2018 Wednesday 2:00 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 86 words
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair has cancelled 250 additional flights on Friday in response to the announcement by the 
German pilots' union that its members would join a strike by Ryanair pilots in Sweden, Ireland and Belgium.
The airline's marketing chief Kenny Jacobs said passengers booked on those flights would be able to change their 
time of departure free of charge or receive their money back.
Ryanair had already cancelled 146 of its 2,400 Friday flights before the Vereinigung Cockpit union's announcement 
on Wednesday.
Load-Date: August 9, 2018
End of Document

German pilot union prepares to announce Ryanair strike
German pilot union prepares to announce Ryanair strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 7, 2018 Tuesday 12:22 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 181 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit (VC) is preparing to announce strike action, with a spokesman saying on 
Tuesday that a midnight deadline passed without the union receiving an improved offer for pay and conditions from 
budget carrier Ryanair.
The spokesman said a strike plan would be announced at 11 am (0900 GMT) on Wednesday. The stoppage is 
expected to include all 400 German Ryanair pilots, who could walk out at 24 hours' notice.
Last week, 96 per cent of the VC union's members voted in favour of industrial action.
The deadline comes three days after Irish Ryanair pilots held a 24-hour strike. It also comes ahead of a strike on 
Friday organized by pilots unions in Sweden, Belgium and Ireland that has prompted Ryanair to cancel 146 of its 
2,400 planned flights that day.
The airline said last week that it had issued notices of possible redundancy to 100 pilots and 200 cabin crew after 
its board approved a plan to cut its Dublin-based fleet from 30 to 24 aircraft over the winter.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 8, 2018
End of Document

German pilots' union yet to receive Ryanair offer as deadline looms
German pilots' union yet to receive Ryanair offer as deadline looms
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 6, 2018 Monday 4:49 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 170 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
German pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit had not received an improved offer for pay and conditions on Monday, 
just hours before a deadline for the low-budget airline to avoid disruption of its services.
A spokesman for the union said in case no offer is made by 2200 GMT, a strike plan will be announced Wednesday 
that is expected to include all 400 German Ryanair pilots. They could walk out at 24 hours' notice.
Last week, 96 per cent of the union's members voted in favour of industrial action.
The deadline comes three days after Irish Ryanair pilots held a 24-hour strike.
Ryanair said the strike had had "no effect" on passengers since it cancelled 24 of Friday's 300 Ryanair flights to 
and from Ireland more than a week ago.
The airline also said it had issued notices of possible redundancy to 100 pilots and 200 cabin crew after its board 
approved a plan to cut its Dublin-based fleet from 30 to 24 aircraft over the winter.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Friederike HeineTel: +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 7, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair urges mediation as pilots in Ireland hold fourth strike
Ryanair urges mediation as pilots in Ireland hold fourth strike
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 3, 2018 Friday 3:44 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 264 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair urged an Irish pilots' union to agree to mediation of a long-running dispute, as the pilots held 
their fourth 24-hour strike on Friday.
The airline said the strike had "no effect" on passengers since it had cancelled 24 of Friday's 300 Ryanair flights to 
and from Ireland more than a week ago.
It accused the Irish public sector trade union Forsa, which represents the pilots, of refusing to "engage or explain" 
its position on two outstanding issues, saying the two sides had broadly agreed on other points.
"Given the non-engagement by Forsa ... [and] that unsuccessful strikes keep repeating, Ryanair now feels the only 
way to introduce common sense is by way of third-party mediation," said Eddie Wilson, the airline's chief personnel 
officer.
Wilson proposed Kieran Mulvey, a former government labour official, for the role of mediator.
Forsa, which has announced a fifth strike for August 10, said Ryanair's mediation offer was an "unexpected and 
positive development."
It said the union would "consult with its members in the company, and looks forward to talking to Kieran Mulvey 
about when a process could begin."
The pilots are unhappy about Ryanair's plans to change seniority rules and its procedures for annual leave, 
transfers and promotions.
The union accused Ryanair of attempted "union busting" last month after it warned that it could cut 100 pilots and 
200 cabin crew from its staff in Ireland as it reduces its Dublin-based fleet from 30 to 24 aircraft over the winter.
Ryanair urges mediation as pilots in Ireland hold fourth strike
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 4, 2018
End of Document

Ryanair refuses to compensate passengers for 'unreasonable' strikes
Ryanair refuses to compensate passengers for 'unreasonable' strikes
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 26, 2018 Thursday 5:44 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 423 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair on Thursday refused to compensate passengers whose flights were cancelled due to strikes 
by Ryanair staff this week because it deems the action "unreasonable."
The airline cancelled 600 flights scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday due to a strike by cabin crew in Belgium, 
Spain and Portugal, affecting some 50,000 passengers.
Under EU legislation for flight cancellations, an airline should pay 250 euros (293 dollars) to each passenger, 
unless they are informed at least two weeks in advance or are offered alternative flights arriving at their destination 
the same day.
An airline can withhold compensation if it can show that the cancellation is "caused by extraordinary circumstances 
which could not have been avoided even if all reasonable measures had been taken," according to the rules.
"Ryanair fully complies with all EU ... legislation. However, as these flight cancellations were caused by 
extraordinary circumstances, no compensation is due," the airline said.
It argued that no compensation is payable "when the union is acting unreasonably and totally beyond the airline's 
control."
Ryanair faces another one-day strike next week by Irish-based pilots, as a European pilots' union on Thursday 
accused it of attempted "union busting" by warning that it could cut up to 300 staff in Ireland this winter.
On Thursday, the airline cancelled 20 of its 300 scheduled flights to and from Ireland on August 3, saying the Irish 
pilots' union had rejected its offer to hold talks.
Ryanair refuses to compensate passengers for 'unreasonable' strikes
The airline said it issued notices of possible redundancy to 100 pilots and 200 cabin crew after its board approved a 
plan to cut its Dublin-based fleet from 30 to 24 aircraft over the winter.
"This unfortunate and entirely avoidable decision by Ryanair can be interpreted at best as a very immature 
response to legitimate strike action," said Dirk Polloczek, president of the European Cockpit Association (ECA).
"At worst as a bold attempt at union busting and an effort to put maximum pressure on pilots to stop industrial 
action," Polloczek added.
Philip von Schoeppenthau, the ECA's secretary general, said the airline's "provocation and unnecessary behaviour 
will only encourage even more pilots to leave Ryanair for competitor airlines."
"The myth of union-friendly Ryanair is falling apart," von Schoeppenthau said, accusing the airline of "reverting to its 
previous anti-union tactics, while claiming publicly to constructively engage with its unions."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 27, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair refuses to compensate passengers for 'unreasonable' strikes
Ryanair refuses to compensate passengers for 'unreasonable' strikes
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 26, 2018 Thursday 1:05 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 271 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair on Thursday refused to compensate passengers whose flights were cancelled due to strikes 
by Ryanair staff this week, because it deems the action "unreasonable."
The airline cancelled 600 flights scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday due to a strike by cabin crew in Belgium, 
Spain and Portugal, affecting some 50,000 passengers.
Under EU legislation for flight cancellations, an airline should pay 250 euros (293 dollars) to each passenger, 
subject to conditions.
"Ryanair fully complies with all EU ... legislation. However, as these flight cancellations were caused by 
extraordinary circumstances, no compensation is due," the airline said.
It argued that no compensation is payable "when the union is acting unreasonably and totally beyond the airline's 
control."
Ryanair faces another one-day strike next week by Irish-based pilots, as a European pilots' union on Thursday 
accused it of attempted "union busting" by warning that it could cut up to 300 staff in Ireland this winter.
The airline said it issued notices of possible redundancy to 100 pilots and 200 cabin crew after its board approved a 
plan to cut its Dublin-based fleet from 30 to 24 aircraft over the winter.
"This unfortunate and entirely avoidable decision by Ryanair can be interpreted at best as a very immature 
response to legitimate strike action," said Dirk Polloczek, president of the European Cockpit Association.
"At worst as a bold attempt at union busting and an effort to put maximum pressure on pilots to stop industrial 
action," Polloczek added.
Ryanair refuses to compensate passengers for 'unreasonable' strikes
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 27, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair warns over Ireland jobs as strikes hit 50,000 passengers
Ryanair warns over Ireland jobs as strikes hit 50,000 passengers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 25, 2018 Wednesday 12:41 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 260 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair warned staff in Ireland that up to 300 jobs could be lost this winter, as strikes by cabin crew 
affected its flights in three other countries on Wednesday.
The airline said it had issued notices of possible redundancy to 100 pilots and 200 cabin crew after its board 
approved a plan to cut its Dublin-based fleet from 30 to 24 aircraft this winter.
If the cut goes ahead, the airline will offer transfers to Poland, and possibly other bases, to "minimize any 
redundancies," Ryanair said.
The airline's chief operating officer, Peter Bellew, suggested the move was partly linked to "forward bookings being 
damaged by rolling strikes by Irish pilots."
Bellew said potential job cuts would be "a deeply regretted consequence" of any damage to Ryanair's "reputation 
for reliability or forward bookings" from its fleet of more than 450 aircraft in 87 European bases.
In a quarterly report on Monday, the airline criticized "unnecessary strikes" by about 25 per cent of Irish-based pilots 
this month.
Ryanair also cancelled 600 flights scheduled for Wednesday and Thursday due to a strike by cabin crew in three 
countries.
"We apologize to the 50,000 Belgium, Spain and Portugal customers whose flights today were cancelled," the 
airline tweeted on Wednesday.
It said all other scheduled Ryanair flights were "operating as normal" on Wednesday, but air-traffic control staff 
shortages in France, Germany and Greece delayed 50 of the airline's 345 early morning flights.
Ryanair warns over Ireland jobs as strikes hit 50,000 passengers
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 26, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair profits fall 20 per cent in first quarter
Ryanair profits fall 20 per cent in first quarter
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 23, 2018 Monday 12:44 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 285 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair reported a 20-per-cent fall in profits in the first quarter of its financial year on Monday, blaming lower fares 
and higher fuel and pilot costs, but the low-cost airline insisted that it remains on track to hit its annual target.
The airline said its net profit dropped to 319 million euros (373 million dollars) in the quarter ended June 30, as 
average fares fell 4 per cent amid some overcapacity in Europe and an early Easter peak.
Higher fuel and staff costs, and strikes by Ryanair pilots and international air traffic controllers (ATC), also affected 
financial performance, it said.
"Traffic grew 7 per cent, to 37.6 million, despite over 2,500 flight cancellations caused by ATC staff shortages and 
ATC strikes," Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary said.
But Ryanair's low fares delivered "an industry-leading 96-per-cent load factor," O'Leary said.
Ryanair said it still expected to achieve its annual profit forecast of 1.25 billion euros to 1.35 billion euros.
The airline said it had introduced measures to make Ryanair more attractive to pilots and cabin crew, including a 
pay increase, improved training and trade union recognition.
Despite signing union recognition agreements in Britain and Italy, and in Germany for cabin crew, the airline said it 
still suffered two "unnecessary strikes" by about 25 per cent of Irish-based pilots this month, while cabin crew have 
threatened strikes in Spain, Portugal and Belgium.
"If these unnecessary strikes continue to damage customer confidence and forward prices/yields in certain country 
markets, then we will have to review our winter schedule," it warned.
Ryanair profits fall 20 per cent in first quarter
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 24, 2018
End of Document

MONDAY, JULY 23
AMSTERDAM: World AIDS conference begins (runs until Friday).

*PARIS: France's interior minister is questioned by lawmakers about an aide to the president who was filmed 
beating a May Day protester.
MOUNTAIN VIEW, CALIFORNIA:: Google's parent company Alphabet reports second quarter results.
DUBLIN: Ryanair reports first quarter results.
HAMBURG: German Open tennis championships continue (until Sunday).
CARCASSONNE, FRANCE: Tour de France rest day.
DUISBURG, GERMANY: "Night Of 1,000 Lights" commemorates victims of Love Parade crowd disaster on July 24, 
2010, when 21 people died and 652 were injured.

platforms in Northern Africa.

announces first half 2018 results.

injured.

Thursday).

Ryanair cancels 600 flights for next week as strike looms
Ryanair cancels 600 flights for next week as strike looms
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 18, 2018 Wednesday 9:13 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 229 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Low-cost airline Ryanair has cancelled 600 flights scheduled for the coming week due to the threat of impending 
strikes by cabin crew, the carrier announced Wednesday.
Some 50,000 passengers will be affected by the cancellations next Wednesday and Thursday, Ryanair said on 
Twitter.
The move would affect 200 flights to and from Spain on each of the days, as well as 50 each for Portugal and 
Belgium, together accounting for around 12 per cent of the airline's total European flight network.
Ryanair's flight attendants are walking out following a call by the cabin crews' respective unions in each of the three 
countries.
Whether German airports are affected by the failures, the airline could not say. Affected passengers would be 
informed.
Ryanair's employees are seeking higher salaries and an improvement in working conditions. The company's Irish 
pilots are also planning to strike this Friday and next Tuesday.
Affected passengers were informed by e-mail or text messages, and have been offered re-bookings or a full refund, 
Ryanair said.
According to company spokesman Kenny Jacobs, the strikes were unjustified, and would only disrupt family 
vacations and benefit the competition.
The flight attendants currently receive salaries of up to 40,000 euros (46,600 dollars) a year, he added.
Ryanair cancels 600 flights for next week as strike looms
Editorial contactsEditing by: Martin Waldman, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 19, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair flight makes emergency landing in Germany after pressure drop
Ryanair flight makes emergency landing in Germany after pressure drop
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 14, 2018 Saturday 6:26 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 333 words
Byline: Reporting by Daniel Moeglich and Marc Kalpidis in Berlin
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
A Ryanair flight carrying 189 passengers from Dublin to the Croatian city of Zadar was diverted to Frankfurt-Hahn 
airport in Germany after a sudden loss in cabin pressure, police said Saturday.
Thirty-three passengers were taken to area hospitals. "The passengers complained of headaches and earaches, 
and suffered from nausea," a German federal police spokesman told dpa.
Other passengers spent the night at the airport.
On Saturday morning, a replacement aircraft departed to complete the trip to Zadar. However, 22 passengers could 
not fly for medical reasons, and would be taken to Zadar by bus, police said.
What exactly happened on board the Boeing 737 was not known.
"Experts must now clarify that, but that can take some time," the police spokesman said.
The plane landed at Frankfurt-Hahn Airport at 11:30 pm (2130 GMT) Friday night.
A passenger told German newspaper Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung that there was a not-too-loud bang and a 
sudden drop in temperature inside the plane.
Oxygen masks dropped from above the seats before the crew announced there would be an emergency descent. 
While there had at first been some panic on board, everyone remained calm in the end.
Many passengers experienced earaches, while others reported bleeding from their ears. One woman was carried 
away on a stretcher.
Ryanair flight makes emergency landing in Germany after pressure drop
In a statement, Ryanair said the reason for the emergency landing was an "inflight depressurization." The airline did 
not provide any details on the exact cause of the incident, nor did it comment on the health of the passengers.
"A pressure drop can happen from time to time, but it only rarely leads to real problems," a spokesman for a 
German pilots' association, Janis Georg Schmitt, told dpa.
It does not put the aircraft in any danger of crashing, and instances of a pressure loss are regularly practised in 
flight simulators, he added.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Martin Waldman, +49 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;Editing by: Stephen 
Lowman, +49 30 2852 31472, <Lowman.Stephen@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 15, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair flight diverted to Germany , police confirm
Ryanair flight diverted to Germany, police confirm
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 14, 2018 Saturday 2:49 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 96 words
Byline: Reporting by Daniel Moeglich and Marc Kalpidis in Berlin
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
A Ryanair flight from Dublin to the Croatian city of Zadar was diverted to Frankfurt-Hahn airport in Germany early 
Saturday, a German federal police spokesman told dpa.
Some 30 passengers were taken to a local hospital after feeling ill on the flight.
Details were not immediately available.
Whether the plane was forced to make an unscheduled stop due to the passengers' illness or for technical reasons 
was not clear.
A spokesman representing the airline could not be reached for comment.

Ryanair flight diverted to Germany with sickened passengers
Ryanair flight diverted to Germany with sickened passengers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 14, 2018 Saturday 7:07 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 131 words
Byline: Reporting by Daniel Moeglich and Marc Kalpidis in Berlin
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
A Ryanair flight from Dublin to the Croatian city of Zadar was diverted to Frankfurt-Hahn airport in Germany early 
Saturday, a German federal police spokesman told dpa.
Some 30 passengers were taken to a local hospital after feeling ill on the flight. A drop in cabin pressure was 
believed to have caused the problem.
"The passengers complained of headaches and earaches, and suffered from nausea," the police spokesman said.
There were 189 passengers on board the plane.
Paramedics took the sickened passengers to hospital, while the others spent the night at the airport.
What happened on board the plane was not immediately clear, but an investigation was being conducted, the police 
spokesman said.

Lufthansa and Ryanair in spat over planes leased to Laudamotion
Lufthansa and Ryanair in spat over planes leased to Laudamotion
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 13, 2018 Friday 9:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 236 words
Byline: Steffen Weyer in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Lufthansa on Friday recalled nine planes it has leased to Laudamotion, a day after Ryanair was given the go-ahead 
by European Union competition authorities to take over the Austrian budget carrier.
Justifying the step, Lufthansa, Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers, said Laudamotion had "repeatedly 
failed to make the agreed payments." The recall has yet to take effect.
The nine planes make up almost half the fleet of Laudamotion, the former Air Berlin subsidiary that used to be 
known as Niki.
Lufthansa, which had wanted to buy Niki from Air Berlin but withdrew from the bidding in December last year, said it 
could make good use of the planes in its own budget carrier, Eurowings.
Speaking to Austrian news agency APA, Laudamotion chief executive Andreas Gruber insisted it had paid all its 
bills related to the planes.
The payments for July had been met at the end of June, and all nine planes were in full use, Gruber said.
Dublin-based Ryanair accused Lufthansa of delaying payments of 1.5 million euros to Laudamotion, terming the 
cancellation of the leases as yet another attempt by Lufthansa "to destabilize and cause damage."
It also said Lufthansa had failed to make available all the planes promised. Lufthansa rejected this.
The European Commission gave the takeover the go-ahead without setting any conditions.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Femke Colborne, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Lufthansa and Ryanair in spat over planes leased to Laudamotion
Load-Date: July 14, 2018
End of Document
Lufthansa and Ryanair in spat over planes leased to Laudamotion
Lufthansa and Ryanair in spat over planes leased to Laudamotion
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 13, 2018 Friday 9:30 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 353 words
Byline: Steffen Weyer in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
Lufthansa on Friday recalled nine planes it has leased to Laudamotion, a day after Ryanair was given the go-ahead 
by European Union competition authorities to take over the Austrian budget carrier.
Justifying the step, Lufthansa, Europe's largest airline by passenger numbers, said Laudamotion had "repeatedly 
failed to make the agreed payments." The recall has yet to take effect.
The nine planes make up almost half the fleet of Laudamotion, the former Air Berlin subsidiary that used to be 
known as Niki.
Lufthansa, which had wanted to buy Niki from Air Berlin but withdrew from the bidding in December last year, said it 
could make good use of the planes in its own budget carrier, Eurowings.
Speaking to Austrian news agency APA, Laudamotion chief executive Andreas Gruber insisted it had paid all its 
bills related to the planes.
The payments for July had been met at the end of June, and all nine planes were in full use, Gruber said.
Dublin-based Ryanair accused Lufthansa of delaying payments of 1.5 million euros to Laudamotion, terming the 
cancellation of the leases as yet another attempt by Lufthansa "to destabilize and cause damage."
It also said Lufthansa had failed to make available all the planes promised. Lufthansa rejected this.
The European Commission gave the takeover the go-ahead without setting any conditions.
Ryanair, which operates throughout Europe, is to take a 75 per cent stake in the Austrian carrier, which flies 
primarily from Germany, Austria and Switzerland to holiday destinations in the Mediterranean and Canary Islands.
Lufthansa and Ryanair in spat over planes leased to Laudamotion
Austrian entrepreneur and former Formula One racer Niki Lauda originally founded the airline under the name Niki 
in 2003 and sold it to the Air Berlin group in 2011. Following Air Berlin's bankruptcy last year, he bought it back in 
January and re-established it as Laudamotion with the help of British travel company Thomas Cook.
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary sees the investment as a way to expand business in the German-speaking 
market, which is dominated by Lufthansa.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Femke Colborne, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 14, 2018

EU gives green light to Ryanair takeover of Austria 's Laudamotion
EU gives green light to Ryanair takeover of Austria's Laudamotion
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 12, 2018 Thursday 8:47 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 200 words
Byline: Alkimos Sartoros in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
European Union competition authorities have given the go-ahead for Dublin-based Ryanair to take over Austrian 
budget carrier Laudamotion, the European Commission announced on Thursday.
The authorization was issued without any conditions, as there were no grounds for reservations on competition 
grounds, the commission said.
Ryanair, which operates throughout Europe, is to take a 75 per cent stake in the Austrian carrier, which flies 
primarily from Germany, Austria and Switzerland to holiday destinations in the Mediterranean and Canaries.
Austrian entrepreneur and former Formula One racer Niki Lauda originally founded the airline under the name Niki 
in 2003 and sold it to the Air Berlin group in 2011. Following Air Berlin's bankruptcy last year, he bought it back in 
January and re-established it as Laudamotion with the help of British travel company Thomas Cook.
Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary sees the investment as a way to expand business in the German-speaking 
market, which is dominated by Lufthansa.
Lufthansa earlier wanted to buy Niki from Air Berlin but withdrew in December last year.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 13, 2018
EU gives green light to Ryanair takeover of Austria 's Laudamotion
End of Document
Ryanair strike due on July 25-26 in Belgium , Italy , Portugal , Spain
Ryanair strike due on July 25-26 in Belgium, Italy, Portugal, Spain
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 5, 2018 Thursday 3:42 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 270 words
Byline: Helen Maguire in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair cabin staff have agreed to go on strike on July 25 and 26 in Belgium, Italy, Portugal and Spain, a 
consortium of trade unions announced on Thursday, following talks in Brussels.
Employees at Europe's largest budget airline have long demanded better pay and working conditions.
Trade unions from Belgium, Spain, Portugal and Italy convened Thursday's talks after Ryanair missed an end-of-
June deadline to apply national labour laws, enter into negotiations with them and apply the same conditions to all 
cabin crew, the unions said in a statement.
"Regretfully, Ryanair chose to continue to ignore its workforce and gave these unions no other choice but to call for 
a national 24 hours strike action," the statement said.
Ryanair cabin crews are due to strike in all four countries on July 25, with Italian staff resuming work on July 26 
while the Belgian, Spanish and Portuguese workforce continue their industrial action.
Unions in other European countries might also take action in the coming weeks, the statement said, noting that 
"legal restrictions and extensive bureaucratic procedures," were currently preventing them from doing so.
The statement calls on the European Commission and EU governments to act against Ryanair's labour practices, 
while urging the European Aviation Safety Agency and its national counterparts to be "more vigilant with Ryanair 
and make them abide by the law."
The statement was signed by the CNE and LBC unions in Belgium, SITCPLA and USO in Spain, the SNPVAC in 
Portugal and Italy's Uiltrasporti union.
Ryanair strike due on July 25-26 in Belgium , Italy , Portugal , Spain
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 6, 2018
End of Document
Ryanair strike due on July 25-26 in Belgium , Italy , Portugal , Spain
Ryanair strike due on July 25-26 in Belgium, Italy, Portugal, Spain
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 5, 2018 Thursday 2:17 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 95 words
Byline: Helen Maguire in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Ryanair staff have agreed to go on strike on July 25 and 26 in Belgium, Italy, Portugal and Spain, the CNE trade 
union told dpa on Thursday, confirming Belgian media reports.
Employees at Europe's largest budget airline have long demanded better pay and working conditions.
Trade unions had convened Thursday's talks in Brussels following an end-of-June ultimatum for Ryanair to accept 
local regulations, as other airlines do, according to the CNE, one of Belgium's largest trade unions.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;

Norway sells remaining stake in Scandinavian carrier SAS
Norway sells remaining stake in Scandinavian carrier SAS
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 27, 2018 Wednesday 11:24 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 243 words
Byline: Lennart Simonsson in Stockholm
Dateline: Stockholm (dpa) - 
Body
The government of Norway said on Wednesday it has sold its remaining shares in Scandinavian airline SAS, 
ending its seven-decade long interest in the firm.
The Norwegian Ministry of Trade, Industry and Fisheries said the sale of Norway's almost 10-per-cent-stake was 
worth about 597 million kroner (73 million dollars).
Prior to the sale, conducted in an auction late Tuesday, the Norwegian state was the third-largest shareholder in the 
carrier, formed in 1946.
"The government has long stated that it was not a long-term owner of SAS. Parliament has on several occasions 
authorized the government to sell off its holdings," Torbjorn Roe Isaken, minister of trade and industry said in a 
statement.
Buyers included investors from Norway and other countries, the ministry said.
"SAS has recently had a positive development, and I believe firmly that the company will continue to work to 
improve its competitive edge," the minister added.
Other main owners include the governments of Denmark and Sweden, which, together, own 29 per cent in SAS.
Sweden has also said it was open to sell its stake, but Danish Finance Minister Kristian Jensen said in a comment 
Wednesday to Danish news agency Ritzau that Denmark had no immediate plans to sell.
SAS has, in recent years, experienced increased competition from  low-cost carriers such as Norwegian Air Shuttle, 
Ryanair and Wizzair.
Norway sells remaining stake in Scandinavian carrier SAS
Editorial contactsEditing by: Niels C Sorrells, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: June 28, 2018

German pilots halt pay talks with Ryanair as strike ballot proceeds
German pilots halt pay talks with Ryanair as strike ballot proceeds
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
June 20, 2018 Wednesday 3:23 PM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 104 words
Byline: Christian Ebner in Frankfurt
Dateline: Frankfurt (dpa) - 
Body
The Cockpit union of German pilots has broken off pay talks with budget airline Ryanair, accusing the Ireland-based 
company of being uncooperative, a Cockpit spokesman said in Frankfurt on Wednesday.
Ryanair representatives had failed to arrive for agreed appointments, the spokesman said.
A strike now looms at the German locations operated by Europe's largest budget carrier. Cockpit has initiated a 
ballot of its members working for Ryanair, the spokesman said.
Dublin-based Ryanair is facing conflict with its pilots in Ireland as well.

Ryanair profits rise despite lower ticket prices and pilot scandal
Ryanair profits rise despite lower ticket prices and pilot scandal
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 21, 2018 Monday 11:51 AM GMT
Copyright 2018 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 187 words
Byline: Theresa Muench in Copenhagen
Dateline: Dublin (dpa) - 
Body
Europe's largest budget airline Ryanair has reported improved profits in the 2017 fiscal year despite lower ticket 
prices and September's mismanagement of pilot schedules.
From April 2017 to March 2018, a 10-per-cent increase in after-tax profit to 1.45 billion euros (1.7 billion dollars) 
was reported by the Irish airline in a statement released on Monday.
"We are pleased to report a 10-per-cent increase in profits, with an unchanged net margin of 20 per cent," said 
CEO Michael O'Leary, who also acknowledged the difficulties of the September 2017 "rostering management 
failure."
Ryanair cancelled around 20,000 flights in the autumn after failing to accommodate for a backlog of holidays for its 
crew, which caused a number of strikes by employees across Europe.
Despite the crisis, the airline still logged over 130 million passengers in 2017, filling 95 per cent of their available 
seats, an industry high.
While O'Leary expects even more passengers in the coming year, he also warns of higher costs for pilots, crew and 
fuel.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Michael Madden in Berlin +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com; 
Load-Date: May 22, 2018
Ryanair profits rise despite lower ticket prices and pilot scandal
End of Document
