Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 12:39 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 419 words
Byline: Andrew McCathie in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Air Berlin passengers faced fresh chaos on Tuesday after the beleaguered German airline cancelled 100 flights due 
to a surge in the number of pilots reporting sick.
The reason for the cancellations is "an extraordinary number of sick reports in the cockpit," said a spokesman for 
Germany's second-biggest airline, which last month filed for insolvency.
Air Berlin has asked passengers to check the status of their flight on the airline's website prior to their arrival at the 
airport after it said it was cancelling 100 of its scheduled 750 flights for Tuesday.
About 200 of the 1,500 pilots due to fly on Tuesday had called in sick, the airline said.
"Today is a day that the existence of Air Berlin is threatened," wrote Air Berlin chief operations officer Oliver Iffert in 
an internal memo seen by dpa.
Calling it a "pilot revolt," the daily Bild reported that the reason for the jump in the number of pilots claiming to be 
sick was a dispute over their possible transition from the insolvent airline to a potential new buyer.
However, the pilots' union, Vereinigung Cockpit, denied the report, saying: "At no point did the VC call for (pilots) to 
report ill."
Air Berlin said it would offer affected passengers the "best alternative travel" options.
The airline announced on Monday that it had slashed a series of international flights as a result of the need to 
reduce its long-haul operations as part of insolvency proceedings.
This included flights to the Caribbean from the western German city of Dusseldorf to September 24.
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
The German government was forced last month to provide the airline with a bridging loan of 150 million euros (180 
million dollars) to help it to continue operating.
Potential buyers have until September 15 to lodge offers for the struggling carrier, with Germany's biggest airline 
Lufthansa among bidders seeking to acquire parts of Air Berlin.
German businessman Hans Rudolf Wohrl this week also unveiled a 500-million-euro bid for Air Berlin, which ran up 
a loss last year of about 782 million euros and has debts totalling nearly 1.2 billion euros.
Air Berlin has operated at a loss every year since 2008, except for 2012, when it sold off its frequent flyer 
programme.
In the meantime, budget airline Ryanair stepped up its campaign on Tuesday to take on Lufthansa in its home base 
of Frankfurt with the Irish carrier announcing 34 new flights from Germany's biggest airport from the middle of next 
year.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Anindita Ramaswamy, +49 30 2852-31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 13, 2017
End of Document
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 12, 2017 Tuesday 8:24 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 456 words
Byline: Andrew McCathie in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Air Berlin passengers faced fresh chaos on Tuesday after the beleaguered German airline cancelled 100 flights due 
to a surge in the number of pilots reporting sick.
The reason for the cancellations is "an extraordinary number of sick reports in the cockpit," said a spokesman for 
Germany's second-biggest airline, which last month filed for insolvency.
Air Berlin has asked passengers to check the status of their flight on the airline's website prior to their arrival at the 
airport after it said it was cancelling 100 of its scheduled 750 flights for Tuesday.
About 200 of the 1,500 pilots due to fly on Tuesday had called in sick, the airline said.
"Today is a day that the existence of Air Berlin is threatened," wrote Air Berlin chief operations officer Oliver Iffert in 
an internal memo seen by dpa.
In another internal memo seen by dpa, the company's board said that 149 captains and first officers had already 
called in sick for Wednesday.
A spokesman for the airline confirmed that cancellations are expected Wednesday.
Calling it a "pilot revolt," the daily Bild reported that the reason for the jump in the number of pilots claiming to be 
sick was a dispute over their possible transition from the insolvent airline to a potential new buyer.
However, the pilots' union, Vereinigung Cockpit, denied the report, saying: "At no point did the VC call for (pilots) to 
report ill."
Air Berlin said it would offer affected passengers the "best alternative travel" options.
Air Berlin hits turbulence, cancels 100 flights over sick pilots
The airline announced on Monday that it had slashed a series of international flights as a result of the need to 
reduce its long-haul operations as part of insolvency proceedings.
This included flights to the Caribbean from the western German city of Dusseldorf to September 24.
The German government was forced last month to provide the airline with a bridging loan of 150 million euros (180 
million dollars) to help it to continue operating.
Potential buyers have until September 15 to lodge offers for the struggling carrier, with Germany's biggest airline 
Lufthansa among bidders seeking to acquire parts of Air Berlin.
German businessman Hans Rudolf Wohrl this week also unveiled a 500-million-euro bid for Air Berlin, which ran up 
a loss last year of about 782 million euros and has debts totalling nearly 1.2 billion euros.
Air Berlin has operated at a loss every year since 2008, except for 2012, when it sold off its frequent flyer 
programme.
In the meantime, budget airline Ryanair stepped up its campaign on Tuesday to take on Lufthansa in its home base 
of Frankfurt with the Irish carrier announcing 34 new flights from Germany's biggest airport from the middle of next 
year.

EU approves German bridging loan for insolvent Air Berlin
EU approves German bridging loan for insolvent Air Berlin
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 4, 2017 Monday 3:32 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 243 words
Byline: Naveena Kottoor in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
The European Commission has approved plans by the German government to grant the country's troubled air 
carrier Air Berlin a temporary bridging loan worth 150 million euros (178.76 million dollars).
Air Berlin, Germany's second-largest airline and an employer of 7,200 people in the country, filed for insolvency in 
August after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad Airways, withdrew financial support.
The move forced the German government to step in to provide the airline with a temporary credit of 150 million 
euros to help it continue operating.
Last week Michael O'Leary, the head of the Irish budget airline Ryanair, complained that the insolvency process 
was designed to strengthen German airline Lufthansa, who has expressed an interest in buying a large share of 
assets in the bankrupt airline.
The commission said in a statement that Germany "committed to ensure that either the loan will be fully repaid, or 
Germany will submit awinding-down plan for Air Berlin."
"The loan will be paid out in instalments under stringent conditions. In particular, Air Berlin has to demonstrate its 
liquidity needs on a weekly basis and new instalments will only be paid when all existing liquidity has been used," 
according to the statement.
"The Commission found that the measure will help to protect the interests of air passengers and to maintain air 
passenger services."
Editorial contactsEditing by: Monica Raymunt, +49 30 2852 31472; <international@dpa.com;
EU approves German bridging loan for insolvent Air Berlin
Load-Date: September 5, 2017
End of Document
THIS WEEK in Brexit: Blame, animosity creep into negotiations
THIS WEEK in Brexit: Blame, animosity creep into negotiations
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
September 1, 2017 Friday 5:15 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 542 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London and Naveena Kottoor in Brussels
Dateline: London/Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
EU and British officials have held perhaps their most disappointing round of talks so far, ending four days of 
meetings with no sign of progress, recriminations on both sides, and little prospect of a smooth resolution to the 
negotiations.
- William Hague, a former leader of British Prime Minister Theresa May's Conservative Party, warned that he 
expected "BIG BUST-UPS" during the months of negotiations until Britain officially leaves the European Union in 
March 2019.
Hague told the BBC that May's negotiating position had been weakened by her poor performance in a snap general 
election in June, when the Conservatives lost their majority in parliament. "We'll end up having to PAY MORE," he 
said. "We'll pay a bigger price for leaving, I think, because of the uncertainties of the election result."
- May was occupied for most of the week with a trade-focused visit to JAPAN, one of several major economies her 
government has targeted for expanded post-Brexit trade and investment. She promised to work to "unblock 
remaining barriers to trade and take steps to build the closest, freest trading relationship between the UK and Japan 
after Brexit."
May told reporters in Japan that she was "NOT A QUITTER" and would lead the Conservatives into another 
election in 2022, despite the pressure that has mounted on her over the June election campaign and criticisms of 
her Brexit policies.
- Michael O'LEARY, the colourful, pro-EU chief executive of budget airline Ryanair, accused May of "swanning 
around Japan drinking tea and sake" instead of handling the Brexit negotiations. "I fail to see what she's doing in 
Japan for three days at the moment, why she's not in Brussels or in Frankfurt or in Paris, which is where these 
negotiations need to take place," O'Leary told Sky News.
THIS WEEK in Brexit: Blame, animosity creep into negotiations
- Meanwhile in Brussels, top negotiators from the EU and Britain met for their third official round of negotiations. But 
as the week progressed the tone among EU officials started sounding increasingly IRRITATED.
- On Monday, before heading into his first meeting the EU's chief negotiator Michel BARNIER said he was 
"concerned." "We must start negotiating seriously," he said pointing to a tight timetable.
- On Tuesday Barnier's boss, Jean-Claude JUNCKER, sounded unimpressed by the position papers put forward by 
the British government in recent weeks. "I did read with the requisite attention all the papers produced by the 
majesty's government and none of those are actually satisfactory," Juncker said.
- At Thursday's closing press conference Barnier did not try very hard to mask his FRUSTRATION with his British 
counterparts. The two sides "did not make any decisive progress," he said.
Barnier warned Britain that, given the STALEMATE on all major issues, discussions on a future trade and economic 
relationship between the EU and Britain were unlikely to go ahead in October as hoped by the British government.
- British Brexit Secretary David DAVIS acknowledged "significant differences to be bridged," especially over a 
financial settlement on what Britain owes the bloc, adding that his government had a duty to its taxpayers to 
interrogate any final financial payment rigorously.
Editorial contactsEditing by: William Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: September 2, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair boss slams May for 'drinking tea and sake' amid Brexit talks
Ryanair boss slams May for 'drinking tea and sake' amid Brexit talks
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 31, 2017 Thursday 11:28 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 236 words
Byline: Bill Smith in London
Dateline: London (dpa) - 
Body
Outspoken Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary on Thursday accused British Prime Minister Theresa May of 
"swanning around Japan drinking tea and sake" instead of handling her country's Brexit negotiations in Europe.
"I fail to see what she's doing in Japan for three days at the moment, why she's not in Brussels or in Frankfurt or in 
Paris, which is where these negotiations need to take place," the head of the Ireland-based budget airline told Sky 
News.
"She's just come back from three weeks' holidays in the Swiss Alps," he told the broadcaster.
"Now, everybody is entitled to their holidays, but there's a crisis coming down the road here in the UK economy in 
the next 12 months.
"Brexit is going to be a disaster for the UK economy, and she needs to be over there negotiating, or at least 
removing these roadblocks, not swanning around Japan drinking tea and sake."
O'Leary said he felt the Brexit negotiations, which are continuing in Brussels this week, were "going nowhere."
"They are a bit of a shambles, and they need a bit of leadership," he said.
"From an aviation perspective, the real challenge for us is, because there's no fallback in aviation - we're not 
covered by WTO rules - there is going to be a cessation of flights from March 2019 if she doesn't get her finger out 
and get a deal done in the next 12 months."

Ryanair chief executive Michael O'Leary on why his airline will not be bidding for any assets belonging to

Load-Date: August 31, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair won't bid for Air Berlin in 'stitch-up' bankruptcy, says CEO
Ryanair won't bid for Air Berlin in 'stitch-up' bankruptcy, says CEO
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 30, 2017 Wednesday 5:48 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 163 words
Byline: Theresa Muench in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
Budget airline Ryanair does not plan to bid for any assets belonging to the insolvent German carrier Air Berlin, chief 
executive Michael O'Leary said on Wednesday.
"We will not get involved in this process: it's a stitch-up," O' Leary said in reference to the charge that the insolvency 
process is designed to help strengthen German airline Lufthansa.
Air Berlin filed for bankruptcy protection earlier this month after its main shareholder, Abu Dhabi-based Etihad 
Airways, withdrew funding in response to years of financial losses.
The German government has provided the company with a temporary credit of 150 million euros (176 million 
dollars) to help it continue operating for around three more months.
German flagship carrier Lufthansa has expressed an interest in buying a large share of assets in the bankrupt 
airline. Air Berlin officials are also in talks with two other interested parties.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Bill Heaney, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 31, 2017
End of Document
F1 great Lauda mulls bid to buy back Air Berlin subsidiary Niki
F1 great Lauda mulls bid to buy back Air Berlin subsidiary Niki
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 26, 2017 Saturday 6:43 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 206 words
Byline: Albert Otti in Vienna
Dateline: Vienna (dpa) - 
Body
Formula One legend Niki Lauda is interested in buying back the Niki airline, which he founded in 2003 and which 
has since become a daughter of insolvent German carrier Air Berlin.
"I have written a letter to Air Berlin's insolvency administrator, in which I express my interest in [Niki]," he said in an 
interview that the Austrian tabloid Kronen Zeitung published online on Saturday.
He said he would like to get the chance to look into Niki's accounts.
"Only afterwards I can decide whether it would make sense to take over Niki again," said Lauda.
The former champion racer, who serves as the Mercedes Formula One team's non-executive chairman, warned 
that Lufthansa should not be allowed to take over Air Berlin as well as Niki.
"Politicians completely forget that we need competition. A Lufthansa monopoly would be catastrophic," he said.
Air Berlin is holding takeover talks with Lufthansa, Easyjet and Ryanair, German Economic Minister Brigitte Zypries 
said Saturday in Berlin.
Lauda founded Niki in 2003. One year later, Air Berlin bought a 24-per-cent stake in his company. The German 
carrier completely took over Niki at the end of 2011.

F1 great Lauda mulls bid to buy back Air Berlin subsidiary Niki

Merkel rules out taxpayers footing the bill for Air Berlin rescue
Merkel rules out taxpayers footing the bill for Air Berlin rescue
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 16, 2017 Wednesday 4:30 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 284 words
Byline: Andrew McCathie in Berlin and Emoke Bebiak in Brussels
Body
Berlin (dpa) - Chancellor Angela Merkel ruled out taxpayers footing the bill for Air Berlin's rescue and said a 
government-backed 150-million-euro (175.5-million-dollar) bridge loan would head off the threat of the insolvent 
airline's collapse.
Berlin was forced to act because bills had to be paid and tickets honoured, Merkel said.
The risk to taxpayers was "relatively small," Merkel said in a YouTube interview on Wednesday.
"Otherwise," she said, "we would not have been permitted to provide this bridging loan."
A Ministry for Economic Affairs spokeswoman said it believed Air Berlin's talks with Lufthansa and other airlines, 
such as EasyJet, that are seeking to carve it up would be completed quickly.
However, Irish low-cost carrier Ryanair said its believed there was a "conspiracy" between Berlin and Lufthansa 
over Air Berlin's future.
Ryanair's comments came after the airline filed complaints with both the German and European competition 
authorities over Air Berlin's insolvency, accusing Berlin of violating anti-monopoly laws by paving the way for 
Lufthansa to take over Air Berlin.
European Commission spokesman Ricardo Cardoso said Wednesday that the commission and Germany were in 
"constructive contact" about the issue.
Merkel said the Federal Government had "very carefully considered" the decision to provide Air Berlin with the 
temporary loan to keep the carrier flying for three months.
Air Berlin's new chief representative Frank Kebekus told dpa he expected the airline's insolvency process to begin 
on November 1.
Merkel rules out taxpayers footing the bill for Air Berlin rescue
Air Berlin is Germany's second-largest airline and employs 7,200 people in the country.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 17, 2017
End of Document
Italy 's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers
Italy's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
August 1, 2017 Tuesday 1:37 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 192 words
Byline: Lena Klimkeit in Rome
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Italy's troubled airline Alitalia on Tuesday got the word out in multiple newspapers and online on Tuesday that it has 
started looking for binding purchase offers from interested buyers.
The airline, which filed for insolvency in May, is soliciting offers from August 7 to September 15, though they would 
be welcome until October 2 at the latest.
Those interested can make an offer either for the entire airline, or only for the air operations or the ground services, 
Alitalia said.
However, the Italian government would give preference to a complete sale offer, according to Ansa news agency.
The deadline for non-binding offers for the airline expired in July.
Low-cost European carrier Ryanair was one of several companies that had expressed an interest and had made a 
non-binding offer for Alitalia's assets, said Ryanair financial head Neil Sorahan in July.
Alitalia has not turned a profit since 2002 and has been on the brink of collapse three times in the past 10 years. 
Privatized in 2008, it has since lost more than 2.5 billion euros (2.95 billion dollars).
Editorial contactsEditing by: Miranda Lee Murray, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: August 2, 2017
Italy 's troubled Alitalia puts call out for binding purchase offers

Ryanair CEO calls Brexit 'greatest economic suicide note in history'
Ryanair CEO calls Brexit 'greatest economic suicide note in history'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 11, 2017 Tuesday 6:03 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 276 words
Byline: Naveena Kottoor in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Michael O'Leary, the chief executive of the low-cost carrier Ryanair, has described Brexit as the "greatest economic 
suicide note in history."
O'Leary and a number of senior airline and aviation executives spoke Tuesday at a hearing in the EU Parliament on 
the impact Brexit could have on the industry.
O'Leary said that there was "a real prospect," of "no flights between Britain and the EU for days, weeks, months," 
should there be no agreement between the two sides.
Britain is set to leave the EU at the end of March 2019.
Airlines executives want both sides to come to an agreement on aviation as soon as possible, since the industry 
tends to sell tickets one year in advance.
Unlike other sectors aviation is not governed by World Trade Organization rules, which could result in the industry 
having to revert to rules dating back to the 1950s, if Britain and the EU fail to come to an agreement, executives 
warned.
O'Leary said that following meetings with British government officials to discuss the issue, he was under the 
impression that the government had "no clue" and that there was a "delusional attitude in London."
He said that one alternative a British government official had presented, should talks with the EU fail, was an 
agreement with Pakistan.
Ryanair CEO calls Brexit 'greatest economic suicide note in history'
"They don't have a bulls notion what they are doing," O'Leary said, adding that he wasn't sure how many Britons 
preferred to spend their summer holidays in Karachi rather than in France, Italy or Spain, the current top 
destinations for British travellers.
Editorial contactsEditing by: , +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;Editing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 
2852 31472, <Lowman.Stephen@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 12, 2017
End of Document
Ryanair CEO calls Brexit 'greatest economic suicide note in history'
Ryanair CEO calls Brexit 'greatest economic suicide note in history'
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
July 11, 2017 Tuesday 6:35 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 426 words
Byline: Naveena Kottoor in Brussels
Dateline: Brussels (dpa) - 
Body
Michael O'Leary, the chief executive of the low-cost European carrier Ryanair, has described Brexit as the "greatest 
economic suicide note in history."
O'Leary and a number of senior airline and aviation executives spoke Tuesday at a hearing in the EU Parliament on 
the impact Brexit could have on the industry.
O'Leary said that there was "a real prospect" of "no flights between Britain and the EU for days, weeks, months," 
should there be no agreement between the two sides.
Britain is set to leave the EU at the end of March 2019.
The executives want both sides to come to an agreement on aviation as soon as possible, since the industry tends 
to sell tickets one year in advance.
Unlike other sectors, aviation is not governed by World Trade Organization rules, which could result in the industry 
having to revert to rules dating back to the 1950s and 1950s, if Britain and the EU fail to come to an agreement, 
executives warned.
Sean Kennedy, who represented Airlines for America, a trade organization of leading carriers, said that without a 
deal, flights between the US and the Britain would come to a halt on day one of Brexit, and warned of "major 
disruption that could wreak havoc on all sides."
He also said that relocating from Britain's Heathrow airport, which is the busiest airport in Europe, was "impossible 
to implement," because of investments worth billions of dollars made by US airlines.
Ryanair CEO calls Brexit 'greatest economic suicide note in history'
Kennedy added that reverting to old rules would mean fewer flights and fewer frequencies, and that transatlantic 
joint ventures between European and US airlines would have to end.
O'Leary said that following meetings with British government officials to discuss the issue, he was under the 
impression that the government had "no clue" and that there was a "delusional attitude in London."
He also said that he was prepared to cancel all flights to and from Britain in 2019, should there be no firm 
agreement by autumn 2018.
The British airport Stansted is currently the largest base for Ryanair in Europe, with Dublin, Milan, Rome, Barcelona 
and Madrid being the top destinations.
He said that one alternative a British government official had presented, should talks with the EU fail, was an 
agreement with Pakistan.
"They don't have a bulls notion what they are doing," O'Leary said, adding that he wasn't sure how many Britons 
preferred to spend their summer holidays in Karachi rather than in France, Italy or Spain, the current top 
destinations for British travellers.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Stephen Lowman, +49 30 285231472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: July 12, 2017
End of Document

dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for MAY 29-JUNE 4, 2017
LUXEMBOURG: Eurostat releases unemployment data for April 2017.
MADRID: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi meets with Spanish President Mariano Rajoy.
BRUSSELS: EU Commission presents reform ideas for the Eurozone.
VIENNA: Initial inquiries into Austrian Eurofighter deal begin, after Austria accused Airbus and Eurofighter of 
misleading the Defence Ministry.
TOKYO: Japanese industrial production data released for April.
BEIJING: China's National Bureau of Statistics releases Purchasing Managers Index for May 2017.
MELBOURNE: Class-action lawsuit against Australian government by refugees held on Manus Island set to begin.
WIESBADEN, GERMANY: Monthly retail figures for Germany released for previous month.
BERLIN: Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders presents his new book "Our Revolution" at Berlin's Freie Universitaet 
university.
WASHINGTON: Organization of American States discusses Venezuela crisis.
DRESDEN, GERMANY: Hearing scheduled in "Gruppe Freital" far-right terrorism trial.
WELLINGTON: State visit by Australian Governor-General Sir Peter Cosgrove to New Zealand (until June 3).
DALLAS, TEXAS: ExxonMobil holds annual general meeting.
BRUSSELS: EU Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) releases annual report for 2016.
INTERNATIONAL: World No Tobacco Day.
INTERNATIONAL: World MS Day.
BARCELONA: Music festival Primavera Sound takes place (until June 4).
__________________________________________________
THURSDAY, JUNE 1
BRUSSELS: EU-China Summit takes place with China represented by Prime Minister Li Keqiang (until June 2).
ST PETERSBURG: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi visits Russia for bilateral talks with Russian President 
Vladimir Putin.
KARLSRUHE, GERMANY: Expected verdict in copyright proceedings over two-second Kraftwerk beat.
KOUROU: Expected launch of an Ariane-Rocket at the European Spaceport.
LONDON: Start of the Sundance Film Festival (until June 4).
HELSINKI: Finland celebrates 100 years of independence.
NAIROBI: Kenya celebrates its independence with Madaraka Day.
LONDON: International think tank Institute for Economics and Peace (IEP) presents its "Global Peace Index" report.
WASHINGTON: Presidential waiver on law requiring the US embassy to relocate from Tel Aviv to Jerusalem is set 
to expire.
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for MAY 29-JUNE 4, 2017
MUNICH: Verdict expected in multimillion-euro lawsuit against German record company Arista Music by Elvis 
Presley Enterprises.
WASHINGTON: LGBT Pride month in the US (until June 30).
LONDON: 50 years since the Beatles album "Sgt. Pepper's Lonely Hearts Club Band" was released.
ST PETERSBURG: St Petersburg International Economic Forum takes place, with President Vladimir Putin 
expected to attend (until June 3).
OXFORD, BRITAIN: "Raphael: The Drawings" exhibition opens at the Ashmolean Museum of Art and Archeology 
(until September 3, 2017).
LUXEMBOURG: European Court of Justice rules on Austrian environmental protection case after fisherman 
complained about hydroelectric power plant.
NEW YORK: Bolivia takes over rotating UN Security Council presidency for June.
SYDNEY: Red Cross chief for Papua New Guinea briefs journalists on political situation ahead of June/July 
elections there.
BRUSSELS: Brussels Economic Forum takes place.
BERLIN: European Biomethane Conference takes place with focus on renewable energy.
LOS ANGELES: 80th birthday of US actor Morgan Freeman.
LONDON: 70th birthday of Rolling Stones guitarist Ronnie Wood.
LONDON: 70th birthday of British actor Jonathan Pryce.
INTERNATIONAL: Global Day of Parents.
__________________________________________________
FRIDAY, JUNE 2
BAIKONUR, KAZAKHSTAN: French astronaut Thomas Pesquet returns to Earth after spending 6 months on the 
International Space Station.
BRITAIN: Prime Minister Theresa May and opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn appear on panel show 
Question Time in election campaign special.
UN: UN Security Council elects five new members for 2018 and 2019 terms.
WASHINGTON: Labour Department releases report on employment situation for May, including unemployment rate 
and payroll data.
WOLFSBURG, GERMANY: Bill Murray performs in premiere of "New Worlds" tour with chamber musicians.
DUBLIN: Deadline for Ireland's ruling Fine Gael party to choose new leader.
PHNOM PENH: Cambodian Prime Minister Hun Sen to participate in election parade.
BERLIN: Albanian President Bujar Nishani visits Germany.
BERLIN: The international Y20 youth conferences brings together young leaders from the G20 countries (until June 
6).
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for MAY 29-JUNE 4, 2017
SINGAPORE: The Asia Security Summit, the IISS Shangri-La Dialogue 2017, takes place (until June 4).
NEW YORK: First exhibition in the US by French author Michel Houellebecq (until August 4).
LONDON: "Gay UK: Love, Law and Liberty" opens at British Museum (until September 19).
BERLIN: 50th anniversary of shooting of German student protester Benno Ohnesorg by police officer Karl-Heinz 
Kurras.
* INTERNATIONAL: International Sex Workers' Day, historically used to highlight poor working conditions.
__________________________________________________
SATURDAY JUNE 3
VALLETTA: Malta goes to the polls in general elections.
PARIS: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi to hold talks with French President Emmanuel Macron.
RIGA: Communal elections takes place in Latvia.
* LJUBLJANA: The presidents of the Balkan states meet at Slovenia's Brdo Castle.
CARDIFF: Champions League final, Juventus v Real Madrid.
WASHINGTON: First anniversary of the death of US boxer Muhammad Ali.
__________________________________________________
SUNDAY, JUNE 4
PHNOM PENH: Communal elections in Cambodia.
ZAGREB: Second round of municipal elections in Croatia.
DRESDEN, GERMANY: Bill Murray performs at Dresden Music Festival as part of "New Worlds" tour with chamber 
musicians.
CANCUN, MEXICO: International Air Transport Association holds annual meeting (until June 6).
NEW YORK: World Ocean Festival.
INTERNATIONAL: International Day of Innocent Children Victims of Aggression.
Load-Date: May 30, 2017
End of Document
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for MAY 29-JUNE 4, 2017
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for MAY 29-JUNE 4, 2017
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
May 29, 2017 Monday 4:00 AM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 1517 words
Byline: Rachel More, +61 2 9322 8065, <, international@dpa.com, ;
Body
All times GMT. If you have any questions about the weekly planner please call or email the dpa desks. Berlin (Mon-
Sun 0600-2100) Tel: +49 30 285231472 Sydney (Mon-Sun 2000-0700) Tel: +61 2 9322 8064 Email: 
international@dpa.com
MONDAY, MAY 29
PARIS: French President Emmanuel Macron to meet Russian President Vladimir Putin.
BRITAIN: Prime Minister Theresa May and opposition Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn face televised interview ahead 
of election.
BERLIN: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi travels to Germany to meet Chancellor Angela Merkel (until May 30).
WASHINGTON: 100th anniversary of birthday of assassinated president John F Kennedy.
WASHINGTON: Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc leaves for US visit (until May 31).
QUEBEC: Student suspect in Quebec mosque attack due in court.
WELLINGTON: Formal welcome for sacred Maori remains returned to New Zealand's Museum Te Papa from the 
Karolinska Institutet in Sweden.
ISTANBUL: Verdict expected in trial of two brothers accused of murdering their sister in so-called honour killing.
EVEREST: Tenzing-Hillary Everest marathon, the world's highest marathon, kicks off (until May 30).
BERGEN, NORWAY: Nordic prime ministers hold an informal meeting with terrorism on the agenda (until May 30).
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for MAY 29-JUNE 4, 2017
ARLINGTON, VIRGINIA: US observes Memorial Day in honour of soldiers who died in service.
ISTANBUL: Istanbul Music Festival begins (until June 21).
STOCKHOLM: German author and illustrator Wolf Erlbruch to accept the Astrid Lindgren Memorial Award for 
literature for children.
CANCUN, MEXICO: World Water Congress takes place (until June 3).
UN: International Day of UN Peacekeepers.
BRUSSELS: EU Green Week takes place (until June 2).
BRUSSELS: EU Competitiveness Council meets (until May 30).
BERLIN: Think20 Summit takes place, bringing together research institutes and think tanks from the G20 countries 
(until May 30).
__________________________________________________
TUESDAY, MAY 30
KUALA LUMPUR: Indonesian and Vietnamese women charged with the killing of Kim Jong Nam to appear at 
magistrate's court, with judge expected to transfer case to high court.
TOKYO: Japanese unemployment rate data released for April.
MUNICH: Hearing scheduled in NSU far-right terrorism trial.
DRESDEN, GERMANY: Hearing scheduled in "Gruppe Freital" far-right terrorism trial.
MOSCOW: Bolshoi Theatre hosts gala-concert to present the choreography and dance awards Prix Benois de la 
Danse.
STUTTGART: German holding company Porsche SE conducts annual general meeting.
BRUSSELS: EU ministers meet to discuss research and space.
BERLIN: "Baywatch" to hit European cinemas.
DUBLIN: RyanAir to release annual results.
BRUSSELS: European Commission likely to propose legislation on volunteer work.
CHINA: Dragon Boat Festival
INTERNATIONAL: Jewish festival of Shavuot is observed (until June 1).
LAAGE, GERMANY: Representatives of all OSCE member states to visit German military airfield.
BERLIN: German Federal Minister for Economic Cooperation and Development Gerd Muller holds panel discussion 
on development in Africa.
__________________________________________________
WEDNESDAY, MAY 31
WASHINGTON: Vietnamese Prime Minister Nguyen Xuan Phuc meets US President Donald Trump at the White 
House.
dpa WEEKLY PLANNER for MAY 29-JUNE 4, 2017
LUXEMBOURG: Eurostat releases flash estimate of Eurozone inflation rate for May 2017.
LUXEMBOURG: Eurostat releases unemployment data for April 2017.
MADRID: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi meets with Spanish President Mariano Rajoy.
BRUSSELS: EU Commission presents reform ideas for the Eurozone.
VIENNA: Initial inquiries into Austrian Eurofighter deal begin, after Austria accused Airbus and Eurofighter of 
misleading the Defence Ministry.

BEIJING: China's National Bureau of Statistics releases Purchasing Managers Index for May 2017.

WIESBADEN, GERMANY: Monthly retail figures for Germany released for previous month.

university.
WASHINGTON: Organization of American States discusses Venezuela crisis.

WELLINGTON: State visit by Australian Governor-General Sir Peter Cosgrove to New Zealand (until June 3).
DALLAS, TEXAS: ExxonMobil holds annual general meeting.
BRUSSELS: EU Anti-Fraud Office (OLAF) releases annual report for 2016.
INTERNATIONAL: World No Tobacco Day.
INTERNATIONAL: World MS Day.
BARCELONA: Music festival Primavera Sound takes place (until June 4).
__________________________________________________
THURSDAY, JUNE 1
BRUSSELS: EU-China Summit takes place with China represented by Prime Minister Li Keqiang (until June 2).
ST PETERSBURG: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi visits Russia for bilateral talks with Russian President 
Vladimir Putin.
KARLSRUHE, GERMANY: Expected verdict in copyright proceedings over two-second Kraftwerk beat.
KOUROU: Expected launch of an Ariane-Rocket at the European Spaceport.
LONDON: Start of the Sundance Film Festival (until June 4).
HELSINKI: Finland celebrates 100 years of independence.
NAIROBI: Kenya celebrates its independence with Madaraka Day.
LONDON: International think tank Institute for Economics and Peace (IEP) presents its "Global Peace Index" report.

to expire.

Italy minister: Alitalia to be sold to best bidder, Lufthansa welcome
Italy minister: Alitalia to be sold to best bidder, Lufthansa welcome
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
April 26, 2017 Wednesday 7:11 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 570 words
Byline: Alvise Armellini in Rome
Dateline: Rome (dpa) - 
Body
Alitalia will be sold to the highest bidder and Germany's Lufthansa is welcome to make an offer for it, Transport 
Minister Graziano Delrio said Wednesday, ruling out a government bailout for Italy's near-bankrupt airline.
Alitalia is in trouble since employees rejected in a referendum a rescue plan based on job and wage cuts. 
Shareholders were due to start proceedings for the company to be put under receivership on Thursday, but the 
meeting has been moved to May 2, a spokesman said.
"The company will be sold to the best bidder," Delrio told the La Stampa newspaper. "Some believed that there 
would have been yet another public rescue. I will say it clearly: there will not be one," he added.
Prime Minister Paolo Gentiloni, speaking in the southern city of Benevento, confirmed "there is no room for a 
nationalization," but said the government would strive to not break up the company, even though workers' rejection 
of the rescue plan "makes [it] harder."
Asked about the possibility of Lufthansa, Europe's largest airline, taking over Alitalia, Delrio said: "There are no 
obstacles [to it], but it is up to shareholders to take decisions. The ball is in their court."
Italian press reports have repeatedly speculated about a Lufthansa takeover, but the German firm has not 
expressed any interest in public. Alitalia's biggest shareholder is currently United Arab Emirates' Etihad, with a 49-
per-cent stake.
Alitalia's main problem is a loss of business on domestic flights - its former core market - to low-cost airlines like 
Ryanair and high-speed train services, while failing to make significant inroads in more lucrative long-haul routes.
Italy minister: Alitalia to be sold to best bidder, Lufthansa welcome
"Clearly, it had inept managers," Antonio Piras of the Fit-Cisl, one of the unions who signed the failed rescue plan, 
said at a briefing at the Foreign Press Association. "There were many wrong choices over the years, and now we 
are paying the consequences," he noted.
According to Piras, the government is facing a dilemma as both rescuing Alitalia at taxpayer expense and letting it 
go bankrupt with large-scale job losses could cost the ruling Democratic Party votes ahead of elections due by early 
2018.
The trade unionist acknowledged that any possible buyer would be best advised to wait until the company's 
"collapse," to then pick up its customers and assets "spending nothing, or almost nothing. That would be the best 
strategy for them."
In another interview with Il Messaggero newspaper, Industry Minister Carlo Calenda, who brokered negotiations on 
the rejected rescue plan, said the government would only be prepared to offer Alitalia a six-month bridging loan.
Italy's former flag carrier employs about 12,500 people and has not turned a profit since 2002. It was privatized in 
2008, and according to a Mediobanca study, it cost the taxpayer 7.4 billion euros (8 billion dollars) during 1974-
2014 to keep the company afloat.
When Etihad became the leading player in Alitalia in 2014, with Italian banks UniCredit and Intesa Sanpaolo as 
junior partners, the aim was to return the company to profit by 2017. Last year, it lost an estimated 400 million 
euros.
The plan rejected by workers foresaw a 2-billion-euro recapitalization in return for nearly 1,600 job losses and an 
average 8-per-cent pay cut for the remaining workforce. The package was rejected with 67 per cent voting against.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Rachel More, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: April 27, 2017
End of Document
Berlin airport strikes extended until early Wednesday
Berlin airport strikes extended until early Wednesday
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
March 13, 2017 Monday 12:19 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 337 words
Byline: Marion van der Kraats and Gioia Forster in Berlin
Dateline: Berlin (dpa) - 
Body
A strike by ground crew workers at Berlin's two commercial airports has been extended until early Wednesday, the 
Verdi union announced.
The initial strike over pay by around 2,000 workers had been called until early Tuesday.
The walkout began at 4 am (0300 GMT) on Monday and affects both of the German capital's airports - Schoenefeld 
in the south-east and Tegel in the north-west.
It will now last until around 5 am (0400 GMT) on Wednesday.
At Tegel, 465 flights are expected to stay grounded on Monday while at Schoenefeld, 195 flights are due to be 
cancelled, a spokesman for the two airports said.
"We are asking all passengers to check with their airline about the status of their flight before they start their trip," a 
statement on a website for the airports said.
Passengers due to land in Berlin have also been affected.
Airlines are re-routing some flights to the eastern German cities of Dresden and Leipzig, with Easyjet landing at the 
former and Ryanair the latter. Passengers are then being bussed to Berlin, two hours away.
Berlin's mayor Michael Mueller, who was due to make a three-day trip to Moscow, also had his journey interrupted. 
A replacement flight for the mayor was organized from Dresden airport.
An earlier strike on Friday caused hundreds of flight cancellations in Berlin.
Berlin airport strikes extended until early Wednesday
"The Verdi strikes mean our capital Berlin has been completely cut off to air travel for days. Not only are the airports 
being damaged but also the image of Germany," said airport association chief Ralph Beisel.
Trade union Verdi is pushing for a pay increase and better working hours for its members, arguing that their 
workload is increasing given the growing number of passengers at Berlin's ageing airports and a greater focus on 
security.
Strike leader Enrico Ruemker said he was waiting for a new offer from management.
A new combined airport for Berlin near Schoenefeld is expected to open in 2019 after years of delays and 
wrangling.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Mark Meadows Tel: +49 30 2852-31472; <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: March 14, 2017

Final ruling nears on Air Berlin, Ryanair defunct route row
Final ruling nears on Air Berlin, Ryanair defunct route row
dpa international (Englischer Dienst)
February 9, 2017 Thursday 5:06 PM GMT
Copyright 2017 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 224 words
Byline:  Anja Semmelroch in Karlsruhe
Dateline: Karlsruhe, Germany (dpa) - 
Body
A decade-long dispute between air carriers Ryanair and Air Berlin could come to an end soon - but still too late - 
after a German court on Thursday referred the case to another court for a final decision.
Air Berlin has been fighting for years to get the German city of Luebeck to disclose alleged advantages given to its 
competitor, Irish low-cost airline Ryanair, in the hope that Ryanair would then have to pay back the money.
Since Air Berlin originally brought the case against Ryanair years ago, the business environment has changed, with 
the Irish carrier stopping its flights to and from Luebeck.
After the airport - code LBC - declared bankruptcy twice, scheduled passenger flights are no longer conducted at all 
in the northern German city.
Germany's Federal Court of Justice pushed the ruling on to a state court in Kiel on Thursday, following a decision 
made by the European Commission this week on a state aid case from 2007 that is relevant for the Luebeck case.
The commission in Brussels said on Tuesday that certain agreements with Ryanair do not constitute state aid.
The case had been pushed around between German courts and the Court of Justice of the European Union in 
Luxembourg, while the judicial bodies were waiting on the Brussels decision.
Editorial contactsEditing by: Shane Strowmatt, +49 30 2852 31472, <international@dpa.com;
Load-Date: February 10, 2017
Final ruling nears on Air Berlin, Ryanair defunct route row
End of Document
NEWS FEATURE
NEWS FEATURE
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
November 29, 2016 Tuesday 1:28 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 706 words
Body
DPA FINANCE Germany labour Lufthansa  NEWS FEATURE   
Lufthansa's business image at stake in showdown with pilots
By Andrew McCathie, dpa   =
  
The stakes are high for Lufthansa as it continues its long-running
battle with pilots to make the savings it says are necessary to meet
the challenges posed by new airline rivals. Will its image survive
what seem to be never-ending rounds of labour stoppages?
  
Frankfurt (dpa) - Lufthansa's shares faced a turbulent trading
session on Tuesday amid the long-running industrial dispute between
the German airline and its pilots. It's a dangerous game which
threatens damage to the carrier's business image.
  
Germany's biggest airline has been forced to ground more than 1,700
flights scheduled for Tuesday and Wednesday after its pilots walked
off the job at midnight Tuesday(2300 GMT Monday) in a pay battle with
the airline that dates back to April 2014.
  
The airline had just endured a days-long labour stoppage last week,
part of the same fight.
  
Lufthansa estimates the cost of the new industrial action at up to 10
million euros (10.6 million dollars) a day, with both sides hardening
their positions as the pilots' union Vereinigung Cockpit threatens to
extend the strike beyond Wednesday.
  
"The conflict is only superficially about numbers," said aviation
analyst Heinrich Grossbongardt. "At its core remains [the airline's]
corporate strategy.
  
"The era of the flag-carrier, such as Lufthansa, is coming to an end
and giving way to one of fierce competition with the low-cost
airlines, which, of course, is linked to cuts in social services for
employees," said Grossbongardt.
  
NEWS FEATURE
Lufthansa is battling to cut costs and restructure its operations in
the face of competition from budget rivals such as Ryanair and
EasyJet in Europe and Middle Eastern airlines including Emirates and
Etihad on long-haul routes.
  
Two-and-a-half years ago, Lufthansa chief Carsten Spohr promised to
ease the industrial tensions between the airline and its pilots.
  
But the strikes set for Tuesday and Wednesday have thrown the travel
plans of about 180,000 passengers into chaos. Lufthansa have now been
hit by 15 pilot walkouts in the last two years.
  
This has raised questions about what impact the strikes eventually
could have on the airline's customer base and business image.
  
Lufthansa's shares were down by nearly 2 per cent at one stage during
Tuesday trading on the Frankfurt Stock Market, before they bounced
back up 0.93 per cent later in the trading session.
  
The airline reported earlier this year that its adjusted earnings
before interest and tax jumped 55 per cent to a record 1.82 billion
euros in 2015 thanks to low fuel costs.
  
But now, the new round of strikes comes as part of the build-up to
the crucial Christmas travel period, with Lufthansa's 5,400 pilots
demanding a backdated 22-per-cent wage hike over five years until
April 2017.
  
A Munich labour court on Monday rejected Lufthansa's call for an
injunction to stop this week's planned industrial action.
  
That came after a court in Frankfurt last week rejected a similar
request by Lufthansa for an injunction to stop a four-day pilots'
strike, which ended Sunday.
  
Last week's industrial action resulted in the cancellation of 2,700
flights and left 350,000 passengers scrambling to make alternative
travel arrangements.
  
The new industrial action has been sparked by a breakdown in talks
between Lufthansa and the pilots, with Vereinigung Cockpit rejecting
the management's new offer of a 4.4-per-cent salary increase and a
one-time payout equivalent to 1.8 months' salary.
  
"There is still no offer from Lufthansa on which to negotiate for the
remuneration of the pilots, which means that the industrial campaign
has to be continued," Joerg Handwerg of Vereinigung Cockpit's
executive committee said.
  
"Both parties are of the opinion that they are the stronger," Hagen
Lesch from the Institute of the German Economy told dpa.
  
"As long as everyone believes that 'we can beat the others,' we
cannot expect a compromise," Lesch said.
  
Lufthansa's budget airline operations Eurowings and Germanwings, as
well as other carriers in the group - SWISS, Austrian Airlines, Air
Dolomiti und Brussels Airlines - have not been affected by the
pilots' strike.
  
  
  
NEWS FEATURE
  
  Nov 2916 1328 GMT  
Load-Date: November 30, 2016
End of Document
Ryanair reports 7-per-cent rise in half-year profit
Ryanair reports 7-per-cent rise in half-year profit
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
November 7, 2016 Monday 10:58 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 161 words
Dateline: London 
Body
DPA FINANCE business Ireland aviation Ryanair  Ryanair reports 7-per-cent rise in half-year profit London   
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, on Monday
said its profit rose 7 per cent to 1.17 billion euros (1.29 billion
dollars) in the first six months of its financial year, despite a
10-per-cent fall in its average fare to 50 euros.
  
The airline said it also cut costs per seat by 10 per cent
year-on-year and opened 73 new routes as it carried some 65
passengers from April to September, up 12 per cent.
  
Ryanair owner Michael O'Leary said the half-yearly results showed "a
creditable performance in difficult market conditions," citing
problems including strikes by air traffic control staff, the effect
of terrorist attacks, and a plunge in the pound since Britain's
Brexit vote in June.
  
Ryanair warned last month that it expects its annual net profit to
fall by up to 125 million euros, mainly due to the fall in the
British currency.
  
  
  
  
  Nov 0716 1058 GMT  
Load-Date: November 10, 2016

Deutsche Presse-Agentur
November 2, 2016 Wednesday 12:04 PM EST

Length: 167 words
Body
DPA FINANCE Germany business Ryanair Lufthansa  1ST LEAD   
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa
By Andrew McCathie, dpa   =
  
Berlin (dpa) - Europe's biggest low-cost airline Ryanair is take on
Lufthansa on its home turf by beginning to fly out of Frankfurt
airport, the German national carrier's main hub.
  
Frankfurt airport operator Fraport and Ryanair announced on Wednesday
that the Irish airline will use Germany's biggest airport to fly from
March 2017 to holiday destinations such as Spain's Mallorca, Alicante
and Malaga, as well as Faro in Portugal.
  
Ryanair is currently planning to operate two aircraft out of
Frankfurt with four departures each day generating about 400,000
passengers a year
  
But the budget airline is already planning an expansion of the number
of destinations it flies to and from Frankfurt by the end of the
year.
  
"We hope that we will be able to offer a significantly bigger flight
plan from winter," said Ryanair spokesman Kenny Jacobs.
  
  
  
  
  Nov 0216 1204 GMT  
Load-Date: November 3, 2016

DPA FINANCE Germany business Ryanair Lufthansa  REFILE   
1ST LEAD
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa
By Andrew McCathie, dpa   =
  
Berlin (dpa) - Europe's biggest low-cost airline Ryanair is to take
on Lufthansa on its home turf by beginning to fly out of Frankfurt
airport, the German national carrier's main hub.
  
Frankfurt airport operator Fraport and Ryanair announced on Wednesday
that the Irish airline will use Germany's biggest airport to fly from
March 2017 to holiday destinations such as Spain's Mallorca, Alicante
and Malaga, as well as Faro in Portugal.
  
Ryanair is currently planning to operate two aircraft out of
Frankfurt with four departures each day generating about 400,000
passengers a year
  
But the budget airline is already planning an expansion of the number
of destinations it flies to and from Frankfurt by the end of the
year.
  
"We hope that we will be able to offer a significantly bigger flight
plan from winter," said Ryanair spokesman Kenny Jacobs.

Ryanair to step up battle with Germany 's Lufthansa
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
November 2, 2016 Wednesday 10:35 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 189 words
Dateline: Berlin 
Body
DPA FINANCE Germany business Ryanair Lufthansa  Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa Berlin   
Irish low-cost airline Ryanair is take on Lufthansa on
its home turf by beginning to fly out of Frankfurt airport, the
German national carrier's main hub.
  
Frankfurt airport operator Fraport and Ryanair are expected to
announced at a press conference on Wednesday that the budget airline
will use Germany's biggest airport to at least initially fly to
Spanish holiday destinations such as Mallorca.
  
  
The Frankfurt-Mallorca route is already served by Lufthansa along
with German airlines Air Berlin, Condor, SunExpress and Tuifly during
the peak summer holiday season.
  
  
Up until now Ryanair, like other low-cost airlines, has tended to
avoid the Frankfurt hub because of the higher airport fees as well as
the longer turnaround times for the aircraft on the ground at the
airport.
  
  
But, according to the daily Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, Ryanair
will receive a new customer discount from Fraport, and the budget
airline will announce a 35-minute turnaround time between landing and
departure at Frankfurt.
  
  
  
  
  Nov 0216 1035 GMT  
Load-Date: November 3, 2016
Ryanair to step up battle with Germany 's Lufthansa

Ryanair to step up battle with Germany's Lufthansa   =
  
Berlin (dpa) - Irish low-cost airline Ryanair is to take on Lufthansa
on its home turf by beginning to fly out of Frankfurt airport, the
German national carrier's main hub.

announced at a press conference on Wednesday that the budget airline
will use Germany's biggest airport to at least initially fly to
Spanish holiday destinations such as Mallorca.

with German airlines Air Berlin, Condor, SunExpress and Tuifly during
the peak summer holiday season.
  
  
Up until now Ryanair, like other low-cost airlines, has tended to
avoid the Frankfurt hub because of the higher airport fees as well as
the longer turnaround times for the aircraft on the ground at the
airport.

will receive a new customer discount from Fraport, and the budget
airline will announce a 35-minute turnaround time between landing and

Ryanair cuts profit forecast amid plunging pound
Ryanair cuts profit forecast amid plunging pound
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
October 18, 2016 Tuesday 10:46 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 250 words
Dateline: London 
Body
DPA FINANCE Ireland business Ryanair  Ryanair cuts profit forecast amid plunging pound London   
Ryanair, Europe's largest low-cost airline, on Tuesday
warned that it expects its annual net profit to fall by up to 125
million euros (138 million dollars), mainly due to a plunge in the
pound since Britain's Brexit vote.
  
The airline said it expects net profit of 1.3 billion to 1.35 billion
euros, down 5 per cent from a previous forecast of 1.375 billion to
1.425 billion euros, after the pound lost about 18 per cent of its
value against the dollar since the Brexit referendum on June 23.
  
The fall in the British currency will reduce Ryanair's average fares
by up to 15 per cent in the second half of this year, it said.
  
"While higher load factors, stronger traffic growth and better cost
control will help to ameliorate these weaker revenues, it is prudent
now to adjust full-year guidance, which will rise by approx 7 per
cent rather than our original guidance of 12 per cent," Ryanair owner
Michael O'Leary said in a statement.
  
"This decline is primarily due to the impact of weaker sterling on
our H2 fares," O'Leary said, adding that the new forecast "remains
heavily dependent upon no further weakness in sterling from its
current levels."
  
Budget airline easyJet issued a similar warning earlier this month,
saying its annual profit is likely to suffer a 90-million-pound hit
from the plunging pound and further impact from a fall in passenger
numbers caused by security fears.
  
  
  
  
  Oct 1816 1046 GMT  
Ryanair cuts profit forecast amid plunging pound
Load-Date: October 19, 2016
End of Document
Hundreds of flights cancelled amid French air traffic control strike
Hundreds of flights cancelled amid French air traffic control strike
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
September 15, 2016 Thursday 4:10 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 240 words
Dateline: Paris 
Body
DPA FINANCE France labour aviation  Hundreds of flights cancelled amid French air traffic control strike 
Paris   
European airlines say hundreds of flights were delayed
or cancelled on Thursday due to a strike by air traffic controllers
in France.
  
Airlines Easyjet, Ryanair, British Airways and Aer Lingus each
reported numerous flights cancelled due to the strike, which was set
to impact thousands of passengers.
  
More than 300 flights were estimated to be cancelled, as airlines in
Europe reduced their offering by 15 per cent, according to lobby
group Airlines for Europe (A4E).
  
The strike, which is expected to last for 35 hours, is the latest of
several walk-outs this year by French air traffic controllers in
protest at France's controversial labour reforms passed in July in an
effort to jumpstart the country's flagging economy.
  
The labour action drew criticism from A4E lobbyists representing
several airlines affected by the strike.
  
"The demands of increasingly mobile European citizens and businesses
cannot be taken hostage by localized industrial action. It is about
time to minimize the impact of these strike actions," A4E chief
Thomas Reynaert said, also criticizing a lack in measures from
European authorities to prevent such strikes.
  
Europe has already seen several strikes this year by air traffic
controllers in Italy, Belgium, Greece and France, leading to
thousands of cancelled and delayed flights.
  
  
  
Hundreds of flights cancelled amid French air traffic control strike
  
  Sep 1516 1610 GMT  
Load-Date: September 16, 2016
End of Document

German fraud investigators raid Ryanair pilot rooms at six airports
German fraud investigators raid Ryanair pilot rooms at six airports
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
July 6, 2016 Wednesday 1:16 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 145 words
Dateline: Koblenz, Germany 
Body
DPA FINANCE Germany justice aviation  German fraud investigators raid Ryanair pilot rooms at six airports 
Koblenz, Germany   
Raids have been carried out on the rooms of
Ryanair pilots at six German airports as part of a tax and social
insurance investigation, a senior public prosecutor confirmed to dpa
on Wednesday.
  
The Irish budget airline's partner companies are suspected of
indulging in fraud relating to tax and social insurance payments,
said Hans Peter Gandner, senior prosecutor for the city of Koblenz.
  
Several dozen officers carried out the raids on Tuesday at Berlin's
Schoenefeld airport, as well as at the airports in Cologne, Weeze in
North Rhine-Westphalia, Frankfurt-Hahn, Bremen and Baden-Baden.
  
The raids resulted from an investigation dating back years into two
British temporary employment agencies that supply pilots to Ryanair.

Ryanair 's strong passenger growth spurs 43-per-cent jump in profit
Ryanair's strong passenger growth spurs 43-per-cent jump in profit
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
May 23, 2016 Monday 9:10 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 188 words
Dateline: London 
Body
DPA FINANCE Ireland business Ryanair  Ryanair's strong passenger growth spurs 43-per-cent jump in profit 
London   
Strong passenger growth, fuller planes and low fuel
costs helped Europe's largest low-cost airline, Ryanair, record a
43-per-cent jump in its annual profit, the airline said on Monday.
  
Ryanair promised to cut passenger fares this year after its post-tax
profit soared to 1.24 billion euros (1.39 billion dollars) in the
financial year to March 31, spurred by rises of 18 per cent in
passengers and 16 per cent in revenue.
  
The airline had "delivered significant traffic and profit growth in
all four quarters," Ryanair owner Michael O'Leary said, adding that
it had attracted "millions of new customers."
  
Ryanair said it flights operated at an average of 93 per cent of
capacity and should remain at a similar level this year, while
passenger numbers are expected to grow by another 9 per cent to 116
million in its new financial year.
  
It expects to reduce average fares by about 7 per cent this year and
forecasts a 13-per-cent rise in net profit to between 1.38 billion
and 1.43 billion euros.
  
  
  
  
  May 2316 0910 GMT

Brexit campaigners object to Ryanair «Fly home to vote Remain» sale
Brexit campaigners object to Ryanair «Fly home to vote Remain» sale
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
May 20, 2016 Friday 1:26 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: POLITICS
Length: 368 words
Dateline: London 
Body
DPA POLITICS Britain politics EU Ryanair  Brexit campaigners object to Ryanair «Fly home to vote Remain» 
sale London   
Campaigners for Britain to leave the European Union
complained to police on Friday that Ryanair has broken election law
through its "Fly home to vote Remain" ticket promotion ahead of a
referendum on June 23.
  
The airline, whose owner Michael O'Leary wants Britain to remain in
the EU, offered British citizens one-way flights home for 19.99
pounds (29 dollars) on June 22 and June 23 for bookings made by
midnight Thursday.
  
"By its discount on flights on the day before, and the day of the
referendum, Ryanair is paying the expense, in part, of provision to
voters in order to influence them to vote in the referendum," Dominic
Cummings, campaign director for Vote Leave, said in a letter of
complaint to London's Metropolitan Police.
  
"This appears to be corrupt, since the company is offering discounts
on the commercial rate to customers with the sole aim of ensuring
that they vote and vote to remain in the European Union," Cummings
said.
  
The Metropolitan Police confirmed it had received the complaint and
would examine it to determine whether any offence had been committed.
  
  
Reacting to the complaint, O'Leary extended the promotion for an
extra 24 hours and said it "fully complies with Ryanair's policy of
lowering the cost of air travel" to and from Britain.
  
"The Leave campaign must be getting really desperate if they're
objecting to low-fare air travel for British citizens, so we're
pleased to extend our 'Fly home to vote Remain' sale by another 24
Brexit campaigners object to Ryanair «Fly home to vote Remain» sale
hours," he said in a Ryanair statement.
  
"As the UK's largest airline, Ryanair is absolutely clear that the UK
economy and its growth prospects are stronger as a member of the
European Union and the single market than they are outside the EU,"
O'Leary said.
  
British election law includes an offence of "treating," making it
illegal for someone to "directly or indirectly give or provide any
food, drink, entertainment or provision to corruptly influence any
voter to vote or refrain from voting."
  
Cummings said Vote Leave believes the Ryanair offer counts as
treating and could also contravene British law on bribery.
  
  
  
  
  May 2016 1326 GMT  
Load-Date: May 21, 2016
End of Document
European stock indexes down amid terrorism, travel fears
European stock indexes down amid terrorism, travel fears
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
March 22, 2016 Tuesday 9:33 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 154 words
Dateline: Berlin 
Body
DPA FINANCE Belgium terrorism markets  European stock indexes down amid terrorism, travel fears Berlin   
Major European stock indexes fell in early Tuesday
trading after reports of two explosions at the main airport in
Brussels that left at least a dozen dead and many others injured.
  
Germany's DAX slipped by 1.75 per cent to 9,775 points, followed by a
slight recovery, with shares in travel-related companies seeing the
biggest falls following the news from Brussels.
  
Britain's FTSE 100 was down nearly 47 points, or 0.8 per cent, at
6,138 points. Euronext 100, the blue chip index for the pan-European
Euronext exchange, fell by almost 1.2 per cent to 861 points.
  
"Once again terrorism has us firmly in its grip," said Robert Halver,
a capital markets analyst at Baader Bank.
  
Shares in airlines Ryanair, Lufthansa, easyjet and Air France were
down between 2.3 and 3.6 per cent in Tuesday trading.

SIDEBAR
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
March 21, 2016 Monday 1:00 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Length: 385 words
Body
DPA x France accident Germany  SIDEBAR   
Germanwings brand name set to slowly disappear   =
  
Berlin (dpa) - Last year's devastating crash of Germanwings flight 4U
9525 resulted in Lufthansa accelerating plans for the Germanwings
brand to be integrated into the airline group's new budget airline,
Eurowings.
  
By October last year, Eurowings had taken over over 55 Germanwings
routes as part of its efforts to transform Eurowings into Europe
third-biggest low-cost carrier.
  
Lufthansa plans to add several more Germanwings routes next month to
Eurowings, which already handles all Germanwings sales.
  
However, Lufthansa's move to create a new budget carrier to compete
with the likes of Britain's Ryanair and Ireland's EasyJet has been
fraught with problems for the Cologne-based airline group.
  
Three years ago, Lufthansa decided to shift the lion's share of its
domestic German flights to Germanwings as it attempted to cut costs
and face up to fierce competition from European discount airlines and
new Middle East-based international carriers.
  
But the switch to Germanwings - where pay rates are lower than other
parts of the Lufthansa group - quickly ran into stiff opposition from
both unions and pilots, triggering a series of damaging strikes by
cabin crew and pilots.
  
Unit labour costs at Eurowings are 30 per cent lower than at the
Lufthansa parent company, the airline said last week.
  
Undeterred by the industrial action, Lufthansa stepped up its plans
for a global discount airline by launching Eurowings' international
operations last year.
  
However, the new global services have been hit by complaints about
long delays in its services.
SIDEBAR
  
Lufthansa hopes to address the problem by expanding the Eurowings
aircraft fleet this year by 10 to 98.
  
Despite the strikes and the March 2015 crash that overshadowed
Lufthansa's 60th anniversary, the airline group last week reported a
record annual profit.
  
Lufthansa said it booked a 55-per-cent surge in adjusted earnings
before interest and taxes jumped to 1.82 billion euros (2 billion
dollars) in 2015 from 1.17 billion euros in 2014, with earnings
boosted by a fall in its aircraft fuel bill and higher passenger
numbers.
  
The Eurowings offshoot contributed to the annual result by posting an
adjusted operating profit of 8 million euros in 2015.
  
  
  
  
  Mar 2116 1300 GMT  
Load-Date: March 22, 2016

Business leaders warn Brexit would «deter investment, threaten jobs»
Business leaders warn Brexit would «deter investment, threaten jobs»
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
February 23, 2016 Tuesday 11:52 AM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: POLITICS
Length: 301 words
Dateline: London 
Body
DPA POLITICS Britain politics EU  Business leaders warn Brexit would «deter investment, threaten jobs» 
London   
A group of more than 100 leaders of major businesses
on Tuesday backed Prime Minister David Cameron's campaign for Britain
to remain in the European Union, saying a British exit, or Brexit,
would "deter investment and threaten jobs."
  
"Business needs unrestricted access to the European market of 500
million people in order to continue to grow, invest and create jobs,"
the business leaders said in a letter published in the Times.
  
"We believe that leaving the EU would deter investment, threaten jobs
and put the economy at risk," the letter read.
  
The nearly 200 signatories included top executives from 36 companies
listed on London's FTSE 100 index.
  
Among the companies represented are Airbus UK, British Telecom, BP,
Diageo, EasyJet, Goldman Sachs International, GSK, HSBC, Rio Tinto,
Rolls Royce, Royal Dutch Shell, Ryanair, SABMiller, Siemens
Manufacturing, Standard Chartered, Virgin Media and Vodafone.
  
"The businesses we lead represent every sector and region of the UK,"
they wrote. "Together we employ hundreds of thousands of people
across the country."
  
Cameron's deal with the 27 other EU leaders last week means "Britain
is better off staying in a reformed European Union," they added,
highlighting agreements to reduce bureaucracy, deepen the single
market and pursue international trade deals.
  
The Confederation of British Industry, which represents some 190,000
businesses, has also backed Cameron, praising the EU reform package
as "a major step forward."
Business leaders warn Brexit would «deter investment, threaten jobs»
  
Britain will conduct a referendum on June 23 on whether or not to
remain part of the EU.
  
Eurosceptics inside Cameron's ruling Conservative party have provided
the strongest support for the "leave" campaign.

DPA FINANCE Ireland business Ryanair  Ryanair doubles profit in third quarter London   
Europe's largest low-cost airline Ryanair on Monday
said its profit doubled to 103 million euros (112 million dollars) in
the last three months of 2015.
  
Passenger volume rose by 20 per cent to 25 million in the three
months to December, the third quarter of the airline's financial
year, while average fares dropped by 1 per cent to 40 euros.
  
"We are pleased to report that our low fares policy delivered strong
Q3 traffic and profit growth," said Michael O'Leary, Ryanair's chief
executive.
  
Bookings were affected by the terrorist attacks in Paris in November,
but the airline "reacted to this softness by running price promotions
and discounted fares to stimulate double digit traffic growth,"
O'Leary said.

EU-based airlines form new alliance to defend their interests
EU-based airlines form new alliance to defend their interests
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
January 20, 2016 Wednesday 5:18 PM EST
Copyright 2016 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 324 words
Dateline: Amsterdam 
Body
DPA FINANCE business aviation EU  EU-based airlines form new alliance to defend their interests Amsterdam   
Five major European airline groups launched a new
alliance on Wednesday aimed at promoting their interests when dealing
with national and EU regulators, with their sector facing fierce
international competition.
  
Aviation firms employ almost 2 million people in the European Union
and are worth 110 billion euros (120 billion dollars) to the bloc's
economy, according to the European Commission, the bloc's executive.
  
But competitors such as Emirates Airline, Qatar Airways and Etihad
Airways have been gaining ground in the European market.
  
The new lobby group, Airlines for Europe (A4E), brings together Air
France-KLM, easyjet, International Airlines Group, Lufthansa Group
and Ryanair, and plans to expand its membership during the coming
months.
  
"For the first time, low-cost and network carriers are creating an
association to support the adoption of a new European aviation
strategy," the heads of the five corporations said in a joint
statement.
  
A4E said it would work with the commission on measures it had
unveiled last month to boost the bloc's aviation sector.
  
The airlines aim to "increase their competitiveness and result in
lower fares and more choice for passengers," by tackling industry
issues such as "large-scale airport monopolies, high charges,
taxation and inefficiencies," the statement said.
  
The group also presented its first study on Wednesday, showing that
airport charges at the EU's 21 largest airports had increased by 80
per cent in the last 10 years, while flight costs dropped 20 per cent
EU-based airlines form new alliance to defend their interests
over the same period.
  
"While the airlines have reduced their fares, EU passengers continue
to be fleeced by excessive airport charges," the group's chief
executives said, urging the bloc to "take action lowering the cost of
the EU's airports by ensuring that monopoly airports are effectively
regulated."
  
  
  
  
  Jan 2016 1718 GMT  
Load-Date: January 21, 2016

Airline industry set for boom time, says aviation body IATA
Airline industry set for boom time, says aviation body IATA
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
December 10, 2015 Thursday 2:03 PM EST
Copyright 2015 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 197 words
Dateline: Geneva 
Body
DPA FINANCE transport world aviation  Airline industry set for boom time, says aviation body IATA Geneva   
The aviation industry is booming again thanks to
cheaper oil after years of difficulties, the world airline
association IATA said in Geneva on Thursday.
  
Airlines could expect profits like never before this year and next,
IATA chief executive Tony Tyler announced as he increased his
previous profit forecast for the sector for 2015 to 33 billion
dollars from 29.3 billion dollars.
  
That figure would be almost twice as much as was recorded in 2014.
  
Next year, aviation industry profit is expected to rise to 36.3
billion dollars.
  
"After years of destruction of our capital, we can finally provide a
minimum level of profitability which an investor would expect," Tyler
said.
  
Oil prices have been plunging for the last year and a half.
  
It even looks better for airlines in the previously difficult market
of Europe. Companies such as Lufthansa, Air France-KLM and Ryanair
are expected to reach a total profit of 6.9 billion dollars this
year, IATA estimated.
  
That would be 1.1 billion more than last thought while 2016 should
see a 8.6 billion dollar profit.

DPA FINANCE Germany labour Lufthansa  1ST LEAD   
Lufthansa reaches deal with union representing ground staff
By Sebastian Raabe, dpa   =
  
Berlin (dpa) - Lufthansa reached a deal with a union representing the
airline's ground staff on Saturday, ending one of several pay and
pension disputes that have caused frequent disruptions for travellers
this year.
  
A statement from the Verdi union said that the German air carrier's
33,000 ground personnel would receive a lump sum payment of 2,250
euros (2,400 dollars) if they worked between April and December 2015.
  
The employees will also receive a 2.2 per cent pay rise for each of
the next two years.
  
Changes to employees' retirement benefits have also been a key
sticking point in the negotiations.
  
The union said Lufthansa agreed that recent and future hires will
receive the same pension scheme as long-time employees. However, all
employees must now contribute 1 per cent of their salary to their
plan while the company will put in 5.2 per cent.
  
Faced with increased competition from rivals such as EasyJet and
Ryanair, Lufthansa has been on a drive to reduce its costs by cutting
jobs and benefits, as well as merging its two lost-cost carriers -
Eurowings and Germanwings - under the single Eurowings brand.
  
Lufthansa also faced industrial action from pilots and cabin crew
this year. The seven-day cabin crew walk-off earlier this month was
the longest in the company's history and led to the cancellation of
4,700 flights.
  
  
  
1ST LEAD
  
  Nov 2815 1640 GMT  
Load-Date: November 29, 2015

Lufthansa flight attendants to begin eight-day strike in Frankfurt
Lufthansa flight attendants to begin eight-day strike in Frankfurt
Deutsche Presse-Agentur
November 6, 2015 Friday 9:23 AM EST
Copyright 2015 Deutsche Presse-Agentur All Rights Reserved
Section: FINANCE
Length: 288 words
Dateline: Berlin 
Body
DPA FINANCE Germany labour aviation  Lufthansa flight attendants to begin eight-day strike in Frankfurt 
Berlin   
Flight attendants at Lufthansa are to begin their
rolling eight-day strike by withdrawing crews from 2 pm (1300 GMT) at
Frankfurt, the German airline's main hub, their union announced.
  
The union, Ufo, is demanding preservation of retirement benefits that
enable many stewards and pursers to retire from 55. The strike
threatens to pull the airline group back into the red after a quarter
where its earnings rose by half and it forecast a strong full year.
  
Instead of holding an all-out strike, Ufo has adopted a rolling
strategy, announcing its members will not crew any take-offs from
Frankfurt for Friday afternoon and evening, whereas crews will work
as normal at Lufthansa's number-two hub, Munich, through Sunday.
  
Crews were also pulled Friday at a minor field, Dusseldorf, where
Lufthansa operates only a single daily international flight and 18
domestic connections.
  
"All passengers of Lufthansa must assume that their flight might get
cancelled at the last minute," Nicoley Baublies, leader of Ufo,
warned. The short-notice tactic has been adopted by the union to
thwart Lufthansa counter-efforts to organize skeleton services.
  
He added the union was no longer open to talks, and would only call
off the strike if Lufthansa made a substantial offer.
  
Lufthansa's 19,000 attendants had previously been docile compared to
its pilots, who have struck 13 times in a similar dispute that is
still simmering.
  
Lufthansa chief executive Carsten Spoehr is spearheading a
cost-cutting drive to ward off competition from both budget lines
Lufthansa flight attendants to begin eight-day strike in Frankfurt
such as Ryanair and mega-carriers from the Gulf such as Emirates.
  
  
  
  
  Nov 0615 0923 GMT
